description: Real Property flashcards for bar exam prep

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 001. Defeasible Fees
cards.backPlain: A defeasible fee is a fee simple estate of potentially infinite duration that may terminate upon the occurrence of a specified event. It is a present fee estate vested in the grantee but subject to divestment if the condition occurs. Creating a defeasible fee requires clear language showing that the estate will end or be forfeited upon a stated event; mere words of desire, hope, or aspiration are not enough. There are three main types of defeasible fees, each paired with a specific future interest: - Fee simple determinable (with a possibility of reverter in the grantor). - Fee simple subject to condition subsequent (with a right of reentry/power of termination in the grantor). - Fee simple subject to an executory interest (with a shifting executory interest in a third party).
cards.frontPrompt: What is a defeasible fee, what language is needed to create one, and what are the three main types and their associated future interests?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::defeasible fee}} is a {{c2::fee simple}} that may {{c3::terminate upon the occurrence of a specified event}}. Creating one requires {{c4::clear forfeiture language}} (mere {{c5::desire, hope, or aspiration}} is insufficient). The main types are {{c6::fee simple determinable}} (with a {{c7::possibility of reverter}}), {{c8::fee simple subject to condition subsequent}} (with a {{c9::right of reentry/power of termination}}), and {{c10::fee simple subject to an executory interest}} (with a {{c11::shifting executory interest}} in a third party).
cards.easyContent: A defeasible fee is a fee simple that can end early upon a specified event. It requires clear forfeiture language and comes in three forms, each with its own future interest (determinable, condition subsequent, and executory interest).
cards.mediumContent: A defeasible fee is a present fee simple estate, potentially infinite, but subject to termination upon a stated event. Clear durational or conditional language is required—mere hopes or wishes are not enough. The three types are: (1) fee simple determinable with a possibility of reverter in the grantor; (2) fee simple subject to condition subsequent with a right of reentry/power of termination in the grantor; and (3) fee simple subject to an executory interest with a shifting executory interest in a third party.
cards.hardContent: A defeasible fee is a fee simple estate that, while potentially of infinite duration, may terminate upon the occurrence of a specified event. The grantee holds a present vested fee, but it is subject to divestment if the condition occurs. To create a defeasible fee, the grantor must use clear language indicating that the estate will end or be forfeited upon the specified event; precatory language of desire, hope, or aspiration is insufficient. There are three principal types: (1) fee simple determinable, which ends automatically upon the stated event and leaves the grantor a possibility of reverter; (2) fee simple subject to condition subsequent, where the grantor must affirmatively exercise a reserved right of reentry (power of termination) to cut off the grantee’s estate; and (3) fee simple subject to an executory interest, where, upon the event, the estate automatically shifts to a third party holding a shifting executory interest.
cards.mnemonic: D-C-E: Determinable, Condition subsequent, Executory interest and linked future interests.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into (1) definition and required language for defeasible fees, and (2) the three types and their associated future interests.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::defeasible fee}} is a {{c2::fee simple estate}} that {{c3::may terminate upon a stated event}}, created by {{c4::clear durational or conditional language}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 002. Fee Simple Determinable
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A fee simple determinable is a fee simple estate that automatically terminates and reverts back to the grantor upon the happening of a given event or condition. For example: "to A so long as A practices law"—if A stops practicing law, the property automatically reverts back to the grantor. 2. Characteristics: 2.1 Automatic forfeiture: Upon occurrence of the given event or condition, the grantee automatically forfeits the estate. 2.2 Potentially infinite: The duration can be infinite so long as the event or condition does not occur. 2.3 Transferable: The fee estate is alienable, devisable, and descendible, subject to the condition. 3. Creation and future interest: A fee simple determinable requires clear durational language; words of desire, hope, or aspiration are insufficient. The accompanying future interest is a possibility of reverter, which is retained by the grantor and becomes possessory automatically if the event or condition occurs.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a fee simple determinable, what are its key characteristics, what language creates it, and what future interest accompanies it?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::fee simple determinable}} is a fee simple estate that {{c2::automatically terminates and reverts back to the grantor}} upon the happening of a given event or condition. For example: "to A {{c3::so long as}} A practices law"—if A stops practicing law, the property automatically reverts back to the grantor. 2. Characteristics: 2.1 {{c4::Automatic forfeiture}}: Upon occurrence of the given event or condition, the grantee automatically forfeits the estate. 2.2 {{c5::Potentially infinite}}: The duration can be infinite so long as the event or condition does not occur. 2.3 {{c6::Transferable}}: The fee estate is {{c7::alienable, devisable, and descendible}}, subject to the condition. 3. {{c8::Creation and future interest}}: A fee simple determinable requires {{c9::clear durational language}}; words of desire, hope, or aspiration are insufficient. The accompanying future interest is a {{c10::possibility of reverter}}, which is {{c11::retained by the grantor}} and becomes possessory automatically if the event or condition occurs.
cards.easyContent: A fee simple determinable is a fee simple that ends automatically when a stated condition occurs, at which point it automatically reverts to the grantor. It uses clear durational language (like "so long as"), and the grantor holds a possibility of reverter.
cards.mediumContent: A fee simple determinable is a fee simple estate that automatically terminates upon a specified event or condition and automatically reverts to the grantor. It is created by clear durational language (e.g., "so long as," "while," "during"), not mere hopes or wishes. The estate is potentially infinite and is freely transferable—alienable, devisable, and descendible—subject to the condition. The future interest is a possibility of reverter in the grantor, which becomes possessory automatically when the condition is breached.
cards.hardContent: A fee simple determinable is a present fee simple estate that is defeasible upon the occurrence of a specified event or condition, at which point the estate ends automatically and the property automatically reverts to the grantor. For example, "to A so long as A practices law" creates a fee simple determinable in A; if A stops practicing law, A’s estate automatically terminates and the grantor’s interest becomes possessory. The estate is potentially of infinite duration if the condition never occurs and is freely transferable—alienable, devisable, and descendible—subject to the condition. Creation requires clear durational language (such as "so long as," "while," or "during"); precatory language of desire, hope, or aspiration is insufficient. The accompanying future interest is a possibility of reverter retained by the grantor, which becomes possessory automatically upon breach of the condition.
cards.mnemonic: FSD: "So long" it lasts, then snaps back.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::fee simple determinable}} {{c2::automatically terminates}} upon a condition and {{c3::automatically reverts to the grantor}}, who holds a {{c4::possibility of reverter}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Fee Simple Subject to Condition Subsequent
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 003. Fee Simple Subject to Condition Subsequent
cards.front: Fee Simple Subject to Condition Subsequent
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A fee simple in which the grantor retains the power to terminate the grantee's estate upon the happening of a specified event or condition. 2. Characteristics: 2.1 Forfeiture not automatic: If the event or condition occurs, the grantee still retains title until the grantor affirmatively exercises the right of reentry. This is what distinguishes a fee simple subject to condition subsequent from a fee simple determinable. 2.2 Potentially infinite: The duration can be infinite so long as the event or condition does not occur, or if it occurs, the grantor does not exercise the right of reentry. 2.3 Transferable: The estate is alienable, devisable, and descendible, subject to the possibility that it will end upon the occurrence of the condition and the grantor's exercise of the right of reentry. 3. Creation and future interest: 3.1 Creation: Clear durational or conditional language must also carve out a right of reentry in favor of the grantor. It must be explicit that the grantor has the right to retake upon occurrence of the event or condition. Words of desire, hope, or aspiration are insufficient. 3.2 Accompanying future interest: The grantor retains a right of reentry (also called a power of termination).
cards.frontPrompt: What is a fee simple subject to condition subsequent, how is it created, and how does it differ from a fee simple determinable?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::fee simple}} in which the {{c2::grantor retains the power to terminate}} the grantee's estate upon the happening of a specified {{c3::event or condition}}. 2. Characteristics: 2.1 {{c4::Forfeiture not automatic}}: If the event or condition occurs, the grantee still retains title until the grantor affirmatively exercises the {{c5::right of reentry}}. This is what distinguishes a fee simple subject to condition subsequent from a {{c6::fee simple determinable}}. 2.2 {{c7::Potentially infinite}}: The duration can be infinite so long as the event or condition does not occur, or if it occurs, the grantor does not exercise the right of reentry. 2.3 {{c8::Transferable}}: The estate is {{c9::alienable, devisable, and descendible}}, subject to the possibility that it will end upon the occurrence of the condition and the grantor's exercise of the right of reentry. 3. Creation and future interest: 3.1 Creation: {{c10::Clear durational or conditional language}} must also carve out a {{c11::right of reentry in favor of the grantor}}. It must be explicit that the grantor has the right to retake upon occurrence of the event or condition. {{c12::Words of desire, hope, or aspiration are insufficient}}. 3.2 Accompanying future interest: The grantor retains a {{c13::right of reentry (power of termination)}}.
cards.easyContent: A fee simple subject to condition subsequent is a fee simple in which the grantor keeps a right of reentry and may terminate the estate if a stated condition occurs; forfeiture is not automatic.
cards.mediumContent: A fee simple subject to condition subsequent is a fee simple where the grantor retains a right of reentry and may terminate the grantee's estate upon a specified condition. The estate is potentially infinite and transferable (alienable, devisable, descendible), but if the condition occurs, the grantee keeps title unless and until the grantor exercises the right of reentry. It is created by clear conditional or durational language that explicitly reserves a right of reentry; precatory words are insufficient.
cards.hardContent: A fee simple subject to condition subsequent is a fee simple in which the grantor retains the power to terminate the grantee's estate if a specified event or condition occurs. The key characteristic is that forfeiture is not automatic: upon occurrence of the condition, the grantee remains title holder until the grantor affirmatively exercises the right of reentry. The estate is potentially infinite and is alienable, devisable, and descendible, subject to the risk of termination. It is created only when clear conditional or durational language is coupled with an explicit reservation of a right of reentry (power of termination) in the grantor; words of desire, hope, or aspiration are not enough. The accompanying future interest is the grantor's right of reentry.
cards.mnemonic: CS: Condition occurs, Still stays until grantor Steps in.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::fee simple subject to condition subsequent}} lets the grantor {{c2::retain a right of reentry}} so {{c3::forfeiture is not automatic}} when the {{c4::stated condition occurs}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Fee Simple Subject to an Executory Interest
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 004. Fee Simple Subject to an Executory Interest
cards.front: Fee Simple Subject to an Executory Interest
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A fee simple that automatically transfers to a third party upon the happening of a specified event or condition. 2. Characteristics: 2.1 Automatic forfeiture: Upon occurrence of the event or condition, the estate automatically transfers to a third person. It is similar to a fee simple determinable, but ownership automatically shifts to a third person, not back to the grantor. 2.2 Potentially infinite: The duration can be infinite so long as the event or condition does not occur. 2.3 Transferable: The estate is alienable, devisable, and descendible, subject to the occurrence of the condition. 2.4 Absolute restraints on alienation are void. 3. Creation and future interest: 3.1 Creation: Clear durational or conditional language is required; words of desire, hope, or aspiration are insufficient. 3.2 Accompanying future interest: A third party holds a shifting executory interest. The executory interest is transferable and is alienable, devisable, and descendible.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a fee simple subject to an executory interest, how is it created, and what future interest accompanies it?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::fee simple}} that {{c2::automatically transfers to a third party}} upon the happening of a specified {{c3::event or condition}}. 2. Characteristics: 2.1 {{c4::Automatic forfeiture}}: Upon occurrence of the event or condition, the estate automatically transfers to a third person. It is similar to a {{c5::fee simple determinable}}, but ownership automatically shifts to a {{c6::third person, not back to the grantor}}. 2.2 {{c7::Potentially infinite}}: The duration can be infinite so long as the event or condition does not occur. 2.3 {{c8::Transferable}}: The estate is {{c9::alienable, devisable, and descendible}}, subject to the occurrence of the condition. 2.4 {{c10::Absolute restraints on alienation are void}}. 3. Creation and future interest: 3.1 Creation: {{c11::Clear durational or conditional language}} is required; words of desire, hope, or aspiration are insufficient. 3.2 Accompanying future interest: A third party holds a {{c12::shifting executory interest}}. The executory interest is transferable and is {{c13::alienable, devisable, and descendible}}.
cards.easyContent: A fee simple subject to an executory interest is a fee simple that will automatically shift to a third party if a stated condition occurs, giving that third party a shifting executory interest.
cards.mediumContent: A fee simple subject to an executory interest is a fee simple estate that automatically forfeits and transfers to a third person upon a specified event or condition. Like a fee simple determinable, forfeiture is automatic, but the new owner is a third party, not the grantor. The estate is potentially infinite and transferable, and absolute restraints on alienation are void. It is created by clear durational or conditional language, and the accompanying future interest in the third party is a shifting executory interest that is alienable, devisable, and descendible.
cards.hardContent: A fee simple subject to an executory interest is a fee simple that automatically transfers to a third party upon the happening of a specified event or condition. Its hallmark is automatic forfeiture in favor of a third person, making it similar to a fee simple determinable except that the estate shifts to a third party rather than back to the grantor. The estate is potentially infinite, and is alienable, devisable, and descendible, though subject to the risk of divestment; absolute restraints on alienation are void. It is created only by clear durational or conditional language (precatory words are insufficient). The accompanying future interest is the third party's shifting executory interest, which itself is alienable, devisable, and descendible.
cards.mnemonic: EI: Estate Instantly to a third party on the condition.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::fee simple subject to an executory interest}} automatically {{c2::forfeits and shifts to a third party}} upon a {{c3::stated condition}}, giving that party a {{c4::shifting executory interest}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 005. Life Estate
cards.backPlain: A life estate is a present possessory estate measured by a life. The life tenant (LT) has ordinary ownership rights but must maintain the property, make reasonable repairs, and avoid waste. A life estate can be defeasible (e.g., determinable, subject to condition subsequent, or subject to an executory interest) or indefeasible. When the life estate ends, possession shifts either back to the grantor (reversion) or to a named third party (remainder). A life estate can also be measured by someone else’s life (life estate pur autre vie), including when the life tenant transfers her life estate to another.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a life estate, what basic duties does a life tenant owe, and what are the main future interests and variations associated with life estates?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::life estate}} is a {{c2::present possessory estate measured by a life}}. The {{c3::life tenant (LT)}} has ordinary ownership rights but must {{c4::maintain the property, make reasonable repairs, and avoid waste}}. A life estate can be {{c5::defeasible or indefeasible}}. When the life estate ends, either a {{c6::reversion in the grantor}} or a {{c7::remainder in a third party}} becomes possessory. A {{c8::life estate pur autre vie}} is measured by {{c9::someone else’s life, including after transfer of a life estate}}.
cards.easyContent: A life estate is a present possessory estate measured by a life. The life tenant must maintain the property and avoid waste, and at the end of the life estate, either a reversion in the grantor or a remainder in a third party becomes possessory. A life estate can also be measured by someone else’s life (pur autre vie).
cards.mediumContent: A life estate is a present possessory estate measured by a life, usually the life tenant’s. It may be defeasible (determinable, subject to condition subsequent, or subject to an executory interest) or indefeasible. The life tenant has ordinary ownership rights but must maintain the property, make reasonable repairs, and not commit waste. When the life estate ends, a reversion in the grantor or a remainder in a third party becomes possessory. A life estate pur autre vie is measured by another person’s life, including when a life tenant transfers her estate and the transferee’s rights end at the death of the original measuring life.
cards.hardContent: A life estate is a present possessory estate lasting only for the duration of a designated life (usually the life tenant’s, but sometimes another measuring life). It can be defeasible (e.g., determinable, subject to condition subsequent, or subject to an executory interest) or indefeasible. The life tenant has ordinary ownership rights, but must maintain the property, make reasonable repairs, and may not commit waste. When the life estate ends, possession shifts either: (1) back to the grantor as a reversion if no third-party taker is named, or (2) to a third person as a remainder if identified in the granting instrument. A life estate pur autre vie is measured by someone else’s life; if the life tenant transfers her estate, the transferee holds a life estate pur autre vie that terminates at the death of the original measuring life, after which the property goes to the grantor (reversion) or to the remainder-holder, if any.
cards.mnemonic: "Life estate = Life-limited ownership"—the estate lasts for a life, then either reverts (reversion) or remains to another (remainder).
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into (1) definition, defeasibility, and duties of life tenants; (2) reversion vs. remainder following a life estate; and (3) life estate pur autre vie and transfer of life estates.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::life estate}} is a {{c2::present possessory estate}} measured by {{c3::a life}}; when it ends, {{c4::a reversion or remainder}} becomes possessory.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 006. Doctrine of Waste
cards.backPlain: Doctrine of Waste – Overview A life tenant (LT) owes duties to future interest holders not to unreasonably use, change, or neglect the property in ways that harm their interests. Such conduct is called waste. There are three main types of waste: 1. Affirmative (voluntary) waste – overuse or exploitation of the property or its natural resources, subject to specific exceptions (e.g., repairs, express grant, prior use, open mines doctrine). 2. Permissive waste – harm resulting from the LT's neglect, including failure to maintain, repair, or pay taxes and carrying charges, subject to limits based on income or reasonable rental value and reimbursement rights. 3. Ameliorative waste – material changes that increase the property's value; traditionally prohibited at common law but generally permitted in modern jurisdictions, especially where neighborhood conditions have changed and the change increases value.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the doctrine of waste in life estates, and what are the three main types of waste at a high level?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::doctrine of waste}}, a {{c2::life tenant (LT)}} owes duties to {{c3::future interest holders}} not to unreasonably use, change, or neglect the property in ways that harm their interests. There are three main types of waste: {{c4::affirmative (voluntary) waste}}, {{c5::permissive waste}}, and {{c6::ameliorative waste}}.
cards.easyContent: The doctrine of waste limits a life tenant's use and care of property to protect future interest holders. Waste can be: (1) affirmative (voluntary) waste—overuse or exploitation; (2) permissive waste—harm from neglect; and (3) ameliorative waste—value-increasing changes that alter the property.
cards.mediumContent: The doctrine of waste prevents a life tenant from unreasonably using, changing, or neglecting property so as to injure future interest holders. Waste is categorized as: (1) affirmative (voluntary) waste—unreasonable exploitation of the property or its natural resources, subject to specific exceptions; (2) permissive waste—damage due to the life tenant's failure to maintain, repair, or pay taxes and carrying charges, limited by the income or reasonable rental value of the property; and (3) ameliorative waste—material alterations that increase value, traditionally barred at common law but generally allowed today, especially when neighborhood conditions have changed.
cards.hardContent: The doctrine of waste provides that a life tenant may not unreasonably use, change, or neglect property in a way that injures the interests of future interest holders. The three main types are: 1. Affirmative (voluntary) waste – unreasonable acts of commission, including overuse or exploitation of natural resources, subject to exceptions for necessary repairs/maintenance, express grants, prior exploitation, and the open mines doctrine. 2. Permissive waste – harm caused by neglect, where the life tenant must maintain and repair the property and pay taxes and carrying charges, but only up to the income/profits or reasonable rental value; future interest holders who step in may seek reimbursement. 3. Ameliorative waste – material changes that increase property value; these were prohibited under common law but are generally permitted in modern jurisdictions, particularly where neighborhood conditions have changed and the alteration increases market value.
cards.mnemonic: Three types of waste = "APA": Affirmative, Permissive, Ameliorative.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) general definition/overview of waste, (2) affirmative (voluntary) waste and natural resources/open mines doctrine, (3) permissive waste and life tenant's duties, and (4) ameliorative waste and modern vs. common law treatment.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::doctrine of waste}} limits a {{c2::life tenant}} from {{c3::unreasonably using, changing, or neglecting}} property, covering {{c4::affirmative}}, {{c5::permissive}}, and {{c6::ameliorative}} waste.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 007. Remainder
cards.backPlain: A remainder is a future interest in a third person (someone other than the grantor) that becomes possessory immediately upon the natural termination of a prior estate of known, fixed duration (usually a life estate or term of years), without cutting short that prior estate. It must be expressly created in the same conveyance as the prior estate and is freely transferable (alienable, devisable, and descendible). An interest that cuts off a prior transferee is not a remainder but an executory interest. Remainders are classified as either vested or contingent. Vested remainders include: (1) indefeasibly vested remainders; (2) vested remainders subject to total divestment (condition subsequent); and (3) vested remainders subject to open (class gifts). Contingent remainders exist where there is a condition precedent to possession, an unascertained or unborn taker, or both.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a remainder and how are remainders generally classified?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::remainder}} is a {{c2::future interest in a third person}} (someone other than the grantor) that becomes possessory {{c3::immediately upon the natural termination}} of a prior estate of known, fixed duration, {{c4::without cutting short that prior estate}}. It must be {{c5::expressly created in the same conveyance}} as the prior estate and is {{c6::alienable, devisable, and descendible}}. An interest that {{c7::cuts off a prior transferee}} is an {{c8::executory interest}}, not a remainder. Remainders are classified as either {{c9::vested}} or {{c10::contingent}}. Vested remainders include {{c11::indefeasibly vested}}, {{c12::vested subject to total divestment}}, and {{c13::vested subject to open (class gifts)}}. A {{c14::contingent remainder}} exists where there is a {{c15::condition precedent}}, an {{c16::unascertained or unborn taker}}, or {{c17::both}}.
cards.easyContent: A remainder is a future interest in someone other than the grantor that waits for a prior fixed estate to end naturally without cutting it short, and it is either vested (various types) or contingent.
cards.mediumContent: A remainder is a future interest in a third party that becomes possessory only when a prior life estate or term of years naturally ends, and it must be created in the same instrument as that prior estate. Remainders are transferable and cannot divest a prior transferee (or they are executory interests instead). They are classified as vested (indefeasibly vested, vested subject to total divestment, or vested subject to open/class gift) or contingent (based on a condition precedent, an unascertained/unborn taker, or both).
cards.hardContent: A remainder is a future interest in someone other than the grantor that becomes possessory immediately upon the natural termination of a prior estate of known, fixed duration—typically a life estate or term of years—without cutting the prior estate short. It must be expressly created in the same conveyance as the prior estate and is freely transferable (alienable, devisable, descendible). An interest that would cut off or divest a prior transferee is an executory interest, not a remainder. Remainders are categorized as vested or contingent. Vested remainders include indefeasibly vested remainders, vested remainders subject to total divestment, and vested remainders subject to open (class gifts). Contingent remainders arise when there is a condition precedent to possession, an unascertained or unborn taker, or both.
cards.mnemonic: "Remainder remains"—it waits, never cuts; types = I-D-O-C: Indefeasible, Divestment, Open, Contingent.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) definition, creation, and basic characteristics; (2) three types of vested remainders; and (3) contingent remainders and how they differ from executory interests.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::remainder}} is a {{c2::future interest in a third party}} that {{c3::waits for a prior life estate or term of years to end naturally}} and is classified as {{c4::vested or contingent}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 008. Vested Remainder
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition and limitations 1.1 A vested remainder is a future interest in a transferee that automatically becomes possessory upon the natural expiration of the preceding estate. 1.2 By definition, a vested remainder cannot: 1.2.1 Be subject to any condition precedent; or 1.2.2 Vest in an unknown or unascertained person. 2. Types of vested remainders 2.1 Indefeasibly vested remainder: certain to become possessory upon termination of the prior estate. 2.2 Vested remainder subject to total divestment: vested but subject to a condition subsequent that can cut off the interest after it becomes possessory. 2.3 Vested remainder subject to open (class gift): vested in a described class of takers, at least one of whom is capable of taking, but the class can expand as more qualifying members are born. 3. Class gifts and closing 3.1 A class remains open while new members can be created and closes when no new members can be added. 3.2 Under the Rule of Convenience, the class closes whenever any member can demand distribution; after-born class members take nothing.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a vested remainder, what are its basic limitations, and what are the main types (including how class gifts open and close)?
cards.cloze: 1. Definition and limitations 1.1 A {{c1::vested remainder}} is a future interest in a transferee that automatically becomes {{c2::possessory upon the natural expiration of the preceding estate}}. 1.2 By definition, a vested remainder cannot: 1.2.1 Be subject to any {{c3::condition precedent}}; or 1.2.2 Vest in an {{c4::unknown or unascertained person}}. 2. Types of vested remainders 2.1 {{c5::Indefeasibly vested remainder}}: certain to become possessory upon termination of the prior estate. 2.2 {{c6::Vested remainder subject to total divestment}}: vested but subject to a {{c7::condition subsequent}} that can cut off the interest after it becomes possessory. 2.3 {{c8::Vested remainder subject to open}} ({{c9::class gift}}): vested in a described {{c10::class of takers}}, at least one of whom is capable of taking, but the class can {{c11::expand as more qualifying members are born}}. 3. Class gifts and closing 3.1 A class remains {{c12::open}} while new members can be created and {{c13::closes}} when no new members can be added. 3.2 Under the {{c14::Rule of Convenience}}, the class closes whenever any member can {{c15::demand distribution}}; {{c16::after-born class members take nothing}}.
cards.easyContent: A vested remainder is a future interest in a transferee that will automatically become possessory when the prior estate naturally ends, and it cannot be subject to a condition precedent or given to an unascertained person. The three types are indefeasibly vested, vested subject to total divestment, and vested subject to open as a class gift. Class gifts stay open while new members can be added and usually close when someone can demand distribution under the Rule of Convenience.
cards.mediumContent: A vested remainder automatically becomes possessory when the preceding estate naturally expires and cannot be subject to a condition precedent or vested in an unknown or unascertained person. The main types are: (1) an indefeasibly vested remainder, which is certain to become possessory when the prior estate ends; (2) a vested remainder subject to total divestment, which is vested but can be cut off by a condition subsequent after possession; and (3) a vested remainder subject to open, where at least one class member is vested but the class can expand until it closes, often under the Rule of Convenience when someone can demand distribution.
cards.hardContent: A vested remainder is a future interest in a transferee that automatically becomes possessory upon the natural expiration of the preceding estate and, by definition, cannot be subject to any condition precedent or vested in an unknown or unascertained person. There are three types: (1) an indefeasibly vested remainder, which is certain to become possessory immediately when the prior estate terminates; (2) a vested remainder subject to total divestment, which is vested but subject to a condition subsequent that can cut off the remainderman’s interest after he takes possession; and (3) a vested remainder subject to open (a class gift), which is vested in a described class of takers, at least one of whom is alive and capable of taking, but the class can expand as additional qualifying members are born. In class gifts, the class remains open while new members can be created and closes when it is no longer possible to add members, and under the Rule of Convenience, the class closes whenever any member can call for distribution, so after-born members take nothing.
cards.mnemonic: VEST: Vested, Ends naturally, Sure takers, no condition precedent.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) definition and limitations of vested remainders, (2) types of vested remainders, and (3) class gifts, class closing, and Rule of Convenience.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::vested remainder}} {{c2::automatically becomes possessory}} when the prior estate ends and {{c3::cannot have a condition precedent}} or {{c4::unascertained takers}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 009. Contingent Remainder
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 A remainder is contingent if it is either: 1.1.1 Subject to a condition precedent; or 1.1.2 Created in favor of an unascertained or unborn person. 2. Remainder subject to a condition precedent 2.1 The remainderman’s taking is contingent on the prior occurrence of some event or condition. 2.2 Once the event or condition occurs, the interest automatically becomes an indefeasibly vested remainder. 2.3 Example: If B is unmarried at the time of the conveyance, A has a life estate, B has a contingent remainder (because marriage is a condition precedent), and the grantor has a reversion in case B is not married when A dies. If B gets married during A’s life, B has an indefeasibly vested remainder. 3. Remainder in unborn or unascertained persons 3.1 A remainder created in favor of unborn or unascertained persons is contingent. 3.2 The remainder is contingent on the grantee being born or ascertained. 3.3 Example: If B is alive, a remainder to the heirs of B is contingent because the heirs of B cannot be ascertained until B dies.
cards.frontPrompt: When is a remainder classified as a contingent remainder, and how do conditions precedent and unborn or unascertained takers affect vesting?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A remainder is {{c1::contingent}} if it is either: 1.1.1 Subject to a {{c2::condition precedent}}; or 1.1.2 Created in favor of an {{c3::unascertained or unborn person}}. 2. Remainder subject to a condition precedent 2.1 The remainderman’s taking is contingent on the prior occurrence of some {{c4::event or condition}}. 2.2 Once the event or condition occurs, the interest automatically becomes an {{c5::indefeasibly vested remainder}}. 2.3 Example: If B is unmarried at the time of the conveyance, A has a {{c6::life estate}}, B has a {{c7::contingent remainder}} (because marriage is a condition precedent), and the grantor has a {{c8::reversion}} in case B is not married when A dies. If B gets married during A’s life, B has an {{c9::indefeasibly vested remainder}}. 3. Remainder in unborn or unascertained persons 3.1 A remainder created in favor of {{c10::unborn or unascertained persons}} is contingent. 3.2 The remainder is contingent on the grantee being {{c11::born or ascertained}}. 3.3 Example: If B is alive, a remainder to the {{c12::heirs of B}} is contingent because the heirs of B cannot be {{c13::ascertained until B dies}}.
cards.easyContent: A contingent remainder is a future interest in a grantee that either depends on a condition precedent or is given to an unborn or unascertained person, so it may never vest. Once the condition occurs or the taker becomes ascertained, it becomes an indefeasibly vested remainder.
cards.mediumContent: A remainder is contingent if it is subject to a condition precedent or is created in favor of an unborn or unascertained person. Where there is a condition precedent, the remainderman’s right to possession depends on that event occurring; when it occurs, the interest becomes an indefeasibly vested remainder. Where the remainder is to unborn or unascertained persons, it is contingent until the taker is born or identified, such as a remainder to the heirs of a living person.
cards.hardContent: A contingent remainder is a future interest in a transferee that has not yet vested because either (1) it is subject to a condition precedent, meaning the remainderman’s right to take possession depends on the prior occurrence of some specified event, or (2) it is created in favor of unborn or unascertained persons, such that the taker cannot yet be identified. When a condition precedent is satisfied, the contingent remainder becomes an indefeasibly vested remainder. Similarly, a remainder to unborn or unascertained persons (for example, to the heirs of B while B is still alive) is contingent until the taker comes into being or is ascertained, such as when B dies and his heirs can finally be determined.
cards.mnemonic: Contingent = Condition or not Known (unborn/unascertained).
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::remainder is contingent}} if it is {{c2::subject to a condition precedent}} or {{c3::given to an unborn or unascertained person}}; when the condition occurs or taker is known, it becomes an {{c4::indefeasibly vested remainder}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Rule of Destructibility, Merger (Shelley's Rule), and the Doctrine of Worthier Title
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 010. Rule of Destructibility, Merger (Shelley's Rule), and the Doctrine of Worthier Title
cards.front: Rule of Destructibility, Merger (Shelley's Rule), and Doctrine of Worthier Title – Overview
cards.frontPrompt: What are the three historical future-interest doctrines (rule of destructibility of contingent remainders, Shelley’s Rule, and the Doctrine of Worthier Title), and how are they treated at common law versus under modern law?
cards.backPlain: Historically, the law developed several special doctrines to modify strict estate-system outcomes involving future interests: 1. Rule of destructibility of contingent remainders - Common law: If a remainder was still contingent when the preceding estate ended (the condition precedent was not yet satisfied), the contingent remainder was destroyed and the remainderman took nothing. - Modern: Most jurisdictions abolish destruction; instead, the grantor (or the grantor’s estate) holds a reversion until the condition is satisfied, at which point the remainderman can take. 2. Merger (Shelley’s Rule / Rule in Shelley’s Case) - Common law: When a grant was "to A for life, then to A’s heirs," the life estate in A and the remainder in A’s heirs merged in A, giving A a fee simple absolute. - Modern: Shelley’s Rule has been abolished in most jurisdictions. A has a life estate, A’s heirs hold contingent remainders (unascertained while A lives), and O retains a reversion in case A dies without heirs. 3. Doctrine of Worthier Title - Common law: When a grant was "to A for life, then to O’s heirs," a purported future interest in O’s heirs was void; the law presumed that O retained a reversion instead. - Modern: Often treated as a rebuttable rule of construction that can be overcome by clear contrary intent in the instrument. All three doctrines reflect a historical preference for keeping future interests with the present grantee or in the grantor, and modern law generally abolishes or softens them to honor the grantor’s express intent.
cards.cloze: Historically, the law developed several special doctrines to modify strict estate-system outcomes involving future interests: 1. {{c1::Rule of destructibility of contingent remainders}} (common law: contingent remainders not vested when the prior estate ends are {{c2::destroyed}}; modern: {{c3::no destruction}}, grantor holds a {{c4::reversion}} until the condition is satisfied). 2. {{c5::Merger (Shelley’s Rule / Rule in Shelley’s Case}}) (common law: "to A for life, then to A’s heirs" gives A a {{c6::fee simple absolute}} by {{c7::merger}}; modern: rule {{c8::abolished}}, A has a {{c9::life estate}}, A’s heirs {{c10::contingent remainders}}, and O a {{c11::reversion}}). 3. {{c12::Doctrine of Worthier Title}} (common law: "to A for life, then to O’s heirs" voids the interest in {{c13::O’s heirs}} and presumes O retained a {{c14::reversion}}; modern: usually a {{c15::rebuttable rule of construction}}). Modern law generally {{c16::abolishes or softens}} these doctrines to better effectuate the grantor’s {{c17::intent}}.
cards.easyContent: Three historic doctrines altered future interests: (1) the rule of destructibility destroyed contingent remainders that had not vested when the prior estate ended; (2) Shelley’s Rule merged "to A for life, then to A’s heirs" into a fee simple in A; and (3) the Doctrine of Worthier Title voided "to A for life, then to O’s heirs" and treated O as holding a reversion. Modern law mostly abolishes destruction and merger and treats Worthier Title as a rebuttable rule of construction.
cards.mediumContent: Historically, courts used three special doctrines to cabin future interests. The rule of destructibility of contingent remainders destroyed a contingent remainder if, when the prior estate ended, the condition precedent was still unsatisfied. Shelley’s Rule applied to grants like "to A for life, then to A’s heirs" and merged the life estate and the remainder in A, giving A a fee simple absolute. The Doctrine of Worthier Title applied to grants like "to A for life, then to O’s heirs" and voided the future interest in O’s heirs, presuming that O retained a reversion. Modern jurisdictions usually preserve contingent remainders instead of destroying them, abolish Shelley’s Rule altogether, and treat Worthier Title as a rebuttable rule of construction rather than a hard invalidating rule.
cards.hardContent: Historically, special future-interest doctrines modified strict estate-system outcomes where language referenced "heirs." Under the rule of destructibility of contingent remainders, if the condition precedent to a contingent remainder remained unsatisfied when the prior estate ended, the contingent remainder was destroyed and the remainderman took nothing; modernly, most jurisdictions reject destruction and instead give the grantor or the grantor’s estate a reversion until the condition is met. Shelley’s Rule (the Rule in Shelley’s Case) applied to conveyances like "to A for life, then to A’s heirs" and, at common law, merged A’s life estate and the remainder in A’s heirs into a fee simple absolute in A; modern jurisdictions largely abolish the rule, so A has a life estate, A’s heirs hold contingent remainders because they are unascertained during A’s life, and O retains a reversion if A dies without heirs. The Doctrine of Worthier Title applied when the grantor gave "to A for life, then to O’s heirs," and at common law voided the contingent remainder or executory interest in O’s heirs, presuming that O retained a reversion instead; today the doctrine is often a mere rule of construction that can be overcome by clear contrary intent in the instrument. Overall, modern law tends to preserve future interests and effectuate the grantor’s stated intent, rather than relying on these technical doctrines.
cards.mnemonic: Destruct, Shelley, Worthier: three old heir-twisting tricks.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three child cards: (1) rule of destructibility of contingent remainders, (2) Shelley’s Rule (merger), and (3) Doctrine of Worthier Title, each contrasting common-law and modern treatment.
cards.clozeLite: Historically, {{c1::destructibility}}, {{c2::Shelley’s Rule}}, and {{c3::Doctrine of Worthier Title}} modified {{c4::future interests}}; {{c5::modern law mostly abolishes or softens them}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 011. Executory Interest
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 An executory interest is a future interest in a third party that takes effect by cutting short some other interest. 1.2 There are two types: shifting and springing. 1.3 An executory interest includes any future interest in a transferee that is not a remainder. 1.4 Executory interest holders lack standing to sue for waste. 1.5 Transferability: executory interests are generally devisable, descendible, and usually transferable inter vivos. 2. Shifting executory interest 2.1 A shifting executory interest always follows a defeasible fee or a vested remainder subject to total divestment. 2.2 It cuts short an interest in someone other than the grantor. 2.3 Example: O grants "to A so long as A uses the property for storage, but if A stops using it for storage, then to B." A has a fee simple subject to an executory interest, and B has a shifting executory interest. If A stops using the property for storage, A’s interest is cut short (not the grantor’s), and B takes. 3. Springing executory interest 3.1 A springing executory interest cuts short a present interest held by the grantor or the grantor’s estate. 3.2 Example: O grants "to A when A gets married." A has an executory interest, and O has a fee simple subject to an executory interest; if A gets married, possession springs from O to A.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an executory interest, what are the differences between shifting and springing executory interests, and what are their basic properties (including standing and transferability)?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 An {{c1::executory interest}} is a future interest in a {{c2::third party}} that takes effect by {{c3::cutting short some other interest}}. 1.2 There are two types: {{c4::shifting}} and {{c5::springing}}. 1.3 An executory interest includes any future interest in a transferee that is {{c6::not a remainder}}. 1.4 Executory interest holders {{c7::lack standing to sue for waste}}. 1.5 Transferability: executory interests are generally {{c8::devisable, descendible, and usually transferable inter vivos}}. 2. {{c9::Shifting executory interest}} 2.1 A shifting executory interest always follows a {{c10::defeasible fee}} or a {{c11::vested remainder subject to total divestment}}. 2.2 It cuts short an interest in {{c12::someone other than the grantor}}. 2.3 Example: O grants "to A so long as A uses the property for storage, but if A stops using it for storage, then to B." A has a {{c13::fee simple subject to an executory interest}}, and B has a {{c14::shifting executory interest}}. If A stops using the property for storage, A’s interest is {{c15::cut short}}, and B takes. 3. {{c16::Springing executory interest}} 3.1 A springing executory interest cuts short a present interest held by the {{c17::grantor or the grantor’s estate}}. 3.2 Example: O grants "to A when A gets married." A has an {{c18::executory interest}}, and O has a {{c19::fee simple subject to an executory interest}}; if A gets married, possession {{c20::springs from O to A}}.
cards.easyContent: An executory interest is a future interest in a transferee that becomes possessory only by cutting short someone else’s estate and is not a remainder. It can be shifting (cutting off another grantee) or springing (cutting off the grantor), and holders generally cannot sue for waste but can transfer the interest.
cards.mediumContent: Executory interests are future interests in third parties that take effect only by divesting a prior interest, and they are any future interests in transferees that are not remainders. Shifting executory interests follow a defeasible fee or vested remainder subject to total divestment and cut off another grantee’s interest (e.g., "to A so long as A uses for storage, then to B"); springing executory interests cut off the grantor’s own present interest (e.g., "to A when A marries"). Executory interests are generally devisable, descendible, and transferable, but holders lack standing to sue for waste before they take possession.
cards.hardContent: An executory interest is a non-possessory future interest in a transferee that becomes possessory only by divesting or cutting short a prior estate; it is any future interest in a transferee that does not qualify as a remainder. There are two forms: (1) a shifting executory interest, which always follows a defeasible fee or a vested remainder subject to total divestment and cuts off an interest in another grantee, as where O grants "to A so long as A uses the property for storage, but if A stops, then to B" (B holds a shifting executory interest that divests A); and (2) a springing executory interest, which cuts off the grantor’s own present interest, as in "to A when A gets married" (A has a springing executory interest, and O holds a fee simple subject to A’s executory interest until A marries). Executory interest holders have no standing to sue for waste before their interest becomes possessory, but the interests are generally devisable, descendible, and transferable inter vivos.
cards.mnemonic: "Shift cuts off a Stranger; Spring cuts off the Source"
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::executory interest}} is any {{c2::future interest in a transferee}} that {{c3::divests a prior estate}} and is {{c4::not a remainder}}; it may be {{c5::shifting}} or {{c6::springing}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 012. Rule Against Perpetuities
cards.backPlain: Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) – Overview 1. Core Rule 1.1 No property interest is valid unless it must vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after the death of a life in being at the time the interest was created. 1.2 If there is any possibility, no matter how remote, that the future interest could vest later than 21 years after the death of the measuring life, the interest is void. 1.3 A measuring life is a life in being at creation whose life events determine whether the interest vests within the RAP period. 2. Application and Analysis 2.1 RAP applies to certain future interests: contingent remainders, gifts to open classes, and executory interests (including, in some jurisdictions, options and rights of first refusal). 2.2 To analyze a conveyance, identify the future interests, apply RAP only to those covered interests using an appropriate measuring life, and if any interest violates RAP, strike only that interest and enforce what remains as the new conveyance. 2.3 Many jurisdictions have reformed RAP (e.g., a 90-year wait-and-see period), but on the bar exam apply the common law RAP unless instructed otherwise.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the Rule Against Perpetuities at a high level, which interests does it generally apply to, and what is the basic approach to analyzing a RAP problem?
cards.cloze: Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) – Overview 1. Core Rule 1.1 No property interest is valid unless it must {{c1::vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after the death of a life in being}} at the time the interest was created. 1.2 A future interest is {{c2::void}} if there is any {{c3::possibility, no matter how remote}} that it will vest more than {{c4::21 years after the death of the measuring life}}. 1.3 A {{c5::measuring life}} is a {{c6::life in being at creation}} whose life events determine whether the interest vests within the RAP period. 2. Application and Analysis 2.1 RAP applies to certain future interests, including {{c7::contingent remainders}}, {{c8::gifts to open classes}}, and {{c9::executory interests}} (and sometimes {{c10::options and rights of first refusal}}). 2.2 To analyze a conveyance, {{c11::identify the future interests}}, {{c12::apply RAP only to covered interests using a measuring life}}, and if an interest violates RAP, {{c13::strike only the offending interest and enforce what remains}}. 2.3 On the bar exam, unless told otherwise, apply the {{c14::common law RAP}} rather than modern reforms (such as a {{c15::90-year wait-and-see period}}).
cards.easyContent: The Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) says a future interest is invalid if it might vest later than 21 years after the death of some life in being at creation. It mainly applies to contingent remainders, class gifts, and executory interests. If an interest violates RAP, you strike that interest and enforce what remains, using the traditional common law rule on the bar exam.
cards.mediumContent: Under the common law Rule Against Perpetuities, no property interest is valid unless it must vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after the death of a life in being at creation. Any conceivable possibility of vesting beyond that period makes the future interest void. RAP applies to contingent remainders, gifts to open classes, and executory interests (and in some jurisdictions, options and rights of first refusal). To analyze a RAP problem, identify the future interests, apply RAP only to covered interests using an appropriate measuring life, and if a violation exists, strike only the offending future interest and enforce the rest as the new conveyance. Assume the traditional common law RAP on the bar exam unless instructed otherwise.
cards.hardContent: The Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) provides that no property interest is valid unless it must vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after the death of a life in being at the time the interest is created. A future interest is void if there is any conceivable, even highly remote, scenario in which it could vest beyond 21 years after the measuring life’s death. The measuring life is a life in being at creation whose life events determine whether the interest vests within the permissible period. RAP applies to contingent remainders, gifts to open classes, and executory interests (and sometimes to options and rights of first refusal), but not to vested remainders. In a RAP analysis, you identify the future interests, apply RAP only to those covered interests using a proper measuring life, and if an interest fails RAP, you strike only that interest and then enforce whatever remains as the new conveyance. Many states have adopted reforms such as a 90-year wait-and-see period, but for bar exam purposes you should assume and apply the traditional common law RAP unless told otherwise.
cards.mnemonic: RAP: "L + 21" — Life in being plus 21 years.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) statement of RAP and measuring life; (2) interests covered and step-by-step RAP analysis.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::common law Rule Against Perpetuities}}, an interest must {{c2::vest, if at all, within 21 years}} of a {{c3::life in being at creation}} and generally applies to {{c4::contingent remainders, class gifts, and executory interests}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Special Considerations Regarding the Rule Against Perpetuities
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 013. Special Considerations Regarding the Rule Against Perpetuities
cards.front: Special Considerations Regarding the Rule Against Perpetuities
cards.backPlain: Special RAP considerations often arise with: (1) contingent interests like options and rights of first refusal, (2) class gifts (including the Rule of Convenience), and (3) classic hypotheticals such as age contingencies beyond 21, the fertile octogenarian, and the charity-to-charity exception. 1. Options and rights of first refusal 1.1 Options and rights of first refusal are contingent interests subject to RAP and are void if they could possibly be exercised outside the perpetuities period. 2. Class gifts 2.1 Class gifts must vest (the class must be closed and all conditions precedent satisfied) within the perpetuities period. 2.2 The Rule of Convenience can sometimes save an otherwise invalid class gift by closing the class when at least one member is entitled to immediate possession. 3. Classic RAP hypotheticals and exceptions 3.1 Age contingencies beyond 21 for an open class are classic RAP problems. 3.2 The fertile octogenarian presumption can make an open class remain open for RAP purposes. 3.3 The charity-to-charity exception exempts conveyances from one charity to another from RAP.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main special categories to watch for under RAP: options/rights of first refusal, class gifts (including the Rule of Convenience), and classic RAP hypotheticals and exceptions?
cards.cloze: Special RAP considerations often arise with: (1) contingent interests like {{c1::options and rights of first refusal}}, (2) {{c2::class gifts}} (including the {{c3::Rule of Convenience}}), and (3) classic hypotheticals such as {{c4::age contingencies beyond 21}}, the {{c5::fertile octogenarian}}, and the {{c6::charity-to-charity exception}}.
cards.easyContent: Special RAP issues commonly arise with options and rights of first refusal, class gifts (and the Rule of Convenience), and classic hypotheticals like age contingencies beyond 21, the fertile octogenarian, and the charity-to-charity exception.
cards.mediumContent: RAP requires special attention for (1) contingent interests like options and rights of first refusal, which must not be exercisable beyond the perpetuities period; (2) class gifts, which must close and vest within the perpetuities period, sometimes saved by the Rule of Convenience; and (3) classic hypotheticals and exceptions, such as open-class age contingencies beyond 21, the fertile octogenarian presumption that any woman can have children at any age, and the charity-to-charity exception exempting charitable transfers from RAP.
cards.hardContent: Special RAP considerations include: (1) contingent interests such as options and rights of first refusal, which are subject to RAP and are void if they could possibly be exercised outside the perpetuities period; (2) class gifts, which must be closed and fully vested (all conditions precedent satisfied for every member) within the perpetuities period, with the Rule of Convenience sometimes saving otherwise invalid gifts by closing the class when at least one member is entitled to immediate possession; and (3) classic hypotheticals and exceptions, including open-class age contingencies beyond 21 and the fertile octogenarian presumption, both of which can create remote vesting problems, contrasted with the charity-to-charity exception, under which RAP does not apply to conveyances from one charity to another.
cards.mnemonic: RAP FOCC: First options, Open class, Octogenarian, Charity, Convenience.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) RAP and options/rights of first refusal, (2) RAP and class gifts including the Rule of Convenience, and (3) classic RAP hypotheticals (age contingencies and fertile octogenarian) plus charity-to-charity exception.
cards.clozeLite: Special RAP issues: {{c1::options and rights of first refusal}}, {{c2::class gifts and the Rule of Convenience}}, and {{c3::classic hypotheticals and exceptions}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 014. Tenancy in Common
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 A tenancy in common is a concurrent estate with multiple tenants in which each co-tenant owns a distinct, undivided interest and each has a right to possession of the whole estate. 2. Characteristics 2.1 Freely transferable: Each tenant in common's interest is freely descendible, devisable, and alienable; a co-tenant's interest can be transferred upon death. 2.2 Rent: A co-tenant can lease his individual interest, which transfers his right of possession to the lessee, but all co-tenants have a right to share in rents from a third-party lessee. 2.3 No survivorship rights: Upon the death of a co-tenant, her interest does not pass by operation of law to remaining co-tenants; instead, it passes through her estate. 2.4 Partition: A co-tenant may seek judicial partition (i.e., division of the property); if physical division is not feasible, the property may be sold and the proceeds apportioned among the co-tenants. 2.5 Default form: Modern law favors tenancy in common; it is the default concurrent estate absent clear language creating another type of co-tenancy.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a tenancy in common, and what are its main characteristics regarding transferability, rent, survivorship, partition, and default status?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A {{c1::tenancy in common}} is a {{c2::concurrent estate}} with multiple tenants in which each co-tenant owns a {{c3::distinct, undivided interest}} and each has a {{c4::right to possession of the whole estate}}. 2. Characteristics 2.1 {{c5::Freely transferable}}: Each tenant in common's interest is freely {{c6::descendible, devisable, and alienable}}; a co-tenant's interest can be transferred upon death. 2.2 {{c7::Rent}}: A co-tenant can lease his individual interest, which transfers his right of possession to the lessee, but all co-tenants have a {{c8::right to share in rents from a third-party lessee}}. 2.3 {{c9::No survivorship rights}}: Upon the death of a co-tenant, her interest {{c10::does not pass by operation of law to remaining co-tenants}}; instead, it {{c11::passes through her estate}}. 2.4 {{c12::Partition}}: A co-tenant may seek judicial partition (division of the property); if physical division is not feasible, the property may be {{c13::sold and the proceeds apportioned among the co-tenants}}. 2.5 {{c14::Default form}}: Modern law favors tenancy in common; it is the {{c15::default concurrent estate}} absent clear language creating another type of co-tenancy.
cards.easyContent: A tenancy in common is a concurrent estate where each co-tenant has a separate undivided interest and a right to possess the whole, with no right of survivorship.
cards.mediumContent: A tenancy in common is a concurrent estate in which each co-tenant owns a distinct but undivided interest and has the right to possess the whole property. Each interest is freely descendible, devisable, and alienable; co-tenants can lease their shares but must share rents from third-party lessees. There are no survivorship rights—each tenant's share passes through their estate. Any co-tenant can seek judicial partition, and if division is not possible, a sale and division of proceeds. Modern law presumes a tenancy in common by default absent clear survivorship language.
cards.hardContent: A tenancy in common is a concurrent estate where multiple co-tenants each hold a distinct, undivided fractional interest in the property, while each retains the right to possess the entire estate. Each tenant in common's interest is freely transferable—descendible, devisable, and alienable—so it can be transferred inter vivos or at death. A co-tenant may lease his own undivided interest, transferring his possessory rights to the lessee, but all co-tenants are entitled to share in any rents paid by a third-party lessee. There is no right of survivorship; upon a co-tenant's death, her interest passes through her estate rather than automatically to the other co-tenants. Any co-tenant may seek judicial partition; where physical partition is impracticable, a court may order a sale of the property and apportion the proceeds among the co-tenants. Under modern law, in the absence of clear language creating a joint tenancy or tenancy by the entirety, a conveyance to multiple persons creates a tenancy in common by default.
cards.mnemonic: "Common is default"—freely transferable, no survivorship, partitionable.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::tenancy in common}} is the {{c2::default concurrent estate}} with {{c3::freely transferable shares}}, {{c4::no right of survivorship}}, and {{c5::partition on demand}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 015. Joint Tenancy
cards.backPlain: 1. Creation 1.1 Four unities must concurrently exist when the tenants take their interests: 1.1.1 Time: Joint tenants must take their interests at the same time. 1.1.2 Title: Joint tenants must receive their interests through the same instrument. 1.1.3 Interest: Joint tenants must take equal and identical interests. 1.1.4 Possession: Joint tenants must have equal possessory rights. 1.2 Express intent required: The grantor must expressly intend to create a joint tenancy; otherwise, a tenancy in common is presumed. 1.3 Right of survivorship: If one joint tenant dies, the surviving joint tenants automatically take equal possession of the deceased tenant's share. 1.4 Transferability: A joint tenant's interest is alienable inter vivos, but not devisable or descendible because of the right of survivorship. 2. Severance and transfer of interests 2.1 Severance: Severance by any joint tenant (e.g., by sale) creates a tenancy in common with respect to the severed interest. 2.2 Transfer: A joint tenant's interest becomes a tenancy in common upon transfer; this does not destroy the entire joint tenancy if two or more joint tenants remain. 2.3 Mortgage (lien theory versus title theory) 2.3.1 Lien theory jurisdiction (majority): A joint tenant can take a mortgage on her interest without severing the joint tenancy because no title passes to the mortgagee. 2.3.2 Title theory jurisdiction (minority): The joint tenancy is severed if any joint tenant takes a mortgage on her interest because title passes to the mortgagee.
cards.frontPrompt: How is a joint tenancy created, what is its right of survivorship and transferability, and how can it be severed, including by transfer or mortgage under lien and title theories?
cards.cloze: 1. Creation 1.1 Four {{c1::unities}} must concurrently exist when the tenants take their interests: 1.1.1 {{c2::Time}}: Joint tenants must take their interests at the {{c3::same time}}. 1.1.2 {{c4::Title}}: Joint tenants must receive their interests through the {{c5::same instrument}}. 1.1.3 {{c6::Interest}}: Joint tenants must take {{c7::equal and identical interests}}. 1.1.4 {{c8::Possession}}: Joint tenants must have {{c9::equal possessory rights}}. 1.2 {{c10::Express intent required}}: The grantor must expressly intend to create a {{c11::joint tenancy}}; otherwise, a {{c12::tenancy in common}} is presumed. 1.3 {{c13::Right of survivorship}}: If one joint tenant dies, the surviving joint tenants automatically take equal possession of the {{c14::deceased tenant's share}}. 1.4 {{c15::Transferability}}: A joint tenant's interest is {{c16::alienable inter vivos}}, but {{c17::not devisable or descendible}} because of the right of survivorship. 2. {{c18::Severance}} and transfer of interests 2.1 Severance: Severance by any joint tenant (e.g., by sale) creates a {{c19::tenancy in common}} with respect to the severed interest. 2.2 Transfer: A joint tenant's interest becomes a tenancy in common upon {{c20::transfer}}; this does not destroy the entire joint tenancy if {{c21::two or more joint tenants remain}}. 2.3 Mortgage ({{c22::lien theory}} versus {{c23::title theory}}) 2.3.1 {{c24::Lien theory jurisdiction (majority)}}: A joint tenant can take a mortgage on her interest {{c25::without severing the joint tenancy}} because {{c26::no title passes to the mortgagee}}. 2.3.2 {{c27::Title theory jurisdiction (minority)}}: The joint tenancy is {{c28::severed}} if any joint tenant takes a mortgage on her interest because {{c29::title passes to the mortgagee}}.
cards.easyContent: A joint tenancy is a concurrent estate created when the four unities of time, title, interest, and possession are present, and it includes a right of survivorship so the surviving joint tenants automatically take the deceased tenant's share.
cards.mediumContent: A joint tenancy arises when the four unities of time, title, interest, and possession are present and the grantor clearly expresses intent to create a joint tenancy; otherwise, a tenancy in common is presumed. Joint tenants have a right of survivorship, so when one dies, the survivors automatically take that share, which makes the interest alienable inter vivos but not devisable or descendible. A joint tenancy is severed as to a tenant's share by a conveyance or other severing act, creating a tenancy in common as to that share, though the remaining tenants can still hold in joint tenancy. Mortgages can also affect severance: in lien theory jurisdictions, a mortgage does not sever the joint tenancy, while in title theory jurisdictions, granting a mortgage severs it because title passes to the mortgagee.
cards.hardContent: A joint tenancy is a concurrent ownership estate defined by the four unities of time, title, interest, and possession: joint tenants must acquire their interests at the same time, through the same instrument, hold equal and identical interests, and have equal rights to possess the whole property. The grantor must expressly indicate an intent to create a joint tenancy; otherwise, the default is a tenancy in common. The key feature is the right of survivorship: on the death of a joint tenant, the surviving joint tenants automatically succeed to the deceased tenant's share, making the interest alienable inter vivos but not devisable or descendible. Severance occurs when any joint tenant destroys one of the unities (for example, by selling her interest), which converts that share into a tenancy in common without necessarily destroying the joint tenancy between the remaining tenants. Mortgages have different effects depending on jurisdiction: under the majority lien theory, a mortgage creates only a lien and does not sever the joint tenancy, whereas under the minority title theory, the transfer of title to the mortgagee severs the joint tenancy as to that share.
cards.mnemonic: Joint tenancy needs TTIP plus clear survivorship.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::joint tenancy}} requires the four unities of {{c2::time}}, {{c3::title}}, {{c4::interest}}, and {{c5::possession}}, plus {{c6::express survivorship intent}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 016. Tenancy by the Entirety
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 A tenancy by the entirety is a marital concurrent estate, similar to a joint tenancy, but held only between a married couple. 2. Creation 2.1 It is created by a conveyance to a married couple and requires the same four unities as a joint tenancy (time, title, interest, and possession). 2.2 In many jurisdictions, a tenancy by the entirety is presumed in any conveyance made jointly to a married couple, absent contrary intent. 3. Characteristics 3.1 Right of survivorship: The property automatically passes to the surviving spouse upon the death of the other spouse. 3.2 No unilateral right to convey or partition: One spouse may not unilaterally convey or partition her interest; an attempt to do so is invalid and will not destroy the tenancy by the entirety. 3.3 Protection from individual creditors: Creditors of one spouse alone cannot reach that spouse's interest; only creditors of the couple (i.e., joint creditors) can reach property held in a tenancy by the entirety. 4. Severance 4.1 A tenancy by the entirety can be severed, which creates a tenancy in common, in only a few ways: 4.1.1 Death of one co-tenant. 4.1.2 Issuance of a divorce decree. 4.1.3 Execution by a joint creditor (for example, foreclosure by a creditor of both spouses).
cards.frontPrompt: What is a tenancy by the entirety, how is it created, what are its key characteristics (including survivorship, transfer, and creditor protection), and how can it be severed?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A {{c1::tenancy by the entirety}} is a {{c2::marital concurrent estate}}, similar to a joint tenancy, but held only between a {{c3::married couple}}. 2. Creation 2.1 It is created by a {{c4::conveyance to a married couple}} and requires the same four unities as a joint tenancy ({{c5::time, title, interest, and possession}}). 2.2 In many jurisdictions, a tenancy by the entirety is {{c6::presumed in any conveyance made jointly to a married couple}}, absent contrary intent. 3. Characteristics 3.1 {{c7::Right of survivorship}}: The property automatically passes to the {{c8::surviving spouse}} upon the death of the other spouse. 3.2 {{c9::No unilateral right to convey or partition}}: One spouse may not unilaterally convey or partition her interest; an attempt to do so is {{c10::invalid and will not destroy the tenancy}}. 3.3 {{c11::Protection from individual creditors}}: Creditors of one spouse alone {{c12::cannot reach that spouse's interest}}; only {{c13::joint creditors of the couple}} can reach property held in a tenancy by the entirety. 4. Severance 4.1 A tenancy by the entirety can be severed, which creates a {{c14::tenancy in common}}, in only a few ways: 4.1.1 {{c15::Death}} of one co-tenant. 4.1.2 Issuance of a {{c16::divorce decree}}. 4.1.3 {{c17::Execution by a joint creditor}} (for example, foreclosure by a creditor of both spouses).
cards.easyContent: A tenancy by the entirety is a concurrent estate held only by a married couple with a right of survivorship, strong limits on unilateral transfer, and significant protection from the individual creditors of one spouse.
cards.mediumContent: A tenancy by the entirety is a marital concurrent estate, similar to a joint tenancy, created by a conveyance to a married couple with the four unities of time, title, interest, and possession. Many jurisdictions presume a tenancy by the entirety when property is conveyed to spouses. It includes a right of survivorship, so the surviving spouse automatically owns the property at the other's death. Neither spouse may unilaterally convey or partition their interest, and individual creditors of one spouse cannot reach the property; only joint creditors of both spouses can. It is severed and converted into a tenancy in common only by death of a spouse, divorce, or execution by a joint creditor.
cards.hardContent: A tenancy by the entirety is a form of concurrent ownership available only to married couples, requiring the same four unities as a joint tenancy—time, title, interest, and possession—and typically arising by a conveyance to "A and B, husband and wife." Many jurisdictions presume a tenancy by the entirety in any conveyance to spouses absent contrary language. The estate features a right of survivorship, so the surviving spouse automatically takes full title upon the other's death. Critically, neither spouse may unilaterally convey, encumber, or partition the property; any such unilateral attempt is invalid and does not destroy the tenancy. The estate is strongly protected from the separate creditors of each spouse, who cannot reach the property, although creditors of both spouses jointly may execute against it. A tenancy by the entirety is severed and becomes a tenancy in common only upon the death of a spouse, dissolution of the marriage by divorce, or execution by a joint creditor (such as foreclosure on a joint debt).
cards.mnemonic: "MEP": Marital only, Extra creditor protection, Protected from unilateral transfer.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::tenancy by the entirety}} is a {{c2::marital concurrent estate}} with {{c3::right of survivorship}}, {{c4::no unilateral transfer}}, and {{c5::protection from separate creditors}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 017. Co Tenants' Rights and Duties
cards.front: Co Tenants' Rights and Duties – Overview
cards.backPlain: In concurrent estates, co-tenants share a set of core rights and duties. Each has an undivided right to possess the whole property and cannot exclude the others absent ouster. A co-tenant in exclusive possession generally owes no rent to co-tenants for his own use, but must account for and share rents from third parties and profits from depleting uses. Co-tenants cannot usually adversely possess against each other unless they actually oust their co-tenants and then satisfy all adverse possession elements for the statutory period. They must each bear their fair share of carrying costs such as property taxes and mortgage interest. A co-tenant who makes reasonable, necessary repairs with notice may seek contribution, while voluntary improvements do not give rise to contribution but are dealt with at partition or sale through credits or debits based on changes in value. Co-tenants may sue one another for waste and may seek judicial partition or, if physical division is not feasible, a sale and division of proceeds. Agreements not to partition are valid only for a reasonable time; longer or permanent bans are void as unreasonable restraints on alienation.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main categories of co-tenants' rights and duties in concurrent estates (possession, rents and profits, adverse possession, costs and contributions, waste, and partition/non-partition agreements)?
cards.cloze: In {{c1::concurrent estates}}, co-tenants share core rights and duties: (1) {{c2::possession}} of the whole subject to {{c3::ouster}} rules; (2) treatment of {{c4::rents and profits}} from {{c5::own use}} versus {{c6::third parties and depleting uses}}; (3) limits on {{c7::adverse possession}} against co-tenants absent {{c8::actual ouster}}; (4) obligations for {{c9::carrying costs}}, {{c10::repairs}}, and {{c11::improvements}}; (5) remedies for {{c12::waste}}; and (6) rights to {{c13::partition or sale}} and limits on {{c14::agreements not to partition}}.
cards.easyContent: Co-tenants all have the right to possess the whole, generally owe no rent to each other for their own use, must share third-party rents and depleting-use profits, share carrying costs, may get contribution for necessary repairs (not voluntary improvements), can sue for waste, and may seek partition or sale, subject to reasonable limits on non-partition agreements.
cards.mediumContent: Co-tenants each have an undivided right to possess the whole and cannot exclude others absent ouster. A co-tenant in exclusive possession owes no rent for personal use, but must share third-party rents and profits from depleting uses. One co-tenant generally cannot adversely possess against others without actual ouster plus full satisfaction of adverse possession elements. Each co-tenant must pay a fair share of carrying costs like taxes and mortgage interest, and a co-tenant who makes reasonable, necessary repairs with notice may seek contribution. Voluntary improvements do not support contribution but are accounted for at partition or sale via credit or debit for changes in value.
