Co-tenants may sue one another for waste and may seek judicial partition or, where physical division is not feasible, a sale and division of proceeds, though agreements not to partition are valid only for a reasonable time.
cards.hardContent: In concurrent estates, each co-tenant has an undivided right to possess the whole property and may not exclude co-tenants absent ouster. Exclusive possession alone does not create a duty to pay rent to other co-tenants for the possessor’s own use, but a co-tenant must account for and share rents received from third parties and profits from depleting uses such as logging, oil and gas extraction, or mining. A co-tenant generally cannot acquire title against other co-tenants by adverse possession unless he actually ousts them (or otherwise clearly repudiates the co-tenancy) and then satisfies all adverse possession elements for the statutory period. Co-tenants must each bear their fair share of carrying costs, including property taxes, mortgage interest, and similar expenses. A co-tenant who makes reasonable, necessary repairs with notice may obtain contribution from the others, but co-tenants have no right to contribution for voluntary improvements; instead, at partition or sale, the improving co-tenant is credited for any increase (or debited for any decrease) in value attributable to the improvement. Co-tenants may bring actions for waste—affirmative, permissive, or ameliorative, as recognized in the jurisdiction—against other co-tenants whose conduct harms or impermissibly alters the property. Any co-tenant may seek judicial partition; if physical division is not feasible, a court may order a sale and divide the proceeds. Co-tenants may agree not to partition, but only for a reasonable duration; long-term or permanent non-partition agreements are void as unreasonable restraints on alienation.
cards.mnemonic: "PRAC R IWP": Possession, Rents, Adverse possession, Costs, Repairs, Improvements, Waste, Partition.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three child cards: (1) possession, rent/profits, and adverse possession; (2) carrying costs, repairs, and improvements; (3) waste and partition/non-partition agreements.
cards.clozeLite: Each co-tenant has an {{c1::undivided right to possess the whole}} and generally owes {{c2::no rent for personal use}} but must {{c3::share third-party rents and depleting-use profits}} and {{c4::pay a fair share of carrying costs}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 018. Leasehold Tenancies
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A leasehold tenancy is an estate in which the tenant has a present possessory interest in the property and the landlord has a future interest (reversion). 2. Four leasehold estates: 2.1 Tenancy for years: 2.1.1 Lasts for a fixed period of time. 2.1.2 Requires a definite beginning and end date. 2.1.3 If the duration is longer than one year, the lease must be in writing under the Statute of Frauds. 2.1.4 Terminates automatically at the end of the fixed period. 2.1.5 No notice of termination is required. 2.1.6 Also referred to as an estate for years. 2.2 Periodic tenancy: A tenancy that repeats for successive periods (for example, month to month) until properly terminated. 2.3 Tenancy at will: A tenancy with no fixed duration that either party can terminate at any time (subject to any required reasonable notice or demand to vacate). 2.4 Tenancy at sufferance: A tenancy that arises when a tenant wrongfully holds over after termination of a lease (holdover tenant).
cards.frontPrompt: What are the four basic leasehold tenancies, and what are the key features of a tenancy for years?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::leasehold tenancy}} is an estate in which the {{c2::tenant}} has a {{c3::present possessory interest}} in the property and the {{c4::landlord}} has a {{c5::future interest (reversion)}}. 2. Four leasehold estates: 2.1 {{c6::Tenancy for years}}: 2.1.1 Lasts for a {{c7::fixed period of time}}. 2.1.2 Requires a {{c8::definite beginning and end date}}. 2.1.3 If the duration is {{c9::longer than one year}}, the lease must be {{c10::in writing under the Statute of Frauds}}. 2.1.4 {{c11::Terminates automatically}} at the end of the fixed period. 2.1.5 {{c12::No notice}} of termination is required. 2.1.6 Also referred to as an {{c13::estate for years}}. 2.2 {{c14::Periodic tenancy}}: A tenancy that repeats for successive periods (for example, month to month) until properly terminated. 2.3 {{c15::Tenancy at will}}: A tenancy with {{c16::no fixed duration}} that either party can terminate at any time (subject to any required reasonable notice or demand to vacate). 2.4 {{c17::Tenancy at sufferance}}: A tenancy that arises when a tenant {{c18::wrongfully holds over}} after termination of a lease ({{c19::holdover tenant}}).
cards.easyContent: Leasehold tenancies give the tenant a present possessory interest and the landlord a reversion, and come in four basic types: tenancy for years, periodic tenancy, tenancy at will, and tenancy at sufferance.
cards.mediumContent: A leasehold tenancy is an estate where the tenant has a present possessory interest and the landlord holds a reversion. The four types are: (1) tenancy for years—fixed term with definite start and end, over one year must be in writing, terminates automatically with no notice; (2) periodic tenancy—renews for set intervals until properly terminated; (3) tenancy at will—no fixed duration, either party may terminate (subject to reasonable notice rules); and (4) tenancy at sufferance—arises when a tenant wrongfully holds over after a lease ends.
cards.hardContent: A leasehold tenancy is an estate in land where the tenant has a present possessory interest and the landlord retains a future interest (reversion). There are four main leasehold estates. (1) Tenancy for years lasts for a fixed period with a definite beginning and end date; if it exceeds one year, the Statute of Frauds requires a writing. It terminates automatically at the end of the term, and no notice is required. It is also called an estate for years. (2) A periodic tenancy is a recurring tenancy for successive intervals (such as month-to-month) that continues until properly terminated. (3) A tenancy at will has no fixed duration and may be terminated by either party at any time, subject to any requirement of reasonable notice or demand to vacate. (4) A tenancy at sufferance arises when a tenant wrongfully remains in possession after a lease terminates (a holdover tenant).
cards.mnemonic: F-P-W-S: Fixed (years), Periodic, Will, Sufferance.
cards.clozeLite: Four leaseholds: {{c1::tenancy for years}}, {{c2::periodic tenancy}}, {{c3::tenancy at will}}, {{c4::tenancy at sufferance}}; tenancy for years has a {{c5::fixed term and ends automatically}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 019. Periodic Tenancy
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A periodic tenancy is a leasehold that is continuous for successive intervals (for example, weeks or months) until either party gives notice of termination. 2. Creation: A periodic tenancy can be created expressly, by implication, or by operation of law. 2.1 Express agreement: The landlord conveys to the tenant for an agreed recurring interval. 2.2 Implication: A lease that does not specify duration but provides for rent to be paid at set intervals creates a periodic tenancy by implication. 2.3 Operation of law (two situations): 2.3.1 Invalid lease: If the tenant takes possession under an invalid lease (for example, a lease that violates the Statute of Frauds), a periodic tenancy arises upon the landlord's acceptance of payment; the period of the tenancy is determined by the period the payment covers. 2.3.2 Holdover tenant: If the landlord accepts rent from a holdover tenant, a periodic tenancy arises for the period the payment covers. 3. Termination: The tenant (or landlord) must give proper notice of termination. 3.1 Sufficient time: The party terminating must give notice one full period in advance; year-to-year tenancies generally require six months' notice. 3.2 Effective date: The effective date of termination must fall at the end of a period of the tenancy. 3.3 Note: The parties can agree by contract to modify these notice requirements.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a periodic tenancy, how is it created (including by operation of law), and what is required to terminate it?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::periodic tenancy}} is a leasehold that is continuous for {{c2::successive intervals}} (for example, weeks or months) until either party gives {{c3::notice of termination}}. 2. Creation: A periodic tenancy can be created {{c4::expressly}}, by {{c5::implication}}, or by {{c6::operation of law}}. 2.1 {{c7::Express agreement}}: The landlord conveys to the tenant for an agreed recurring interval. 2.2 {{c8::Implication}}: A lease that does not specify duration but provides for {{c9::rent to be paid at set intervals}} creates a periodic tenancy by implication. 2.3 {{c10::Operation of law}} (two situations): 2.3.1 {{c11::Invalid lease}}: If the tenant takes possession under an invalid lease (for example, a lease that violates the {{c12::Statute of Frauds}}), a periodic tenancy arises upon the landlord's {{c13::acceptance of payment}}; the period of the tenancy is determined by the {{c14::period the payment covers}}. 2.3.2 {{c15::Holdover tenant}}: If the landlord {{c16::accepts rent from a holdover tenant}}, a periodic tenancy arises for the {{c17::period the payment covers}}. 3. Termination: The tenant (or landlord) must give {{c18::proper notice}} of termination. 3.1 {{c19::Sufficient time}}: The party terminating must give notice {{c20::one full period in advance}}; {{c21::year-to-year tenancies}} generally require {{c22::six months'}} notice. 3.2 {{c23::Effective date}}: The effective date of termination must fall at the {{c24::end of a period}} of the tenancy. 3.3 Note: The parties can {{c25::agree by contract to modify}} these notice requirements.
cards.easyContent: A periodic tenancy is a lease that automatically renews for set intervals until either party gives proper notice, which generally must be one full period in advance and effective at the end of a period.
cards.mediumContent: A periodic tenancy is a leasehold that continues for successive intervals (such as month-to-month) until either party properly terminates. It can arise by express agreement, by implication when rent is paid at set intervals with no fixed term, or by operation of law when a tenant holds under an invalid lease or as a holdover and the landlord accepts rent, with the period set by the rent interval. Termination requires proper notice—normally one full period, six months for year-to-year—with the termination date at the end of a tenancy period, subject to contractual modification.
cards.hardContent: A periodic tenancy is a leasehold estate that continues for successive intervals (for example, weeks or months) until either party gives notice of termination. It can be created: (1) expressly, by leasing the property for a recurring interval; (2) by implication, when the lease does not specify duration but provides that rent is paid at set intervals; and (3) by operation of law, either when a tenant takes possession under an invalid lease and the landlord accepts rent (the period being the rent interval) or when a landlord accepts rent from a holdover tenant, thereby creating a new periodic tenancy for the period the payment covers. To terminate, the tenant or landlord must give proper notice: generally one full period in advance (with year-to-year tenancies usually requiring six months' notice), and the effective date of termination must fall at the end of a tenancy period, unless the parties agree otherwise by contract.
cards.mnemonic: Periodic = "PIANO": Paid Intervals Automatically, Notice to end Only.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::periodic tenancy}} is a lease that {{c2::continues for successive intervals}} until {{c3::proper notice}}—usually {{c4::one full period (six months for year-to-year)}}—effective {{c5::at the end of a tenancy period}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 020. Tenancy at Will
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A tenancy at will is a tenancy with no fixed duration that is terminable by either party at any time without advance notice. 2. Creation: A true tenancy at will generally requires an express agreement that the lease is terminable at will. Without such an express agreement, courts usually treat the lease as an implied periodic tenancy. 3. Termination (by will or by operation of law): 3.1 By will: Either party can terminate the lease at any time, but a reasonable demand to vacate the premises is usually required. 3.2 By operation of law (occurs upon any of the following): 3.2.1 Death of either party. 3.2.2 Waste by the tenant. 3.2.3 Assignment by the tenant. 3.2.4 Transfer of title by the landlord. 3.2.5 Lease of the premises by the landlord to a third party.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a tenancy at will, how is it created, and what events terminate it (by will and by operation of law)?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::tenancy at will}} is a tenancy with {{c2::no fixed duration}} that is terminable by {{c3::either party at any time}} without advance notice. 2. Creation: A true tenancy at will generally requires an {{c4::express agreement}} that the lease is {{c5::terminable at will}}. Without such an express agreement, courts usually treat the lease as an {{c6::implied periodic tenancy}}. 3. Termination (by will or by operation of law): 3.1 By will: Either party can terminate the lease at any time, but a {{c7::reasonable demand to vacate}} the premises is usually required. 3.2 By operation of law (occurs upon any of the following): 3.2.1 {{c8::Death}} of either party. 3.2.2 {{c9::Waste}} by the tenant. 3.2.3 {{c10::Assignment}} by the tenant. 3.2.4 {{c11::Transfer of title}} by the landlord. 3.2.5 {{c12::Lease to a third party}} by the landlord.
cards.easyContent: A tenancy at will is a lease with no fixed duration that either party can terminate at any time, typically after a reasonable demand to vacate, and it usually ends automatically upon certain events like death or transfer of the property.
cards.mediumContent: A tenancy at will is a non-fixed-duration tenancy that either party may terminate at any time, usually after a reasonable demand to vacate. It normally arises only by express agreement that the lease is terminable at will; otherwise courts tend to treat open-ended arrangements as periodic tenancies. It terminates either by the will of either party or by operation of law upon events such as the death of either party, tenant's waste or assignment, landlord's transfer of title, or landlord leasing the premises to someone else.
cards.hardContent: A tenancy at will is a leasehold estate with no fixed duration that is terminable at any time by either landlord or tenant, generally without formal notice but usually only after a reasonable demand to vacate. A true tenancy at will generally requires an express agreement that the tenancy is terminable at will; absent such an agreement, courts typically construe the arrangement as an implied periodic tenancy instead. Termination may occur by will (either party choosing to end the tenancy) or by operation of law upon specific events, including the death of either party, the tenant's commission of waste, the tenant's assignment of the tenancy, the landlord's transfer of title, or the landlord leasing the premises to a third party.
cards.mnemonic: "WILL" = Whenever It Lacks Limits: ends whenever either side chooses or key events occur.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::tenancy at will}} is a {{c2::non-fixed-duration tenancy}} that {{c3::either party may terminate at any time}} and usually {{c4::requires express agreement}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 021. Tenancy at Sufferance
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A tenancy at sufferance is the default tenancy that arises when a tenant continues to possess property after the lease expires (i.e., a holdover tenant). 2. Creation: 2.1 The tenant holds possession beyond the lease's expiration. 2.2 The expired lease's terms and conditions automatically carry over to govern the tenancy at sufferance. 3. Landlord's options: 3.1 Sue to evict (and recover damages), or 3.2 Impose a new periodic tenancy. 3.2.1 Raised rent: The landlord can demand higher rent for both the holdover period and any new periodic tenancy if the landlord gave notice of the increase before the lease expired. 3.2.2 Commercial leases: If the expired lease was for one year or longer, the new periodic tenancy can be year-to-year. 4. Exception: Imposing a new periodic tenancy must be reasonable. 4.1 A new periodic tenancy is unreasonable if: 4.1.1 The tenant only remains in possession for a few hours. 4.1.2 The tenant is not at fault for the delay in vacating (for example, due to illness). 4.1.3 The lease is seasonal (for example, a ski cabin or beach house).
cards.frontPrompt: When does a tenancy at sufferance arise, what options does the landlord have with a holdover tenant, and when is imposing a new periodic tenancy unreasonable?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::tenancy at sufferance}} is the default tenancy that arises when a tenant {{c2::continues to possess property after the lease expires}} (i.e., a {{c3::holdover tenant}}). 2. Creation: 2.1 The tenant {{c4::holds possession beyond the lease's expiration}}. 2.2 The {{c5::expired lease's terms and conditions}} automatically carry over to govern the tenancy at sufferance. 3. Landlord's options: 3.1 {{c6::Sue to evict}} (and recover damages), or 3.2 {{c7::Impose a new periodic tenancy}}. 3.2.1 {{c8::Raised rent}}: The landlord can demand {{c9::higher rent}} for both the holdover period and any new periodic tenancy if the landlord gave {{c10::notice of the increase before}} the lease expired. 3.2.2 {{c11::Commercial leases}}: If the expired lease was for {{c12::one year or longer}}, the new periodic tenancy can be {{c13::year-to-year}}. 4. Exception: Imposing a new periodic tenancy must be {{c14::reasonable}}. 4.1 A new periodic tenancy is unreasonable if: 4.1.1 The tenant only remains in possession for {{c15::a few hours}}. 4.1.2 The tenant is {{c16::not at fault}} for the delay in vacating (for example, due to illness). 4.1.3 The lease is {{c17::seasonal}} (for example, a ski cabin or beach house).
cards.easyContent: A tenancy at sufferance arises when a tenant wrongfully holds over after a lease ends; the landlord may either evict or create a new periodic tenancy, but creating a new tenancy must be reasonable.
cards.mediumContent: A tenancy at sufferance is a default tenancy that arises when a tenant continues in possession after the lease expires, making the tenant a holdover. The prior lease's terms and conditions carry over. The landlord can either sue to evict and recover damages or choose to impose a new periodic tenancy, potentially at a higher rent if a rent increase was noticed before expiration, and commercial holdovers after a one-year lease can be treated as year-to-year tenancies. However, imposing a new periodic tenancy must be reasonable and is generally unreasonable when the holdover is only for a few hours, the tenant is not at fault for the delay, or the lease is seasonal.
cards.hardContent: A tenancy at sufferance arises when a tenant wrongfully remains in possession after a lease has expired, becoming a holdover tenant. This default tenancy is created when the tenant holds over, and the expired lease's terms and conditions automatically govern the interim period. Faced with a holdover, the landlord has two main options: (1) sue to evict and recover damages, or (2) elect to impose a new periodic tenancy. If the landlord had given notice of a rent increase before expiration, the landlord may charge the higher rent for both the holdover period and any new periodic tenancy, and in commercial settings, if the prior lease was for one year or more, the new periodic tenancy may be year-to-year. Imposing a new periodic tenancy must nonetheless be reasonable; it is unreasonable where the tenant remains only a few hours beyond expiration, where the tenant is not at fault for the delay (such as illness), or where the lease is seasonal, like a ski cabin or beach house.
cards.mnemonic: "SUFFER" = tenant Stays Under Finished Fixed-term, Either Removed or Renewed (reasonably).
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::tenancy at sufferance}} arises when a tenant {{c2::holds over after lease expiration}} and landlord may {{c3::evict}} or {{c4::impose a new periodic tenancy, if reasonable}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 022. Tenant's Duties at Common Law
cards.backPlain: At common law, tenants owed several key duties to the landlord and to others: 1. Duty to repair: The tenant must maintain the premises and make ordinary repairs, though in residential leases this duty is modified by the implied warranty of habitability. 2. Duty not to commit waste: The tenant must avoid voluntary, permissive, and ameliorative waste. 3. Destruction of premises: At common law, the tenant still owed rent even if the premises were destroyed without fault; under modern law, the tenant generally may terminate the lease in such circumstances. 4. Duty regarding rent and illegal use: The tenant must pay rent and not use the premises for illegal purposes; nonpayment or illegal use can give the landlord remedies such as termination or damages. 5. Liability to third parties: The tenant may be liable in tort for injuries to third persons caused by dangerous conditions within the tenant's control.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main common law duties a tenant owes regarding repair, waste, destruction of premises, rent and illegal use, and liability to third parties?
cards.cloze: At common law, tenants owed several key duties: 1. Duty to {{c1::repair}} and maintain the premises (subject in residential leases to the {{c2::implied warranty of habitability}}). 2. Duty not to commit {{c3::waste}} (including voluntary, permissive, and ameliorative waste). 3. Rules on {{c4::destruction of the premises}} (tenant owed rent at common law, may {{c5::terminate}} under modern law when destroyed without fault). 4. Duty to {{c6::pay rent}} and avoid {{c7::illegal uses}} of the property. 5. Possible tort liability for injuries to third persons from {{c8::dangerous conditions within the tenant's control}}.
cards.easyContent: At common law, tenants must repair, avoid waste, bear the risk of destruction at common law (though modern law often lets them terminate), pay rent and avoid illegal uses, and may be liable in tort for dangerous conditions they control.
cards.mediumContent: A tenant's common law duties include: (1) duty to repair and maintain the premises and make ordinary repairs (limited in residential leases by the implied warranty of habitability); (2) duty not to commit voluntary, permissive, or ameliorative waste; (3) bearing the loss for destruction of the premises without fault at common law (still owing rent), though modern law generally allows termination; (4) duty to pay rent and not use the premises for illegal purposes, with landlord remedies of termination or damages and injunctive relief; and (5) potential tort liability to third parties for dangerous conditions within the tenant's control.
cards.hardContent: At common law, tenants owe several categories of duties. They must repair and maintain the premises and make ordinary repairs, though in residential leases this is tempered by the implied warranty of habitability. They must avoid waste, including voluntary waste (overt harmful acts like removing fixtures), permissive waste (neglect or failure to care for the property), and ameliorative waste (unauthorized alterations that change or increase value). Common law treated tenants as still owing rent even if the premises were destroyed without fault of either party, but modern law generally allows tenants to terminate in such circumstances. Tenants also must pay rent and refrain from using the property for illegal purposes; nonpayment can lead to a tenancy at sufferance upon wrongful holdover, and illegal uses permit the landlord to terminate or seek damages and injunctive relief, though minor occasional illegal acts typically do not constitute a breach. Finally, tenants may be liable in tort to third persons for injuries caused by dangerous conditions within the tenant's control.
cards.mnemonic: Tenant duties: "R-W-D-R-I" – Repair, Waste, Destruction rules, Rent/illegal use, Injury.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) duty to repair and habitability interaction, (2) three types of waste, (3) destruction of premises common law vs modern, (4) duty to pay rent and illegal use, and (5) tort liability to third parties.
cards.clozeLite: Tenant duties: {{c1::repair and ordinary maintenance}}, avoid {{c2::voluntary, permissive, and ameliorative waste}}, bear {{c3::common-law risk of destruction}}, {{c4::pay rent and avoid illegal use}}, and {{c5::tort liability for dangerous conditions controlled}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 023. Fixtures
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 A fixture is a once-movable chattel that is annexed (affixed) to real property such that it becomes part of the realty. 1.2 Fixture issues often arise with leaseholds but apply to all real property estates. 1.3 Fixtures pass with ownership of the land. 1.4 Exception: A life tenant's representative may remove annexed chattel within a reasonable time after the life tenant's death. 2. Determining whether a chattel has become a fixture 2.1 Intent controls: The annexor's intent is usually determinative. 2.2 The fixture issue almost always arises where annexors affix their own chattel to their own property. 2.3 Chattel integrated into a structure (for example, heating pipes, bricks built into a wall) almost always becomes a fixture. 3. Landlord–tenant rules 3.1 The agreement between landlord and tenant, if it exists, is controlling. 3.2 Tenant installations: A tenant may remove chattel she installed if: 3.2.1 Removal occurs before the lease expires; and 3.2.2 Removal does not cause substantial harm to the property. 4. Waste 4.1 If the tenant impermissibly removes fixtures, she commits voluntary waste.
cards.frontPrompt: In real property, what is a fixture, how do you determine if a chattel has become a fixture, and what special rules govern tenant-installed fixtures?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A {{c1::fixture}} is a once-movable {{c2::chattel}} that is {{c3::annexed (affixed) to real property}} such that it becomes part of the realty. 1.2 Fixture issues often arise with {{c4::leaseholds}} but apply to all real property estates. 1.3 Fixtures {{c5::pass with ownership of the land}}. 1.4 Exception: A {{c6::life tenant's representative}} may remove annexed chattel within a {{c7::reasonable time after the life tenant's death}}. 2. Determining whether a chattel has become a fixture 2.1 {{c8::Intent controls}}: The annexor's intent is usually determinative. 2.2 The fixture issue almost always arises where annexors affix their {{c9::own chattel to their own property}}. 2.3 Chattel {{c10::integrated into a structure}} (for example, heating pipes, bricks built into a wall) almost always becomes a fixture. 3. Landlord–tenant rules 3.1 The {{c11::agreement between landlord and tenant}}, if it exists, is controlling. 3.2 {{c12::Tenant installations}}: A tenant may remove chattel she installed if: 3.2.1 Removal occurs {{c13::before the lease expires}}; and 3.2.2 Removal does not cause {{c14::substantial harm to the property}}. 4. Waste 4.1 If the tenant impermissibly removes fixtures, she commits {{c15::voluntary waste}}.
cards.easyContent: A fixture is a once-movable chattel that has been affixed to land so that it becomes part of the realty and passes with the land. Intent, integration into the structure, and any landlord–tenant agreement control whether something is a fixture.
cards.mediumContent: A fixture is a once-movable chattel annexed to real property so that it becomes part of the realty and passes with ownership of the land. Whether an item is a fixture is usually determined by the annexor's intent, with chattels integrated into a structure (like heating pipes or bricks in a wall) almost always treated as fixtures. In landlord–tenant settings, any agreement controls; otherwise, a tenant may remove her installations if she does so before the lease ends and without substantial damage. A life tenant's representative may remove annexed chattel within a reasonable time after death, and a tenant who impermissibly removes fixtures commits voluntary waste.
cards.hardContent: A fixture is a once-movable chattel that has been annexed (affixed) to real property so that it becomes part of the realty and therefore passes with ownership of the land. Fixture disputes often arise in leaseholds but apply to all real property estates. Whether a chattel has become a fixture is generally governed by the annexor's intent; disputes frequently involve annexors who affix their own chattel to their own property, and chattels that are integrated into the structure (such as heating pipes or bricks in a wall) are almost always fixtures. In landlord–tenant situations, any express agreement between landlord and tenant is controlling. Absent agreement, a tenant may remove chattel she installed if she removes it before the lease expires and the removal does not cause substantial harm to the property. A life tenant's representative may remove annexed chattel within a reasonable time after the life tenant's death. If the tenant impermissibly removes fixtures, she commits voluntary waste.
cards.mnemonic: FIT: Fixtures are Integrated, Intent-based, and pass with the Title.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::fixture}} is a once-movable {{c2::chattel annexed to real property}} that {{c3::passes with ownership of the land}}; {{c4::annexor's intent}} and {{c5::landlord–tenant agreements}} usually control.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 024. Landlord Remedies for Tenant Breach
cards.front: Landlord Remedies for Tenant Breach – Overview
cards.backPlain: When a tenant breaches leasehold duties, the landlord’s remedies depend on whether the tenant retains possession or abandons the premises. If the tenant stays, the landlord may evict or continue the lease and sue for rent. If the tenant abandons, the landlord may accept surrender, ignore abandonment (minority), or, under the majority rule, must reasonably attempt to re-let and recover losses from the breaching tenant. Landlord remedies are limited: the landlord may not use self-help to recover possession, must properly handle and return any security deposit (minus only legitimate damages or contractually permitted losses), and may not engage in retaliatory eviction or other retaliation when the tenant exercises protected rights (such as reporting housing code violations).
cards.frontPrompt: When a tenant breaches a lease, what are the main categories of landlord remedies depending on possession, and what key limits cabin those remedies?
cards.cloze: When a tenant {{c1::breaches leasehold duties}}, the landlord’s remedies depend on whether the tenant {{c2::retains possession}} or {{c3::abandons}} the premises. If the tenant stays, the landlord may {{c4::evict}} or {{c5::continue the lease and sue for rent}}. If the tenant abandons, the landlord may {{c6::accept surrender}}, {{c7::ignore abandonment (minority)}}, or, under the {{c8::majority rule}}, must {{c9::reasonably attempt to re-let and recover losses}}. The landlord may not {{c10::use self-help}} to regain possession, must {{c11::properly handle and return any security deposit}} (minus only {{c12::legitimate damages or contractually permitted losses}}), and may not engage in {{c13::retaliatory eviction}} or retaliation when the tenant {{c14::exercises protected rights}} such as reporting housing code violations.
cards.easyContent: Landlord remedies for tenant breach turn on whether the tenant stays or abandons. If the tenant stays, the landlord can evict or keep the lease and sue for rent. If the tenant abandons, the landlord can accept surrender, ignore it (minority), or, under the majority rule, must try to re-let and recover losses. Limits: no self-help, proper handling/return of security deposits, and no retaliatory eviction when tenants exercise protected rights.
cards.mediumContent: When a tenant breaches, first ask whether the tenant remains in possession or has abandoned the premises. If the tenant stays, the landlord may bring a summary eviction proceeding or continue the lease and sue for rent due. If the tenant abandons, the landlord may accept surrender and terminate further liability, ignore abandonment and hold the tenant liable for unpaid rent (minority), or, under the majority rule, must make reasonable efforts to re-let and then recover the difference plus costs. These remedies are constrained: the landlord cannot use self-help to regain possession, must collect, hold, and return any security deposit, retaining only amounts for damages or other contractually allowed losses, and may not retaliate against tenants for reporting code violations or exercising protected rights.
cards.hardContent: Landlord remedies for tenant breach are structured around possession. If the tenant remains in possession, the landlord may (1) file a summary eviction proceeding to regain possession, or (2) continue the lease in force and sue for accrued rent. If the tenant abandons, the landlord may: (a) treat the abandonment as a surrender, accept it, and release the tenant from further liability; (b) ignore the abandonment and hold the tenant liable for the full rent due under the lease (minority rule); or (c) under the majority rule, has a duty to make reasonable efforts to re-let the premises and may then hold the breaching tenant liable for losses, generally the difference between the contract rent and the new rent plus re-letting costs. These remedies are limited. The landlord may not resort to self-help (such as forcible removal, lockouts, or cutting off utilities) to recover possession. Security deposits, typically collected at the start of the lease to secure against damage or abandonment, must be returned when the lease terminates, less only legitimate damages or other contractually permitted deductions. In addition, landlords are barred from retaliatory eviction or other retaliatory measures when tenants lawfully report housing code or other violations or assert their statutory or contractual rights.
cards.mnemonic: SIR for abandonment: Surrender, Ignore (minority), Re-let (majority).
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) remedies when tenant remains in possession, (2) remedies when tenant abandons (SIR), and (3) limits on landlord remedies (no self-help, security deposits, retaliatory eviction).
cards.clozeLite: Landlord remedies turn on {{c1::whether the tenant remains or abandons}}. If the tenant abandons, the majority rule imposes a {{c2::duty to reasonably re‑let}} and then {{c3::recover the difference plus costs}}. Remedies are limited by {{c4::no self‑help}}, {{c5::proper security‑deposit handling}}, and {{c6::no retaliatory eviction}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 025. Landlord's Duties and Warranties
cards.backPlain: 1. Landlord's implied duties to the tenant 1.1 Duty to deliver possession on the first day of the lease. 1.1.1 Majority (English Rule): The landlord must deliver actual (physical) possession to the tenant on the first day of the lease. 1.1.2 Minority (American Rule): The landlord need only deliver legal possession; the new tenant is responsible for evicting a holdover tenant. 1.2 Tenant's remedy for breach of the duty to deliver possession: money damages. 2. Other implied protections 2.1 Implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. 2.2 Implied warranty of habitability (residential leases). 2.3 Tort liability (landlord's liability in tort for dangerous conditions, as provided by common law and statutes).
cards.frontPrompt: What implied duties and warranties does a landlord owe a tenant, and how do the English and American rules differ regarding delivery of possession?
cards.cloze: 1. Landlord's implied duties to the tenant 1.1 Duty to {{c1::deliver possession}} on the first day of the lease. 1.1.1 Majority ({{c2::English Rule}}): The landlord must deliver {{c3::actual (physical) possession}} to the tenant on the first day of the lease. 1.1.2 Minority ({{c4::American Rule}}): The landlord need only deliver {{c5::legal possession}}; the new tenant is responsible for {{c6::evicting a holdover tenant}}. 1.2 Tenant's remedy for breach of the duty to deliver possession: {{c7::money damages}}. 2. Other implied protections 2.1 {{c8::Implied covenant of quiet enjoyment}}. 2.2 {{c9::Implied warranty of habitability}} (residential leases). 2.3 {{c10::Tort liability}} (landlord's liability in tort for dangerous conditions, as provided by common law and statutes).
cards.easyContent: Landlords must deliver possession at lease start (actual possession under the majority English Rule, legal possession only under the minority American Rule) and are liable in damages if they fail. They also owe tenants an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, and may face tort liability for dangerous conditions.
cards.mediumContent: A landlord has an implied duty to deliver possession on the first day of the lease. Under the majority English Rule, the landlord must deliver actual physical possession; under the minority American Rule, the landlord need only deliver legal possession, and the new tenant must evict any holdover. Breach of this duty entitles the tenant to money damages. In addition, the landlord owes implied protections including the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, the implied warranty of habitability for residential leases, and potential tort liability for dangerous conditions.
cards.hardContent: Landlords have several implied duties and warranties toward tenants. First, they must deliver possession on the first day of the lease. Under the majority English Rule, the landlord must provide actual, physical possession, such that any holdover occupant is removed; failure to do so is a breach for which the tenant may recover money damages. Under the minority American Rule, the landlord need only convey legal possession, and the tenant bears the burden of evicting any holdover. Beyond delivery of possession, landlords are subject to an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, and a range of tort liabilities for dangerous or defective conditions as defined by common law and statutes.
cards.mnemonic: E for English = Empty; A for American = Authority only.
cards.clozeLite: A landlord must {{c1::deliver possession on the first day of the lease}} and, under the {{c2::English Rule}}, give {{c3::actual physical possession}}, while under the {{c4::American Rule}} only {{c5::legal possession}} is required.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 026. Implied Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 A tenant has an implied right to quiet use and enjoyment of the premises, without interference from the landlord. 1.2 Breach may occur by actual or constructive eviction. 1.3 Breach may occur by the landlord's wrongful conduct causing loss of use and enjoyment by the tenant. 2. Actual eviction 2.1 Actual eviction occurs when the landlord wrongfully evicts or excludes the tenant from the property. 3. Constructive eviction 3.1 Constructive eviction occurs when the landlord's actions or inactions render the property uninhabitable or unusable. 3.2 Elements of constructive eviction: 3.2.1 Breach of duty: The landlord breached a duty to the tenant. 3.2.2 Substantial interference: Major and/or chronic problems (for example, a leaky roof) are caused by the landlord's wrongful conduct. 3.2.3 Notice and opportunity to cure: The tenant must inform the landlord of the problem and give a reasonable opportunity to repair; the landlord must fail to act meaningfully. 3.2.4 Vacate: The tenant must vacate the premises within a reasonable period after the landlord fails to repair.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, and how do actual and constructive eviction—particularly the elements of constructive eviction—establish a breach?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A tenant has an implied right to {{c1::quiet use and enjoyment of the premises}}, without interference from the landlord. 1.2 Breach may occur by {{c2::actual}} or {{c3::constructive}} eviction. 1.3 Breach may occur by the landlord's {{c4::wrongful conduct}} causing loss of use and enjoyment by the tenant. 2. Actual eviction 2.1 Actual eviction occurs when the landlord {{c5::wrongfully evicts or excludes}} the tenant from the property. 3. Constructive eviction 3.1 Constructive eviction occurs when the landlord's {{c6::actions or inactions}} render the property {{c7::uninhabitable or unusable}}. 3.2 Elements of constructive eviction: 3.2.1 {{c8::Breach of duty}}: The landlord breached a duty to the tenant. 3.2.2 {{c9::Substantial interference}}: Major and/or chronic problems (for example, a leaky roof) are caused by the landlord's wrongful conduct. 3.2.3 {{c10::Notice and opportunity to cure}}: The tenant must inform the landlord of the problem and give a reasonable opportunity to repair; the landlord must fail to act meaningfully. 3.2.4 {{c11::Vacate}}: The tenant must vacate the premises within a reasonable period after the landlord fails to repair.
cards.easyContent: The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment gives the tenant a right to use and enjoy the premises without landlord interference. A breach can occur through actual eviction (wrongful exclusion) or constructive eviction, where the landlord’s wrongful failure to fix serious problems substantially interferes with use and the tenant gives notice, allows time to cure, and then vacates.
cards.mediumContent: Under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, the tenant is entitled to quiet use and enjoyment of the premises free from landlord interference. A breach arises through actual eviction when the landlord wrongfully evicts or excludes the tenant, or through constructive eviction when the landlord’s actions or inactions make the premises uninhabitable or unusable. Constructive eviction requires (1) a landlord breach of duty, (2) substantial interference with the tenant’s use (e.g., major, chronic defects), (3) tenant notice and a reasonable opportunity for the landlord to cure, and (4) the tenant vacating within a reasonable time after the landlord fails to repair.
cards.hardContent: The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees a tenant the right to quietly use and enjoy the leased premises without wrongful interference by the landlord. A breach can be shown by actual eviction, where the landlord wrongfully evicts or excludes the tenant from the property, or by constructive eviction, which arises when the landlord’s actions or inactions render the premises uninhabitable or unusable. To establish constructive eviction, the tenant must prove: (1) the landlord breached a duty owed to the tenant; (2) the breach caused substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment, such as major or chronic defects like a continually leaking roof; (3) the tenant gave the landlord notice of the problem and a reasonable opportunity to repair, and the landlord failed to act meaningfully; and (4) the tenant vacated the premises within a reasonable period after the landlord failed to remedy the condition.
cards.mnemonic: Constructive eviction needs B-S-N-V: Breach, Substantial interference, Notice, Vacate.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::implied covenant of quiet enjoyment}} is breached by {{c2::actual eviction}} or {{c3::constructive eviction}}. Constructive eviction requires {{c4::breach, substantial interference, notice/opportunity to cure, and vacating}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 027. Implied Warranty of Habitability
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 Residential property must be fit for basic human dwelling. 1.2 Residential only: The implied warranty of habitability does not apply to commercial leases. 1.3 Absolute duty: The warranty cannot be waived or modified by lease terms. 1.4 Local housing code or case law specifies the standard for breach. 1.5 Examples: No heat in winter, no plumbing, no running water, or similar conditions may constitute a breach of the implied warranty of habitability. 2. Tenant's remedies (after giving notice and a reasonable opportunity to cure) 2.1 Move: Vacate the premises and terminate the lease. 2.2 Repair and deduct: Make reasonable repairs and deduct the costs from future rent. 2.3 Reduce or withhold rent: Reduce rent or stop payment until a court determines the fair rental value given the breach; the tenant must place withheld rent in escrow. 2.4 Remain and sue: Remain in possession and seek money damages.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, when is it breached, and what remedies does a tenant have upon breach?
cards.cloze: 1. In general 1.1 {{c1::Residential property}} must be fit for {{c2::basic human dwelling}}. 1.2 {{c3::Residential only}}: The implied warranty of habitability does not apply to {{c4::commercial leases}}. 1.3 {{c5::Absolute duty}}: The warranty cannot be waived or modified by lease terms. 1.4 {{c6::Local housing code or case law}} specifies the standard for breach. 1.5 Examples: {{c7::No heat in winter, no plumbing, no running water}}, or similar conditions may constitute a breach of the implied warranty of habitability. 2. Tenant's remedies (after giving notice and a reasonable opportunity to cure) 2.1 {{c8::Move}}: Vacate the premises and terminate the lease. 2.2 {{c9::Repair and deduct}}: Make reasonable repairs and deduct the costs from future rent. 2.3 {{c10::Reduce or withhold rent}}: Reduce rent or stop payment until a court determines the fair rental value given the breach; the tenant must place withheld rent in {{c11::escrow}}. 2.4 {{c12::Remain and sue}}: Remain in possession and seek {{c13::money damages}}.
cards.easyContent: The implied warranty of habitability requires residential premises to be fit for basic human dwelling, as defined by housing codes and case law, and cannot be waived. Upon a material breach (like no heat, plumbing, or water), a tenant who gives notice and time to cure can move out, repair and deduct, withhold or reduce rent (placing it in escrow), or stay and sue for damages.
cards.mediumContent: In residential leases, the implied warranty of habitability obligates the landlord to keep the premises fit for basic human dwelling. It applies only to residential properties, not commercial leases, and is an absolute duty that cannot be waived by agreement. Local housing codes or case law set the standard; conditions such as no heat in winter, lack of plumbing, or no running water typically constitute breaches. After giving notice and a reasonable opportunity to cure, the tenant may (1) move out and terminate the lease, (2) repair the defect and deduct reasonable costs from rent, (3) reduce or withhold rent, placing withheld sums in escrow until a court determines fair rental value, or (4) remain in possession and sue for money damages.
cards.hardContent: The implied warranty of habitability is an absolute, non-waivable duty imposed on landlords in residential leases to maintain premises fit for basic human habitation. It does not extend to commercial leases. The standard for breach is supplied by local housing codes and case law; serious deficiencies such as no heat in winter, lack of functional plumbing, or absence of running water commonly amount to violations. When the landlord breaches, the tenant, after providing notice and a reasonable opportunity to cure, may choose among several remedies: (1) move out, treating the lease as terminated; (2) make reasonable repairs and deduct the cost from future rent; (3) reduce or withhold rent until a court determines the appropriate reduced rental value, with withheld amounts placed in escrow; or (4) remain in possession and bring an action for money damages, sometimes including consequential or punitive damages where authorized.
cards.mnemonic: HOMES: Human dwelling, Only residential, Mandatory, Evaluated by codes, Serious defects.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::implied warranty of habitability}} is an {{c2::absolute, non-waivable duty}} in {{c3::residential}} leases, breached by {{c4::serious defects like no heat or water}}, giving tenant {{c5::multiple remedial options}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 028. Landlord Tort Liability to Tenant
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A landlord may be liable to a tenant for injuries occurring on the leased property. A landlord is liable for injuries involving: 1.1 Common areas: The landlord owes a duty of reasonable care in maintaining and repairing common areas (e.g., hallways, stairs). 1.2 Latent defects: The landlord has a duty to disclose hidden defects that he knows or should reasonably know of. 1.3 Assumption of repairs: If the landlord chooses to undertake repairs, he is liable for harm caused by negligent repairs. 1.4 Public use: The landlord is liable for known defects if he knows the property is for public use and knows or should know that the tenant is unlikely to repair (for example, a concert hall or convention center). 1.5 Seasonal or short-term lease of a furnished dwelling: The landlord is liable for defects that cause harm to the tenant.
cards.frontPrompt: For what types of conditions or situations can a landlord be liable in tort to a tenant for injuries occurring on the leased property?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A landlord may be liable to a tenant for injuries occurring on the leased property. A landlord is liable for injuries involving: 1.1 {{c1::Common areas}}: The landlord owes a {{c2::duty of reasonable care}} in maintaining and repairing common areas (e.g., hallways, stairs). 1.2 {{c3::Latent defects}}: The landlord has a duty to {{c4::disclose hidden defects}} that he knows or should reasonably know of. 1.3 {{c5::Assumption of repairs}}: If the landlord chooses to undertake repairs, he is liable for harm caused by {{c6::negligent repairs}}. 1.4 {{c7::Public use}}: The landlord is liable for {{c8::known defects}} if he knows the property is for public use and knows or should know that the tenant is unlikely to repair (for example, a concert hall or convention center). 1.5 {{c9::Seasonal or short-term lease of a furnished dwelling}}: The landlord is liable for {{c10::defects that cause harm to the tenant}}.
cards.easyContent: A landlord can be liable in tort to a tenant for injuries in common areas, undisclosed latent defects, negligent repairs, defects in property held open for public use, and defects in short-term furnished leases.
cards.mediumContent: A landlord may be liable to a tenant for injuries on the leased property when: (1) common areas are negligently maintained; (2) latent defects known or reasonably knowable to the landlord are not disclosed; (3) the landlord negligently performs repairs he undertakes; (4) the landlord knows of defects in property held out for public use and knows the tenant is unlikely to repair; and (5) defects in a short-term, furnished dwelling cause harm.
cards.hardContent: A landlord may be liable to a tenant in tort for injuries occurring on the leased property in several situations: (1) Common areas: the landlord owes a duty of reasonable care in maintaining and repairing common areas such as hallways and stairs. (2) Latent defects: the landlord has a duty to disclose hidden defects that he knows or should reasonably know of. (3) Assumption of repairs: if the landlord chooses to undertake repairs, he is liable for harm caused by negligent repairs. (4) Public use: the landlord is liable for known defects if he knows the property is for public use and knows or should know that the tenant is unlikely to repair, such as in a concert hall or convention center. (5) Seasonal or short-term lease of a furnished dwelling: the landlord is liable for defects in the premises that cause harm to the tenant.
cards.mnemonic: C-L-A-P-S: Common, Latent, Assumed repairs, Public, Short-term.
cards.clozeLite: Landlord tort liability arises for {{c1::negligently maintained common areas}}, {{c2::undisclosed latent defects}}, {{c3::negligent repairs}}, {{c4::public use defects}}, and {{c5::short-term furnished dwelling defects}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 029. Assignments and Subleases
cards.backPlain: Unless restricted by lease terms, a tenant may transfer her leasehold interest either in whole (assignment) or in part (sublease). In an assignment, the tenant transfers the entire leasehold and the assignee comes into privity of estate with the landlord, while the original tenant usually remains in privity of contract and secondarily liable for rent absent novation. In a sublease, only a partial interest is transferred; the original tenant remains the landlord’s tenant in both privity of estate and contract, and the sublessee is typically not directly liable to the landlord. Lease provisions restricting assignment or sublease are enforceable but generally construed against landlords, and consent may waive such restrictions unless clearly reserved in the lease.
cards.frontPrompt: How can a tenant transfer a leasehold interest, and at a high level how do assignments, subleases, and lease restrictions differ?
cards.cloze: Unless restricted by lease terms, a tenant may transfer her leasehold interest either {{c1::in whole (assignment)}} or {{c2::in part (sublease)}}. In an {{c3::assignment}}, the tenant transfers the {{c4::entire leasehold}} and the {{c5::assignee comes into privity of estate with the landlord}}, while the {{c6::original tenant usually remains in privity of contract}}. In a {{c7::sublease}}, only a {{c8::partial interest}} is transferred; the {{c9::original tenant remains the landlord’s tenant in privity of estate and contract}}, and the {{c10::sublessee is typically not directly liable to the landlord}}. Lease provisions restricting assignment or sublease are {{c11::enforceable but construed against landlords}}, and {{c12::landlord consent may waive such restrictions unless clearly reserved}}.
cards.easyContent: A tenant can transfer the entire leasehold (assignment) or only part of it (sublease), unless the lease restricts transfers. Assignments create privity of estate between assignee and landlord; subleases keep the original tenant in privity with the landlord and usually leave the sublessee with no direct liability to the landlord. Clauses restricting transfers are enforceable but construed against landlords, and consent may waive them unless clearly reserved.
cards.mediumContent: Unless restricted by the lease, a tenant may transfer her leasehold interest in whole (assignment) or in part (sublease). In an assignment, the entire leasehold passes to the assignee, who comes into privity of estate with the landlord; the original tenant typically remains in privity of contract and secondarily liable for rent absent novation. In a sublease, only part of the leasehold interest is conveyed; the original tenant remains in privity of estate and contract with the landlord, and the sublessee usually has no direct liability to the landlord unless obligations are expressly assumed. Lease clauses limiting assignments or subleases are generally enforceable but strictly construed against landlords, and once consent is given it may operate as a waiver of further restrictions unless the lease clearly preserves them.
cards.hardContent: Leasehold interests are generally transferable unless the lease restricts transfer. A transfer of the tenant’s entire remaining interest (both in duration and physical space) is an assignment, which places the assignee in privity of estate with the landlord and subjects both to covenants that run with the land, while the original tenant generally remains in privity of contract and liable for rent unless released by novation. A transfer of less than the tenant’s full interest is a sublease: the original tenant (sublessor) remains in both privity of estate and contract with the landlord, and the sublessee pays rent to the sublessor and is not usually directly liable to the landlord or bound by covenants unless expressly assumed. Lease provisions restricting assignment or sublease are enforceable but construed against the landlord, and a landlord’s consent to an assignment or sublease often waives enforcement of such restrictions going forward unless the lease clearly provides otherwise.
cards.mnemonic: Assignment = All; Sublease = Slice (partial; tenant still tied).
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) general transferability of leaseholds, (2) assignment and its privity/rent consequences, (3) sublease and its privity/rent consequences, and (4) construction and waiver of assignment/sublease restrictions.
cards.clozeLite: In an {{c1::assignment}}, the {{c2::entire remaining leasehold}} passes and the {{c3::assignee enters privity of estate}} with the landlord; in a {{c4::sublease}}, only {{c5::part of the interest}} is conveyed and the {{c6::original tenant stays in privity}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 030. Easement
cards.backPlain: An easement is a non-possessory property interest that confers a right to use another's land. The burdened land is the servient estate, and the benefited land—if any—is the dominant estate. Easements can be appurtenant (tied to a dominant parcel) or in gross (benefiting a person or entity), and may be affirmative (allowing use) or negative (restricting otherwise permissible uses). Easements may be created by express grant or reservation, implication, necessity, or prescription.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an easement in property law, and what are the major categories and methods of creation?
cards.cloze: An {{c1::easement}} is a {{c2::non-possessory property interest}} that confers a {{c3::right to use another's land}}. The burdened land is the {{c4::servient estate}}, and the benefited land—if any—is the {{c5::dominant estate}}. Easements can be {{c6::appurtenant}} or {{c7::in gross}}, and may be {{c8::affirmative}} or {{c9::negative}}. They may be created by {{c10::express grant or reservation}}, {{c11::implication}}, {{c12::necessity}}, or {{c13::prescription}}.
cards.easyContent: An easement is a non-possessory right to use another’s land. The land burdened is the servient estate, and the land benefited (if any) is the dominant estate. Easements can be appurtenant or in gross, affirmative or negative, and can be created by express grant or reservation, implication, necessity, or prescription.
cards.mediumContent: An easement is a non-possessory property interest giving a right to use another’s land. The burdened land is the servient estate; the benefited land is the dominant estate, if there is one. Easements may be appurtenant (benefiting a parcel and running with it) or in gross (benefiting a person or entity), and affirmative (allowing use) or negative (restricting otherwise permissible uses). They can arise by express grant or reservation, implication, necessity, or prescription.
cards.hardContent: An easement is a non-possessory property interest that confers a right to use another's land. The land burdened by the easement is the servient estate, and the land benefited by it, if any, is the dominant estate. Easements are categorized as appurtenant vs. in gross and affirmative vs. negative. They may be created by (1) express grant or reservation, (2) implication, (3) necessity, or (4) prescription. Appurtenant easements run with a dominant parcel, while easements in gross benefit a person or entity and are tied only to the servient land. Affirmative easements allow use of the servient estate; negative easements restrict otherwise permissible uses.
cards.mnemonic: Easements AINN: Appurtenant/In gross, Nonpossessory use, Negative/Affirmative.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) definition and estates (servient vs. dominant), (2) appurtenant vs. in gross, (3) affirmative vs. negative, and (4) methods of creation.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::easement}} is a {{c2::non-possessory right to use another’s land}} that may be {{c3::appurtenant or in gross}} and {{c4::affirmative or negative}}, created by {{c5::express grant or reservation, implication, necessity, or prescription}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 031. Scope of Easements
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: An easement's scope is determined by the terms or conditions that created it. In interpreting an easement's scope, courts will consider the reasonable intent of the original parties. 2. Expansion: Easement holders cannot unilaterally expand the scope of their easement (for example, through overuse or misuse). Overuse or misuse of an easement does not terminate the easement; the remedy for a violation is an injunction or damages. 3. Duty to repair: The easement holder has a duty to make repairs if he is the sole user. If both the servient landowner and the easement holder use an easement, the repair costs are apportioned between them.
cards.frontPrompt: How is the scope of an easement determined, can the holder unilaterally expand it, and who bears the duty to repair?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: An easement's scope is determined by the {{c1::terms or conditions that created it}}. In interpreting an easement's scope, courts will consider the {{c2::reasonable intent of the original parties}}. 2. {{c3::Expansion}}: Easement holders {{c4::cannot unilaterally expand}} the scope of their easement (for example, through overuse or misuse). {{c5::Overuse or misuse does not terminate}} the easement; the remedy for a violation is {{c6::an injunction or damages}}. 3. {{c7::Duty to repair}}: The easement holder has a duty to make repairs if he is the {{c8::sole user}}. If both the servient landowner and the easement holder use an easement, the {{c9::repair costs are apportioned}} between them.
cards.easyContent: The scope of an easement is set by the terms and intent of the original grant; the holder cannot unilaterally expand it, and overuse leads to remedies like injunctions or damages, not termination. The holder must repair if he alone uses it, but if both parties use it, repair costs are shared.
cards.mediumContent: An easement’s scope is defined by the terms or conditions that created it, interpreted in light of the reasonable intent of the original parties. The holder may not unilaterally expand the easement’s scope by overuse or misuse; such conduct does not terminate the easement but is remedied by injunction or damages. The easement holder must repair the easement if he is the sole user; if both the servient owner and the holder use it, they share repair costs.
cards.hardContent: The scope of an easement is determined by the terms or conditions under which it was created, and courts interpret those terms in light of the reasonable intent of the original parties. An easement holder may not unilaterally expand the scope of the easement, such as by materially increasing its use or changing its character. Overuse or misuse does not, by itself, terminate the easement; instead, the servient owner’s remedies are typically an injunction to limit the use to its proper scope or an award of damages. With respect to repairs, the easement holder has a duty to make repairs when he is the sole user of the easement. When both the servient landowner and the easement holder make use of the easement, the obligation to repair is apportioned between them.
cards.mnemonic: SCOPE: Set by terms, Cannot Overextend, Pay for repairs if Exclusive.
cards.clozeLite: An easement’s scope is set by {{c1::the creating terms}} and {{c2::intent of the original parties}}; the holder {{c3::cannot unilaterally expand}} it and {{c4::overuse is remedied by injunction or damages}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Express Easement (Easement by Grant or Reservation)
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 032. Express Easement (Easement by Grant or Reservation)
cards.front: Express Easement (Easement by Grant or Reservation)
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: Easements may be expressly created by grant or reservation. 2. Grant: An express grant of the easement is created by an instrument (for example, a written agreement) in which the servient estate owner gives an easement to the owner of the dominant estate. 3. Reservation: A grantor conveys title to land but reserves the right to continue using the land for a designated purpose. The grantor may only reserve an easement for himself; a reservation that purports to benefit a third party is void. For example: O conveys property to A, reserving an easement allowing access to a path across the property. 4. Requirements: Express easements must be: 4.1 In writing (otherwise they violate the Statute of Frauds); and 4.2 Signed by the servient estate holder.
cards.frontPrompt: How are express easements created by grant or reservation, and what formal requirements must they satisfy?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: Easements may be expressly created by {{c1::grant}} or {{c2::reservation}}. 2. {{c3::Grant}}: An express grant of the easement is created by an {{c4::instrument (e.g., a written agreement)}} in which the {{c5::servient estate owner}} gives an easement to the {{c6::owner of the dominant estate}}. 3. {{c7::Reservation}}: A grantor conveys title to land but {{c8::reserves the right to continue using the land for a designated purpose}}. The grantor may only reserve an easement {{c9::for himself}}; a reservation that purports to benefit a {{c10::third party is void}}. For example: O conveys property to A, reserving an easement allowing access to a path across the property. 4. Requirements: Express easements must be: 4.1 {{c11::In writing}} (otherwise they violate the {{c12::Statute of Frauds}}); and 4.2 {{c13::Signed by the servient estate holder}}.
cards.easyContent: Express easements arise by written grant from the servient owner to the dominant owner or by reservation when the grantor keeps a use right when conveying title. They must be in writing and signed by the servient estate holder to satisfy the Statute of Frauds.
cards.mediumContent: Express easements are created either by grant—where the servient owner, by written instrument, gives an easement to the dominant owner—or by reservation, where a grantor conveys title but reserves a specified use of the land. A reservation can benefit only the grantor; an attempt to reserve an easement for a third party is void. To be valid, express easements must comply with the Statute of Frauds: they must be in writing and signed by the servient estate holder.
cards.hardContent: Express easements are servitudes created by explicit agreement, either by grant or reservation. In a grant, the servient estate owner uses a written instrument, such as a deed or easement agreement, to give an easement to the owner of the dominant estate. In a reservation, a grantor conveys title to land but reserves the right to continue using the land for a designated purpose; under modern rules, the grantor may reserve an easement only for himself, and a reservation purporting to benefit a third party is void. For example, O conveys property to A but reserves an easement to use a path across the property. Because an express easement is an interest in land, it must satisfy the Statute of Frauds, meaning it must be in writing and signed by the servient estate holder.
cards.mnemonic: GRaRS: Grant or Reservation, Signed writing; reservation only helps grantor.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::express easement}} is created by {{c2::grant or reservation}} and must {{c3::be in writing and signed by the servient owner}}; a {{c4::reservation may benefit only the grantor}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 033. Easement by Prescription
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: An easement by prescription is acquired through use of another's land, similar to acquiring title by adverse possession. 1.1 Requirements: The acquirer's use of another's land must be: 1.1.1 Continuous for the applicable statutory period; 1.1.2 Open and notorious so that the owner knows or should know of the use; 1.1.3 Actual; and 1.1.4 Hostile, meaning without the owner's permission. 2. Termination by prescription: An easement can also be terminated by prescription if the servient landowner interferes with the easement in a way that satisfies the same requirements (continuous, open and notorious, actual, and hostile) for the statutory period.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an easement by prescription, what are its elements, and how can an easement be terminated by prescription?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: An {{c1::easement by prescription}} is acquired through use of another's land, similar to acquiring title by {{c2::adverse possession}}. 1.1 Requirements: The acquirer's use of another's land must be: 1.1.1 {{c3::Continuous}} for the applicable statutory period; 1.1.2 {{c4::Open and notorious}} so that the owner knows or should know of the use; 1.1.3 {{c5::Actual}}; and 1.1.4 {{c6::Hostile, meaning without the owner's permission}}. 2. Termination by prescription: An easement can also be {{c7::terminated by prescription}} if the servient landowner interferes with the easement in a way that satisfies the same requirements (continuous, open and notorious, actual, and hostile) for the statutory period.
cards.easyContent: An easement by prescription is acquired through continuous, open and notorious, actual, and hostile use of another's land for the statutory period, similar to adverse possession.
cards.mediumContent: An easement by prescription arises when a user makes continuous, open and notorious, actual, and hostile (non-permissive) use of another's land for the statutory period. The same elements, when satisfied by the servient owner’s interfering use, can extinguish an existing easement by prescription.
cards.hardContent: An easement by prescription is acquired through use of another's land in a manner that is continuous for the applicable statutory period, open and notorious so that the owner knows or should know of the use, actual, and hostile, meaning without the owner's permission. An easement can also be terminated by prescription if the servient landowner interferes with the easement in a way that is continuous, open and notorious, actual, and hostile for the statutory period.
cards.mnemonic: COAH: Continuous, Open and notorious, Actual, Hostile.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::easement by prescription}} requires {{c2::continuous}}, {{c3::open and notorious}}, {{c4::actual}}, and {{c5::hostile}} use for the {{c6::statutory period}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 034. Easement by Implication
cards.backPlain: An easement by implication is an easement the law implies from the circumstances, even though it is not expressly granted. There are two main situations: 1. Implied easement from prior use by a common grantor: When a common grantor uses one part of a tract to benefit another before division, and that use is continuous and apparent, reasonably necessary, and intended to continue, an easement by implication may arise in favor of the benefited parcel after the land is divided. 2. Implied easements without prior use: Even if there was no prior use, an easement may be implied based on (a) subdivision plats (lots sold with reference to a map/plan), or (b) the needs of a holder of a profit à prendre to cross the land as reasonably necessary to extract resources.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an easement by implication, and what are the main categories in which it arises?
cards.cloze: An {{c1::easement by implication}} is an easement the law implies from the circumstances, even though it is not expressly granted. There are two main situations: 1. {{c2::Implied easement from prior use by a common grantor}}: When a common grantor uses one part of a tract to benefit another before division, and that use is continuous and apparent, reasonably necessary, and intended to continue, an easement by implication may arise in favor of the benefited parcel after the land is divided. 2. {{c3::Implied easements without prior use}}: Even if there was no prior use, an easement may be implied based on (a) {{c4::subdivision plats}} (lots sold with reference to a map/plan), or (b) the needs of a holder of a {{c5::profit à prendre}} to cross the land as reasonably necessary to extract resources.
cards.easyContent: An easement by implication is an unwritten easement the law infers from the circumstances, either from a common grantor’s prior, continuous, apparent, reasonably necessary use intended to continue after division, or from situations like subdivision plats or a profit à prendre that imply a right of access.
cards.mediumContent: An easement by implication is an easement not expressly granted but inferred from the circumstances. It most commonly arises from a common grantor’s prior use: before division, one part of a tract is used to benefit another in a way that is continuous and apparent, reasonably necessary, and intended to continue. Separately, easements may also be implied without prior use when lots are sold with reference to a subdivision plat, or when a holder of a profit à prendre needs to cross the land as reasonably necessary to extract resources.
cards.hardContent: An easement by implication is an easement not expressly created but inferred from the parties’ conduct and the circumstances. The classic case is an implied easement from prior use by a common grantor: before division of a single tract, the grantor uses one portion of the land in an easement-like way to benefit another portion; the use is continuous and apparent; it is reasonably necessary for enjoyment of the dominant tenement; and the parties intended the use to continue after the division. In addition, easements can be implied even without prior use where: (1) lots in a subdivision are sold with reference to a subdivision plat or map, which implies easements consistent with the plan (e.g., streets shown on the plat), or (2) the holder of a profit à prendre is impliedly allowed to pass over the land’s surface as reasonably necessary to reach and extract the resources covered by the profit.
cards.mnemonic: PCNI: Prior, Continuous, Necessary, Intended use implies easement.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) elements of easement by implication from prior use; (2) implied easements from subdivision plats; (3) implied easements associated with a profit à prendre.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::easement by implication}} is {{c2::not expressly granted}} but {{c3::inferred from the circumstances}}, often from {{c4::prior continuous, apparent, reasonably necessary use}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 035. Easement by Necessity
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: An easement by necessity can arise if access to or from a property is impossible without the easement, so that the easement's existence becomes strictly necessary. 2. Creation: An easement by necessity usually arises when a landowner sells a portion of her property and the resulting division deprives one lot owner of access to a public road or utility. The owner of the servient estate can choose a reasonable location for the easement. 3. Termination: The easement by necessity expires automatically when the necessity ends, such as when other access becomes available.
cards.frontPrompt: When does an easement by necessity arise, how is it created, who chooses its location, and when does it terminate?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: An {{c1::easement by necessity}} can arise if access to or from a property is {{c2::impossible without the easement}}, so that the easement's existence becomes strictly necessary. 2. Creation: An easement by necessity usually arises when a {{c3::landowner sells a portion of her property}} and the resulting division deprives one lot owner of {{c4::access to a public road or utility}}. The owner of the {{c5::servient estate}} can choose a {{c6::reasonable location}} for the easement. 3. Termination: The easement by necessity {{c7::expires automatically when the necessity ends}}, such as when other access becomes available.
cards.easyContent: An easement by necessity arises when, after a land division, a parcel would otherwise have no access to a public road or utility, and it ends automatically when that necessity ends.
cards.mediumContent: An easement by necessity arises when a landowner conveys part of her land and the division leaves one lot without access to a public road or utility, making an access easement strictly necessary. The servient owner may select a reasonable location for the easement, and the easement terminates automatically once the necessity ceases.
cards.hardContent: An easement by necessity arises when, typically after a conveyance that divides a tract, one of the resulting parcels is landlocked or otherwise lacks access to a public road or utility, making the easement strictly necessary for ingress and egress. The servient estate owner may choose a reasonable location for the easement. The easement terminates automatically when the necessity ends, such as when alternative access becomes available.
cards.mnemonic: NEED ROAD: Necessity Easement Ends when Different Route Opens, Access Done.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::easement by necessity}} arises when a conveyance leaves a parcel {{c2::without access to a public road or utility}}, is {{c3::strictly necessary for access}}, the {{c4::servient owner chooses a reasonable location}}, and it {{c5::terminates automatically when the necessity ceases}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 036. Negative Easements
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A negative easement entitles the holder to prevent the servient landowner from engaging in otherwise permissible actions on his own land. 1.1 Four traditional categories of acts may be prevented: 1.1.1 Light; 1.1.2 Air; 1.1.3 Subjacent or lateral support; and/or 1.1.4 Flow of water from an artificial stream. 2. Creation: A negative easement can only be created by express grant, usually a writing signed by the grantor. 3. Note: Restrictive covenants are utilized more frequently than negative easements to prevent a landowner from engaging in certain activities on their land.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a negative easement, what are the traditional categories it covers, and how is it created?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::negative easement}} entitles the holder to {{c2::prevent the servient landowner from engaging in otherwise permissible actions}} on his own land. 1.1 Four traditional categories of acts may be prevented: 1.1.1 {{c3::Light}}; 1.1.2 {{c4::Air}}; 1.1.3 {{c5::Subjacent or lateral support}}; and/or 1.1.4 {{c6::Flow of water from an artificial stream}}. 2. Creation: A negative easement can only be created by {{c7::express grant}}, usually a {{c8::writing signed by the grantor}}. 3. Note: {{c9::Restrictive covenants}} are utilized more frequently than negative easements to prevent a landowner from engaging in certain activities on their land.
