cards.easyContent: A negative easement allows its holder to stop the servient owner from doing certain otherwise lawful acts relating to light, air, support, or artificial water flow, and must be created by express grant.
cards.mediumContent: A negative easement gives the holder the right to prevent the servient landowner from engaging in otherwise permissible uses of his land, traditionally limited to light, air, subjacent or lateral support, and artificial water flow. It can be created only by an express written grant signed by the grantor, and in practice restrictive covenants are more commonly used to limit land use.
cards.hardContent: A negative easement is a nonpossessory interest that entitles its holder to prevent the servient landowner from engaging in otherwise permissible actions on his own land. At common law, negative easements were limited to four categories: protection of light, air, subjacent or lateral support, and the flow of water from an artificial stream. A negative easement can only be created by express grant, typically in a writing signed by the grantor. Today, restrictive covenants are more frequently used than negative easements to restrict landowners' activities.
cards.mnemonic: Negative easements protect LASW: Light, Air, Support, Water (artificial).
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::negative easement}} lets the holder {{c2::prevent otherwise lawful uses}} of servient land, limited to {{c3::light, air, support, and artificial water flow}} and created {{c4::only by express written grant}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 037. Termination of Easements
cards.backPlain: Easements can be terminated in several recognized ways. The main modes are: (1) estoppel, based on the servient owner's reasonable reliance on the holder's apparent abandonment; (2) end of necessity, for easements by necessity when the underlying need ends; (3) destruction of the servient tenement, unless caused willfully by the servient owner; (4) release by deed from the easement holder to the servient owner; (5) abandonment, requiring physical acts demonstrating an intent to permanently give up the easement, with non-use or mere words insufficient; (6) merger, when one person comes to own both the easement and the servient estate, with no automatic revival upon later re-division; (7) prescription, when the servient owner extinguishes the easement by interfering with it using the elements of adverse possession; and (8) expiration by its terms, when a fixed term ends or a stated condition occurs.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main recognized ways an easement can be terminated?
cards.cloze: Easements can be terminated in several recognized ways. The main modes are: (1) {{c1::estoppel}}; (2) {{c2::end of necessity}}; (3) {{c3::destruction of the servient tenement}}; (4) {{c4::release by deed}}; (5) {{c5::abandonment by physical acts showing permanent intent to give it up}}; (6) {{c6::merger of ownership of the easement and servient estate}}; (7) {{c7::prescription using adverse possession elements}}; and (8) {{c8::expiration by its own terms (fixed term or stated condition)}}.
cards.easyContent: Easements terminate by estoppel, end of necessity, destruction of the servient land, release, abandonment, merger, prescription, or expiration by their own terms.
cards.mediumContent: An easement can end by: (1) estoppel; (2) end of necessity (for easements by necessity); (3) destruction of the servient tenement (unless willful by the servient owner); (4) release by a deed from the easement holder; (5) abandonment by physical acts showing a permanent intent to give it up; (6) merger when one person owns both the easement and the servient estate, with no automatic revival if later split; (7) prescription when the servient owner blocks it using adverse possession elements; and (8) expiration of a fixed term or upon a stated condition in the easement's terms.
cards.hardContent: Easements may be terminated in several ways: (1) estoppel, where the servient owner reasonably relies on the easement holder's conduct or representations suggesting an intent to abandon, with non-use alone insufficient; (2) end of necessity, which automatically ends easements by necessity when the need ceases; (3) destruction of the servient tenement, unless caused willfully by the servient owner; (4) release, when the holder executes a deed of release to the servient owner; (5) abandonment, requiring physical acts demonstrating an intent to permanently give up the easement, with mere words or non-use insufficient; (6) merger, when a single owner acquires title to both the easement and servient estate, and later re-division does not revive the easement; (7) prescription, when the servient owner interferes with the easement using the elements of adverse possession; and (8) expiration, when a fixed term ends or a specified condition occurs under the easement's terms.
cards.mnemonic: Easements end by END ARM PE: Estoppel, Necessity, Destruction, Abandonment, Release, Merger, Prescription, Expiration.
cards.atomizationNotes: Atomized into two children: (1) consent/intent-based modes (estoppel, release, abandonment); (2) structural/automatic modes (necessity ends, destruction, merger, prescription, expiration).
cards.clozeLite: Easements can terminate by {{c1::estoppel}}, {{c2::end of necessity}}, {{c3::destruction of the servient tenement}}, {{c4::release or abandonment}}, {{c5::merger or prescription}}, or {{c6::expiration by their own terms}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 038. Licenses and Profits
cards.backPlain: 1. License: A license is a right to use another person's (the licensor's) land, which is revocable at the licensor's will. 1.1 Examples: Oral permission for a neighbor to use the licensor's pool, theater tickets (grant a license to ticket holders), and the right to use a parking lot. 1.2 Not an interest in land: A license is a privilege, not an interest in land (distinguish from an affirmative easement). 1.3 Revocable: The licensor may revoke the privilege at any time, unless estoppel applies. 1.4 Inalienable: A license may not be assigned or transferred; any attempt to do so revokes the license. 1.5 No Statute of Frauds requirement: A license may be oral or written. A license can result from an easement that is invalid under the Statute of Frauds. 1.5.1 Example: An oral grant of a permanent easement between neighbors may result in a license because the Statute of Frauds is not satisfied. 2. Profit: A profit is a non-possessory property interest that entitles its holder to enter a servient estate to remove resources. 2.1 Examples: Minerals, timber, soil, fish. 2.2 Rules: All rules governing easements apply to profits, including rules on creation, transferability, and termination. 2.3 Extinguishment: A profit may be extinguished through misuse or overuse of resources on the servient estate.
cards.frontPrompt: In real property, what is a license, what is a profit, and how do they differ in nature and rules?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::License}}: A license is a {{c2::right to use another person's (the licensor's) land, which is revocable at the licensor's will}}. 1.1 Examples: Oral permission for a neighbor to use the licensor's pool, {{c3::theater tickets}} (grant a license to ticket holders), and the right to use a parking lot. 1.2 Not an interest in land: A license is a {{c4::privilege, not an interest in land}} (distinguish from an {{c5::affirmative easement}}). 1.3 Revocable: The licensor may revoke the privilege at any time, unless {{c6::estoppel}} applies. 1.4 Inalienable: A license may not be {{c7::assigned or transferred}}; any attempt to do so revokes the license. 1.5 No {{c8::Statute of Frauds}} requirement: A license may be oral or written. A license can result from an easement that is invalid under the Statute of Frauds. 1.5.1 Example: An oral grant of a {{c9::permanent easement}} between neighbors may result in a license because the Statute of Frauds is not satisfied. 2. {{c10::Profit}}: A profit is a {{c11::non-possessory property interest}} that entitles its holder to {{c12::enter a servient estate to remove resources}}. 2.1 Examples: {{c13::Minerals, timber, soil, fish}}. 2.2 Rules: All rules governing {{c14::easements}} apply to profits, including rules on {{c15::creation, transferability, and termination}}. 2.3 Extinguishment: A profit may be extinguished through {{c16::misuse or overuse}} of resources on the servient estate.
cards.easyContent: A license is a revocable privilege to use another’s land that is not an interest in land, while a profit is a non-possessory interest allowing entry onto land to remove resources, governed by easement rules.
cards.mediumContent: A license is a revocable, inalienable privilege to use another’s land, not an interest in land and not subject to the Statute of Frauds. It may arise when an attempted easement fails the Statute of Frauds. A profit is a non-possessory interest to enter a servient estate to remove resources (like minerals or timber), is governed by easement rules on creation, transfer, and termination, and can be extinguished by misuse or overuse.
cards.hardContent: A license is a right to use another person's land, revocable at the licensor's will. It is a mere privilege, not an interest in land, and is therefore inalienable—any attempt to assign or transfer it revokes the license. No Statute of Frauds requirement applies, so a license may be oral or written, and may result when an attempted easement fails the Statute of Frauds (e.g., an oral grant of a permanent easement). Typical licenses include oral permission to use a pool, theater tickets, or parking rights. A profit, by contrast, is a non-possessory property interest allowing its holder to enter a servient estate to remove resources such as minerals, timber, soil, or fish. All rules that govern easements apply to profits, including rules on creation, transferability, and termination, and a profit may be extinguished by misuse or overuse of the servient estate's resources.
cards.mnemonic: LP: License = Permission; Profit = Permission plus Product.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::license}} is a {{c2::revocable, inalienable privilege}} to use land, not an {{c3::interest in land}}. A {{c4::profit}} is a {{c5::non-possessory interest}} to enter and remove resources, governed by {{c6::easement rules}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 039. Covenants
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A covenant is a promise to do or refrain from doing something related to land; it is a contractual limitation or promise regarding land. 1.1 Note: Covenants are not property interests. 2. Real covenant: A real covenant is a covenant concerning real property. 2.1 Runs with the land at law: Subsequent owners may be burdened by the covenant or may enforce it. 2.2 Different requirements apply for burdens and benefits running with the land. 2.3 Affirmative covenant: A promise to do something related to land. 2.4 Restrictive covenant: A promise to refrain from doing something related to land. 3. Termination (a covenant can terminate by): 3.1 Written release. 3.2 Merger of the benefited and burdened estates. 3.3 Condemnation of the burdened property. 4. Covenants vs. equitable servitudes (difference is the remedy): 4.1 Covenant: Money damages. 4.2 Equitable servitude: Injunction.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a real covenant in real property law, how is it classified, how can it terminate, and how does it differ from an equitable servitude?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::covenant}} is a {{c2::promise to do or refrain from doing something related to land}}; it is a {{c3::contractual limitation or promise}} regarding land. 1.1 Note: Covenants are {{c4::not property interests}}. 2. {{c5::Real covenant}}: A real covenant is a covenant concerning real property. 2.1 {{c6::Runs with the land at law}}: Subsequent owners may be {{c7::burdened by the covenant or may enforce it}}. 2.2 Different requirements apply for {{c8::burdens and benefits running with the land}}. 2.3 {{c9::Affirmative covenant}}: A promise to {{c10::do something related to land}}. 2.4 {{c11::Restrictive covenant}}: A promise to {{c12::refrain from doing something related to land}}. 3. Termination (a covenant can terminate by): 3.1 {{c13::Written release}}. 3.2 {{c14::Merger}} of the benefited and burdened estates. 3.3 {{c15::Condemnation}} of the burdened property. 4. Covenants vs. {{c16::equitable servitudes}} (difference is the {{c17::remedy}}): 4.1 Covenant: {{c18::Money damages}}. 4.2 Equitable servitude: {{c19::Injunction}}.
cards.easyContent: A covenant is a contractual promise about land use that can bind or benefit successors as a real covenant, with money damages as the remedy, while equitable servitudes use injunctions instead.
cards.mediumContent: A covenant is a contractual promise to do or not do something related to land and is not itself a property interest. A real covenant concerns real property and can run with the land so that subsequent owners may be burdened or may enforce it. Covenants can be affirmative (promising to do something) or restrictive (promising not to do something). They may terminate by written release, merger of benefited and burdened estates, or condemnation of the burdened property. The key distinction from an equitable servitude is the remedy: covenants are enforced by money damages, equitable servitudes by injunction.
cards.hardContent: A covenant is a contractual promise concerning land use—a promise to do or refrain from doing something related to land—and is a contractual limitation rather than a property interest. A real covenant is a covenant concerning real property that may "run with the land" at law so that subsequent owners may be burdened by it or may enforce it. Different requirements govern whether the burden or the benefit runs. Real covenants are classified as either affirmative (a promise to do something related to land) or restrictive (a promise to refrain from doing something related to land). Real covenants may terminate by written release, by merger of the benefited and burdened estates in one owner, or by condemnation of the burdened property. The main doctrinal distinction between covenants and equitable servitudes is the remedy: covenants are enforced by money damages, while equitable servitudes are enforced by injunction.
cards.mnemonic: Covenant = Contract cash; Servitude = Stop/Start by injunction.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::real covenant}} is a {{c2::contractual promise about land use}} that {{c3::runs with the land}} and is enforced by {{c4::money damages, not injunction}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Requirements for Burdens of Covenants to Run with Land
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 040. Requirements for Burdens of Covenants to Run with Land
cards.front: Requirements for Burdens of Covenants to Run with Land
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A successor in interest to the burdened estate will be bound by a covenant if the following requirements are satisfied. 1.1 Writing: The original covenant was in writing. 1.2 Intent: The original parties intended to bind successors in interest; look to the language of the covenant. Courts are liberal in construing the requisite intent. 1.3 Touches and concerns the land: The covenant must affect the parties' legal relations as landowners (a very low standard). Homeowner association fees satisfy this requirement. 1.4 Horizontal and vertical privity: Both must exist between the interested parties. 1.4.1 Horizontal privity: The relationship between the original covenanting parties (for example, grantor/grantee, landlord/tenant, fee ownership/easement right in the same land, mortgagor/mortgagee). 1.4.2 Vertical privity: The relationship between the covenanting parties and their successors in interest (for example, contract, devise, or descent). 1.5 Notice: The successor in interest had notice of the covenant when she took her interest.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for the burden of a real covenant to run with the land and bind a successor to the burdened estate?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::successor in interest to the burdened estate}} will be bound by a covenant if the following requirements are satisfied. 1.1 {{c2::Writing}}: The original covenant was in writing. 1.2 {{c3::Intent}}: The original parties intended to bind successors in interest; look to the language of the covenant. Courts are liberal in construing the requisite intent. 1.3 {{c4::Touches and concerns the land}}: The covenant must affect the parties' {{c5::legal relations as landowners}} (a very low standard). {{c6::Homeowner association fees}} satisfy this requirement. 1.4 {{c7::Horizontal and vertical privity}}: Both must exist between the interested parties. 1.4.1 {{c8::Horizontal privity}}: The relationship between the original covenanting parties (for example, {{c9::grantor/grantee, landlord/tenant, fee ownership/easement right in the same land, mortgagor/mortgagee}}). 1.4.2 {{c10::Vertical privity}}: The relationship between the covenanting parties and their successors in interest (for example, {{c11::contract, devise, or descent}}). 1.5 {{c12::Notice}}: The successor in interest had notice of the covenant when she took her interest.
cards.easyContent: For the burden of a real covenant to run with the land, there must be a written covenant, intent to bind successors, the covenant must touch and concern the land, horizontal and vertical privity, and the successor must have notice.
cards.mediumContent: A successor to the burdened estate is bound by a covenant only if: (1) the original covenant was in writing; (2) the original parties intended the burden to bind successors, as shown by the covenant’s language (liberally construed); (3) the covenant touches and concerns the land by affecting the parties’ legal relations as landowners (e.g., HOA fees); (4) both horizontal privity between the original covenanting parties (such as grantor/grantee, landlord/tenant, fee owner/easement holder, or mortgagor/mortgagee) and vertical privity between those parties and their successors (via contract, devise, or descent); and (5) the successor had notice of the covenant when taking her interest.
cards.hardContent: The burden of a real covenant will run with the land and bind a successor to the burdened estate only if several elements are met. First, writing: the original covenant must be in writing. Second, intent: the original covenanting parties must have intended that the burden bind their successors in interest, which is determined from the language of the covenant and is liberally construed. Third, the covenant must touch and concern the land—i.e., it must affect the parties’ legal relations as landowners; this is a low threshold, and obligations such as homeowner association fees satisfy it. Fourth, there must be both horizontal and vertical privity: horizontal privity exists between the original covenanting parties (e.g., grantor and grantee, landlord and tenant, a fee owner and an easement holder in the same land, or mortgagor and mortgagee), while vertical privity exists between each covenanting party and her successor in interest via contract, devise, or descent. Finally, the successor in interest must have notice of the covenant at the time she acquires her interest.
cards.mnemonic: Burden runs with land if "WIT HN": Writing, Intent, Touch and concern, Horizontal privity, Notice (plus vertical privity).
cards.clozeLite: Burden runs if {{c1::writing}}, {{c2::intent to bind successors}}, {{c3::touch and concern}}, {{c4::horizontal and vertical privity}}, and {{c5::successor has notice}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Requirements for Benefits of Covenants to Run with the Land
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 041. Requirements for Benefits of Covenants to Run with the Land
cards.front: Requirements for Benefits of Covenants to Run with the Land
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A successor in interest to the benefiting estate may enforce the covenant if the following requirements are satisfied. 2. Requirements: 2.1 Writing: The original covenant was in writing. 2.2 Intent: The original parties intended the benefit to run with the land; look to the language of the covenant. Courts are liberal in construing the requisite intent. 2.3 Touches and concerns the land: The covenant must affect the parties' legal relations as landowners (a very low standard). 2.4 Vertical privity: Successors in interest are in vertical privity with the original covenanting parties (for example, through contract, devise, or descent). Vertical privity can be relaxed (not full) for the burden to run. Horizontal privity is not required in a majority of states.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for the benefit of a real covenant to run with the land so that a successor to the benefiting estate can enforce it?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::successor in interest to the benefiting estate}} may enforce the covenant if the following requirements are satisfied. 2. Requirements: 2.1 {{c2::Writing}}: The original covenant was in writing. 2.2 {{c3::Intent}}: The original parties intended the {{c4::benefit}} to run with the land; look to the language of the covenant. Courts are liberal in construing the requisite intent. 2.3 {{c5::Touches and concerns the land}}: The covenant must affect the parties' {{c6::legal relations as landowners}} (a very low standard). 2.4 {{c7::Vertical privity}}: Successors in interest are in vertical privity with the original covenanting parties (for example, through {{c8::contract, devise, or descent}}). Vertical privity can be {{c9::relaxed}} (not full) for the burden to run. {{c10::Horizontal privity is not required}} in a majority of states.
cards.easyContent: For the benefit of a real covenant to run with the land, there must be a written covenant, intent for the benefit to run, the covenant must touch and concern the land, and there must be vertical privity, but usually no horizontal privity is required.
cards.mediumContent: A successor to the benefiting estate can enforce a real covenant if: (1) the original covenant is in writing; (2) the original parties intended the benefit to run with the land, as shown in the covenant language (liberally construed); (3) the covenant touches and concerns the land by affecting the parties’ legal relations as landowners; and (4) there is vertical privity between the original covenanting party and the successor via contract, devise, or descent. Vertical privity may be relaxed for some burdens, and horizontal privity is generally not required for the benefit to run in most states.
cards.hardContent: The benefit of a real covenant runs with the land so that a successor in interest to the benefiting estate may enforce it when several conditions are met. First, there must be a writing: the original covenant must be set forth in a written instrument. Second, intent: the original parties must have intended that the benefit of the covenant run with the land, which is inferred from the language of the covenant and is liberally construed. Third, the covenant must touch and concern the land by affecting the parties’ legal relations as landowners, a low standard. Fourth, there must be vertical privity between the original covenanting party and the successor in interest—typically established by transfer through contract, devise, or descent. Vertical privity rules for the benefit are generally more relaxed than for the burden, and, in a majority of states, horizontal privity between the original parties is not required for the benefit to run.
cards.mnemonic: Benefit needs only WIT V: Writing, Intent, Touch & concern, Vertical privity.
cards.clozeLite: Benefit of a real covenant runs if there is {{c1::a writing}}, {{c2::intent for the benefit to run}}, {{c3::touch and concern}}, and {{c4::vertical privity}} ({{c5::no horizontal privity usually required}}).

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 042. Equitable Servitudes
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: 1.1 Equitable servitudes are covenants enforced in equity against successors through injunctive relief (i.e., an injunction is the remedy). 1.2 An equitable servitude is a covenant that will be enforced against successors of the burdened land who have notice of the covenant. 1.3 Privity is not required to bind successors. 2. Creation (requirements): 2.1 Writing: There must generally be a written promise. 2.1.1 Exception: Reciprocal negative servitudes may be implied from a common scheme for development of a residential subdivision. 2.2 Intent: The original parties must intend to bind successors. 2.3 Touches and concerns the land: The servitude must affect the parties' legal relations as landowners. 2.4 Notice: Successors of the burdened land must have notice; notice is not required for the benefit to run. 2.5 Defenses to enforcement: A court will not enforce an equitable servitude if any of the following conditions exist: 2.5.1 Pervasive changes in the neighborhood. 2.5.2 Estoppel. 2.5.3 Acquiescence. 2.5.4 Unclean hands. 2.5.5 Laches.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an equitable servitude, how is it created and enforced, and what defenses can prevent its enforcement?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 {{c1::Equitable servitudes}} are {{c2::covenants enforced in equity against successors}} through {{c3::injunctive relief}} (i.e., an injunction is the remedy). 1.2 An equitable servitude is a covenant that will be enforced against {{c4::successors of the burdened land}} who have {{c5::notice}} of the covenant. 1.3 {{c6::Privity is not required}} to bind successors. 2. Creation (requirements): 2.1 {{c7::Writing}}: There must generally be a written promise. 2.1.1 Exception: {{c8::Reciprocal negative servitudes}} may be {{c9::implied from a common scheme for development}} of a residential subdivision. 2.2 {{c10::Intent}}: The original parties must intend to bind successors. 2.3 {{c11::Touches and concerns the land}}: The servitude must affect the parties' legal relations as landowners. 2.4 {{c12::Notice}}: Successors of the burdened land must have notice; notice is {{c13::not required for the benefit to run}}. 2.5 Defenses to enforcement: A court will not enforce an equitable servitude if any of the following conditions exist: 2.5.1 {{c14::Pervasive changes in the neighborhood}}. 2.5.2 {{c15::Estoppel}}. 2.5.3 {{c16::Acquiescence}}. 2.5.4 {{c17::Unclean hands}}. 2.5.5 {{c18::Laches}}.
cards.easyContent: An equitable servitude is a covenant about land use enforced in equity by injunction against successors with notice, without requiring privity, and is created mainly by a written promise that touches and concerns the land, subject to defenses like changed conditions and unclean hands.
cards.mediumContent: Equitable servitudes are covenants enforced in equity against successors through injunctive relief, so successors of the burdened land with notice can be bound even without privity. They are usually created by a written promise where the original parties intended to bind successors, the promise touches and concerns the land, and successors of the burdened land have notice; under a common scheme for a residential subdivision, reciprocal negative servitudes may be implied instead of written. Defenses to enforcement include pervasive changes in the neighborhood, estoppel, acquiescence, unclean hands, and laches.
cards.hardContent: An equitable servitude is a covenant concerning land use that is enforced in equity rather than at law. It binds successors of the burdened land who have notice of the servitude and is enforced through injunctive relief. Unlike real covenants, privity of estate is not required to bind successors. Equitable servitudes are generally created by a written promise in which the original parties intend the restriction to bind successors, the restriction touches and concerns the land by affecting the parties’ legal relations as landowners, and successors to the burdened estate take with notice. Under the doctrine of reciprocal negative servitudes, a court may imply an equitable servitude from a common scheme of development in a residential subdivision even without a specific writing for each lot. A court may decline to enforce an equitable servitude where defenses apply, including pervasive changes in the neighborhood undermining the original purpose, estoppel (where the benefited party induced reliance), acquiescence in violations, unclean hands by the party seeking enforcement, or laches due to unreasonable delay causing prejudice.
cards.mnemonic: Equitable servitude = WITN + E-CLUA (Writing/common scheme, Intent, Touch, Notice + defenses).
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::equitable servitude}} is a {{c2::covenant enforced in equity by injunction}} that {{c3::binds successors with notice without privity}} if it {{c4::touches and concerns the land}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 043. Reciprocal Negative Servitudes
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: If land is subdivided into parcels under a common development scheme, and only some parcels have negative servitudes, these restrictions may be impliedly binding against all subdivided parcels. 1.1 Purpose: Allows lot owners to enforce restrictions on the use of property against other subdivision lot owners, typically through injunction. 1.2 Exam note: This usually arises where an owner divides land into smaller lots to create a common development scheme or subdivision. The reciprocal negative servitude is created by implication if the following are met. 2. Requirements for creation by implication: 2.1 Common scheme: The developer evidenced an intent to create a negative servitude under a common scheme for all subdivided parcels. 2.1.1 A common scheme may be evidenced by a recorded plat, a general pattern of restrictions, and/or oral representations to early buyers. 2.2 Notice: The owner of the subject lot had notice of the restriction in the deeds of other subdivision lots. 2.2.1 Notice may be one of three types: 2.2.1.1 Actual notice: literal knowledge of the restriction. 2.2.1.2 Inquiry notice: the neighborhood’s character indicates a common restriction. 2.2.1.3 Record notice: the chain of title for the owner’s lot includes a prior deed containing a negative covenant or servitude.
cards.frontPrompt: When will reciprocal negative servitudes be implied in a subdivision, and what are the requirements for creation by implication?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: If land is subdivided into parcels under a {{c1::common development scheme}}, and only some parcels have {{c2::negative servitudes}}, these restrictions may be impliedly binding against all subdivided parcels. 1.1 Purpose: Allows lot owners to {{c3::enforce restrictions on the use of property against other subdivision lot owners}}, typically through {{c4::injunction}}. 1.2 Exam note: This usually arises where an owner divides land into smaller lots to create a {{c5::common development scheme or subdivision}}. The reciprocal negative servitude is created by {{c6::implication}} if the following are met. 2. Requirements for creation by implication: 2.1 {{c7::Common scheme}}: The developer evidenced an intent to create a negative servitude under a common scheme for all subdivided parcels. 2.1.1 A common scheme may be evidenced by a {{c8::recorded plat}}, a {{c9::general pattern of restrictions}}, and/or {{c10::oral representations to early buyers}}. 2.2 {{c11::Notice}}: The owner of the subject lot had notice of the restriction in the deeds of other subdivision lots. 2.2.1 Notice may be one of three types: 2.2.1.1 {{c12::Actual notice}}: literal knowledge of the restriction. 2.2.1.2 {{c13::Inquiry notice}}: the neighborhood’s character indicates a common restriction. 2.2.1.3 {{c14::Record notice}}: the chain of title for the owner’s lot includes a prior deed containing a negative covenant or servitude.
cards.easyContent: Reciprocal negative servitudes allow courts to imply subdivision-wide restrictions where a developer created a common development scheme and other lot owners had notice of similar restrictions in the subdivision.
cards.mediumContent: Reciprocal negative servitudes arise by implication when land is subdivided under a common development scheme and only some lots are expressly restricted, but the developer intended a common scheme and the subject owner had notice. A common scheme can be shown by a recorded plat, a general pattern of restrictions, or oral representations to early buyers. Notice may be actual, inquiry (from the neighborhood’s character), or record (from the chain of title).
cards.hardContent: If land is subdivided into parcels under a common development scheme and only some parcels bear express negative servitudes, these restrictions may be impliedly binding on all lots as reciprocal negative servitudes. The doctrine’s purpose is to allow subdivision lot owners to enforce use restrictions against each other, usually by injunction. Creation by implication requires: (1) a common scheme—developer evidence of intent to impose a negative servitude on all subdivided parcels, which may be shown by a recorded plat, a general pattern of restrictions, or oral representations to early buyers; and (2) notice—the subject lot owner had actual, inquiry, or record notice of the restriction in other subdivision deeds, including where the neighborhood’s character or the chain of title reveals the common restriction.
cards.mnemonic: CSR: Common Scheme and Notice, Reciprocal enforcement.
cards.clozeLite: Reciprocal negative servitudes arise when a {{c1::common development scheme}} exists and the owner had {{c2::actual, inquiry, or record notice}} of similar restrictions.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 044. Adverse Possession
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A trespasser may acquire title to another’s property without compensation by possessing the property for a specified period, in a manner conflicting with the true owner’s rights. 2. Requirements: The trespasser’s possession of the land must be: 2.1 Continuous for the statutory period: Possession must be similar to an ordinary owner’s use of the property. Daily possession is not required if an ordinary user would not use the property daily (for example, a winter cabin). 2.2 Open and notorious: The trespasser’s possession must be conspicuous such that the true owner would know of the trespass if he inspected his property regularly. The owner need not actually know of the trespasser’s use. 2.3 Actual and exclusive: The trespasser must possess a reasonable portion of the property to the exclusion of the owner and the public. 2.4 Hostile: Possession must be without the owner’s permission. There is no knowledge or intent requirement (the trespasser need not intend to adversely possess). 2.4.1 Leasehold: If a tenant stays in possession after a lease has expired, he is presumed to have permission (a tenancy at sufferance), rather than beginning a period of adverse possession.
cards.frontPrompt: What is adverse possession, and what are the required elements a trespasser must satisfy to acquire title?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::trespasser}} may acquire title to another’s property without compensation by possessing the property for a specified period, in a manner conflicting with the true owner’s rights. 2. Requirements: The trespasser’s possession of the land must be: 2.1 {{c2::Continuous for the statutory period}}: Possession must be similar to an ordinary owner’s use of the property. Daily possession is not required if an ordinary user would not use the property daily (for example, a winter cabin). 2.2 {{c3::Open and notorious}}: The trespasser’s possession must be conspicuous such that the true owner would know of the trespass if he inspected his property regularly. The owner need not actually know of the trespasser’s use. 2.3 {{c4::Actual and exclusive}}: The trespasser must possess a reasonable portion of the property to the exclusion of the owner and the public. 2.4 {{c5::Hostile}}: Possession must be without the owner’s permission. There is no knowledge or intent requirement (the trespasser need not intend to adversely possess). 2.4.1 {{c6::Leasehold}}: If a tenant stays in possession after a lease has expired, he is presumed to have permission (a {{c7::tenancy at sufferance}}), rather than beginning a period of adverse possession.
cards.easyContent: Adverse possession allows a trespasser to gain title if they possess land for the statutory period in a way that is continuous, open and notorious, actual and exclusive, and hostile to the true owner.
cards.mediumContent: Adverse possession is a method by which a trespasser can acquire title to another’s land without paying, by possessing it in a manner that conflicts with the true owner’s rights for the statutory period. The possession must be (1) continuous for the statutory period, similar to ordinary use; (2) open and notorious, so a reasonably diligent owner would discover it; (3) actual and exclusive, occupying a reasonable portion of the land to the exclusion of the owner and public; and (4) hostile, i.e., without permission, with no requirement that the trespasser intend to take title. A holdover tenant is presumed permissive and is a tenant at sufferance, not an adverse possessor.
cards.hardContent: Adverse possession permits a trespasser to obtain title to another’s property without compensation by possessing it for the statutory period in a way that conflicts with the true owner’s rights. The possession must satisfy four requirements: (1) continuous for the statutory period—use similar to that of an ordinary owner, not necessarily daily (e.g., a winter cabin need not be occupied year-round); (2) open and notorious—conspicuous enough that a regularly inspecting true owner would discover the use, even if the owner has no actual knowledge; (3) actual and exclusive—the trespasser actually possesses a reasonable portion of the property and excludes the true owner and the public; and (4) hostile—without the owner’s permission, with no requirement of bad faith or an intent to take title. A tenant who simply holds over after lease expiration is presumed to have permission and is a tenant at sufferance, which does not start the adverse possession clock.
cards.mnemonic: Think "COAH": Continuous, Open, Actual, Hostile possession.
cards.clozeLite: Adverse possession lets a {{c1::trespasser}} gain title by {{c2::continuous}}, {{c3::open and notorious}}, {{c4::actual and exclusive}}, and {{c5::hostile}} possession for the {{c6::statutory period}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 045. Miscellaneous Adverse Possession Rules
cards.backPlain: Several miscellaneous rules qualify adverse possession: 1. Statute of limitations and future interests: - The statute of limitations does not begin to run if the true owner was under a legal disability when adverse possession began. - The statute does not run against future interest holders until their interest becomes possessory. 2. Restrictive covenants: - Whether a covenant runs after adverse possession depends on whether the possessor’s use complied with or violated the covenant. 3. Color of title: - A defective written claim to title can allow an adverse possessor who occupies part of the tract to gain title to the entire tract described. 4. Government land: - Government-owned land is generally immune from adverse possession. 5. Leasing and marketable title: - An adverse possessor may lease the land and still be deemed in possession, but title obtained by adverse possession is not marketable until quieted.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main miscellaneous rules that modify or qualify adverse possession (e.g., SoL/disability, future interests, restrictive covenants, color of title, government land, and leasing/marketable title)?
cards.cloze: Miscellaneous rules affecting adverse possession include: (1) {{c1::statute of limitations and disability}} (SoL does not begin if the true owner was under a legal disability when possession began); (2) {{c2::future interests}} (SoL does not run against future interest holders until their interest becomes possessory); (3) {{c3::restrictive covenants}} (whether the covenant runs depends on whether the adverse possessor’s use complied with or violated it); (4) {{c4::color of title}} (adverse possession of part under a defective claim can give title to the entire described tract); (5) {{c5::government land}} (generally immune from adverse possession); and (6) {{c6::leasing and marketable title}} (the adverse possessor may lease the land, but title is not marketable until quieted).
cards.easyContent: Miscellaneous rules affect adverse possession: tolling for disability and future interests, limits on government land, how restrictive covenants and color of title operate, and how leasing and marketability work for an adverse possessor’s title.
cards.mediumContent: Miscellaneous adverse possession rules: (1) the statute of limitations does not start if the owner was under a legal disability when possession began; (2) it does not run against future interest holders until their interest becomes possessory; (3) a restrictive covenant will run only if the adverse possessor’s use complied with it; (4) color of title lets one who actually occupies part of a described parcel acquire title to the entire tract; (5) government land generally cannot be adversely possessed; and (6) adverse possessors may lease the land and still be in possession, but their title is not marketable until quieted.
cards.hardContent: Several miscellaneous rules qualify adverse possession: (1) Statute of limitations and disability: the limitations period does not begin to run if the true owner was under a legal disability (e.g., minority, incompetence) when the adverse possession began. (2) Future interests: limitations do not run against future interest holders (e.g., remaindermen) until their interest becomes possessory. (3) Restrictive covenants: whether a restrictive covenant runs with land acquired by adverse possession depends on the possessor’s use—if they violated the covenant, it will not run; if they complied, it will. (4) Color of title: a defective written claim of title (color of title) can expand the scope of adverse possession so that actual possession of part of the land described is sufficient to acquire title to the entire parcel described. (5) Government land: government-owned property is generally immune from acquisition by adverse possession. (6) Leasing and marketable title: an adverse possessor may lease all or part of the property to a third party and still be considered in possession, but title obtained through adverse possession is not marketable until confirmed in an action to quiet title.
cards.mnemonic: "DR FCG L": Disability, Remainders, Covenants, Government, Color, Leasing.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into five children: (1) SoL/disability/future interests; (2) restrictive covenants; (3) color of title; (4) government land; (5) leasing by adverse possessor and marketable title.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 046. Adverse Possession
cards.backPlain: Tacking and Concurrent Owners: 1. Tacking: Adverse possessors can tack together successive periods of adverse possession to satisfy the statutory period, even if successive possession was by different adverse possessors. 1.1 Must be successive: There cannot be gaps between periods of adverse possession. 1.2 Privity: Tacking requires privity between successive adverse holders, satisfied if the subsequent possessor takes by descent, devise, or by deed purporting to convey title. Tacking is not permitted if one adverse claimant ousts the preceding claimant. 2. Concurrent owners: Co-tenants may not adversely possess each other’s interests unless ouster has occurred. To adversely possess a co-tenant’s interest, the co-tenant must be excluded from the land for the statutory period, and the statutory period begins once exclusion (ouster) begins.
cards.frontPrompt: How does tacking work in adverse possession, and under what conditions can one co-tenant adversely possess another co-tenant’s interest?
cards.cloze: Tacking and Concurrent Owners: 1. {{c1::Tacking}}: Adverse possessors can tack together successive periods of adverse possession to satisfy the statutory period, even if successive possession was by different adverse possessors. 1.1 Must be {{c2::successive}}: There cannot be gaps between periods of adverse possession. 1.2 {{c3::Privity}}: Tacking requires privity between successive adverse holders, satisfied if the subsequent possessor takes by {{c4::descent}}, {{c5::devise}}, or by {{c6::deed purporting to convey title}}. Tacking is not permitted if one adverse claimant {{c7::ousts}} the preceding claimant. 2. {{c8::Concurrent owners}}: Co-tenants may not adversely possess each other’s interests unless {{c9::ouster}} has occurred. To adversely possess a co-tenant’s interest, the co-tenant must be excluded from the land for the statutory period, and the statutory period begins once exclusion (ouster) begins.
cards.easyContent: Tacking lets successive adverse possessors add their periods together if their possession is continuous and in privity, while co-tenants can only adversely possess another’s share if they clearly oust the other and exclude them for the statutory period.
cards.mediumContent: In adverse possession, tacking allows successive adverse possessors to combine their periods of possession to meet the statutory period, but only if the possession is continuous (no gaps) and there is privity—typically where the later possessor takes by descent, devise, or deed purporting to convey title. Tacking is not allowed where one adverse possessor simply ousts another. For concurrent owners, a co-tenant generally cannot adversely possess another co-tenant’s interest unless there is an ouster—clear exclusion of the other co-tenant from possession for the full statutory period, with the clock starting at ouster.
cards.hardContent: Tacking in adverse possession allows different adverse possessors to combine their respective periods of possession to reach the statutory limitations period. Tacking is permitted only when possession is truly successive—without gaps—and when there is privity between the successive adverse holders, usually because the later possessor takes the property by descent, devise, or under a deed that purports to convey title. If one adverse claimant merely ousts another, without such privity, tacking is not allowed. As to concurrent owners, co-tenants do not normally adversely possess each other’s interests because each has a right to possess the whole. Adverse possession of a co-tenant’s share requires an ouster: the adversely possessing co-tenant must clearly exclude the other co-tenant from the land, and maintain that exclusion for the statutory period, with the limitations period beginning when ouster occurs.
cards.mnemonic: Tacking needs CP: Continuous + Privity; co-tenant AP needs Ouster.
cards.clozeLite: Tacking lets {{c1::successive adverse possessors}} {{c2::combine their periods}} if possession is {{c3::continuous and in privity}}; a {{c4::co-tenant}} must {{c5::oust and exclude}} the other for the {{c6::statutory period}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 047. Land Sale Contracts and Conveyancing
cards.backPlain: 1. Land sale contracts (subject to the Statute of Frauds) must be: 1.1 In writing. 1.2 Signed by the party to be bound. 1.3 Sufficiently definite to articulate essential terms (for example, identify grantor and grantee, intent to convey, consideration to be paid, and a description of the land). 2. Exception: Partial performance. 2.1 A land sale contract outside the Statute of Frauds is enforceable against the seller if the buyer does any two of the following: 2.1.1 Pays all or part of the purchase price. 2.1.2 Takes possession. 2.1.3 Makes substantial improvements. 3. Land sale process: 3.1 Contract: Agreement to buy and sell land. 3.2 Escrow period: Transfer of funds through escrow. 3.3 Closing: Completion of escrow and delivery of the deed. 3.4 Conveyance: Successful deed transfer, upon which property is conveyed to the new owner.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the Statute of Frauds requirements for a land sale contract, what is the partial performance exception, and what are the basic stages of the land sale process?
cards.cloze: 1. Land sale contracts (subject to the {{c1::Statute of Frauds}}) must be: 1.1 {{c2::In writing}}. 1.2 {{c3::Signed}} by the party to be bound. 1.3 Sufficiently definite to articulate {{c4::essential terms}} (for example, identify grantor and grantee, intent to convey, consideration to be paid, and a description of the land). 2. Exception: {{c5::Partial performance}}. 2.1 A land sale contract outside the Statute of Frauds is enforceable against the seller if the buyer does any {{c6::two}} of the following: 2.1.1 Pays all or part of the {{c7::purchase price}}. 2.1.2 Takes {{c8::possession}}. 2.1.3 Makes {{c9::substantial improvements}}. 3. Land sale process: 3.1 {{c10::Contract}}: Agreement to buy and sell land. 3.2 {{c11::Escrow period}}: Transfer of funds through escrow. 3.3 {{c12::Closing}}: Completion of escrow and delivery of the deed. 3.4 {{c13::Conveyance}}: Successful deed transfer, upon which property is conveyed to the new owner.
cards.easyContent: Land sale contracts must satisfy the Statute of Frauds—being in writing, signed, and stating essential terms—but may be enforced without a writing if the buyer partially performs by at least two acts like paying, taking possession, or improving the land; the overall process runs from contract to escrow, closing, and final conveyance by deed.
cards.mediumContent: A valid land sale contract must comply with the Statute of Frauds: it must be in writing, signed by the party to be bound, and contain essential terms such as the parties, intent to convey, price or consideration, and a description of the property. The partial performance doctrine allows enforcement of an oral land sale contract against the seller if the buyer does any two of the following: pays all or part of the purchase price, takes possession, or makes substantial improvements. The basic land sale process proceeds through (1) contract, (2) an escrow period in which funds and documents are held and exchanged, (3) closing with escrow completion and deed delivery, and (4) conveyance, where legal title passes to the buyer by deed.
cards.hardContent: Land sale contracts are subject to the Statute of Frauds and must be in writing, signed by the party to be bound, and sufficiently definite to set out all essential terms, including identification of the grantor and grantee, intent to convey, the consideration to be paid, and a reasonably certain description of the land. An exception exists for partial performance: an otherwise unenforceable oral land sale contract is enforceable in equity, typically against the seller, if the buyer performs any two of the following acts—pays all or part of the purchase price, takes possession of the property, or makes substantial improvements to it. The overall land sale process moves from (1) the contract stage, where the parties agree to buy and sell; to (2) the escrow period, during which funds and documents are held and conditions satisfied; to (3) closing, when escrow is completed and the deed is delivered; and finally to (4) conveyance, when a valid deed transfers legal title to the new owner.
cards.mnemonic: SOF needs WET: Writing, Essential terms, signature; partial performance needs PPI.
cards.clozeLite: A land sale contract must {{c1::satisfy the Statute of Frauds}} and the {{c2::partial performance doctrine}} allows enforcement if the buyer does {{c3::any two of payment, possession, or improvements}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Equitable Conversion and Risk of Loss
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 048. Equitable Conversion and Risk of Loss
cards.front: Equitable Conversion and Risk of Loss – Overview
cards.backPlain: Equitable conversion in land sale contracts recharacterizes the parties’ interests between contract and closing. Once a valid land sale contract is executed, the buyer is treated in equity as the owner of the real property, and the seller as owning a personal property right to the sale proceeds while holding legal title in trust for the buyer. This affects (1) who is protected from the seller’s pre-contract creditors, (2) who bears the risk of loss if the property is destroyed before closing (usually the buyer, absent a contrary agreement), and (3) how each party’s interest passes if either dies before closing (seller’s interest as personalty; buyer’s interest as realty).
cards.frontPrompt: In a land sale contract, what is equitable conversion and what are its main consequences for risk of loss and the parties’ interests (including on death before closing)?
cards.cloze: In a land sale contract, {{c1::equitable conversion}} treats the {{c2::buyer}} as the owner of the {{c3::real property}} and the {{c4::seller}} as owning a {{c5::personal property}} right to the {{c6::sale proceeds}} while holding {{c7::legal title in trust}} for the buyer between contract and closing. This affects (1) protection from the seller’s {{c8::pre-contract creditors}}, (2) allocation of {{c9::risk of loss}} if the property is destroyed before closing (usually the {{c10::buyer}}, absent a different contract allocation), and (3) whether each party’s interest passes as {{c11::realty or personalty}} if a party {{c12::dies before closing}}.
cards.easyContent: Equitable conversion recharacterizes interests between contract and closing: the buyer is treated as owning the land, the seller owns the right to the sale proceeds and holds legal title in trust. This controls who is protected from the seller’s creditors, who bears risk of loss (usually the buyer), and whether each party’s interest passes as realty or personalty on death.
cards.mediumContent: Once a land sale contract is executed, equitable conversion treats the buyer as the equitable owner of the real property and the seller as owning a personal property right to the sale proceeds while holding legal title in trust. This structure means: (1) the buyer is protected against the seller’s pre-contract judgment creditors, whose claims are converted into an interest in the seller’s proceeds, not the land; (2) in most jurisdictions, the buyer bears the risk of loss if the property is destroyed before closing, unless the parties reallocate risk by contract, and the seller must credit insurance proceeds; and (3) on death before closing, the seller’s interest passes as personalty and the buyer’s as realty.
cards.hardContent: Equitable conversion arises in land sale contracts between execution of the contract and delivery of the deed. The buyer is treated as the equitable owner of the real property, and the seller as owning personal property—the right to the sale proceeds—while holding legal title in trust for the buyer. This has three main consequences: (1) as to the seller’s pre-contract obligations, any judgment against the seller is converted into an interest in the seller’s sale proceeds and is not enforceable against the land, thereby protecting the buyer’s equitable ownership; (2) as to risk of loss, in most jurisdictions if the property is destroyed before closing through no fault of the parties, the buyer bears the risk of loss—even if the buyer has not taken possession—unless the parties contractually reallocate risk, and the seller must credit any insurance proceeds against the purchase price; and (3) as to death before closing, the seller’s interest (right to proceeds) passes as personalty and the buyer’s interest (right to the land) passes as realty, so the respective estates can sue for sale proceeds or delivery of the property.
cards.mnemonic: BEC: Buyer owns Estate, seller owns Cash.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) definition and consequences of equitable conversion vis-à-vis creditor claims, (2) risk of loss allocation before closing (including insurance), and (3) effect of death of buyer or seller before closing on how interests pass.
cards.clozeLite: After a land sale contract, {{c1::equitable conversion}} treats the {{c2::buyer as equitable owner of the land}} and the {{c3::seller as owning personalty (sale proceeds)}}, so {{c4::buyer usually bears risk of loss}} and {{c5::interests pass as realty vs. personalty on death}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Implied Promises in Land Sale Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 049. Implied Promises in Land Sale Contracts
cards.front: Implied Promises in Land Sale Contracts – Overview
cards.backPlain: Every land sale contract contains two key implied promises and associated remedies if they are breached before closing: 1. Implied promise of marketable title: The seller implicitly promises to deliver title at closing that is free from a reasonable risk of litigation. Certain defects—such as unquieted adverse possession, significant encumbrances, or existing zoning violations—can render title unmarketable, though the buyer may waive this protection. 2. Implied promise regarding condition and disclosures: The seller implicitly promises not to make material misstatements and to disclose known latent material defects. For new construction, there is also an implied warranty of quality from the seller–builder. 3. Remedies and merger: If the seller breaches these implied promises, the buyer must raise the issue and allow a reasonable time to cure before closing. If not cured, the buyer may pursue contract and equitable remedies. If the buyer fails to act before closing, the land sale contract merges into the deed and the seller’s liability is generally limited to deed covenants.
cards.frontPrompt: What implied promises arise in every land sale contract and, in general terms, how do breaches of those promises relate to buyer remedies and the merger doctrine?
cards.cloze: Every land sale contract contains two key {{c1::implied promises}} and associated remedies if they are breached before closing: 1. An implied promise of {{c2::marketable title}}—that the seller will deliver title at closing that is {{c3::free from a reasonable risk of litigation}}. 2. An implied promise regarding {{c4::condition and disclosures}}—that the seller will not make {{c5::material misstatements}} and will {{c6::disclose known latent material defects}} (plus an {{c7::implied warranty of quality}} for new construction). If these promises are breached and not cured before closing, the buyer may seek {{c8::contract and equitable remedies}}. If the buyer does not act before closing, the land sale contract {{c9::merges into the deed}}, generally limiting the seller’s liability to {{c10::deed covenants}}.
cards.easyContent: Every land sale contract carries implied promises of marketable title and honest disclosure (plus an implied quality warranty for new construction), and the buyer must raise and seek to cure breaches before closing or else the contract merges into the deed.
cards.mediumContent: In land sale contracts, the seller implicitly promises: (1) to deliver marketable title—title free from a reasonable risk of litigation at closing; and (2) to avoid material misstatements and to disclose known latent material defects, with an implied warranty of quality for new construction. If these promises are breached, the buyer must object and allow time to cure before closing; if uncured, the buyer may pursue contract and equitable remedies. If the buyer fails to raise issues before closing, the land sale contract merges into the deed, limiting claims to deed covenants.
cards.hardContent: Every land sale contract contains two main implied promises. First, there is an implied promise to provide marketable title—title that, at closing, is free from a reasonable risk of litigation. Certain defects, such as unquieted adverse possession, substantial encumbrances, or existing zoning violations, can render title unmarketable, although the buyer may waive this protection. Second, there is an implied promise that the seller will not materially misrepresent facts and will disclose known latent material defects, and in the case of new construction, the seller–builder also provides an implied warranty of quality in construction. If the seller breaches either implied promise, the buyer must raise the issue and give the seller a reasonable opportunity to cure before closing; if the defect is not cured, the buyer may seek rescission, damages, specific performance, or quiet title. If the buyer does not object before closing, the land sale contract merges into the deed, and the seller’s liability is generally confined to covenants contained in the deed.
cards.mnemonic: MT + DD + Q: Marketable Title, Disclosure/Dishonesty, Quality for new builds.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) implied promise of marketable title and what makes title unmarketable; (2) implied duty to disclose and not misrepresent, including implied warranty of quality for new construction; and (3) remedies for breach and merger doctrine.
