cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 050. Deeds
cards.backPlain: A deed is the written instrument that passes legal title in real property from the seller (grantor) to the buyer (grantee). For a deed to be effective, it must satisfy the formal requirements for validity (lawful execution, delivery, and acceptance). Deeds also vary in the scope of covenants for title they provide: general warranty deeds provide the broadest protections, special warranty deeds provide more limited assurances tied to the grantor’s ownership period, and quitclaim deeds provide no covenants at all, merely conveying whatever interest the grantor has, if any.
cards.frontPrompt: What does a deed do in real property law, and what are the main requirements and types of deeds to be aware of?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::deed}} is the written instrument that passes {{c2::legal title}} in real property from the {{c3::grantor}} to the {{c4::grantee}}. For a deed to be effective, it must satisfy the formal requirements for {{c5::validity}} ({{c6::lawful execution}}, {{c7::delivery}}, and {{c8::acceptance}}). Deeds also vary in the scope of {{c9::covenants for title}} they provide: {{c10::general warranty deeds}} provide the broadest protections, {{c11::special warranty deeds}} provide more limited assurances tied to the grantor’s ownership period, and {{c12::quitclaim deeds}} provide {{c13::no covenants}}, merely conveying whatever interest the grantor has.
cards.easyContent: A deed is the instrument that transfers legal title to land. It must be validly executed, delivered, and accepted, and it can be structured as a general warranty, special warranty, or quitclaim deed, which differ in the strength of title covenants.
cards.mediumContent: A deed conveys legal title from grantor to grantee. To be effective, it must meet formal validity requirements—lawful execution, delivery with present intent to be bound, and acceptance by the grantee. Deeds also differ in their title protections: general warranty deeds include six covenants for title, special warranty deeds contain limited assurances tied to the grantor’s period of ownership, and quitclaim deeds convey only whatever interest the grantor has with no covenants.
cards.hardContent: A deed is the written instrument used to pass legal title to real property from the grantor to the grantee. For a deed to be effective, it must be lawfully executed, delivered with the grantor’s present intent to be bound, and accepted by the grantee. Delivery and acceptance doctrines also address conditional and third‑party (escrow) transfers. Substantively, deeds vary based on the covenants for title they provide: a general warranty deed includes six covenants for title and offers the broadest protection; a special warranty deed limits the grantor’s assurances to defects arising during the grantor’s ownership; and a quitclaim deed merely conveys whatever interest the grantor has, without any covenants or promise of title.
cards.mnemonic: "LED" for deed validity: Lawful execution, Effective delivery, and Delivery must be Accepted.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into (1) validity requirements (execution, delivery, acceptance, conditional/third‑party delivery) and (2) comparison of general warranty, special warranty, and quitclaim deeds.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::deed}} conveys {{c2::legal title}} from {{c3::grantor to grantee}} and must be {{c4::lawfully executed, delivered, and accepted}}; common types are {{c5::general warranty, special warranty, and quitclaim deeds}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: General Warranty Deeds and Covenants for Title
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 051. General Warranty Deeds and Covenants for Title
cards.front: General Warranty Deeds and Covenants for Title
cards.backPlain: 1. General warranty deeds include six covenants for title. These covenants concern the condition of title, not the physical condition of the property. 2. Present covenants (breached, if at all, at the time of delivery): 2.1 Seisin: the grantor covenants that he is the rightful owner (i.e., has title and possession) and that the deed covers the described land. 2.2 Right to convey: the grantor covenants that he has the right to convey the property. 2.3 Covenant against encumbrances: the grantor covenants that the land is free from encumbrances (e.g., servitudes, mortgages), except as otherwise stated. 3. Future covenants (breached, if at all, only after delivery): 3.1 Quiet enjoyment: the grantor covenants that the grantee will not be disturbed by a third party's claim of lawful title. 3.2 Warranty: the grantor agrees to defend against lawful claims of title by others. 3.3 Further assurances: the grantor promises to perform future acts reasonably necessary to perfect the title conveyed.
cards.frontPrompt: What six covenants for title are contained in a general warranty deed, and which are present versus future covenants?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::General warranty deeds}} include {{c2::six covenants for title}}. These covenants concern the {{c3::condition of title}}, not the physical condition of the property. 2. {{c4::Present covenants}} (breached, if at all, at the time of delivery): 2.1 {{c5::Seisin}}: the grantor covenants that he is the {{c6::rightful owner}} (i.e., has title and possession) and that the deed covers the described land. 2.2 {{c7::Right to convey}}: the grantor covenants that he has the {{c8::right to convey}} the property. 2.3 Covenant {{c9::against encumbrances}}: the grantor covenants that the land is {{c10::free from encumbrances}} (e.g., servitudes, mortgages), except as otherwise stated. 3. {{c11::Future covenants}} (breached, if at all, only after delivery): 3.1 {{c12::Quiet enjoyment}}: the grantor covenants that the grantee will not be {{c13::disturbed by a third party's claim of lawful title}}. 3.2 {{c14::Warranty}}: the grantor agrees to {{c15::defend against lawful claims of title by others}}. 3.3 {{c16::Further assurances}}: the grantor promises to {{c17::perform future acts reasonably necessary to perfect the title conveyed}}.
cards.easyContent: A general warranty deed contains six covenants for title—three present (seisin, right to convey, against encumbrances) and three future (quiet enjoyment, warranty, further assurances)—all addressing the condition of title, not the property’s physical condition.
cards.mediumContent: General warranty deeds provide the greatest protection because they include six covenants for title. The present covenants, breached if at all at delivery, are seisin (grantor is the rightful owner of the described land), right to convey (grantor has the power to convey), and against encumbrances (no undisclosed encumbrances like servitudes or mortgages). The future covenants, breached only if problems arise after delivery, are quiet enjoyment (grantee will not be disturbed by someone with superior lawful title), warranty (grantor will defend against lawful title claims), and further assurances (grantor will do whatever is reasonably needed to perfect title).
cards.hardContent: General warranty deeds include six covenants for title, which protect the grantee as to the state of title rather than the physical condition of the property. The three present covenants, which are breached if at all at the time of delivery, are: (1) seisin, in which the grantor warrants that he is the rightful owner, having both title and possession, and that the deed describes the land he owns; (2) right to convey, in which the grantor warrants that he has legal power to transfer the property; and (3) covenant against encumbrances, in which the grantor warrants that there are no undisclosed encumbrances such as servitudes or mortgages. The three future covenants, breached if at all only after delivery, are: (4) quiet enjoyment, which promises that the grantee will not be disturbed by a third party with lawful title; (5) warranty, in which the grantor agrees to defend the grantee against lawful title claims; and (6) further assurances, in which the grantor promises to execute any further documents or take reasonable steps necessary to perfect the title conveyed.
cards.mnemonic: Present: SRE; Future: QWF — "Sure, We’re Quiet and Worry-Free."
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::general warranty deed}} has six covenants: three present—{{c2::seisin}}, {{c3::right to convey}}, {{c4::against encumbrances}}—and three future—{{c5::quiet enjoyment}}, {{c6::warranty and further assurances}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 052. Bona Fide Purchasers for Value
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A bona fide purchaser (BFP) is one who purchases property for value (i.e., gives pecuniary consideration) without notice of a prior conveyance. Whether a buyer is a BFP is important in the context of recording statutes. 2. Purchasers: 2.1 Include mortgagees for value. 2.2 Do not include donees, heirs, or devisees. 2.3 Donees, heirs, and devisees are not protected by the recording statutes unless the Shelter Rule applies. 3. Notice: a buyer has notice of a prior conveyance by any of the following: 3.1 Actual notice: actual knowledge from any source. 3.2 Inquiry notice: what a reasonable inspection of the land or further investigation of facts would reveal, regardless of whether the buyer actually inspects. 3.3 Record notice: knowledge that would be obtained from a routine title search, such as a previous conveyance properly recorded in the chain of title (not a wild deed).
cards.frontPrompt: Who qualifies as a bona fide purchaser for value for purposes of the recording acts, and what kinds of notice of prior conveyances will defeat BFP status?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::bona fide purchaser (BFP)}} is one who {{c2::purchases property for value}} (i.e., gives pecuniary consideration) {{c3::without notice of a prior conveyance}}. Whether a buyer is a BFP is important in the context of {{c4::recording statutes}}. 2. Purchasers: 2.1 Include {{c5::mortgagees for value}}. 2.2 Do not include {{c6::donees, heirs, or devisees}}. 2.3 Donees, heirs, and devisees are not protected by the recording statutes unless the {{c7::Shelter Rule}} applies. 3. {{c8::Notice}}: a buyer has notice of a prior conveyance by any of the following: 3.1 {{c9::Actual notice}}: {{c10::actual knowledge}} from any source. 3.2 {{c11::Inquiry notice}}: what a {{c12::reasonable inspection}} of the land or further investigation of facts would reveal, regardless of whether the buyer actually inspects. 3.3 {{c13::Record notice}}: knowledge that would be obtained from a {{c14::routine title search}}, such as a previous conveyance properly recorded in the {{c15::chain of title}} (not a {{c16::wild deed}}).
cards.easyContent: A bona fide purchaser for value pays money or other value for property without notice of a prior conveyance, and is protected by recording statutes unless the buyer has actual, inquiry, or record notice of the earlier interest.
cards.mediumContent: A BFP is someone who purchases property for value, including mortgagees for value, without notice of a prior conveyance, and BFP status is central under the recording acts. Donees, heirs, and devisees are not BFPs and are generally not protected by recording statutes unless the Shelter Rule applies. Notice that defeats BFP status may be actual (direct knowledge), inquiry (what a reasonable inspection or follow-up on facts would reveal), or record (what a routine title search would show, such as earlier deeds properly recorded in the chain of title).
cards.hardContent: A bona fide purchaser (BFP) is a person who gives pecuniary consideration for a conveyance of property and lacks notice of any prior conveyance at the time of purchase. BFP status is critical under recording statutes in determining priority among conflicting claimants. Purchasers include mortgagees who advance value, but do not include donees, heirs, or devisees; those parties are generally outside the protection of recording statutes unless they qualify under the Shelter Rule through a BFP grantor. Notice that will defeat BFP protection may be: (1) actual notice—direct knowledge of the prior interest from any source; (2) inquiry notice—information that a reasonable person would obtain from inspecting the land or investigating suspicious facts, even if the buyer does not in fact investigate; and (3) record notice—what a standard title search in the public records would reveal, such as a prior deed properly recorded in the chain of title (as opposed to a wild deed outside the chain).
cards.mnemonic: BFP AIR: Buyer For Pay; Actual, Inquiry, Record notice defeats.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::bona fide purchaser for value}} gives {{c2::pecuniary consideration}} {{c3::without notice of prior conveyances}}; defeating notice can be {{c4::actual}}, {{c5::inquiry}}, or {{c6::record}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 053. Recording Statutes
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: If a prior conveyance or interest is not recorded, a subsequent purchaser or mortgagee may be protected under a recording statute. The level of protection depends on the type of recording statute. 1.1 Notice statutes 1.1.1 A subsequent bona fide purchaser (BFP) always prevails. 1.1.2 Whether or not she records first, a subsequent BFP always prevails over a prior grantee who fails to record. 1.1.3 Typical statutory language: "No conveyance or mortgage of an interest in land shall be valid against any subsequent purchaser for value without notice thereof, unless it is recorded." 2. Race-notice statutes 2.1 The first subsequent BFP to record prevails. 2.2 Typical statutory language: "No conveyance or mortgage of an interest in land shall be valid against any subsequent purchaser for value, without notice thereof, whose conveyance is first recorded." 3. Race statutes 3.1 The first grantee to record prevails, regardless of whether the buyer is a BFP. 3.2 For example, a non-BFP purchaser who records first prevails over a later BFP. 3.3 Typical statutory language: "No conveyance or mortgage of an interest in land shall be valid against any other conveyance whose recording is first in time."
cards.frontPrompt: What are the three main types of recording statutes (notice, race-notice, race), and how does each determine which claimant prevails?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: If a prior conveyance or interest is not recorded, a subsequent purchaser or mortgagee may be protected under a {{c1::recording statute}}. The level of protection depends on the type of recording statute. 1.1 {{c2::Notice statutes}} 1.1.1 A subsequent {{c3::bona fide purchaser (BFP)}} always prevails. 1.1.2 Whether or not she records first, a subsequent BFP always prevails over a prior grantee who {{c4::fails to record}}. 1.1.3 Typical statutory language: "No conveyance or mortgage of an interest in land shall be valid against any subsequent purchaser for value {{c5::without notice}} thereof, unless it is recorded." 2. {{c6::Race-notice statutes}} 2.1 The first subsequent {{c7::BFP to record}} prevails. 2.2 Typical statutory language: "No conveyance or mortgage of an interest in land shall be valid against any subsequent purchaser for value, without notice thereof, {{c8::whose conveyance is first recorded}}." 3. {{c9::Race statutes}} 3.1 The first grantee to {{c10::record}} prevails, regardless of whether the buyer is a BFP. 3.2 For example, a {{c11::non-BFP purchaser who records first}} prevails over a later BFP. 3.3 Typical statutory language: "No conveyance or mortgage of an interest in land shall be valid against any other conveyance whose recording is {{c12::first in time}}."
cards.easyContent: Recording statutes protect certain later takers when a prior interest is unrecorded. Depending on whether the jurisdiction has a notice, race-notice, or race statute, either a later BFP (with or without recording first) or simply the first recorder will prevail.
cards.mediumContent: Recording statutes determine who prevails when there are competing claims to the same property and a prior interest is not recorded. Under a notice statute, a subsequent BFP prevails over an unrecorded prior grantee even if the BFP records later. Under a race-notice statute, the first subsequent BFP to record prevails. Under a race statute, the first grantee to record wins regardless of notice or BFP status.
cards.hardContent: If a prior conveyance or interest is not recorded, a subsequent purchaser or mortgagee may gain priority under a recording statute. In a notice jurisdiction, any subsequent bona fide purchaser for value without notice of the prior interest prevails over a prior grantee who fails to record, even if the BFP records later. In a race-notice jurisdiction, the subsequent BFP must also be the first to record to prevail. In a pure race jurisdiction, the first grantee to record prevails, even if that grantee is not a BFP; a non-BFP who records first can defeat a later BFP. Each type of statute uses characteristic language focusing on lack of notice, first recording, or both.
cards.mnemonic: N → RN → R: Notice = BFP; Race-Notice = first BFP to record; Race = first recorder.
cards.clozeLite: Under a {{c1::notice}} statute, a {{c2::subsequent BFP}} wins even if recording later. Under {{c3::race-notice}}, the first BFP to {{c4::record}} wins. Under {{c5::race}}, the first {{c6::grantee to record}} wins.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 054. Chain of Title Problems
cards.backPlain: Shelter Rule, Wild Deeds, and Estoppel by Deed: 1. Issues that can arise with recording statutes and the chain of title: 1.1 Shelter rule 1.1.1 One who takes from a BFP will prevail against any interest the transferor-BFP would have prevailed against, even if the transferee had actual notice of a prior conveyance. 1.1.2 This protects donees, heirs, or devisees of BFPs who cannot qualify as BFPs and would not otherwise receive protection under notice or race-notice statutes. 1.2 Wild deeds 1.2.1 A wild deed is a recorded deed unconnected to the chain of title (for example, due to a clerk's filing error or the failure to record a prior deed). 1.2.2 Record notice cannot be derived from a wild deed. 1.2.3 A wild deed cannot exist in a tract index system. 1.3 Estoppel by deed 1.3.1 A grantor who conveys title to land he does not then own is estopped from subsequently acquiring the same land as against that grantee. 1.3.2 When the grantor later acquires title, title automatically passes to the benefit of the earlier grantee. 1.3.3 This prevents one from conveying land they do not presently own and later validly acquiring it against the grantee (for example, through a will).
cards.frontPrompt: What are the shelter rule, wild deeds, and estoppel by deed, and how do they affect chain of title and recording priority?
cards.cloze: Shelter Rule, Wild Deeds, and Estoppel by Deed: 1. Issues that can arise with {{c1::recording statutes}} and the {{c2::chain of title}}: 1.1 {{c3::Shelter rule}} 1.1.1 One who takes from a {{c4::bona fide purchaser (BFP)}} will prevail against any interest the transferor-BFP would have prevailed against, even if the transferee had {{c5::actual notice}} of a prior conveyance. 1.1.2 This protects {{c6::donees, heirs, or devisees of BFPs}} who cannot qualify as BFPs and would not otherwise receive protection under notice or race-notice statutes. 1.2 {{c7::Wild deeds}} 1.2.1 A wild deed is a recorded deed {{c8::unconnected to the chain of title}} (for example, due to a clerk's filing error or the failure to record a prior deed). 1.2.2 {{c9::Record notice cannot be derived}} from a wild deed. 1.2.3 A wild deed cannot exist in a {{c10::tract index}} system. 1.3 {{c11::Estoppel by deed}} 1.3.1 A grantor who conveys title to land he does not then own is {{c12::estopped from subsequently acquiring the same land}} as against that grantee. 1.3.2 When the grantor later acquires title, {{c13::title automatically passes}} to the benefit of the earlier grantee. 1.3.3 This prevents one from conveying land they do not presently own and later validly acquiring it against the grantee (for example, through a will).
cards.easyContent: Chain of title problems include the shelter rule, wild deeds, and estoppel by deed. These doctrines govern when later takers can piggyback on a BFP’s status, when a recorded deed gives no notice, and when after-acquired title passes automatically to an earlier grantee.
cards.mediumContent: Under the shelter rule, anyone who takes from a BFP steps into the BFP’s shoes and prevails against the same interests, even if the transferee has actual notice; this protects donees, heirs, and devisees of BFPs. A wild deed is a recorded deed outside the chain of title, often due to a missing prior link, and it cannot provide record notice; it cannot occur in a tract index system. Estoppel by deed prevents a grantor from later asserting title against an earlier grantee when the grantor conveyed before owning the land; once the grantor acquires title, it automatically passes to that grantee.
cards.hardContent: Recording and chain of title problems include: (1) The shelter rule: Anyone who takes from a bona fide purchaser for value acquires the BFP’s protection and will prevail against any interest the transferor-BFP would have defeated, even if the transferee has actual notice of a prior conveyance. This allows donees, heirs, or devisees (who do not give value and thus are not BFPs) to gain the benefit of the BFP’s status under notice and race-notice statutes. (2) Wild deeds: A wild deed is recorded but unconnected to the chain of title because an earlier link was never recorded or due to a recording error. Such a deed does not provide record notice to subsequent purchasers and cannot exist in a pure tract index system. (3) Estoppel by deed: A grantor who purports to convey land he does not yet own is estopped, as against that grantee, from later asserting title to that land once he acquires it. When the grantor later obtains title, it automatically passes to the earlier grantee, preventing the grantor from cutting off the grantee’s rights by later acquisition (e.g., through a will).
cards.mnemonic: Shelter: under BFP’s umbrella; Wild: lost in records; Estoppel: later title snaps to grantee.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::shelter rule}}, a transferee from a {{c2::BFP}} takes the BFP’s protection. A {{c3::wild deed}} is {{c4::recorded outside the chain of title}}. {{c5::Estoppel by deed}} makes {{c6::after-acquired title pass automatically to the earlier grantee}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 055. Real Estate Brokers and Agents
cards.backPlain: 1. Most real property sales are negotiated by real estate brokers. 1.1 Seller's agent 1.1.1 A seller's agent is a broker who obtains the listing from the seller, i.e., is engaged by the seller to assist in the sale of the property. 1.1.2 The seller's agent has a fiduciary duty to the seller. 1.1.3 The seller's agent earns a commission from the sale of the property once the sale closes. 1.1.4 The seller's agent may still earn a commission if the sale fails to close due to the seller's fault (for example, the seller backs out). 1.2 Buyer's agent 1.2.1 A buyer's agent's primary relationship is with the buyer; for example, the agent shows the buyer potential properties the buyer may purchase. 1.2.2 The buyer's agent is typically compensated by receiving a portion of the listing broker's commission, i.e., is paid out of the seller's agent's commission. 1.2.3 At common law, a buyer's agent owed a fiduciary duty to the seller because the buyer's agent was technically a subagent of the seller's agent. 1.2.4 Under modern statutes, a separate agreement between the buyer's agent and buyer is required; the buyer's agent owes a fiduciary duty to the buyer but no fiduciary duty to the seller. 2. Duty to disclose 2.1 Real estate agents have a duty to disclose material information about the property of which they have actual knowledge.
cards.frontPrompt: In real estate sales, what are the roles and fiduciary duties of seller’s and buyer’s agents, and what duty to disclose do agents owe?
cards.cloze: 1. Most real property sales are negotiated by {{c1::real estate brokers}}. 1.1 {{c2::Seller's agent}} 1.1.1 A seller's agent is a broker who {{c3::obtains the listing from the seller}}, i.e., is engaged by the seller to assist in the sale of the property. 1.1.2 The seller's agent has a {{c4::fiduciary duty}} to the seller. 1.1.3 The seller's agent earns a {{c5::commission}} from the sale of the property once the sale closes. 1.1.4 The seller's agent may still earn a commission if the sale fails to close due to the {{c6::seller's fault}} (for example, the seller backs out). 1.2 {{c7::Buyer's agent}} 1.2.1 A buyer's agent's primary relationship is with the {{c8::buyer}}; for example, the agent shows the buyer potential properties the buyer may purchase. 1.2.2 The buyer's agent is typically compensated by receiving a portion of the {{c9::listing broker's commission}}, i.e., is paid out of the seller's agent's commission. 1.2.3 At {{c10::common law}}, a buyer's agent owed a fiduciary duty to the {{c11::seller}} because the buyer's agent was technically a {{c12::subagent of the seller's agent}}. 1.2.4 Under {{c13::modern statutes}}, a separate agreement between the buyer's agent and buyer is required; the buyer's agent owes a fiduciary duty to the {{c14::buyer}} but no fiduciary duty to the seller. 2. {{c15::Duty to disclose}} 2.1 Real estate agents have a duty to disclose {{c16::material information}} about the property of which they have {{c17::actual knowledge}}.
cards.easyContent: Real estate sales are usually handled by brokers: a seller’s agent owes a fiduciary duty to the seller and earns a commission, while a buyer’s agent represents the buyer under modern statutes. Agents must disclose material facts about the property they actually know.
cards.mediumContent: In most real property sales, a listing broker acts as the seller's agent, owes the seller fiduciary duties, and earns a commission when the sale closes (and may still earn it if the seller’s fault prevents closing). A buyer's agent primarily serves the buyer; traditionally the buyer's agent was treated as the seller's subagent and owed fiduciary duties to the seller, but under modern statutes a written buyer-agency agreement makes the buyer’s agent a fiduciary of the buyer only. All real estate brokers have a duty to disclose material information about the property that they actually know.
cards.hardContent: Most real property sales involve real estate brokers. The seller's agent (listing broker) is engaged by the seller to market and sell the property, owes a fiduciary duty to the seller, and earns a commission upon closing; the seller's agent may still be entitled to the commission if the sale fails to close due to the seller’s fault, such as backing out. A buyer's agent’s primary relationship is with the buyer, showing and advising on potential purchases. Typically, the buyer's agent is compensated from the listing broker’s commission. At common law, the buyer’s agent was technically a subagent of the seller’s agent and thus owed fiduciary duties to the seller. Under modern statutes, a separate written agreement creates a buyer’s agent who owes fiduciary duties to the buyer and no fiduciary duty to the seller. In addition, agents have a duty to disclose material information about the property of which they have actual knowledge.
cards.mnemonic: Old rule: buyer’s agent serves seller; new rule: written buyer-agency serves buyer.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::listing broker}} is the {{c2::seller's agent}}, owing {{c3::fiduciary duties to the seller}} and earning a {{c4::commission at closing}}. All brokers must {{c5::disclose material facts they actually know}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 056. Mortgages
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 A mortgage is a security interest in land that serves as collateral for the repayment of a loan (also known as a mortgage lien). 1.2 Writing required: A mortgage must be in writing to satisfy the Statute of Frauds. 1.3 Mortgagor: The mortgagor is the debtor/borrower/landowner. 1.4 Mortgagee: The mortgagee is the creditor/lender. 2. Parties' rights (theories of title) 2.1 Lien theory (majority): The mortgagor has title and the right to possession absent foreclosure; the mortgagee has only a lien, conferring a right to take action for ownership of the land if the mortgagor defaults on the loan. 2.2 Title theory (minority): The mortgagee has title to the property during the loan term, not the mortgagor-borrower. 2.3 Intermediate theory (minority): The mortgagor has title and the right to possession until default occurs under the mortgage; after default, the mortgagee has title and the right to possession. 2.4 Note: Unless instructed otherwise, assume lien theory applies on the MBE. 3. Equitable mortgage; acceleration clauses 3.1 Equitable mortgage: A debtor gives a creditor a deed to his land as collateral for the debt (instead of executing a formal mortgage); equity treats this as a mortgage. 3.2 Acceleration clauses: Terms in loan agreements that require the mortgagor to pay off the full loan immediately if certain conditions are met (for example, if the mortgagor misses too many payments).
cards.frontPrompt: What is a mortgage, what are the lien, title, and intermediate theories of mortgage rights, and what are an equitable mortgage and an acceleration clause?

In general 1.1 A {{c1::mortgage}} is a {{c2::security interest in land}} that serves as collateral for the repayment of a loan (also known as a {{c3::mortgage lien}}). 1.2 Writing required: A mortgage must be in writing to satisfy the {{c4::Statute of Frauds}}. 1.3 {{c5::Mortgagor}}: The mortgagor is the {{c6::debtor/borrower/landowner}}. 1.4 {{c7::Mortgagee}}: The mortgagee is the {{c8::creditor/lender}}. 2. Parties' rights (theories of title) 2.1 {{c9::Lien theory}} (majority): The mortgagor has {{c10::title and the right to possession}} absent foreclosure; the mortgagee has only a {{c11::lien}}, conferring a right to take action for ownership of the land if the mortgagor defaults on the loan. 2.2 {{c12::Title theory}} (minority): The mortgagee has {{c13::title to the property during the loan term}}, not the mortgagor-borrower. 2.3 {{c14::Intermediate theory}} (minority): The mortgagor has title and the right to possession until {{c15::default}} occurs under the mortgage; after default, the mortgagee has title and the right to possession. 2.4 Note: Unless instructed otherwise, assume {{c16::lien theory}} applies on the MBE. 3. {{c17::Equitable mortgage}}; {{c18::acceleration clauses}} 3.1 Equitable mortgage: A debtor gives a creditor a {{c19::deed to his land as collateral}} for the debt (instead of executing a formal mortgage); {{c20::equity treats this as a mortgage}}. 3.2 Acceleration clauses: Terms in loan agreements that require the mortgagor to {{c21::pay off the full loan immediately}} if certain conditions are met (for example, if the mortgagor misses too many payments).
cards.easyContent: A mortgage is a written security interest in land that secures repayment of a loan between a mortgagor (borrower) and mortgagee (lender). Most jurisdictions follow lien theory, where the borrower keeps title and possession, and equity may treat a deed given as collateral as an equitable mortgage.
cards.mediumContent: A mortgage is a written security interest in real property given by a mortgagor (debtor/landowner) to a mortgagee (creditor/lender) as collateral for a loan, satisfying the Statute of Frauds. Under lien theory (majority), the mortgagor holds title and possession and the mortgagee has only a lien enforceable upon default. Under title theory (minority), the mortgagee holds title during the loan term, and under intermediate theory (minority), the mortgagor keeps title and possession until default, after which they shift to the mortgagee. A deed given as security is treated in equity as an equitable mortgage, and acceleration clauses allow the lender to demand immediate payment of the full balance upon specified defaults.
cards.hardContent: A mortgage is a written security interest in land (a mortgage lien) given by a mortgagor— the debtor/borrower/landowner—to a mortgagee, the creditor/lender, as collateral for a loan; the arrangement must comply with the Statute of Frauds. The parties' rights depend on the jurisdiction’s theory of title. Under lien theory (the majority rule and default assumption on the MBE), the mortgagor retains legal title and the right to possession unless and until foreclosure, while the mortgagee holds only a lien that can be enforced if the mortgagor defaults. Under title theory (a minority approach), the mortgagee holds legal title during the loan term, and the mortgagor has only an equitable interest. Under intermediate theory (also a minority), the mortgagor holds title and possession until default, at which point title and the right to possession shift to the mortgagee. A deed given to a creditor as security for a debt, instead of a formal mortgage instrument, will be treated in equity as an equitable mortgage. Many loan agreements also contain acceleration clauses that allow the lender to declare the entire balance immediately due and payable upon specified events of default, such as repeated missed payments.
cards.mnemonic: MORtgage: MortgagOR = Owner; Mortgagee = lEnder with lien.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::mortgage}} is a written {{c2::security interest in real property}} given by a {{c3::mortgagor}} to a {{c4::mortgagee}}; most states follow {{c5::lien theory}} where the borrower keeps title and possession.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Transfer of Mortgage Interests and Holders in Due Course
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 057. Transfer of Mortgage Interests and Holders in Due Course
cards.front: Transfer of Mortgage Interests and Holders in Due Course
cards.backPlain: 1. Mortgagor transfer 1.1 Where the mortgagor sells the property, the mortgage remains on the land; the grantee takes subject to the mortgage but is not personally liable for repayment unless they assume it. 1.2 The mortgagor remains liable to the mortgagee for the loan. 1.3 Assumption 1.3.1 If the grantee promises to pay the existing mortgage loan, the grantee becomes primarily liable to the mortgagee. 1.3.2 The original mortgagor is secondarily liable as a surety. 2. Mortgagee transfer 2.1 A mortgagee (creditor) can transfer her interest by: 2.1.1 Endorsing the mortgage note and delivering it to the transferee; or 2.1.2 Executing a separate assignment of the mortgage interest. 3. Holder in due course 3.1 A holder in due course of a mortgage note takes it free of any personal defenses the mortgagor could have raised against the original mortgagee (for example, lack of consideration, fraudulent inducement). 3.2 However, the holder in due course remains subject to real defenses (for example, duress, fraud in the factum, incapacity, illegality, infancy, insolvency). 4. Requirements for holder in due course status 4.1 Negotiable note: The note must be a negotiable instrument made payable to the named mortgagee. 4.2 Indorsed: The note must be signed (indorsed) by the named mortgagee. 4.3 Delivered: The note must be delivered to the transferee. 4.4 Good faith and value paid: The transferee must take the note in good faith (without notice of illegality or defenses) and pay value.
cards.frontPrompt: When a mortgagor or mortgagee transfers their interest, how does liability change, and what is a holder in due course of a mortgage note and its requirements?

Requirements for {{c16::holder in due course}} status 4.1 {{c17::Negotiable note}}: The note must be a negotiable instrument made payable to the named mortgagee. 4.2 {{c18::Indorsed}}: The note must be signed (indorsed) by the named mortgagee. 4.3 {{c19::Delivered}}: The note must be delivered to the transferee. 4.4 {{c20::Good faith and value paid}}: The transferee must take the note in good faith (without notice of illegality or defenses) and pay value.
cards.easyContent: When a mortgagor sells the property, the mortgage sticks to the land and the buyer is only personally liable if they assume it; the original mortgagor stays liable. Mortgagees can transfer notes, and a holder in due course of the note takes free of personal but not real defenses if formal requirements are met.
cards.mediumContent: If a mortgagor sells mortgaged property, the mortgage remains on the land and the grantee takes subject to it but is not personally liable on the debt unless they expressly assume it; in that case, the grantee becomes primarily liable and the mortgagor remains secondarily liable as a surety. A mortgagee may transfer her interest by endorsing and delivering the mortgage note or by assigning the mortgage. A holder in due course of a negotiable mortgage note takes the note free of the mortgagor’s personal defenses (such as lack of consideration or fraudulent inducement) but remains subject to real defenses (such as duress, fraud in the factum, incapacity, or illegality). To be a holder in due course, the transferee must take a negotiable note payable to the mortgagee, indorsed and delivered to the transferee, in good faith and for value without notice of problems.
cards.hardContent: When a mortgagor sells property burdened by a mortgage, the mortgage follows the land, so the grantee takes subject to the mortgage, but the grantee is not personally liable on the debt unless they assume it. The original mortgagor continues to be personally liable to the mortgagee. If the grantee assumes the mortgage by promising to pay the existing loan, the grantee becomes primarily liable to the mortgagee, and the original mortgagor becomes secondarily liable as a surety. The mortgagee (creditor) may transfer her interest either by endorsing the mortgage note and delivering it to a transferee, or by executing a separate assignment of the mortgage interest. A holder in due course of a negotiable mortgage note takes the note free of the mortgagor’s personal defenses (such as lack of consideration, prior payment, or fraudulent inducement), but remains subject to real defenses (including duress, fraud in the factum, incapacity, illegality, infancy, and certain insolvency defenses). To attain holder in due course status, the transferee must receive a negotiable note made payable to the named mortgagee, properly indorsed and delivered, and must take it in good faith and for value, without notice of any illegality or defenses.
cards.mnemonic: HDC needs NID-GV: Negotiable, Indorsed, Delivered, Good faith, for Value.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::mortgage follows the land}}; buyer is {{c2::personally liable only if they assume}}. An {{c3::HDC of a negotiable mortgage note}} takes {{c4::free of personal but not real defenses}} if {{c5::negotiable, indorsed, delivered, good faith, for value, no notice}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Foreclosure and Mortgagee Rights to Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 058. Foreclosure and Mortgagee Rights to Property
cards.front: Foreclosure and Mortgagee Rights to Property – Overview
cards.backPlain: Upon a mortgagor's default, the mortgagee has several possible remedies and rights: 1. Foreclosure and Sale - The mortgagee may foreclose (typically by judicial action) and have the property sold to satisfy the debt. - If the sale proceeds are insufficient, the mortgagee may seek a deficiency judgment against the mortgagor. - If proceeds exceed the debt, surplus goes to junior lienholders in order of priority. 2. Redemption Rights - The mortgagor usually has an equitable right of redemption before a judicial foreclosure sale by paying the amount due, including in equitable mortgage situations. - Some jurisdictions also provide a statutory right of redemption, allowing the mortgagor to repurchase the property for a limited time after the foreclosure sale. 3. Deed in Lieu of Foreclosure - Instead of foreclosure, the mortgagor and mortgagee may agree that the mortgagor will convey a deed in lieu of foreclosure in full satisfaction of the debt, if the transaction is fair and reasonable. 4. Mortgagee Possession - The mortgagee’s right to take possession before foreclosure depends on lien, title, or intermediate theory, but the mortgagee can also take possession with the mortgagor’s consent or after abandonment. - A mortgagee in possession must account for rents, manage the property, and may incur tort liability.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main remedies and rights of a mortgagee upon default, including foreclosure and sale, redemption, deeds in lieu of foreclosure, and possession theories?
cards.cloze: Upon a mortgagor's default, the {{c1::mortgagee}} may: (1) {{c2::foreclose and have the property sold}}, potentially seeking a {{c3::deficiency judgment}} or distributing any {{c4::surplus}} to {{c5::junior lienholders}}; (2) respect the mortgagor’s {{c6::equitable right of redemption}} before sale and, in some jurisdictions, a {{c7::statutory right of redemption}} after sale; (3) accept a {{c8::deed in lieu of foreclosure}} if the arrangement is {{c9::fair and reasonable}}; and (4) seek {{c10::possession}} depending on whether the jurisdiction follows {{c11::lien}}, {{c12::title}}, or {{c13::intermediate}} theory, or by {{c14::consent}} or {{c15::abandonment}}, while bearing duties to {{c16::account for rents}}, {{c17::manage the property}}, and potential {{c18::tort liability}}.
cards.easyContent: Upon default, the mortgagee can foreclose and sell the property (possibly getting a deficiency judgment and paying junior lienholders from any surplus); the mortgagor has equitable and sometimes statutory redemption rights; the parties may instead use a deed in lieu of foreclosure; and the mortgagee’s right to possession before foreclosure depends on the jurisdiction’s lien/title/intermediate theory, with duties if in possession.
cards.mediumContent: When the mortgagor defaults, the mortgagee may foreclose by judicial action, sell the property, seek a deficiency judgment if proceeds are insufficient, and pay any surplus to junior lienholders by priority. The mortgagor retains an equitable right of redemption before a judicial foreclosure sale and, in some jurisdictions, a statutory right of redemption after sale, including in equitable mortgage situations. To avoid foreclosure, the parties may agree to a deed in lieu of foreclosure if the deal is fair and reasonable. The mortgagee’s right to possession before foreclosure depends on whether the jurisdiction follows lien, title, or intermediate theory, but the mortgagee can also take possession with consent or after abandonment and then must account for rents, manage the property, and may incur tort liability.
cards.hardContent: Upon default, a mortgagee has several rights and remedies. The mortgagee may foreclose (typically by judicial action) and have the property sold to satisfy the debt in whole or in part. If the sale proceeds are less than the debt, the mortgagee may pursue a deficiency judgment against the mortgagor; if proceeds exceed the debt balance, junior lienholders are paid in order of priority from the surplus. The mortgagor has an equitable right of redemption at any time before a judicial foreclosure sale by paying the amount due, including in equitable mortgage situations where the creditor appears to hold legal title via a deed. In some jurisdictions, there is also a statutory right of redemption, allowing the mortgagor, for a specified period after the foreclosure sale, to repurchase the property. As an alternative to foreclosure, the mortgagor may convey a deed in lieu of foreclosure in satisfaction of the debt, which is valid so long as the transaction is fair and reasonable under the circumstances. A mortgagee’s right to possession prior to foreclosure depends on the jurisdiction’s theory: under lien theory, there is no right to possession before foreclosure; under title theory, the mortgagee may take possession at any time upon demand; and under intermediate theory, the right arises upon default. The mortgagee can also take possession with the mortgagor’s consent or upon abandonment. A mortgagee in possession must account for rents, manage the property, and may incur tort liability to third parties.
cards.mnemonic: Remedies are FDR-P: Foreclose, Deficiency, Redemption, Possession theories.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) foreclosure, deficiency, and surplus; (2) redemption in equity, equitable mortgages, and statutory redemption; (3) deed in lieu of foreclosure; and (4) mortgagee possession and lien/title/intermediate theories.
cards.clozeLite: Upon default, the {{c1::mortgagee may foreclose and sell}}, seek a {{c2::deficiency judgment}}, the mortgagor has {{c3::equitable and statutory redemption}}, and {{c4::possession depends on lien/title/intermediate theory}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Foreclosure and Multiple Rights to Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 059. Foreclosure and Multiple Rights to Property
cards.front: Foreclosure and Multiple Rights to Property – Overview
cards.backPlain: Foreclosure reallocates rights among multiple creditors based on priority rules. 1. Priority of creditors - Creditors must record their interests, and recorded interests usually take priority in the order of recording. - Purchase money mortgages (PMMs), given to finance the purchase of the property, are superior to other interests; if both a seller PMM and a third-party lender PMM exist, the seller's PMM is senior. - Parties can alter the normal priority order by subordination agreements. 2. Effect of foreclosure on junior vs. senior interests - A properly conducted foreclosure of a senior mortgage terminates joined junior interests, leaving junior lienholders to seek deficiency judgments against the debtor but not the land; junior lienholders are necessary parties to a senior foreclosure. - Foreclosure of a junior mortgage does not affect senior interests; the buyer at a junior foreclosure sale takes the property subject to all senior mortgages, which remain enforceable against the land.
cards.frontPrompt: How does foreclosure redistribute rights among creditors, considering recording priority, purchase money mortgages, and the different effects on junior and senior interests?
cards.cloze: Foreclosure reallocates rights among multiple creditors based on {{c1::priority rules}}. 1. {{c2::Priority of creditors}} - Creditors must {{c3::record}} their interests, and recorded interests usually take priority in the order of {{c4::recording}}. - {{c5::Purchase money mortgages (PMMs)}}, given to finance the purchase of the property, are {{c6::superior}} to other interests; if both a {{c7::seller PMM}} and a {{c8::third-party lender PMM}} exist, the {{c9::seller's PMM}} is senior. - Parties can alter the normal priority order by {{c10::subordination agreements}}. 2. {{c11::Effect of foreclosure on junior vs. senior interests}} - A properly conducted foreclosure of a {{c12::senior mortgage}} {{c13::terminates joined junior interests}}, leaving junior lienholders to seek {{c14::deficiency judgments}} against the debtor but not the land; junior lienholders are {{c15::necessary parties}} to a senior foreclosure. - Foreclosure of a {{c16::junior mortgage}} does {{c17::not affect senior interests}}; the buyer at a junior foreclosure sale takes the property {{c18::subject to}} all senior mortgages, which {{c19::remain enforceable against the land}}.
cards.easyContent: Foreclosure reallocates rights based on priority. Recording and purchase money mortgage rules set who is senior, and senior vs. junior foreclosures have different effects on which interests are wiped out or survive.
cards.mediumContent: Priority among mortgages is set mainly by recording, with earlier-recorded interests generally senior, but purchase money mortgages take special priority, and parties may contractually subordinate their interests. A senior foreclosure, with proper joinder, wipes out junior interests but leaves senior interests intact; junior lienholders then look to deficiency judgments, while senior lienholders remain secured and can later foreclose. A junior foreclosure leaves senior mortgages in place, so the buyer takes subject to those senior liens.
cards.hardContent: Foreclosure governs how multiple rights in the same property are reordered among creditors. Priority is primarily determined by recording, with recorded interests generally taking priority in the order recorded. Purchase money mortgages (PMMs), given in exchange for funds used to buy the property, are superior to other interests, and a seller’s PMM is senior to a third-party lender’s PMM; parties may alter this hierarchy through subordination agreements. In a foreclosure of a senior mortgage, properly joined junior interests are terminated: junior lienholders can no longer look to the land but may seek deficiency judgments against the debtor. Junior lienholders are necessary parties to such senior foreclosures, and failure to join them leaves their junior interest on the land. By contrast, foreclosure of a junior mortgage does not affect senior interests; the purchaser at a junior foreclosure sale takes the property subject to all senior mortgages, which remain on the land and can themselves be foreclosed if unpaid.
cards.mnemonic: P-R-J-S: PMM, Recording, Juniors wiped, Seniors survive.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) recording and purchase money mortgage priority, (2) treatment and joinder of junior interests in senior foreclosures, and (3) effect of junior foreclosures on senior interests and the buyer.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::purchase money mortgage}} gets special priority over other liens, and a {{c2::senior foreclosure}} wipes out {{c3::joined junior interests}} but leaves {{c4::senior liens}} intact.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 060. lateral and subadjacent support
cards.backPlain: Lateral and subjacent support protect a landowner’s right to have land, in its natural state, physically supported by neighboring or underlying estates. 1. Lateral support (side support) - Ownership of land includes the right to have the land, in its natural state, supported by adjoining land. - An adjoining owner who excavates can be liable if removal of support causes subsidence of the neighboring land or damage to its structures. - Liability depends on whether the land would have collapsed in its natural condition and whether the defendant acted negligently. 2. Subjacent support (under-surface support) - Subjacent support concerns underground (subjacent) structures—such as mines, tunnels, or parking garages—that must support the surface estate. - Subjacent owners owe strict liability duties to support the surface land and pre-existing structures, and can be liable in negligence for damage to later-constructed buildings.
cards.frontPrompt: What are a landowner’s basic rights to lateral and subjacent support, and in general how is liability determined when support is removed?
cards.cloze: Lateral and {{c1::subjacent support}} protect a landowner’s right to have land, in its {{c2::natural state}}, physically supported by neighboring or underlying estates. 1. {{c3::Lateral support}} (side support) - Ownership of land includes the right to have the land, in its natural state, supported by {{c4::adjoining land}}. - An adjoining owner who {{c5::excavates}} can be liable if removal of support causes {{c6::subsidence}} of the neighboring land or damage to its structures. 2. {{c7::Subjacent support}} (under-surface support) - Subjacent support concerns {{c8::underground structures}}—such as {{c9::mines, tunnels, or parking garages}}—that must support the {{c10::surface estate}}. - Subjacent owners owe {{c11::strict liability}} duties to support the surface land and pre-existing structures, and can be liable in {{c12::negligence}} for damage to later-constructed buildings.
cards.easyContent: Support rights protect a landowner’s right to have land, in its natural state, supported from the side (lateral support) and from below (subjacent support). Liability typically turns on whether the land would have collapsed in its natural state and whether the defendant was negligent.
cards.mediumContent: A landowner is entitled to lateral support from adjoining land and subjacent support from underground structures. If removal of support causes the land, in its natural state, to subside, strict liability usually applies; if damage is due to extra weight from buildings or later additions, the plaintiff often must prove negligence. Subjacent support specifically involves underground works—like mines, tunnels, or garages—that must support the surface land and pre-existing structures, with strict liability for failure to do so and negligence as the standard for later-built structures.
cards.hardContent: Support rights include lateral support from neighboring land and subjacent support from underlying structures. For lateral support, adjoining owners may not remove support so as to cause the neighbor’s land, in its natural state, to subside; strict liability can apply if natural-state subsidence occurs, and negligence governs many building-related claims. For subjacent support, underground estates—such as mines, tunnels, and parking garages—must support the surface land and the structures existing when the subjacent estate was created; subjacent owners are strictly liable for failure to support the surface and pre-existing structures, but are only liable in negligence for damage to subsequently constructed buildings.
cards.mnemonic: Support: L for Lateral from Land; S for Subjacent from Subsurface.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) lateral support – definition and strict liability for land in natural state, (2) lateral support and buildings – strict liability vs negligence, and (3) subjacent support – definition and liability rules.
cards.clozeLite: A landowner is entitled to {{c1::lateral support}} from adjoining land and {{c2::subjacent support}} from underground structures; {{c3::strict liability}} applies for natural-state subsidence, and {{c4::negligence}} usually governs damage from extra building weight.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 061. Water Rights in Watercourses
cards.backPlain: 1. In general 1.1 Land bordering watercourses (natural or artificial bodies of water, such as lakes and rivers) is governed by either the riparian doctrine or the prior appropriation doctrine. 2. Riparian doctrine 2.1 Under the riparian doctrine, water belongs to those who own land bordering the watercourse (riparian owners). 2.2 Reasonable use theory (majority): riparian owners share rights to reasonable use and are liable to other owners if their use unreasonably interferes with other owners' use; the utility of the use is balanced against the gravity of the harm. 2.3 Natural flow theory (minority): riparian owners may be enjoined for any use resulting in a substantial or material reduction in others' water quantity, quality, or velocity. 2.4 Under both theories, natural uses (e.g., household use) generally prevail over artificial uses (e.g., manufacturing or irrigation). 3. Prior appropriation doctrine 3.1 Under the prior appropriation doctrine, water rights are originally acquired by actual beneficial use. 3.2 Priority of beneficial use determines rights to the water; the first individual to make a beneficial (productive) use of the water has the superior legal right to continued use.
cards.frontPrompt: How do the riparian and prior appropriation doctrines allocate rights to use water from watercourses, and how do the reasonable use and natural flow theories differ?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::In general}} 1.1 Land bordering watercourses (natural or artificial bodies of water, such as lakes and rivers) is governed by either the {{c2::riparian doctrine}} or the {{c3::prior appropriation doctrine}}. 2. {{c4::Riparian doctrine}} 2.1 Under the riparian doctrine, water belongs to those who {{c5::own land bordering the watercourse}} (riparian owners). 2.2 {{c6::Reasonable use theory}} (majority): riparian owners share rights to {{c7::reasonable use}} and are liable to other owners if their use {{c8::unreasonably interferes}} with others' use; courts balance the {{c9::utility of the use}} against the {{c10::gravity of the harm}}. 2.3 {{c11::Natural flow theory}} (minority): riparian owners may be {{c12::enjoined}} for any use resulting in a {{c13::substantial or material reduction}} in others' water quantity, quality, or velocity. 2.4 Under both theories, {{c14::natural uses}} (e.g., household use) generally prevail over {{c15::artificial uses}} (e.g., manufacturing or irrigation). 3. {{c16::Prior appropriation doctrine}} 3.1 Under the prior appropriation doctrine, water rights are originally acquired by {{c17::actual beneficial use}}. 3.2 {{c18::Priority of beneficial use}} determines rights to the water; the {{c19::first}} individual to make a beneficial (productive) use of the water has the {{c20::superior legal right}} to continued use.
cards.easyContent: Water rights in watercourses are governed either by the riparian doctrine, which ties rights to ownership of land along the water, or by the prior appropriation doctrine, which gives priority to the first person to put the water to beneficial use.
cards.mediumContent: Under the riparian doctrine, owners of land bordering a watercourse share rights to use the water. Most states follow the reasonable use theory, allowing riparians to make reasonable uses but holding them liable when their use unreasonably interferes with others, based on a utility-versus-harm balance. Some states follow the natural flow theory, more strictly limiting uses that substantially or materially reduce others’ water quantity, quality, or velocity. In either approach, natural uses such as domestic consumption generally take precedence over artificial uses such as manufacturing. Under the prior appropriation doctrine, common in western states, water rights arise from actual beneficial use, and priority goes to the first appropriator, whose beneficial use gives a superior right to continued use.
cards.hardContent: Where land borders watercourses such as lakes and rivers, water use is governed either by the riparian doctrine or the prior appropriation doctrine. Under the riparian doctrine, water belongs to owners of land bordering the watercourse. The majority reasonable use theory allows riparians to make reasonable uses and imposes liability only when a use unreasonably interferes with other riparians’ uses, determined by balancing the utility of the use against the gravity of the harm. By contrast, under the minority natural flow theory, riparians may be enjoined for uses that cause a substantial or material reduction in the quantity, quality, or velocity of others’ water, more strictly protecting natural flow. Under both theories, natural uses, like household consumption, generally prevail over artificial uses, like industrial or irrigation uses, when there is conflict. Under the prior appropriation doctrine, water rights are not tied to land ownership but to actual beneficial use, and priority of beneficial use determines rights: the first person to divert and beneficially use the water acquires a superior legal right to that amount, which is protected against later users.
cards.mnemonic: RIParian = Rivers by property; PRIOR = First user wins.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::riparian doctrine}}, rights go with {{c2::bordering land}} and are limited by {{c3::reasonable or natural flow theories}}; under {{c4::prior appropriation}}, priority goes to {{c5::first beneficial use}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Water Rights in Groundwater and Surface Water
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 062. Water Rights in Groundwater and Surface Water
cards.front: Water Rights in Groundwater and Surface Water
cards.backPlain: 1. Groundwater 1.1 Groundwater is water beneath the surface that is not confined to a known channel (e.g., water in wells). 1.2 Different states use different approaches to groundwater; the most common are: 1.2.1 Reasonable use (used in many eastern states). 1.2.2 Prior appropriation (used in many western states). 2. Surface water 2.1 Surface water is water from rain, springs, or other runoff that has not yet reached a natural watercourse. 2.2 Landowners can generally use surface water as they please, but may be liable for interrupting its flow in a way that impacts other owners. 2.3 Liability depends on which theory applies: 2.3.1 Natural flow theory: owners cannot unreasonably alter natural drainage. 2.3.2 Common enemy theory: owners can do anything to change drainage or combat flow unless it causes unnecessary damage to others' land. 2.3.3 Reasonable use theory: liability is determined by balancing the utility of the owner's use against the gravity of the harm from that use.
cards.frontPrompt: How are rights in groundwater and surface water defined, and how do the natural flow, common enemy, and reasonable use theories regulate surface water drainage?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Groundwater}} 1.1 Groundwater is water {{c2::beneath the surface}} that is {{c3::not confined to a known channel}} (e.g., water in wells). 1.2 Different states use different approaches to groundwater; the most common are: 1.2.1 {{c4::Reasonable use}} (used in many eastern states). 1.2.2 {{c5::Prior appropriation}} (used in many western states). 2. {{c6::Surface water}} 2.1 Surface water is water from {{c7::rain, springs, or other runoff}} that has not yet reached a natural watercourse. 2.2 Landowners can generally use surface water as they please, but may be liable for {{c8::interrupting its flow}} in a way that impacts other owners. 2.3 Liability depends on which theory applies: 2.3.1 {{c9::Natural flow theory}}: owners cannot {{c10::unreasonably alter natural drainage}}. 2.3.2 {{c11::Common enemy theory}}: owners can do anything to {{c12::change drainage or combat flow}} unless it causes {{c13::unnecessary damage}} to others' land. 2.3.3 {{c14::Reasonable use theory}}: liability is determined by {{c15::balancing the utility of the owner's use}} against the {{c16::gravity of the harm}} from that use.
cards.easyContent: Groundwater is underground water not in a defined channel, regulated mainly by reasonable use or prior appropriation, depending on the state. Surface water is runoff not yet in a watercourse, and landowner liability for altering its flow depends on whether the jurisdiction follows natural flow, common enemy, or reasonable use theories.
cards.mediumContent: Groundwater consists of water beneath the surface that is not confined to a known channel, such as water in wells, and states commonly regulate it either under a reasonable use approach (common in the East) or a prior appropriation approach (common in the West). Surface water is water from rain, springs, or runoff that has not yet entered a natural watercourse; landowners are generally free to use it but may be liable if their actions unreasonably affect neighbors. Liability for altering surface water drainage depends on the governing theory: the natural flow theory limits unreasonable changes to natural drainage; the common enemy theory allows landowners broad freedom to divert or repel surface water unless they cause unnecessary harm; and the reasonable use theory weighs the utility of the actor’s conduct against the harm caused.
cards.hardContent: Groundwater is water beneath the earth’s surface that is not confined to a defined channel, such as water extracted from wells. States regulate groundwater under different doctrines, most commonly reasonable use—limiting withdrawals to reasonable uses related to the overlying land—or prior appropriation, which allocates rights based on priority of beneficial use, similar to surface appropriative rights in western states. Surface water consists of water from rain, springs, and other runoff that has not yet reached a natural watercourse. Landowners generally may use or manage surface water on their land, but they may incur liability if their actions interfere with neighboring landowners’ rights. Jurisdictions follow one of several theories: under the natural flow theory, owners may not unreasonably alter the natural drainage patterns; under the common enemy theory, surface water is treated as a common enemy that each owner may combat or divert as they wish, provided they do not cause unnecessary damage to others; and under the reasonable use theory, courts balance the utility of a landowner’s measures to manage surface water against the gravity of the harm to neighboring lands to determine liability.
cards.mnemonic: Surface water theories: N-C-R—Natural, Common enemy, Reasonable use.
cards.clozeLite: Groundwater is {{c1::underground water not in a defined channel}}, regulated by {{c2::reasonable use}} or {{c3::prior appropriation}}. Surface water drainage is governed by {{c4::natural flow}}, {{c5::common enemy}}, or {{c6::reasonable use}} theories.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Government Zoning Power, Variances, and Nonconforming Use
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 063. Government Zoning Power, Variances, and Nonconforming Use
cards.front: Government Zoning Power, Variances, and Nonconforming Use – Overview
cards.frontPrompt: What are the basic rules governing government zoning power, variances, and nonconforming uses?
cards.backPlain: Overview: 1. Zoning power: Government may enact zoning laws to reasonably control land use if authorized by an enabling act, but those ordinances must be reasonably related to the public welfare, not overly restrictive, and not racially discriminatory. 2. Variances: A variance is permission to deviate from the literal terms of a zoning ordinance. To obtain a variance, a landowner must show undue hardship and that the variance will not be contrary to the public welfare. 3. Nonconforming uses: A once lawful use made nonconforming by a new zoning law is generally protected from immediate elimination absent just compensation, although the government may phase it out via amortization so the owner can recoup the use’s value.
cards.cloze: Overview of {{c1::zoning power}}, {{c2::variances}}, and {{c3::nonconforming uses}}: 1. {{c4::Zoning power}} allows government to regulate land use under an {{c5::enabling act}}, but ordinances must serve the {{c6::public welfare}} and cannot be {{c7::overly restrictive}} or {{c8::racially discriminatory}}. 2. {{c9::Variances}} permit deviation from the literal zoning terms if the owner shows {{c10::undue hardship}} and that the variance is {{c11::not contrary to the public welfare}}. 3. {{c12::Nonconforming uses}} are once lawful uses made unlawful by new zoning and generally cannot be {{c13::eliminated immediately}} without {{c14::just compensation}}, though the government may use {{c15::amortization}} to phase them out.
cards.easyContent: Zoning power lets government regulate land use if authorized and tied to public welfare. Variances allow case‑by‑case deviations for undue hardship that do not harm public welfare. Lawful nonconforming uses generally cannot be cut off immediately without compensation, though they can be phased out through amortization.
cards.mediumContent: Government may regulate land use through zoning if authorized by an enabling act, but zoning ordinances must be reasonably related to public welfare and cannot be overly restrictive or racially discriminatory. A variance is permission to depart from a zoning ordinance when the landowner proves undue hardship and that the change will not be contrary to public welfare. A once lawful use that becomes nonconforming under new zoning is generally protected from immediate termination without just compensation, but may be phased out through amortization so the owner can recoup the use’s value.
cards.hardContent: Zoning power, variances, and nonconforming uses fit together as follows: (1) Zoning power arises from an enabling act authorizing local governments to regulate land use, but ordinances must be reasonably related to public welfare, not unduly restrictive, and not racially discriminatory. (2) Variances are individualized permissions to deviate from the literal terms of a zoning ordinance, granted only upon a showing of undue hardship and that granting the variance will not be contrary to the public welfare. (3) Nonconforming uses are once lawful existing uses rendered nonconforming by new zoning; they generally cannot be eliminated all at once without just compensation, although the government may use amortization schedules that allow the use to continue or be compensated over time while the owner recoups its value.
cards.mnemonic: Z-V-N: Zoning, Variance hardship, Nonconforming needs pay or phase-out.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) zoning power and limits, (2) variances definition and requirements, (3) nonconforming uses, compensation, and amortization.
cards.clozeLite: Government may regulate land use by {{c1::zoning}} if tied to {{c2::public welfare}}. A {{c3::variance}} needs {{c4::undue hardship}} and no harm to welfare. {{c5::Lawful nonconforming uses}} usually need pay or {{c6::amortization}} to end.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 064. Special Use Permits and Exactions
cards.backPlain: 1. Special use permits 1.1. Certain property uses require a special use permit even where zoning generally allows the type of use (for example, hospitals and drive-thrus in commercial zoning districts). 2. Exactions 2.1. An exaction is a condition the government places on approval of a new development. 2.2. The condition is usually a payment or gift of property to the government to offset the development's demands on public services. 2.3. For example: Due to population increase from a new housing development, the government will have to install new bus stops and traffic lights in surrounding areas; the government can seek some exaction (for example, a payment) from the developer. 3. Requirements for valid exactions 3.1. Nexus: There must be a rational relationship (nexus) between the exaction sought by the government and the burden on public facilities created by the development. 3.2. Proportionality: The exaction must reasonably relate, in nature and scope, to the impact of the development.
cards.frontPrompt: What are special use permits and exactions in land use law, and what constitutional requirements must exactions satisfy?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Special use permits}} 1.1. Certain property uses require a special use permit even where zoning generally allows the type of use (for example, {{c2::hospitals and drive-thrus in commercial districts}}). 2. {{c3::Exactions}} 2.1. An exaction is a {{c4::condition the government places on approval of a new development}}. 2.2. The condition is usually a {{c5::payment or gift of property to the government}} to offset the development's demands on public services. 2.3. For example: Due to population increase from a new housing development, the government will have to install new bus stops and traffic lights; the government can seek some exaction (for example, a payment) from the developer. 3. Requirements for valid exactions 3.1. {{c6::Nexus}}: There must be a {{c7::rational relationship (nexus)}} between the exaction sought by the government and the burden on public facilities created by the development. 3.2. {{c8::Proportionality}}: The exaction must {{c9::reasonably relate, in nature and scope, to the impact of the development}}.
cards.easyContent: Some otherwise allowed land uses need special use permits, and exactions are development conditions like payments or land dedications that must have a rational nexus to, and be proportional with, the development’s impact.
cards.mediumContent: Special use permits are required for certain uses—such as hospitals or drive-thrus—even in zones that generally allow that type of use. Exactions are conditions on development approval, usually requiring a payment or conveyance of property to offset the project’s impact on public services. For an exaction to be valid, there must be a rational nexus between the exaction and the burden created by the development, and the exaction must be proportional in nature and scope to that impact.
cards.hardContent: A special use permit is required for specific uses—such as hospitals or drive-thrus—even where the zoning classification generally allows that type of use. An exaction is a condition the government imposes on development approval, typically requiring the developer to make a payment or dedicate property to the government to offset increased burdens on public services. Constitutionally valid exactions must satisfy (1) nexus: a rational relationship between the exaction and the burden the development places on public facilities; and (2) proportionality: the exaction must reasonably relate, in nature and scope, to the development’s impact.
cards.mnemonic: Exactions need N-P: Nexus and Proportionality.
cards.clozeLite: Valid {{c1::exactions}} need a {{c2::rational nexus}} to the development’s burden and {{c3::proportionality}} in nature and scope to its impact.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Conflicts of Law in Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 065. Conflicts of Law in Real Property
cards.front: Conflicts of Law in Real Property
cards.backPlain: 1. Governing law for real property 1.1. Real property is subject to the law of the jurisdiction where it is situated (the situs). 1.2. For example: A dispute over property in California is generally governed by California law. 1.3. This rule applies to the disposition of real property, whether by descent, deed, or other method. 2. Contracts related to real property 2.1. Contracts related to real property are generally governed by the law of the place where the property is situated. 2.2. However, traditional conflict-of-law rules may apply if the property is merely incidental to a contract and the contract is of a personal nature.
cards.frontPrompt: In conflicts of law, which jurisdiction’s law governs interests and contracts involving real property?
cards.cloze: 1. Governing law for real property 1.1. Real property is subject to the law of the jurisdiction where it is situated (the {{c1::situs}}). 1.2. For example: A dispute over property in California is generally governed by {{c2::California law}}. 1.3. This rule applies to the {{c3::disposition of real property}}, whether by {{c4::descent}}, {{c5::deed}}, or other method. 2. Contracts related to real property 2.1. Contracts related to real property are generally governed by the law of the {{c6::place where the property is situated}}. 2.2. However, traditional {{c7::conflict-of-law rules}} may apply if the property is {{c8::merely incidental to a contract}} and the contract is of a {{c9::personal nature}}.
cards.easyContent: Real property issues are generally governed by the law of the state where the land is located, and contracts related to that land usually follow the same rule unless the land is only incidental to a personal contract.
cards.mediumContent: Under conflict-of-law principles, real property is governed by the law of the jurisdiction where the property is located (the situs), including disposition by descent, deed, or other methods. Contracts relating to real property are likewise typically governed by the law of the place where the property is situated, unless the land is merely incidental to a personal contract, in which case traditional conflicts rules may select a different governing law.
cards.hardContent: In conflicts of law, real property is governed by the law of the jurisdiction where the property is located (the situs). This situs rule applies to all dispositions of real property, including by deed, descent, or other means. Contracts related to real property are generally governed by the law of the place where the property is situated. However, if the property is only incidental to the agreement and the contract is primarily personal in nature, traditional conflict-of-law principles (such as place of contracting or most significant relationship) may determine a different governing law.
cards.mnemonic: SITUS rules the soil: land law = land’s location.
cards.clozeLite: In conflicts of law, {{c1::real property interests}} and {{c2::contracts relating to real property}} are generally governed by the {{c3::law of the situs}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Defeasible Fees – Definition and Required Language
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 001-1. Defeasible Fees – Definition and Required Language
cards.front: Defeasible Fees – Definition and Required Language
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of a defeasible fee: - A defeasible fee is a fee simple estate of potentially infinite duration that can be terminated upon the occurrence of a specified event. - It is a present fee estate vested in some person, who may lose the fee interest if the stated condition occurs. 2. Language required to create a defeasible fee: - The grant must use clear words of intent indicating that the fee estate will be forfeited or end upon a stated event. - Merely precatory language—words of desire, hope, or aspiration—is insufficient to create a defeasible fee.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a defeasible fee, and what kind of language is required to create one?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::defeasible fee}} is a {{c2::fee simple estate}} of potentially infinite duration that can be {{c3::terminated upon the occurrence of a specified event}}. It is a {{c4::present fee estate vested}} in a person, who may {{c5::lose the fee interest if the condition occurs}}. To create a defeasible fee, the grantor must use {{c6::clear words of intent}} that the estate will be {{c7::forfeited or end upon a stated event}}; mere {{c8::desire, hope, or aspiration}} is {{c9::insufficient}}.
cards.easyContent: A defeasible fee is a fee simple that might end early if a stated event happens. It is a present fee in the grantee but subject to divestment. Creating one requires clear forfeiture or conditional language, not just hopes or wishes.
cards.mediumContent: A defeasible fee is a present fee simple estate that can last forever but is subject to termination if a specified condition occurs. The grantee’s fee is vested but defeasible. To create such an estate, the instrument must use clear durational or conditional language signaling that the estate will end or be forfeited upon the event; precatory language of desire, hope, or aspiration does not suffice.
cards.hardContent: A defeasible fee is a fee simple estate that, while potentially of infinite duration, may terminate upon the occurrence of a specified event. The grantee holds a present vested fee interest that is subject to divestment if the condition occurs. Creating a defeasible fee requires clear language of forfeiture or termination—e.g., language indicating that the estate shall end, revert, or cease upon the happening of a specified event. Merely precatory wording that expresses a desire, hope, or aspiration—without clearly conditioning the continuation of the estate—is insufficient to create a defeasible fee.
cards.mnemonic: Defeasible Fee: Fee that can Fail on a Future event.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::defeasible fee}} is a {{c2::present fee simple}} that {{c3::terminates if a condition occurs}} and {{c4::requires clear durational or conditional language}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Defeasible Fees – Types and Future Interests
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 001-2. Defeasible Fees – Types and Future Interests
