cards.front: Defeasible Fees – Types and Future Interests
cards.backPlain: There are three main types of defeasible fees, each paired with a specific future interest: 1. Fee simple determinable: - The estate automatically ends upon the happening of a specified event. - When the condition occurs, the property automatically reverts to the grantor. - The grantor holds a possibility of reverter. 2. Fee simple subject to condition subsequent: - The grantor retains the power to terminate the grantee’s estate if a condition occurs. - Termination is not automatic; the grantor must take affirmative action (such as reentry) to cut off the estate. - The grantor holds a right of reentry (also called a power of termination). 3. Fee simple subject to an executory interest: - The estate automatically shifts to a third party upon the happening of a specified event. - The third party, not the grantor, holds the future interest. - That third party’s future interest is a shifting executory interest.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the three main types of defeasible fees, and what future interest accompanies each?
cards.cloze: There are three main types of {{c1::defeasible fees}}: 1. {{c2::Fee simple determinable}} – The estate {{c3::automatically ends}} upon the specified event, and the property {{c4: :automatically reverts to the grantor}}. The grantor holds a {{c5::possibility of reverter}}. 2. {{c6::Fee simple subject to condition subsequent}} – The grantor {{c7::retains the power to terminate}} the grantee’s estate if the condition occurs, but termination is {{c8::not automatic}}; the grantor must {{c9::take affirmative action (reenter)}}. The grantor holds a {{c10::right of reentry}} ({{c11::power of termination}}). 3. {{c12::Fee simple subject to an executory interest}} – Upon the event, the estate {{c13::automatically shifts to a third party}}. That third party holds a {{c14::shifting executory interest}}.
cards.easyContent: The three types of defeasible fees are: (1) fee simple determinable, which ends automatically and gives the grantor a possibility of reverter; (2) fee simple subject to condition subsequent, where the grantor must act to cut it off and holds a right of reentry; and (3) fee simple subject to an executory interest, which automatically shifts to a third party holding a shifting executory interest.
cards.mediumContent: Defeasible fees come in three main forms: (1) A fee simple determinable ends automatically when the stated event happens, and the property automatically reverts to the grantor, who holds a possibility of reverter. (2) A fee simple subject to condition subsequent does not end automatically; instead, the grantor has a reserved right of reentry (power of termination) and must affirmatively exercise it after the condition occurs to terminate the grantee’s estate. (3) A fee simple subject to an executory interest automatically shifts to a third party on the occurrence of the condition; that third party holds a shifting executory interest rather than the grantor holding any reversionary interest.
cards.hardContent: The three principal types of defeasible fees each have distinct mechanics and associated future interests: (1) Fee simple determinable: The estate automatically ends upon the occurrence of the specified event. When the condition happens, the grantee’s fee terminates by operation of law, and the property automatically reverts to the grantor. The grantor’s corresponding future interest is a possibility of reverter. (2) Fee simple subject to condition subsequent: The grantor reserves the power to terminate the grantee’s estate if a specified condition is breached. The occurrence of the condition does not itself automatically end the estate; instead, the grantor must take affirmative steps (typically reentry or bringing an action to quiet title) to cut off the grantee’s interest. The grantor’s corresponding future interest is a right of reentry, also called a power of termination. (3) Fee simple subject to an executory interest: Upon the occurrence of the specified event, the estate automatically divests the current fee holder and shifts to a designated third party. That third party’s corresponding future interest is a shifting executory interest, rather than any reversionary interest in the grantor.
cards.mnemonic: D-C-E: Determinable, Condition Subsequent, Executory (PER, RE, SE).
cards.clozeLite: Three defeasible fees: {{c1::fee simple determinable → possibility of reverter}}, {{c2::fee simple subject to condition subsequent → right of reentry}}, {{c3::fee simple subject to an executory interest → shifting executory interest}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Life Estate – Definition, Defeasibility, and Duties
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 005-1. Life Estate – Definition, Defeasibility, and Duties
cards.front: Life Estate – Definition, Defeasibility, and Duties
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of a life estate: 1.1 A life estate is a present possessory estate that lasts only for the life of a designated person, usually the life of the interest holder (the life tenant, or LT). 2. Defeasibility of life estates: 2.1 A life estate can be defeasible like fee estates (e.g., determinable, subject to condition subsequent, or subject to an executory interest) or indefeasible. 3. Rights and duties of the life tenant: 3.1 The life tenant has all ordinary ownership rights, including the right to possess, use, and enjoy the property during the measuring life. 3.2 The life tenant must maintain the property and make reasonable repairs to preserve the estate. 3.3 The life tenant cannot commit waste (affirmative, permissive, or ameliorative waste, as further developed in separate cards).
cards.frontPrompt: What is a life estate, in what ways can it be defeasible or indefeasible, and what basic duties does a life tenant owe?
cards.cloze: 1. Definition of a life estate: 1.1 A {{c1::life estate}} is a {{c2::present possessory estate}} that lasts only for the {{c3::life of a designated person}}, usually the {{c4::life tenant (LT)}}. 2. Defeasibility of life estates: 2.1 A life estate can be {{c5::defeasible like fee estates}} (e.g., {{c6::determinable, subject to condition subsequent, or subject to an executory interest}}) or {{c7::indefeasible}}. 3. Rights and duties of the life tenant: 3.1 The life tenant has {{c8::ordinary ownership rights}} (possess, use, and enjoy the property) during the measuring life. 3.2 The life tenant must {{c9::maintain the property and make reasonable repairs}}. 3.3 The life tenant {{c10::cannot commit waste}}.
cards.easyContent: A life estate is a present possessory estate lasting for a life. It can be defeasible or indefeasible. The life tenant has ordinary ownership rights but must maintain the property, make reasonable repairs, and avoid waste.
cards.mediumContent: A life estate is a present possessory estate measured by a designated life, usually the life tenant’s. It can be defeasible (e.g., determinable, subject to condition subsequent, or subject to an executory interest) or indefeasible. The life tenant may possess and use the property, but must maintain it, make reasonable repairs, and not commit waste.
cards.hardContent: A life estate is a present possessory estate that endures only for the duration of a specified life, typically the life tenant’s. Like fee estates, it may be structured as defeasible (e.g., determinable, subject to condition subsequent, or subject to an executory interest) or as indefeasible. The life tenant enjoys ordinary ownership rights, including possession and use, but owes duties to preserve the estate: maintaining the property, making reasonable repairs, and refraining from committing waste (affirmative, permissive, or ameliorative).
cards.mnemonic: "LIFE": Limited Interest, For a life, must avoid waste.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::life estate}} is a {{c2::present possessory estate}} measured by a {{c3::designated life}}; the life tenant must {{c4::maintain and repair}} and {{c5::avoid waste}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 005-2. Life Estate – Reversion and Remainder
cards.backPlain: 1. Future interests following a life estate: 1.1 Reversion: 1.1.1 A reversion is the future interest retained by the grantor when a life estate does not provide for disposition of the property to a third party. 1.1.2 Example: O grants "to A for life." A is the life tenant; O has a reversion that becomes possessory when A dies. 1.2 Remainder: 1.2.1 A remainder is the future interest in a third person that becomes possessory upon the natural expiration of the preceding life estate. 1.2.2 The remainder is created in the same instrument that creates the life estate. 1.2.3 Example: O grants "to A for life, then to B." A is the life tenant; B has a remainder that becomes possessory when A dies.
cards.frontPrompt: What future interests can follow a life estate, and how do reversion and remainder differ in terms of who holds them and how they arise?
cards.cloze: 1. Future interests following a life estate: 1.1 {{c1::Reversion}}: 1.1.1 A reversion is the {{c2::future interest retained by the grantor}} when a life estate does not provide for disposition of the property to a third party. 1.1.2 Example: O grants "{{c3::to A for life}}." A is the life tenant; {{c4::O has a reversion}} that becomes possessory when A dies. 1.2 {{c5::Remainder}}: 1.2.1 A remainder is the {{c6::future interest in a third person}} that becomes possessory upon the {{c7::natural expiration of the preceding life estate}}. 1.2.2 The remainder is {{c8::created in the same instrument}} that creates the life estate. 1.2.3 Example: O grants "{{c9::to A for life, then to B}}." A is the life tenant; {{c10::B has a remainder}} that becomes possessory when A dies.
cards.easyContent: After a life estate, either the grantor can hold a reversion or a third party can hold a remainder. A reversion stays with the grantor if no third-party taker is named; a remainder is given to a third person in the same instrument as the life estate.
cards.mediumContent: When a life estate ends, a future interest becomes possessory. If the grantor keeps the future interest because no third-party successor is named, it is a reversion. If the future interest is given in the same instrument to a third party to take when the life estate naturally ends, it is a remainder.
cards.hardContent: A life estate is normally followed by a future interest. If the grantor retains the interest when conveying "to A for life" and does not specify a third-party taker, the grantor holds a reversion, which becomes possessory at A’s death. If the grantor names a third person to take on the natural expiration of the life estate in the same instrument—e.g., "to A for life, then to B"—that third person holds a remainder. Both reversion and remainder are non-possessory until the life estate ends, but a reversion is in the grantor, whereas a remainder is in a third party.
cards.mnemonic: Reversion RETURNS to grantor; remainder REMAINS with another.
cards.clozeLite: After a {{c1::life estate}}, the {{c2::grantor}} holds a {{c3::reversion}} if no third party is named, but a {{c4::remainder}} is given to a {{c5::third party}} in the same instrument.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Life Estate Pur Autre Vie and Transfer of Life Estates
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 005-3. Life Estate Pur Autre Vie and Transfer of Life Estates
cards.front: Life Estate Pur Autre Vie and Transfer of Life Estates
cards.backPlain: 1. Life estate pur autre vie (p.a.v.): 1.1 A life estate may be measured by the life of someone other than the life tenant. 1.2 Example: O grants "to A for the life of B." A is the life tenant, holding the property until B dies, at which point the property reverts to O (or passes as otherwise provided by reversion or remainder). 2. Transfer of life estates and resulting pur autre vie interests: 2.1 A life tenant may transfer her life estate to another person. 2.2 When the life tenant transfers her life estate, the transferee holds a life estate pur autre vie measured by the original measuring life. 2.3 Example: O grants "to A for life." A then transfers her life estate to B. B holds a life estate pur autre vie measured by A’s life. When A dies, B’s interest terminates, and the property goes to O (reversion) or to any named remainder-holder.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a life estate pur autre vie, and what happens when a life tenant transfers her life estate to another person?
cards.cloze: 1. Life estate pur autre vie (p.a.v.): 1.1 A {{c1::life estate pur autre vie}} is a life estate measured by the {{c2::life of someone other than the life tenant}}. 1.2 Example: O grants "{{c3::to A for the life of B}}." A is the life tenant, holding the property until {{c4::B dies}}, at which point the property {{c5::reverts to O or passes under any reversion or remainder}}. 2. Transfer of life estates: 2.1 A {{c6::life tenant may transfer her life estate}} to another person. 2.2 The transferee then holds a {{c7::life estate pur autre vie}} measured by the {{c8::original measuring life}}. 2.3 Example: O grants "to A for life" and A transfers to B. {{c9::B holds a life estate pur autre vie measured by A’s life}}. When {{c10::A dies}}, B’s interest {{c11::terminates}}, and the property {{c12::returns to the grantor (reversion) or passes to any remainder-holder}}.
cards.easyContent: A life estate pur autre vie is a life estate measured by someone else’s life. If a life tenant transfers her estate, the transferee holds a life estate pur autre vie that ends when the original measuring life ends, at which point the reversion or remainder becomes possessory.
cards.mediumContent: A life estate pur autre vie arises when a life estate is measured by a third person’s life—for example, "to A for the life of B." A holds the estate until B dies, and then the property returns to the grantor or passes under any remainder. When a life tenant transfers her life estate, the transferee takes a life estate pur autre vie measured by the original life; the transferee’s interest automatically ends when that measuring life ends.
cards.hardContent: A life estate pur autre vie exists when the duration of the estate is tied to a life other than that of the current holder. In a grant "to A for the life of B," A enjoys possession only while B is alive; upon B’s death, O’s reversion (or a named remainder) becomes possessory. Similarly, if O grants "to A for life" and A conveys her life estate to B, B holds a life estate pur autre vie measured by A’s life. B’s interest terminates automatically at A’s death, regardless of B’s own lifespan, and title then shifts according to the grant’s future interests (reversion or remainder).
cards.mnemonic: Pur autre vie: "for another's life"—measured by someone else.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::life estate pur autre vie}} is measured by {{c2::another person’s life}}; a transferee’s interest {{c3::ends when that measuring life ends}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Doctrine of Waste – General Rule and Types
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 006-1. Doctrine of Waste – General Rule and Types
cards.front: Doctrine of Waste – General Rule and Types
cards.backPlain: Doctrine of Waste – General Rule and Types 1. General rule: 1.1 A life tenant (LT) cannot commit acts that constitute an unreasonable use of the land and/or injure the interests of a future interest holder; doing so constitutes waste. 2. Types of waste: 2.1 Affirmative (voluntary) waste – acts of commission that overuse or exploit the property or its natural resources. 2.2 Permissive waste – harm to the property due to the LT's neglect or failure to maintain, repair, or pay carrying charges. 2.3 Ameliorative waste – LT acts that materially change the property but economically benefit the land.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general doctrine of waste for life tenants, and what are the three main categories of waste?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::doctrine of waste}}, a {{c2::life tenant (LT)}} cannot commit acts that constitute an {{c3::unreasonable use of the land}} and/or injure the interests of a {{c4::future interest holder}}; doing so constitutes {{c5::waste}}. There are three main types of waste: - {{c6::Affirmative (voluntary) waste}} – acts of commission that overuse or exploit the property or its natural resources. - {{c7::Permissive waste}} – harm to the property due to the LT's neglect or failure to maintain, repair, or pay carrying charges. - {{c8::Ameliorative waste}} – LT acts that materially change the property but economically benefit the land.
cards.easyContent: Waste occurs when a life tenant unreasonably uses or fails to care for property in a way that harms future interest holders. The three types are affirmative, permissive, and ameliorative waste.
cards.mediumContent: The doctrine of waste limits what a life tenant may do with the property, to protect future interest holders. Waste is any unreasonable use, change, or neglect that injures their interests. It is divided into: affirmative (voluntary) waste—overuse or exploitation; permissive waste—harm from neglect; and ameliorative waste—value-increasing changes that materially alter the property.
cards.hardContent: The doctrine of waste provides that a life tenant may not unreasonably use, change, or neglect the property so as to injure the interests of future interest holders. Such conduct is called waste and is grouped into three categories: (1) affirmative (voluntary) waste, involving acts of commission that overuse or exploit the property or its natural resources; (2) permissive waste, involving harm from the life tenant's neglect, including failure to maintain, repair, or pay taxes and other carrying costs; and (3) ameliorative waste, consisting of material alterations that increase the property's economic value but still change its character.
cards.mnemonic: Waste = "APA": Affirmative, Permissive, Ameliorative.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::doctrine of waste}} limits what a {{c2::life tenant}} may do to protect {{c3::future interest holders}} and is divided into {{c4::affirmative}}, {{c5::permissive}}, and {{c6::ameliorative}} waste.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Affirmative (Voluntary) Waste – Natural Resources and Open Mines
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 006-2. Affirmative (Voluntary) Waste – Natural Resources and Open Mines
cards.front: Affirmative Waste – Natural Resources and Open Mines
cards.backPlain: Affirmative (Voluntary) Waste – Natural Resources and Open Mines 1. Definition: 1.1 Affirmative (voluntary) waste occurs when the life tenant (LT) engages in acts of commission that unreasonably consume, exploit, or deplete the property or its natural resources. 2. General rule on natural resources: 2.1 The LT cannot consume or exploit natural resources (e.g., minerals, oil, gas, timber) on the land except in limited circumstances. 3. Exceptions allowing exploitation of natural resources: 3.1 Where necessary for repairs or maintenance of the land. 3.2 When the grant expressly gives the right to exploit. 3.3 If the land was used for exploitation of resources prior to the grant (i.e., prior use). 3.4 Open mines doctrine: If exploitation occurred before the life estate, the LT may only extract from already-open mines; opening new mines or substantially expanding exploitation beyond prior use is prohibited.
cards.frontPrompt: What is affirmative (voluntary) waste with respect to natural resources, and what are the exceptions including the open mines doctrine?
cards.cloze: Affirmative (voluntary) waste occurs when a {{c1::life tenant (LT)}} engages in acts of commission that unreasonably consume, exploit, or deplete the {{c2::property or its natural resources}}. General rule: The LT {{c3::cannot consume or exploit natural resources}} on the land except in limited circumstances: - {{c4::Necessary for repairs or maintenance}} of the land. - When the grant {{c5::expressly gives the right to exploit}}. - When the land was used for {{c6::exploitation of resources prior to the grant}} (prior use). - {{c7::Open mines doctrine}}: If exploitation occurred before the life estate, the LT may only extract from {{c8::already-open mines}} and may not open new mines or substantially expand beyond prior use.
cards.easyContent: Affirmative waste is unreasonable exploitation of the land or its natural resources. A life tenant generally may not extract resources unless needed for repairs, expressly authorized, consistent with prior use, or under the open mines doctrine (only from already-open mines).
cards.mediumContent: Affirmative (voluntary) waste involves acts of commission by a life tenant that unreasonably consume or exploit the property or its natural resources. The life tenant is generally barred from extracting minerals, timber, or similar resources except: (1) when reasonably necessary for repairs or maintenance; (2) when the grant expressly authorizes exploitation; (3) when exploitation is consistent with use that existed prior to the grant; and (4) under the open mines doctrine, which permits continued extraction from mines already open before the life estate, but not opening new ones or expanding exploitation beyond prior use.
cards.hardContent: Affirmative (voluntary) waste consists of unreasonable acts by the life tenant that consume or exploit the corpus of the land, especially its natural resources. As a default, the life tenant may not extract minerals, oil, gas, timber, or similar resources because this depletes the estate and injures future interest holders. However, exploitation is permitted when: (1) it is reasonably necessary for repairs or maintenance of the land; (2) the grant expressly authorizes exploitation; (3) the land was already being used for resource extraction before the grant, so continuation is consistent with the established use; and (4) under the open mines doctrine, if mines or wells were already open prior to the life estate, the life tenant may continue to extract from those already-open operations but may not open new mines or otherwise materially expand exploitation beyond the historical pattern.
cards.mnemonic: Affirmative waste = "REPO": Repairs, Express grant, Prior use, Open mines.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::life tenant}} commits {{c2::affirmative (voluntary) waste}} by {{c3::unreasonably exploiting natural resources}}, unless {{c4::REPO: Repairs, Express grant, Prior use, Open mines}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Permissive Waste – Neglect and Life Tenant’s Duties
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 006-3. Permissive Waste – Neglect and Life Tenant’s Duties
cards.front: Permissive Waste – Neglect and Duties of Life Tenant
cards.backPlain: Permissive Waste – Neglect and Duties of Life Tenant 1. Definition: 1.1 Permissive waste is harm to the property due to the life tenant's (LT's) neglect or failure to act. 2. Duty to repair and maintain: 2.1 The LT has a duty to repair and maintain the property in a reasonable state of repair. 2.2 This duty is limited to the extent of income or profits derived from the land, or its reasonable rental value. 3. Duty to pay carrying charges: 3.1 The LT must pay ordinary carrying charges, including: 3.1.1 Property taxes. 3.1.2 Interest on encumbrances (e.g., mortgage interest) to the extent required of the LT. 3.1.3 Similar ongoing charges necessary to preserve the property. 4. Reimbursement rights: 4.1 Future interest holders who assume the LT's obligations (e.g., pay taxes or necessary repairs to prevent loss) are entitled to reimbursement from the LT, to the extent of the LT's duty.
cards.frontPrompt: What is permissive waste, what duties does a life tenant have to avoid it, and what are the limits and reimbursement rules?
cards.cloze: Permissive waste is {{c1::harm to the property due to the life tenant's (LT's) neglect or failure to act}}. The LT's duties to avoid permissive waste include: - Duty to {{c2::repair and maintain}} the property in a reasonable state of repair, limited to the {{c3::income or profits derived from the land, or its reasonable rental value}}. - Duty to pay ordinary {{c4::carrying charges}}, including {{c5::property taxes}}, {{c6::interest on encumbrances}}, and other similar ongoing charges necessary to preserve the property. If {{c7::future interest holders}} assume the LT's obligations (e.g., pay taxes or necessary repairs), they are entitled to {{c8::reimbursement}} from the LT to the extent of the LT's duty.
cards.easyContent: Permissive waste is harm caused by the life tenant’s neglect. The life tenant must reasonably maintain and repair the property and pay taxes and similar carrying charges, but only up to the income or reasonable rental value. Future interest holders who pay these costs can seek reimbursement.
cards.mediumContent: Permissive waste arises when a life tenant allows property to deteriorate through inaction. To avoid permissive waste, the life tenant must keep the property in reasonable repair and pay ordinary carrying charges such as property taxes and interest on encumbrances. These duties are limited by the amount of income or profits from the land, or by its reasonable rental value. If future interest holders step in to pay these obligations to protect the property, they can seek reimbursement from the life tenant to the extent of the life tenant’s duty.
cards.hardContent: Permissive waste is waste by omission—harm to the property resulting from the life tenant's failure to act. The life tenant must exercise reasonable care to maintain and repair the premises and is obligated to pay ordinary carrying costs such as property taxes, interest on encumbrances, and similar charges that are necessary to preserve the property. However, these obligations are not unlimited: the life tenant's duty runs only up to the amount of income or profits actually derived from the land, or its reasonable rental value if not rented. If future interest holders pay taxes, interest, or necessary repairs to prevent loss or foreclosure, they are entitled to reimbursement from the life tenant to the extent that these payments fall within the life tenant's capped duty.
cards.mnemonic: Permissive waste = R-TIC: Repair, Taxes, Interest, Carrying charges.
cards.clozeLite: Permissive waste is {{c1::waste by omission}} when a {{c2::life tenant allows deterioration}} and must {{c3::repair and pay ordinary carrying charges}} only {{c4::up to income or reasonable rental value}}; future interest holders who pay {{c5::can seek reimbursement}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 006-4. Ameliorative Waste – Value-Increasing Changes
cards.backPlain: Ameliorative Waste – Value-Increasing Changes 1. Definition: 1.1 Ameliorative waste consists of life tenant (LT) acts that materially change the property but economically benefit the land (i.e., increase its value). 2. Common law rule: 2.1 At common law, ameliorative waste was generally prohibited. 2.2 The LT could not substantially alter the property even if the change increased its market value. 3. Modern rule: 3.1 In most modern jurisdictions, ameliorative waste is usually permitted. 3.2 Courts especially allow changes where neighborhood conditions have changed such that the existing use is no longer reasonable or valuable, and the alteration increases the property's value. 3.3 Some courts consider whether future interest holders object and may require compensation or consent in close cases.
cards.frontPrompt: What is ameliorative waste, and how do common law and modern rules treat value-increasing changes by a life tenant?
cards.cloze: Ameliorative waste consists of {{c1::life tenant acts that materially change the property but economically benefit the land}}. Under the {{c2::common law rule}}, ameliorative waste was generally {{c3::prohibited}}, and a life tenant could not substantially alter the property even if the change {{c4::increased its market value}}. In {{c5::most modern jurisdictions}}, ameliorative waste is usually {{c6::permitted}}, especially where {{c7::neighborhood conditions have changed}} and the alteration {{c8::increases the property's value}}.
cards.easyContent: Ameliorative waste is when a life tenant makes major changes that increase the property’s value. Common law usually barred such changes, but modern law generally allows them, especially if neighborhood conditions have changed and the change increases value.
cards.mediumContent: Ameliorative waste occurs when a life tenant materially alters the property in a way that benefits it economically. At common law, such alterations were treated as waste and were typically forbidden, even if they raised market value. Modern courts, however, tend to allow value-increasing changes, particularly when surrounding neighborhood conditions have changed so that the old use is less suitable and the new use better reflects the property's highest and best use.
cards.hardContent: Ameliorative waste refers to substantial alterations by a life tenant that change the character of the property but enhance its economic value. Traditional common law prioritized preserving the donor's intent and the property's original character, so it generally prohibited such changes regardless of any increase in value. In contrast, most modern jurisdictions take a more economic and pragmatic approach: courts commonly permit ameliorative changes, especially where surrounding neighborhood conditions have evolved—e.g., residential to commercial—and the proposed alteration would increase the property's market value. Some courts will factor in the wishes of future interest holders and may condition approval on their consent or compensation, but the default modern tendency is to allow reasonable, value-increasing changes.
cards.mnemonic: AMELIORATE: Ancient bars, Modern Embraces Legal Improvements Often Raising Added Taxable Equity.
cards.clozeLite: At {{c1::common law}}, {{c2::ameliorative waste}} (value-increasing changes) was {{c3::treated as forbidden waste}}, but {{c4::modern courts usually allow}} such {{c5::value-increasing changes when neighborhood conditions change}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 007-1. Remainders – Definition and Characteristics
cards.frontPrompt: What is a remainder in real property, and what are its key creation and transferability characteristics (including how it differs from an executory interest)?
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of a remainder: 1.1 A remainder is a future interest in a third person (someone other than the grantor). 1.2 It becomes possessory immediately upon the natural termination of a prior estate of known, fixed duration (usually a life estate or term of years). 1.3 It does not cut short the prior estate; it simply waits for that estate to end naturally. Example: O grants "to A for life, then to B." A has a life estate; B has a remainder. 2. Creation of a remainder: 2.1 A remainder must be expressly created in the same conveyance in which the preceding estate is created. 3. Transferability and distinction from executory interests: 3.1 A remainder is freely transferable: it is alienable (transferable inter vivos), devisable (by will), and descendible (by intestacy). 3.2 A true remainder cannot cut off or divest an interest held by a prior transferee. 3.3 If a supposed "remainder" would cut off or divest a prior transferee, it is actually an executory interest, not a remainder.
cards.cloze: A {{c1::remainder}} is a {{c2::future interest in a third person}} (someone other than the grantor) that becomes possessory {{c3::immediately upon the natural termination}} of a prior estate of known, fixed duration (usually a life estate or term of years), and {{c4::does not cut short the prior estate}}. A remainder must be {{c5::expressly created in the same conveyance}} in which the preceding estate is created. A remainder is {{c6::alienable, devisable, and descendible}}. A true remainder {{c7::cannot cut off or divest an interest held by a prior transferee}}; if it does, it is an {{c8::executory interest}}, not a remainder.
cards.easyContent: A remainder is a future interest in someone other than the grantor that waits for a prior life estate or term of years to end naturally and never cuts it short. It must be created in the same instrument as the prior estate, is freely transferable, and if it would divest a prior transferee, it is an executory interest instead.
cards.mediumContent: A remainder is a future interest in a third person that becomes possessory only when a preceding fixed estate (like a life estate) naturally terminates, without cutting that estate short. It must be expressly created in the same conveyance as the prior estate. Remainders are fully transferable—alienable, devisable, and descendible—and cannot divest a prior transferee; interests that divest are executory interests, not remainders.
cards.hardContent: A remainder is defined as a future interest in a third person (not the grantor) that becomes possessory immediately upon the natural termination of a prior estate of known, fixed duration, such as a life estate or term of years. It never cuts short the prior estate; instead, it passively waits for that estate to end. Remainders must be expressly created in the same instrument that creates the prior estate. They are fully transferable: alienable inter vivos, devisable by will, and descendible by intestacy. A crucial limitation is that a true remainder cannot cut off or divest a prior transferee’s interest; if the future interest operates by divesting a prior transferee, it is classified as an executory interest instead of a remainder.
cards.mnemonic: "Remainder remains"—it waits; if it cuts off, it’s executory.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::remainder}} is a {{c2::future interest in a third person}} that {{c3::waits for a prior fixed estate to end naturally}} and {{c4::cannot divest a prior transferee (otherwise executory interest)}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 007-2. Remainders – Types of Vested Remainders
cards.frontPrompt: What are the three types of vested remainders, and how is each defined and illustrated?
cards.backPlain: 1. Vested remainders – overview: 1.1 A vested remainder is a remainder given to an ascertained person (or persons) and not subject to a condition precedent. 1.2 There are three major types of vested remainders: indefeasibly vested, vested subject to total divestment, and vested subject to open. 2. Indefeasibly vested remainder: 2.1 Definition: A remainder in an identified taker with no conditions precedent remaining; the taker is certain to take possession upon the natural termination of the prior estate. 2.2 Example: "To A for life, then to B." A has a life estate; B has an indefeasibly vested remainder. 3. Vested remainder subject to total divestment (subject to a condition subsequent): 3.1 Definition: A remainder that is presently vested in an ascertained taker but may be cut off by a condition subsequent. 3.2 Example: "To A for life, then to B, but if B ever divorces, then to C." B has a vested remainder subject to total divestment in favor of C. 4. Vested remainder subject to open (class gift): 4.1 Definition: A remainder vested in at least one member of a class, where the class is capable of expanding (opening) to let in additional members. 4.2 Example: "To A for life, then to A’s children." If A has one child at the time of the grant, that child has a vested remainder subject to open, because later-born children of A can also share in the remainder.
cards.cloze: A {{c1::vested remainder}} is a remainder given to an {{c2::ascertained person}} and {{c3::not subject to a condition precedent}}. There are three main types: 1. {{c4::Indefeasibly vested remainder}} – a remainder in an {{c5::identified taker with no conditions precedent}} remaining, so the taker is certain to take possession when the prior estate ends. Example: "To A for life, then to B" – B has an indefeasibly vested remainder. 2. {{c6::Vested remainder subject to total divestment}} – a vested remainder that may be {{c7::cut off by a condition subsequent}}. Example: "To A for life, then to B, but if B ever divorces, then to C" – B has a vested remainder subject to total divestment. 3. {{c8::Vested remainder subject to open}} (a {{c9::class gift}}) – a remainder {{c10::vested in at least one member of a class}} where the class is {{c11::capable of expanding}}. Example: "To A for life, then to A’s children" – if A has one child, that child has a vested remainder subject to open in favor of later-born children.
cards.easyContent: Vested remainders are given to known takers without any condition precedent. They come in three types: indefeasibly vested (certain to take), vested subject to total divestment (could be cut off by a later condition), and vested subject to open (a class gift where at least one member is in, but the class can grow).
cards.mediumContent: A vested remainder is a future interest in an ascertained person that is not subject to any condition precedent to becoming possessory. The three types are: (1) indefeasibly vested remainders, where the named taker is certain to take upon the prior estate’s natural end; (2) vested remainders subject to total divestment, where the interest is vested now but can be cut off by a condition subsequent; and (3) vested remainders subject to open, where at least one class member holds a vested share, but the class can still expand to include additional takers.
cards.hardContent: Vested remainders are remainders that are (1) given to an ascertained or identified person and (2) not subject to any condition precedent to becoming possessory. They are broken down into: • Indefeasibly vested remainders: the taker is identified and there are no remaining conditions precedent, so the interest is certain to become possessory upon natural termination of the prior estate (e.g., "To A for life, then to B"). • Vested remainders subject to total divestment: the interest is vested in an ascertained taker, but it is subject to a condition subsequent that can cut it off completely (e.g., "To A for life, then to B, but if B ever divorces, then to C" – B’s remainder is vested now but defeasible by the divorce condition). • Vested remainders subject to open (class gifts): the interest is vested in at least one member of a class, but the class remains open so that additional persons can join and share in the interest (e.g., "To A for life, then to A’s children" when A already has one child – that child has a vested remainder subject to open in favor of later-born children).
cards.mnemonic: Vested types = "I-D-O": Indefeasibly vested, Divestment, Open.
cards.clozeLite: The three types of vested remainders are {{c1::indefeasibly vested}}, {{c2::vested subject to total divestment}}, and {{c3::vested subject to open}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Remainders – Contingent Remainders and Executory Interests
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 007-3. Remainders – Contingent Remainders and Executory Interests
cards.front: Remainders – Contingent Remainders and Executory Interests
cards.frontPrompt: When is a remainder contingent, and how do contingent remainders differ from executory interests?
cards.backPlain: 1. Contingent remainders – definition: 1.1 A remainder is contingent if it does not meet the requirements for a vested remainder. 1.2 Specifically, a remainder is contingent if any of the following apply: (a) There is a condition precedent to the future interest becoming possessory; or (b) The future interest is given to an unascertained or unborn taker; or (c) Both a condition precedent and an unascertained or unborn taker are present. 2. Examples of contingent remainders: 2.1 Condition precedent: "To A for life, then to B if B graduates from law school." B’s remainder is contingent on graduation (a condition precedent). 2.2 Unascertained taker: "To A for life, then to A’s first grandchild to reach 21." If A has no qualifying grandchild yet, the remainder is contingent because the taker is unascertained/unborn. 3. Distinction from executory interests: 3.1 A contingent remainder must still follow the natural termination of the prior estate and cannot divest a prior transferee. 3.2 If the future interest instead cuts short or divests a prior transferee’s interest (rather than waiting for natural termination), it is an executory interest, not a contingent remainder. 3.3 Put differently, contingent remainders are conditional future interests that "wait" for the prior estate to end naturally, while executory interests "spring" or "shift" by divesting or cutting off an earlier interest.
cards.cloze: A {{c1::contingent remainder}} is a remainder that fails the requirements for vesting. A remainder is contingent if: • There is a {{c2::condition precedent}} to the future interest becoming possessory; or • The future interest is given to an {{c3::unascertained or unborn taker}}; or • {{c4::Both}} a condition precedent and an unascertained taker are present. Contingent remainders still {{c5::wait for the natural termination}} of the prior estate and {{c6::do not divest a prior transferee}}. If a future interest instead {{c7::cuts off or divests}} a prior transferee’s interest, it is an {{c8::executory interest}}, not a contingent remainder.
cards.easyContent: A contingent remainder is a remainder that is not yet vested because there is a condition precedent, an unascertained/unborn taker, or both. It still waits for the prior estate to end naturally. If the future interest would instead cut off a prior transferee, it is an executory interest, not a contingent remainder.
cards.mediumContent: Contingent remainders arise when a remainder is subject to a condition precedent, is given to an unascertained or unborn person, or both. Although they are conditional or uncertain, they are still remainders: they become possessory, if at all, only when the prior estate naturally ends and they do not divest any prior transferee. By contrast, executory interests operate by cutting off or divesting an earlier interest, so they do not qualify as remainders.
cards.hardContent: A contingent remainder is any remainder that does not qualify as vested—either because there is an unsatisfied condition precedent to possession, because the taker is unascertained or unborn, or because both are true. For example, "To A for life, then to B if B graduates from law school" creates a contingent remainder in B, conditional on graduation. Likewise, a gift "To A for life, then to A’s first grandchild to reach 21" is contingent so long as no grandchild has yet satisfied the condition and the taker is unascertained. Crucially, contingent remainders still wait for the natural termination of the prior estate and do not cut short any prior transferee. If the future interest instead operates by divesting or cutting off a prior transferee’s interest—such as "To A, but if B returns from Rome, then to B"—the interest is classified as an executory interest (springing or shifting), not as a contingent remainder.
cards.mnemonic: C-U-B, Don’t Cut: Condition, Unascertained, Both; no cutting—else executory.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::contingent remainder}} is contingent if there is a {{c2::condition precedent}}, an {{c3::unascertained or unborn taker}}, or both, and it {{c4::waits for the prior estate to end naturally}} instead of {{c5::cutting off a prior transferee}} (which would be an {{c6::executory interest}}).

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 008-1. Vested Remainder – Definition and Limitations
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of a vested remainder 1.1 A vested remainder is a future interest in a transferee that automatically becomes possessory upon the natural expiration of the preceding estate. 2. Limitations on vested remainders 2.1 By definition, a remainder is vested only if: 2.1.1 It is not subject to any condition precedent; and 2.1.2 It is vested in an ascertained (known) person. 2.2 If an interest is subject to a condition precedent or held by an unknown or unascertained person, it is a contingent remainder, not a vested remainder.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a vested remainder, and what limitations must be met for a remainder to be vested rather than contingent?
cards.cloze: 1. Definition of a vested remainder 1.1 A {{c1::vested remainder}} is a {{c2::future interest in a transferee}} that automatically becomes {{c3::possessory upon the natural expiration of the preceding estate}}. 2. Limitations on vested remainders 2.1 A remainder is vested only if: 2.1.1 It is {{c4::not subject to any condition precedent}}; and 2.1.2 It is vested in an {{c5::ascertained (known) person}}. 2.2 If an interest is {{c6::subject to a condition precedent}} or held by an {{c7::unknown or unascertained person}}, it is a {{c8::contingent remainder}}, not a vested remainder.
cards.easyContent: A vested remainder is a future interest in a transferee that will automatically become possessory when the prior estate naturally ends. It must not be subject to a condition precedent and must be given to a known, ascertained person; otherwise it is a contingent remainder.
cards.mediumContent: A vested remainder is a future interest in a transferee that becomes possessory automatically when the prior estate naturally expires. It is vested only if there is no condition precedent attached to taking possession and the remainderman is an ascertained (known) person. If either a condition precedent exists or the taker is unascertained, the interest is a contingent remainder rather than a vested one.
cards.hardContent: A vested remainder is a future interest in a transferee that is ready to become possessory upon the natural termination of the preceding estate, without any further conditions needing to occur. By definition, a vested remainder cannot be subject to any condition precedent and must be held by an ascertained (known and identified) person. When a supposed remainder is either subject to a condition that must occur before the interest can become possessory, or is given to an unknown or unascertained person (such as "to A for life, then to A’s first child" when A has no children yet), the interest is categorized as a contingent remainder instead of a vested remainder.
cards.mnemonic: Vested = ready to possess: no condition precedent and a known taker.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::vested remainder}} is a future interest that {{c2::automatically becomes possessory}} when the prior estate ends, with {{c3::no condition precedent}} and {{c4::an ascertained taker}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 008-2. Vested Remainder – Types
cards.backPlain: 1. Three types of vested remainders 1.1 Indefeasibly vested remainder 1.1.1 Becomes possessory immediately and certainly upon termination of the prior estate. 1.1.2 There is no condition subsequent that can cut off the interest once it becomes possessory. 1.2 Vested remainder subject to total divestment 1.2.1 The interest is vested, but it is subject to a condition subsequent. 1.2.2 The remainderman can be divested after taking possession if the condition subsequent occurs. 1.3 Vested remainder subject to open (class gift) 1.3.1 The remainder is vested in a described class of takers, at least one of whom is alive and capable of taking possession. 1.3.2 The class can expand as additional qualifying members are born or come into existence. 1.3.3 The interest of existing class members can be partially reduced as the class opens to additional members.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the three types of vested remainders and how do they differ (indefeasible, subject to total divestment, and subject to open)?
cards.cloze: 1. Three types of vested remainders 1.1 {{c1::Indefeasibly vested remainder}} 1.1.1 Becomes {{c2::possessory immediately and certainly}} upon termination of the prior estate. 1.1.2 There is {{c3::no condition subsequent}} that can cut off the interest once it becomes possessory. 1.2 {{c4::Vested remainder subject to total divestment}} 1.2.1 The interest is vested, but it is subject to a {{c5::condition subsequent}}. 1.2.2 The remainderman can be {{c6::divested after taking possession}} if the condition subsequent occurs. 1.3 {{c7::Vested remainder subject to open}} ({{c8::class gift}}) 1.3.1 The remainder is vested in a described {{c9::class of takers}}, at least one of whom is {{c10::alive and capable of taking possession}}. 1.3.2 The class can {{c11::expand as additional qualifying members are born}}. 1.3.3 The share of existing class members can be {{c12::partially reduced}} as the class opens to additional members.
cards.easyContent: The three types of vested remainders are: (1) an indefeasibly vested remainder, which is certain to become possessory when the prior estate ends; (2) a vested remainder subject to total divestment, which is vested but can be cut off by a condition subsequent after possession; and (3) a vested remainder subject to open, where at least one class member is vested but the class can grow, shrinking existing members’ shares.
cards.mediumContent: Indefeasibly vested remainders are certain to become possessory immediately when the prior estate ends, with no condition subsequent that can cut them off. A vested remainder subject to total divestment is presently vested in an ascertained person but is subject to a condition subsequent that can divest the interest after it becomes possessory. A vested remainder subject to open is vested in a described class of takers, at least one of whom is alive and capable of taking, but the class can expand as more qualifying members appear, which can reduce the shares of existing class members.
cards.hardContent: Vested remainders fall into three main categories. An indefeasibly vested remainder is a vested interest that is guaranteed to become possessory immediately upon the natural termination of the prior estate, with no condition subsequent that might divest it. A vested remainder subject to total divestment is presently vested in an ascertained remainderman, but the remainderman’s interest is subject to a condition subsequent; if that condition occurs after possession begins, the remainderman’s interest is cut off. A vested remainder subject to open arises in the context of a class gift, where the remainder is vested in a described class of takers and at least one member is already alive and capable of taking, but the class remains open to additional qualifying members, so the shares of existing members can be reduced as the class expands.
cards.mnemonic: Types: I-D-O — Indefeasible, Divested, Open-class.
cards.clozeLite: Three types: {{c1::indefeasibly vested remainder}}, {{c2::vested remainder subject to total divestment}}, and {{c3::vested remainder subject to open}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Vested Remainder – Class Gifts and Rule of Convenience
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 008-3. Vested Remainder – Class Gifts and Rule of Convenience
cards.front: Vested Remainder – Class Gifts and Rule of Convenience
cards.backPlain: 1. Open vs. closed class in class gifts 1.1 A class is "open" when new members can still be added (for example, while the life tenant is still alive and capable of having children). 1.2 A class "closes" when no new members can be created (for example, at the death of the life tenant, or when it is otherwise impossible to add qualifying members). 2. Rule of Convenience 2.1 The Rule of Convenience is a default rule that closes a class whenever any member of the class is entitled to demand distribution of her share. 2.2 Once the class closes under the Rule of Convenience, later-born or later-qualifying persons are excluded and take nothing from that class gift. 3. Relationship to vested remainders subject to open 3.1 A vested remainder subject to open is a class gift where at least one class member’s interest is already vested, but the class remains open to additional members until it closes. 3.2 The timing of class closing—either naturally when no more members can be created or earlier under the Rule of Convenience—determines who shares in the vested class gift.
cards.frontPrompt: How do open and closed classes work in class gifts, and what does the Rule of Convenience do in relation to vested remainders subject to open?
cards.cloze: 1. Open vs. closed class in class gifts 1.1 A class is {{c1::open}} when new members can still be added (for example, while the life tenant is still alive and capable of having children). 1.2 A class {{c2::closes}} when no new members can be created (for example, at the {{c3::death of the life tenant}} or when it is otherwise impossible to add qualifying members). 2. Rule of Convenience 2.1 The {{c4::Rule of Convenience}} is a default rule that closes a class whenever any member of the class is {{c5::entitled to demand distribution}} of her share. 2.2 Once the class closes under the Rule of Convenience, {{c6::later-born or later-qualifying persons are excluded}} and {{c7::take nothing}} from that class gift. 3. Relationship to vested remainders subject to open 3.1 A {{c8::vested remainder subject to open}} is a {{c9::class gift}} where at least one class member’s interest is already vested, but the class remains open to additional members until it closes. 3.2 The timing of {{c10::class closing}}—either naturally when no more members can be created or earlier under the Rule of Convenience—determines {{c11::who shares in the vested class gift}}.
cards.easyContent: In class gifts, a class is open when new members can still join and closes when no more can be added, such as at the life tenant’s death. The Rule of Convenience is a default rule that closes the class as soon as any member can demand distribution, so later-born members are excluded. This is crucial for vested remainders subject to open, where at least one class member is vested but the group stays open until the class closes.
cards.mediumContent: Class gifts involve an "open" class while it is still possible for new members to qualify, and the class becomes "closed" when adding new members is no longer possible, such as when the life tenant dies. The Rule of Convenience is a default rule that closes the class as soon as any member of the class is entitled to demand distribution of her share; anyone who joins the class after that point is excluded and takes nothing. Vested remainders subject to open are class gifts where at least one member is vested but the class is still open, and the timing of class closing—either naturally or under the Rule of Convenience—determines the final membership and allocation of the vested class gift.
cards.hardContent: For class gifts, courts distinguish between open and closed classes. A class is open when additional qualifying members can still be created—for example, while a life tenant is still alive and capable of having more children—and closes when it is no longer possible to add members, such as at the death of the life tenant or another event that makes further qualifying members impossible. The Rule of Convenience is a default construction rule: it closes a class whenever any member of the class is entitled to demand distribution of his or her share. After the class closes under this rule, later-born or later-qualifying individuals are excluded and receive nothing from that class gift. These principles are central to vested remainders subject to open, which are vested class gifts where at least one member has a vested interest but the class remains open until closing. The moment of class closing, whether by natural end of the possibility of new members or by the Rule of Convenience, determines exactly who is included in the vested remainder subject to open and how the property is ultimately divided among class members.
cards.mnemonic: Open class lets more in; Convenience Rule shuts door when payout begins.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::class gift}} is {{c2::open}} while new members can qualify and {{c3::closes}} when none can be added; the {{c4::Rule of Convenience}} closes the class when a member can {{c5::demand distribution}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Rule of Destructibility of Contingent Remainders
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 010-1. Rule of Destructibility of Contingent Remainders
cards.front: Rule of Destructibility of Contingent Remainders
cards.frontPrompt: What is the rule of destructibility of contingent remainders, and how do common-law and modern rules differ?
cards.backPlain: Rule of destructibility of contingent remainders 1. Common-law rule 1.1 A contingent remainder is destroyed if it remains contingent when the preceding estate ends. 1.2 If the condition precedent to the remainder is not satisfied before or at the time the prior estate ends, the contingent remainderman takes nothing. 2. Modern rule 2.1 Modern law in most jurisdictions has abolished the rule of destructibility. 2.2 Instead, if the prior estate ends before the condition is satisfied, the grantor or the grantor’s estate holds a reversion. 2.3 When and if the grantee later satisfies the condition, the grantee can take the estate pursuant to the contingent remainder, rather than having the interest destroyed.
cards.cloze: {{c1::Rule of destructibility of contingent remainders}} 1. {{c2::Common-law rule}} 1.1 A {{c3::contingent remainder}} is {{c4::destroyed}} if it remains contingent when the {{c5::preceding estate ends}}. 1.2 If the {{c6::condition precedent}} is not satisfied before or at the time the prior estate ends, the contingent remainderman takes {{c7::nothing}}. 2. {{c8::Modern rule}} 2.1 Most modern jurisdictions have {{c9::abolished}} the rule of destructibility. 2.2 If the prior estate ends before the condition is satisfied, the {{c10::grantor or the grantor’s estate}} holds a {{c11::reversion}}. 2.3 When the {{c12::condition is later satisfied}}, the {{c13::grantee}} can take under the {{c14::contingent remainder}}, rather than having the interest destroyed.
cards.easyContent: At common law, if a contingent remainder was still contingent when the prior estate ended, it was destroyed and the remainderman took nothing. Modernly, destruction is generally abolished; the grantor holds a reversion until the condition is satisfied and then the grantee can take.
cards.mediumContent: The rule of destructibility of contingent remainders provided that if a contingent remainder had not vested by the time the prior estate ended—because its condition precedent was still unsatisfied—the remainder was destroyed and the contingent remainderman got nothing. Modern law typically rejects this harsh result: instead, the grantor (or the grantor’s estate) holds a reversion until the condition is met, at which point the holder of the contingent remainder can still take.
cards.hardContent: Historically, the rule of destructibility of contingent remainders was a strict timing rule for future interests. When a life estate or other preceding estate ended, any remainder conditioned on an unsatisfied condition precedent—such as the remainderman reaching a certain age—was destroyed if it was still contingent at that moment. The would-be remainderman took nothing, and the estate shifted according to whatever other interests remained (often to the grantor or the grantor’s heirs). Modern jurisdictions largely abolish this rule. Instead of destruction, the grantor or the grantor’s estate holds a reversion while the condition remains unsatisfied, and if the condition is later met, the contingent remainderman can still take according to the terms of the grant.
cards.mnemonic: CLAW kills, MODERN mends: CL destroys, modern parks reversion.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card for rule of destructibility of contingent remainders.
cards.clozeLite: At common law, a {{c1::contingent remainder}} not vested when the {{c2::prior estate ends}} is {{c3::destroyed}}; {{c4::modern law abolishes}} this.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Merger (Shelley’s Rule / Rule in Shelley’s Case)
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 010-2. Merger (Shelley's Rule / Rule in Shelley's Case)
cards.front: Merger (Shelley’s Rule / Rule in Shelley’s Case)
cards.frontPrompt: When does Shelley’s Rule (the Rule in Shelley’s Case) apply, what was its effect at common law, and how is it treated under modern law?
cards.backPlain: Merger (Shelley’s Rule / Rule in Shelley’s Case) 1. When it arises 1.1 Shelley’s Rule arises when a conveyance attempts to give: - a life estate to a grantee, and - a remainder to that same grantee’s heirs. 1.2 Classic form: "to A for life, then to A’s heirs," with A alive. 2. Common-law effect 2.1 At common law, the life estate in A and the remainder in A’s heirs merge in A. 2.2 As a result, A receives a fee simple absolute. 2.3 Example: O grants "to A for life, then to A’s heirs," and A is alive. Under Shelley’s Rule, the remainder in A’s heirs merges with A’s life estate, and A has a fee simple absolute. 3. Modern rule 3.1 Shelley’s Rule has been abolished in most jurisdictions. 3.2 Under the modern view, the language is honored as written: - A has a life estate. - A’s heirs have contingent remainders because they are unascertained while A is alive. - O has a reversion because A could die without heirs. 3.3 The modern approach treats "heirs" as a legitimate future-interest taker rather than automatically merging their interest into A’s present estate.
cards.cloze: {{c1::Merger (Shelley’s Rule / Rule in Shelley’s Case)}} 1. {{c2::When it arises}} 1.1 Applies when a conveyance gives a {{c3::life estate}} to a grantee and a {{c4::remainder to that same grantee’s heirs}}. 1.2 Classic form: "{{c5::to A for life, then to A’s heirs}}" while A is alive. 2. {{c6::Common-law effect}} 2.1 The {{c7::life estate}} in A and the {{c8::remainder in A’s heirs}} {{c9::merge in A}}. 2.2 A takes a {{c10::fee simple absolute}}. 2.3 Example: O grants "to A for life, then to A’s heirs"; at common law, A ends up with {{c11::fee simple absolute}}. 3. {{c12::Modern rule}} 3.1 Shelley’s Rule has been {{c13::abolished in most jurisdictions}}. 3.2 Instead: - A has a {{c14::life estate}}. - A’s heirs have {{c15::contingent remainders}} (unascertained while A is alive). - O retains a {{c16::reversion}} in case A dies without heirs. 3.3 Modern law generally {{c17::honors the grantor’s language}} rather than forcing merger.
cards.easyContent: Shelley’s Rule applied to language like "to A for life, then to A’s heirs". At common law it merged A’s life estate and the remainder in A’s heirs into a fee simple absolute in A. Modernly, the rule is mostly abolished: A just has a life estate, A’s heirs hold contingent remainders, and O has a reversion.
cards.mediumContent: Under Shelley’s Rule (the Rule in Shelley’s Case), if a conveyance gave a life estate to A and a remainder to A’s heirs, the law treated both interests as being in A and merged them, giving A a fee simple absolute. For example, "to A for life, then to A’s heirs" with A alive created a fee simple absolute in A at common law. Modern jurisdictions generally abolish this rule. Today, that same grant usually means A has a life estate, A’s heirs hold contingent remainders because they are unascertained until A’s death, and O retains a reversion in case A dies without heirs.
cards.hardContent: Shelley’s Rule, or the Rule in Shelley’s Case, is a historic doctrine of merger that disfavored splitting present and future interests between a grantee and the grantee’s "heirs." It arises when a conveyance grants a life estate to a grantee and a remainder to that same grantee’s heirs (e.g., "to A for life, then to A’s heirs" with A alive). At common law, the rule treated the life estate and the remainder as both being in A and merged them, so A took a fee simple absolute. The named "heirs" did not hold a separate future interest. Modern courts in most jurisdictions have abolished Shelley’s Rule. They instead honor the text of the grant: A takes a life estate; A’s heirs (unascertained while A lives) hold contingent remainders; and O retains a reversion because A could die without heirs. The modern approach focuses on effectuating the grantor’s express intent rather than automatically enlarging A’s estate.
cards.mnemonic: Shelley stacks: A + A’s heirs merge into A’s fee.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card for Shelley’s Rule / merger.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::Shelley’s Rule}}, a grant "{{c2::to A for life, then to A’s heirs}}" gave A a {{c3::fee simple absolute}} at {{c4::common law}}, but is {{c5::abolished in most modern jurisdictions}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 010-3. Doctrine of Worthier Title
cards.frontPrompt: When does the Doctrine of Worthier Title apply, what is its common-law effect, and how is it treated in modern law?
cards.backPlain: Doctrine of Worthier Title 1. When it arises 1.1 The doctrine arises when the grantor creates a life estate in another person but purports to create a future interest in the grantor’s own heirs. 1.2 Classic form: "to A for life, then to O’s heirs." 2. Common-law effect 2.1 At common law, a purported remainder or executory interest in the grantor’s heirs is void. 2.2 The law presumes that the grantor retained a reversion instead of creating a future interest in the heirs. 2.3 Example: O grants "to A for life, then to O’s heirs." Under the doctrine, the contingent remainder in O’s heirs is void. 2.4 Result: A has a life estate and O has a reversion. 3. Modern rule 3.1 In modern law, the Doctrine of Worthier Title is often treated as a rule of construction rather than a firm invalidating rule. 3.2 Courts may still presume that the grantor intended to retain a reversion, but this presumption can be rebutted by clear contrary intent in the instrument. 3.3 If the grantor clearly intends to give a future interest to "O’s heirs," modern courts may honor that grant instead of collapsing it into a reversion.
cards.cloze: {{c1::Doctrine of Worthier Title}} 1. {{c2::When it arises}} 1.1 Applies when the {{c3::grantor}} creates a {{c4::life estate in another}} but purports to create a {{c5::future interest in the grantor’s own heirs}}. 1.2 Classic form: "{{c6::to A for life, then to O’s heirs}}." 2. {{c7::Common-law effect}} 2.1 A purported {{c8::remainder or executory interest}} in the grantor’s heirs is {{c9::void}}. 2.2 The law presumes that the {{c10::grantor retained a reversion}} instead. 2.3 Example: O grants "to A for life, then to O’s heirs"; the {{c11::contingent remainder in O’s heirs}} is void. 2.4 Result: A has a {{c12::life estate}} and O has a {{c13::reversion}}. 3. {{c14::Modern rule}} 3.1 Often treated as a {{c15::rule of construction}} rather than a strict invalidating rule. 3.2 Courts may presume a {{c16::reversion in O}}, but that presumption can be {{c17::rebutted by clear contrary intent}} in the instrument. 3.3 If the grantor clearly intends a future interest in "O’s heirs," modern courts may {{c18::honor the future interest}} rather than collapsing it into a reversion.
cards.easyContent: The Doctrine of Worthier Title applied to grants like "to A for life, then to O’s heirs." At common law, it voided the future interest in O’s heirs and treated O as retaining a reversion. Modernly, it is usually just a rebuttable rule of construction that can be overcome by clear contrary intent.
cards.mediumContent: The Doctrine of Worthier Title arises when the grantor gives someone a life estate but purports to give a remainder or executory interest to the grantor’s own heirs, as in "to A for life, then to O’s heirs." At common law, that future interest in O’s heirs was void, and the law presumed that O simply retained a reversion. Today, many jurisdictions treat the doctrine as a rule of construction: courts may presume a retained reversion in O but will honor a clear intent to give a future interest directly to "O’s heirs."
cards.hardContent: The Doctrine of Worthier Title is another historic doctrine disfavoring direct grants to "heirs" of the grantor. It arises when O creates a present interest in someone else, commonly a life estate in A, and then purports to create a future interest in "O’s heirs" (e.g., "to A for life, then to O’s heirs"). At common law, the law treated any such remainder or executory interest in O’s heirs as void and instead presumed that O retained a reversion. Thus in the classic example, A holds a life estate and O holds a reversion; O’s heirs take, if at all, by descent from O rather than by purchase under the deed. Modern courts often recharacterize the Doctrine of Worthier Title as a rebuttable rule of construction rather than a hard invalidating rule. They may initially presume that the grantor intended to keep a reversion, but if the instrument clearly shows an intent to create a future interest in "O’s heirs," that intent can be honored notwithstanding the traditional doctrine.
cards.mnemonic: Worthier Title: O keeps title, heirs’ future flunks.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card for Doctrine of Worthier Title.
cards.clozeLite: Doctrine of Worthier Title: arises with a grant {{c1::"to A for life, then to O’s heirs"}}; at common law {{c2::O’s heirs’ future interest is void}} and {{c3::O is presumed to retain a reversion}}; today it is usually {{c4::a rebuttable rule of construction}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Rule Against Perpetuities – Core Rule and Measuring Life
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 012-1. Rule Against Perpetuities – Core Rule and Measuring Life
cards.front: Rule Against Perpetuities – Core Rule and Measuring Life
cards.backPlain: Rule Against Perpetuities – Core Rule and Measuring Life 1. Core RAP Statement 1.1 No property interest is valid unless it must vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after the death of a life in being at the time the interest was created. 1.2 A future interest is void if there is any possibility, no matter how remote, that it will vest more than 21 years after the death of the measuring life. 2. Measuring Life 2.1 A measuring life is a life in being at the time the interest is created. 2.2 The measuring life is someone whose actions during life, at death, or within 21 years after death determine whether the future interest will vest within the RAP period. 2.3 If there is any conceivable scenario in which the interest could vest later than 21 years after the measuring life’s death, the interest violates RAP and is void.
cards.frontPrompt: What does the common law Rule Against Perpetuities require for the validity of a future interest, and what is a measuring life?
cards.cloze: Rule Against Perpetuities – Core Rule and Measuring Life 1. Core RAP Statement 1.1 No property interest is valid unless it must {{c1::vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after the death of a life in being}} at the time the interest was created. 1.2 A future interest is {{c2::void}} if there is any {{c3::possibility, no matter how remote}} that it will {{c4::vest more than 21 years after the death of the measuring life}}. 2. Measuring Life 2.1 A {{c5::measuring life}} is a {{c6::life in being at the time the interest is created}}. 2.2 The measuring life is someone whose {{c7::actions during life, at death, or within 21 years after death}} determine whether the future interest vests within the RAP period. 2.3 If there is any {{c8::conceivable scenario}} in which the interest could vest later than {{c9::21 years after the measuring life’s death}}, the interest {{c10::violates RAP and is void}}.
cards.easyContent: The common law Rule Against Perpetuities says a future interest is invalid unless it is certain to vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after the death of some life in being at creation. A measuring life is that life in being whose life events determine whether vesting occurs within that period.
cards.mediumContent: Under the common law RAP, no property interest is valid unless it must vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after the death of a life in being when the interest is created. If there is any possible scenario, however remote, in which the interest might vest beyond 21 years after the measuring life’s death, the interest is void. A measuring life is a life in being at creation whose conduct, death, or events within 21 years thereafter are relevant to whether the interest vests in time.
cards.hardContent: The Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) invalidates future interests that are not certain to vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after the death of some life in being at the time the interest is created. The test is highly demanding: if one can imagine any conceivable, even highly remote, chain of events in which the interest does not vest until more than 21 years after the death of the measuring life, the interest is void from the outset. A measuring life is a person who is alive when the interest is created and whose life, death, or events occurring within 21 years after death bear on whether the interest will vest. Choosing an appropriate measuring life is key to applying RAP correctly.
cards.mnemonic: "Life in being + 21" – RAP requires vesting no later than 21 years after a measuring life in being.
cards.clozeLite: Under common law {{c1::RAP}}, an interest is void if it might vest {{c2::later than 21 years}} after a {{c3::life in being}} at creation, called the {{c4::measuring life}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Rule Against Perpetuities – Covered Interests and Analysis Steps
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 012-2. Rule Against Perpetuities – Covered Interests and Analysis Steps
cards.front: Rule Against Perpetuities – Covered Interests and Analysis Steps
cards.backPlain: Rule Against Perpetuities – Covered Interests and Analysis Steps 1. Interests Subject to RAP 1.1 RAP applies to: (a) Contingent remainders. (b) Gifts to open classes (class gifts that may still open or change). (c) Executory interests. 1.2 In many jurisdictions, RAP also applies to: (a) Options to purchase. (b) Rights of first refusal. 1.3 RAP does not apply to vested remainders. 2. Step-by-Step RAP Analysis 2.1 Determine the interests created by the conveyance, identifying all future interests. 2.2 Isolate the interests that are of a type covered by RAP (contingent remainders, open class gifts, executory interests, and, in some jurisdictions, options and rights of first refusal). 2.3 For each covered interest, select an appropriate measuring life (a relevant life in being at creation) and ask whether the interest must vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after that life’s death. 2.4 If there is any possibility, no matter how remote, that the interest could vest beyond 21 years after the measuring life’s death, the interest violates RAP and is void. 2.5 If an interest violates RAP, strike only the offending future interest from the conveyance. 2.6 Whatever remains after striking the invalid interest is enforced as the new conveyance. 3. Modern Reforms (Exam Note) 3.1 Many states have reformed the common law RAP, often by: (a) Providing an alternative vesting period (e.g., a 90-year wait-and-see period). 3.2 Unless the question states otherwise, apply the traditional common law RAP on the bar exam.
cards.frontPrompt: Which kinds of future interests are subject to the Rule Against Perpetuities, and how do you systematically analyze a conveyance for a RAP violation and its consequences?
cards.cloze: Rule Against Perpetuities – Covered Interests and Analysis Steps 1. Interests Subject to RAP 1.1 RAP applies to: (a) {{c1::Contingent remainders}}. (b) {{c2::Gifts to open classes}}. (c) {{c3::Executory interests}}. 1.2 In many jurisdictions, RAP also applies to: (a) {{c4::Options to purchase}}. (b) {{c5::Rights of first refusal}}. 1.3 RAP does {{c6::not apply}} to {{c7::vested remainders}}. 2. Step-by-Step RAP Analysis 2.1 {{c8::Determine the interests created}} by the conveyance, identifying all future interests. 2.2 {{c9::Isolate the interests}} that are of a type covered by RAP. 2.3 For each covered interest, {{c10::select an appropriate measuring life}} and ask whether the interest {{c11::must vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after that life’s death}}. 2.4 If there is any {{c12::possibility, no matter how remote}}, that the interest could vest beyond {{c13::21 years after the measuring life’s death}}, the interest {{c14::violates RAP and is void}}. 2.5 If an interest violates RAP, {{c15::strike only the offending future interest}} from the conveyance. 2.6 Whatever remains after striking the invalid interest is {{c16::enforced as the new conveyance}}. 3. Modern Reforms (Exam Note) 3.1 Many states have {{c17::reformed the common law RAP}}, often by providing an {{c18::alternative vesting period}} such as a {{c19::90-year wait-and-see period}}. 3.2 On the bar exam, unless told otherwise, apply the {{c20::traditional common law RAP}}.
cards.easyContent: RAP mainly applies to contingent remainders, class gifts, and executory interests (and in some states, options and rights of first refusal), not to vested remainders. To analyze a conveyance, identify the future interests, pick a measuring life, see if the interest must vest within life in being plus 21 years, and if not, strike only that interest and enforce the rest. On the bar exam, assume the classic common law RAP unless told otherwise.
cards.mediumContent: The interests subject to RAP are contingent remainders, gifts to open classes, and executory interests, and in some jurisdictions, options to purchase and rights of first refusal. Vested remainders are safe from RAP. To analyze a conveyance, first identify all future interests; second, focus only on those types subject to RAP; third, for each such interest, choose a suitable measuring life and ask whether it must vest, if at all, within 21 years of that person’s death. If any conceivable scenario allows for later vesting, the interest is void. You then strike only that interest and enforce what’s left as the new conveyance. Although many states have modern reforms like a 90-year wait-and-see period, bar exam questions default to the traditional common law RAP unless specified.
cards.hardContent: RAP scrutinizes only certain future interests: contingent remainders, gifts to open classes, and executory interests are classic RAP targets, and many jurisdictions extend RAP to options to purchase and rights of first refusal. Vested remainders, by contrast, are not subject to RAP. The analysis proceeds in a systematic way: (1) determine all interests granted in the conveyance; (2) identify which of those are RAP-sensitive types; (3) for each such interest, select an appropriate measuring life—typically a relevant person alive at creation whose existence affects vesting; (4) test whether it is logically necessary that the interest, if it vests at all, will do so no later than 21 years after that life’s death; and (5) if any logically possible scenario permits vesting later than that period, declare the interest void under RAP. The remedy is precise: you strike only the offending future interest and enforce whatever remains as the operative conveyance. Although many states have adopted reforms, including a 90-year statutory wait-and-see period or other extensions, bar exam questions generally require application of the classic common law RAP unless explicitly stated otherwise.
cards.mnemonic: RAP hits CRazy OPEN EXECs: Contingent Remainders, OPEN classes, EXECutory interests.
cards.clozeLite: RAP targets {{c1::contingent remainders}}, {{c2::open class gifts}}, {{c3::executory interests}} (plus some {{c4::options/rights of first refusal}}) but not {{c5::vested remainders}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: RAP – Options and Rights of First Refusal
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 013-1. RAP – Options and Rights of First Refusal
cards.front: RAP – Options and Rights of First Refusal
