cards.backPlain: RAP and contingent purchase rights 1. Options and rights of first refusal as contingent interests 1.1 Options and rights of first refusal are contingent interests in property. 2. RAP application 2.1 These contingent interests violate the Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) if they could possibly be exercised outside the perpetuities period (measured by lives in being plus 21 years). 2.2 If there is any chance—no matter how remote—that the option or right of first refusal could be exercised beyond the perpetuities period, the interest is void from the outset under RAP.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the Rule Against Perpetuities apply to options and rights of first refusal?
cards.cloze: RAP and contingent purchase rights 1. {{c1::Options}} and {{c2::rights of first refusal}} are {{c3::contingent interests}} in property. 2. RAP application 2.1 These contingent interests violate the {{c4::Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP)}} if they could possibly be {{c5::exercised outside the perpetuities period}} (lives in being plus {{c6::21 years}}). 2.2 If there is {{c7::any chance, however remote}}, that the option or right of first refusal could be exercised beyond the perpetuities period, the interest is {{c8::void from the outset}} under RAP.
cards.easyContent: Options and rights of first refusal are contingent interests subject to RAP and are invalid if they could possibly be exercised beyond lives in being plus 21 years.
cards.mediumContent: Because options and rights of first refusal are contingent interests, they fall under RAP: if there is any possibility that they might be exercised after the perpetuities period (lives in being plus 21 years), they are void from creation.
cards.hardContent: Options and rights of first refusal are treated as contingent future interests in property. Under the Rule Against Perpetuities, they are invalid if there is any conceivable scenario in which they could be exercised beyond the perpetuities period (measured as lives in being at the time of creation plus 21 years). RAP is tested at the time of creation, and if remote vesting is possible, the option or right of first refusal is void ab initio.
cards.mnemonic: OFRP: Options & First Refusal are Perpetuities problems.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Options}} and {{c2::rights of first refusal}} are {{c3::contingent interests}} subject to {{c4::RAP}} and are void if they {{c5::might be exercised after lives in being plus 21 years}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: RAP – Class Gifts and the Rule of Convenience
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 013-2. RAP – Class Gifts and the Rule of Convenience
cards.front: RAP – Class Gifts and the Rule of Convenience
cards.backPlain: RAP and class gifts 1. RAP requirements for class gifts 1.1 For a class gift to satisfy the Rule Against Perpetuities, the class must be closed and all conditions precedent must be satisfied for every member within the perpetuities period. 1.2 If the class remains open or conditions precedent might be satisfied for some members beyond the perpetuities period, the class gift may violate RAP. 2. Rule of Convenience 2.1 The Rule of Convenience is a rule of construction that may save a class gift that would otherwise violate RAP. 2.2 Under the Rule of Convenience, the class closes when at least one class member is entitled to immediate possession or enjoyment. 2.3 By closing the class at that time, the Rule of Convenience can prevent later-born members from joining the class and creating remote vesting problems under RAP.
cards.frontPrompt: How do class gifts satisfy RAP, and how can the Rule of Convenience help save a potentially invalid class gift?
cards.cloze: RAP and class gifts 1. RAP requirements for class gifts 1.1 For a {{c1::class gift}} to satisfy the {{c2::Rule Against Perpetuities}}, the {{c3::class must be closed}} and {{c4::all conditions precedent}} must be satisfied for {{c5::every member}} within the {{c6::perpetuities period}}. 1.2 If the class remains {{c7::open}} or conditions precedent might be satisfied for some members {{c8::beyond the perpetuities period}}, the class gift may {{c9::violate RAP}}. 2. Rule of Convenience 2.1 The {{c10::Rule of Convenience}} is a {{c11::rule of construction}} that may save a class gift that would otherwise violate RAP. 2.2 Under the Rule of Convenience, the class {{c12::closes}} when at least {{c13::one class member}} is entitled to {{c14::immediate possession or enjoyment}}. 2.3 By closing the class at that time, the Rule of Convenience can prevent {{c15::later-born members}} from joining the class and creating {{c16::remote vesting problems}} under RAP.
cards.easyContent: A class gift satisfies RAP only if the class closes and all members’ conditions are satisfied within the perpetuities period. The Rule of Convenience can close the class when someone is entitled to possession, preventing remote vesting.
cards.mediumContent: For class gifts, RAP requires that the class close and all conditions precedent for every member be satisfied within the perpetuities period. If additional members could join later or satisfy conditions later, the gift can be invalid. The Rule of Convenience, a rule of construction, can close the class once a member is entitled to immediate possession, preventing later-born members from creating remote vesting problems.
cards.hardContent: Class gifts are especially vulnerable under RAP because the class can remain open over time. To comply, the class must be closed and all conditions precedent for every class member must be satisfied within the perpetuities period; if it is possible for after-born class members to join or for existing members to satisfy conditions beyond that period, the class gift may be void. The Rule of Convenience operates as a saving construction: it closes the class at the first moment when any class member is entitled to immediate possession or enjoyment, thereby excluding later-born members and often avoiding RAP violations by ensuring all vested interests fall within the perpetuities period.
cards.mnemonic: For class gifts under RAP, remember "CCC": Class must Close, Conditions satisfied, Convenience rule can save.
cards.clozeLite: For {{c1::class gifts}}, RAP requires the {{c2::class close}} and {{c3::all conditions precedent}} be satisfied within the {{c4::perpetuities period}}; the {{c5::Rule of Convenience}} can close the class when someone is entitled to immediate possession.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: RAP – Classic Hypotheticals and the Charity-to-Charity Exception
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 013-3. RAP – Classic Hypotheticals and the Charity-to-Charity Exception
cards.front: RAP – Classic Hypotheticals and the Charity-to-Charity Exception
cards.backPlain: Classic RAP hypotheticals and exception 1. Age contingency beyond 21 for an open class 1.1 A conveyance to an open class that is contingent on members reaching an age over 21 is a classic RAP problem. 1.2 Such a conveyance is void under RAP if there is any possibility that some class member’s interest might vest more than 21 years after a life in being at the time of creation. 2. Fertile octogenarian 2.1 RAP assumes that any woman is capable of giving birth regardless of age or physical condition. 2.2 This "fertile octogenarian" presumption keeps certain classes open indefinitely for RAP analysis. 2.3 Example: Grantor conveys "to A for life, then to A's children who reach 30." A is 80 and has a 40-year-old son. 2.3.1 This violates RAP because A’s son could die, A could have a daughter at 81, then die when she is 82. The daughter’s interest would not vest until she reaches 30, which is more than 21 years after A’s death. 3. Charity-to-charity exception 3.1 RAP does not apply to conveyances from one charity to another charity. 3.2 Thus, future interests that are entirely between charitable organizations are exempt from RAP, even if they might otherwise vest remotely.
cards.frontPrompt: How do classic RAP hypotheticals like age contingencies beyond 21 and the fertile octogenarian work, and what is the charity-to-charity exception?
cards.cloze: Classic RAP hypotheticals and exception 1. {{c1::Age contingency beyond 21}} for an {{c2::open class}} 1.1 A conveyance to an open class that is contingent on members reaching an {{c3::age over 21}} is a classic RAP problem. 1.2 Such a conveyance is {{c4::void under RAP}} if there is any possibility that some class member’s interest might vest more than {{c5::21 years after a life in being}} at the time of creation. 2. {{c6::Fertile octogenarian}} 2.1 RAP assumes that {{c7::any woman is capable of giving birth regardless of age or physical condition}}. 2.2 This presumption keeps certain {{c8::classes open indefinitely}} for RAP analysis. 2.3 Example: Grantor conveys "to A for life, then to A's children who reach 30." A is 80 and has a 40-year-old son. 2.3.1 This violates RAP because A’s son could die, A could have a daughter at 81, then die when she is 82. The daughter’s interest would not vest until she reaches {{c9::30}}, which is more than {{c10::21 years after A’s death}}. 3. {{c11::Charity-to-charity exception}} 3.1 RAP {{c12::does not apply}} to conveyances from {{c13::one charity to another charity}}. 3.2 Future interests entirely between {{c14::charitable organizations}} are therefore {{c15::exempt from RAP}}, even if they might otherwise vest remotely.
cards.easyContent: Classic RAP issues include age contingencies over 21 for an open class and the fertile octogenarian presumption that any woman can have children at any age, both creating remote vesting risks. By contrast, conveyances from one charity to another are exempt from RAP under the charity-to-charity exception.
cards.mediumContent: RAP problems often involve open classes whose members must reach an age higher than 21; because additional members could be born later and take longer than 21 years after a life in being to reach the required age, the gift can be void. The fertile octogenarian presumption compounds this by assuming that any woman, no matter how old, might still have children, keeping the class open for RAP analysis. On the other hand, the charity-to-charity exception exempts gifts from one charitable organization to another from RAP, even if vesting might otherwise be remote.
cards.hardContent: An open class gift conditioned on members reaching an age over 21 is a classic RAP trap, because it is possible for a later-born class member’s interest to vest more than 21 years after all lives in being at creation, rendering the gift void. The fertile octogenarian doctrine reinforces this risk: the law presumes that any woman, regardless of age or condition, can bear children, so the class remains open for RAP purposes, allowing hypothetical later-born children whose interests might vest too remotely. In contrast, the charity-to-charity exception provides that RAP does not apply to future interests where both the transferor and transferee are charitable organizations, so even interests that could vest beyond the perpetuities period are valid if they are entirely between charities.
cards.mnemonic: Classic RAP quirks: "F-A-C"—Fertile octogenarian, Age over 21, Charity-to-charity.
cards.clozeLite: Classic RAP traps include {{c1::age contingencies over 21 for open classes}} and the {{c2::fertile octogenarian}}; {{c3::charity-to-charity gifts}} are {{c4::exempt from RAP}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Co-Tenants – Possession, Own Use Rent, Third-Party Rents, and Adverse Possession
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 017-1. Co-Tenants – Possession, Own Use Rent, Third-Party Rents, and Adverse Possession
cards.front: Co-Tenants – Possession, Rents/Profits, and Adverse Possession
cards.backPlain: 1. Possession rights 1.1 Each co-tenant has an undivided right to possess the whole property; there is no right to an exclusive physical portion absent agreement. 1.2 No co-tenant has the right to exclusive possession against the others unless there is an ouster—i.e., conduct that actually excludes or clearly denies the others' right to possess. 2. Rent and profits 2.1 Own use: A co-tenant in exclusive possession is not required to pay rent to, or reimburse, other co-tenants for his own use of the land, absent ouster or an agreement to pay rent. 2.2 Third-party rents: Each co-tenant has a right to share proportionately in rents collected from third-party tenants. 2.3 Depleting uses: Each co-tenant has a right to share proportionately in profits derived from uses that deplete the property's value (for example, timber, oil and gas production, or mining). 3. Adverse possession between co-tenants 3.1 A co-tenant may not ordinarily acquire title to the exclusion of other co-tenants through adverse possession. 3.2 To adversely possess against co-tenants, the possessor must (a) actually oust the other co-tenants or otherwise clearly repudiate the co-tenancy, and (b) satisfy all adverse possession elements—actual, open and notorious, exclusive, hostile, and continuous—for the full statutory period after the ouster or repudiation.
cards.frontPrompt: In a concurrent estate, what are the rules governing co-tenants' rights to possess the property, obligations to pay rent for their own use, duties to share rents and profits from third parties and depleting uses, and the circumstances under which one co-tenant can adversely possess against the others?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Possession rights}} 1.1 Each co-tenant has an {{c2::undivided right to possess the whole property}}; there is no right to an exclusive physical portion absent agreement. 1.2 No co-tenant has the right to {{c3::exclusive possession}} against the others unless there is an {{c4::ouster}}—conduct that actually excludes or clearly denies the others' right to possess. 2. {{c5::Rent and profits}} 2.1 {{c6::Own use}}: A co-tenant in exclusive possession is {{c7::not required to pay rent}} to, or reimburse, other co-tenants for his own use of the land, absent {{c8::ouster}} or an agreement to pay rent. 2.2 {{c9::Third-party rents}}: Each co-tenant has a right to {{c10::share proportionately in rents}} collected from third-party tenants. 2.3 {{c11::Depleting uses}}: Each co-tenant has a right to share in {{c12::profits from uses that deplete the property's value}} (e.g., timber, oil and gas, mining). 3. {{c13::Adverse possession between co-tenants}} 3.1 A co-tenant may not ordinarily acquire title to the exclusion of other co-tenants through adverse possession. 3.2 To adversely possess against co-tenants, the possessor must {{c14::actually oust the others or clearly repudiate the co-tenancy}} and then satisfy {{c15::all adverse possession elements}} for the {{c16::full statutory period}} after ouster or repudiation.
cards.easyContent: Co-tenants all have a right to possess the whole property. A co-tenant in exclusive possession usually owes no rent to others for personal use, but must share third-party rents and profits from depleting uses. One co-tenant cannot adversely possess against others unless he actually ousts them (or clearly repudiates the co-tenancy) and then satisfies all adverse possession elements for the statutory period.
cards.mediumContent: Each co-tenant has an undivided right to possess the whole, and none may exclude the others absent ouster. A co-tenant in exclusive possession does not owe rent to co-tenants merely for using the land himself, but must account for and share rents collected from third-party tenants and profits from depleting uses like timber, oil, or minerals. Generally, one co-tenant cannot adversely possess against the others simply by staying in exclusive possession. Instead, he must actually oust them or clearly repudiate the co-tenancy, give notice through his conduct, and then meet all adverse possession requirements—actual, open and notorious, exclusive, hostile, and continuous—for the entire statutory period after ouster.
cards.hardContent: In a concurrent estate, each co-tenant holds an undivided interest in the whole property and has a co-equal right to possess the entire parcel. No co-tenant has a right to a particular piece of the land, and a co-tenant cannot assert exclusive possession against other co-tenants unless his conduct amounts to ouster, such as physically excluding them or clearly denying their right to enter. A co-tenant in exclusive possession for personal use is not required to pay rent or otherwise reimburse other co-tenants simply because he is the one using the property. However, where a co-tenant leases the property to a third party or engages in depleting uses like timber harvesting, oil and gas extraction, or mining, he must account to the other co-tenants and share rents and profits proportionately. As to adverse possession, the general rule is that one co-tenant cannot acquire title against others merely by long exclusive possession, because that use is consistent with the co-tenancy. To adversely possess against co-tenants, the possessor must first oust them or otherwise clearly repudiate the co-tenancy in a way that is communicated or apparent to them, and then satisfy all elements of adverse possession—actual, open and notorious, exclusive, hostile, and continuous—for the full statutory period measured from the ouster or repudiation.
cards.mnemonic: "PRA": Possession, Rents/Profits, Adverse possession.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 1 of 3 for real-property-017: focuses on possession, own-use rent, third-party rents/depleting uses, and adverse possession between co-tenants.
cards.clozeLite: Each co-tenant has an {{c1::undivided right to possess the whole}} and owes {{c2::no rent for sole personal use}}, but must {{c3::share third-party rents and depleting profits}}. Adverse possession requires {{c4::ouster or clear repudiation of the co-tenancy}} plus {{c5::all standard AP elements}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Co-Tenants – Carrying Costs, Repairs, and Improvements
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 017-2. Co-Tenants – Carrying Costs, Repairs, and Improvements
cards.front: Co-Tenants – Carrying Costs, Repairs, and Improvements
cards.backPlain: 1. Carrying costs 1.1 Each co-tenant is responsible for his fair share of carrying costs necessary to preserve the property or the title, such as property taxes, mortgage interest, and similar expenses. 1.2 A co-tenant who pays more than his share of carrying costs may seek contribution from the other co-tenants. 2. Repairs 2.1 A co-tenant who makes reasonable, necessary repairs to the property may seek contribution from other co-tenants for their fair share. 2.2 Most courts require the repairing co-tenant to give notice to the other co-tenants before performing the repairs as a condition of obtaining contribution. 3. Improvements 3.1 Voluntary improvements (those that are not necessary to preserve or maintain the property) generally do not give the improving co-tenant any right to contribution from other co-tenants. 3.2 However, at partition or sale, the improving co-tenant is entitled to credit for any increase in the property's value attributable to the improvement and must bear any loss in value attributable to the improvement. 3.3 Courts typically measure the credit or debit by the change in market value caused by the improvement, not by the cost of the work itself.
cards.frontPrompt: In a concurrent estate, how do co-tenants share responsibility for carrying costs, when can a co-tenant obtain contribution for repairs, and how are voluntary improvements by one co-tenant treated both during the co-tenancy and at partition or sale?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Carrying costs}} 1.1 Each co-tenant is responsible for his {{c2::fair share}} of carrying costs necessary to preserve the property or title, such as {{c3::property taxes, mortgage interest, and similar expenses}}. 1.2 A co-tenant who pays more than his share of carrying costs may seek {{c4::contribution}} from the other co-tenants. 2. {{c5::Repairs}} 2.1 A co-tenant who makes {{c6::reasonable, necessary repairs}} to the property may seek contribution from other co-tenants for their fair share. 2.2 Most courts require the repairing co-tenant to give {{c7::notice}} to the other co-tenants before performing the repairs as a condition of obtaining contribution. 3. {{c8::Improvements}} 3.1 {{c9::Voluntary improvements}} generally do {{c10::not}} give the improving co-tenant any right to {{c11::contribution}} from other co-tenants. 3.2 At {{c12::partition or sale}}, the improving co-tenant is entitled to {{c13::credit for any increase in value}} attributable to the improvement and must bear any {{c14::loss in value}} attributable to it. 3.3 Courts usually measure this credit or debit by the {{c15::change in market value}}, not by the {{c16::cost of the work}}.
cards.easyContent: Co-tenants must each pay their fair share of carrying costs like taxes and mortgage interest, and a co-tenant who makes necessary repairs with notice can get contribution. Voluntary improvements do not give a right to contribution, but at partition or sale, the improving co-tenant is credited (or debited) based on how the improvement changed the property's value.
cards.mediumContent: Each co-tenant is obligated to bear a proportionate share of carrying costs such as property taxes, mortgage interest, and similar necessary expenses that preserve the property or title. A co-tenant who pays more than his share can seek contribution from the others. For repairs, a co-tenant who undertakes reasonable, necessary repairs that maintain the property may obtain contribution from co-tenants for their proportional shares, typically provided he gave them notice before making the repairs. In contrast, voluntary improvements do not support contribution during the co-tenancy. Instead, at partition or sale, the improving co-tenant is compensated by credit for any increase in market value attributable to the improvements and must absorb any decrease in value attributable to them, with courts focusing on the change in value rather than the cost of the work.
cards.hardContent: Co-tenants share financial responsibilities related to preserving the property and its title. Each co-tenant must pay a fair share of carrying costs such as property taxes, mortgage interest, and similar ongoing expenses; a co-tenant who pays more than his share may generally seek contribution from the others for the excess. With respect to repairs, a co-tenant who undertakes reasonable, necessary repairs that maintain the property in good condition is typically entitled to contribution from the other co-tenants for their proportional shares, provided that he gave them notice or an opportunity to participate before incurring the expense, as many courts require notice as a prerequisite to contribution. By contrast, purely voluntary improvements—those beyond what is necessary to maintain the property—do not give the improving co-tenant a present right to contribution during the co-tenancy. The law instead adjusts interests at partition or sale: the improving co-tenant receives a credit for any increase in the property's market value attributable to the improvement, and must bear any decrease in value attributable to it. Courts generally calculate these adjustments based on the net change in market value caused by the improvement, not the raw cost of construction or alteration.
cards.mnemonic: "CRI": Co-tenants share Carrying costs, Repairs reimbursed, Improvements later adjusted.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 2 of 3 for real-property-017: focuses on carrying costs, repairs, and improvements among co-tenants.
cards.clozeLite: Co-tenants share {{c1::carrying costs}} and a repairing co-tenant with {{c2::notice}} can get {{c3::contribution}}; {{c4::voluntary improvements}} are adjusted only {{c5::at partition or sale}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Co-Tenants – Waste and Partition / Non-Partition Agreements
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 017-3. Co-Tenants – Waste and Partition / Non-Partition Agreements
cards.front: Co-Tenants – Waste and Partition / Non-Partition Agreements
cards.backPlain: 1. Waste between co-tenants 1.1 A co-tenant can bring an action for waste against another co-tenant whose conduct harms or improperly alters the property. 1.2 Types of waste generally recognized (depending on jurisdiction) include: • Affirmative waste: voluntary acts that substantially reduce the property's value (e.g., destructive timbering, demolition). • Permissive waste: neglect resulting in deterioration or damage (e.g., failing to make ordinary repairs or pay property taxes). • Ameliorative waste: unauthorized changes that increase subjective utility but materially alter the property's character (some jurisdictions recognize this as actionable). 1.3 Waste actions may be brought during the life of the co-tenancy to prevent or remedy improper uses of the property. 2. Partition and sale 2.1 Any co-tenant generally has the right to seek judicial partition of the property, thereby ending the co-tenancy. 2.2 Partition in kind: If feasible, a court prefers to physically divide the property, giving each co-tenant a separate parcel consistent with their interests. 2.3 Partition by sale: If physical division is not practical or would substantially diminish the value of the property, a court may order a sale and apportion the proceeds among co-tenants according to their interests. 3. Agreements not to partition 3.1 Co-tenants may contractually agree not to partition the property. 3.2 Such non-partition agreements are enforceable only if they are limited to a reasonable duration and serve legitimate purposes. 3.3 An agreement that permanently or unreasonably restricts partition is void as an unreasonable restraint on alienation.
cards.frontPrompt: In a co-tenancy, what are the rules governing waste actions between co-tenants, the right to judicial partition or sale, and the validity of agreements not to partition?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Waste between co-tenants}} 1.1 A co-tenant can bring an {{c2::action for waste}} against another co-tenant whose conduct harms or improperly alters the property. 1.2 Types of waste may include {{c3::affirmative waste}} (voluntary acts that substantially reduce value), {{c4::permissive waste}} (neglect causing deterioration), and {{c5::ameliorative waste}} (unauthorized changes that alter the property's character), depending on the jurisdiction. 1.3 Waste actions may be brought {{c6::during the life of the co-tenancy}} to prevent or remedy improper uses. 2. {{c7::Partition and sale}} 2.1 Any co-tenant generally has the right to seek {{c8::judicial partition}}. 2.2 {{c9::Partition in kind}}: If feasible, a court prefers to {{c10::physically divide the property}} among co-tenants. 2.3 {{c11::Partition by sale}}: If physical division is not practical or would significantly reduce value, a court may order a {{c12::sale}} and {{c13::apportion the proceeds}} according to co-tenants' interests. 3. {{c14::Agreements not to partition}} 3.1 Co-tenants may {{c15::agree not to partition}} the property. 3.2 Such agreements are enforceable only if limited to a {{c16::reasonable duration}} and serve {{c17::legitimate purposes}}. 3.3 An agreement that {{c18::permanently or unreasonably restricts partition}} is {{c19::void as an unreasonable restraint on alienation}}.
cards.easyContent: Co-tenants can sue each other for waste when one co-tenant improperly harms or alters the property. Any co-tenant may seek judicial partition; courts prefer physical division but can order a sale and division of proceeds if necessary. Co-tenants may agree not to partition, but only for a reasonable time; overly long or permanent restrictions are invalid as unreasonable restraints on alienation.
cards.mediumContent: Co-tenants owe duties not to commit waste against the shared property. A co-tenant may bring an action for waste against another whose acts harm or improperly alter the property, including affirmative waste (destructive acts), permissive waste (neglect leading to deterioration), and, in some jurisdictions, ameliorative waste (unauthorized changes that alter the property's character). These actions can be brought while the co-tenancy continues. Each co-tenant also has a general right to seek judicial partition to terminate the co-tenancy; courts prefer partition in kind, physically dividing the land, but will order a sale and division of proceeds when physical division is impractical or significantly reduces value. Co-tenants may enter non-partition agreements, but they are enforceable only if of reasonable duration and for legitimate purposes; agreements that permanently or unreasonably bar partition are void as unreasonable restraints on alienation.
cards.hardContent: In a co-tenancy, each co-tenant must refrain from committing waste with respect to the common property. A co-tenant can sue another co-tenant for waste if that co-tenant's conduct damages the property, allows it to deteriorate, or materially and improperly alters its character. Jurisdictions typically recognize affirmative waste (voluntary destructive acts such as overharvesting timber or demolishing structures), permissive waste (failure to perform ordinary maintenance or pay charges like taxes leading to deterioration or loss), and, in some jurisdictions, ameliorative waste (unauthorized changes that increase market value but significantly change the property's nature, such as converting a historic residence into commercial space). Waste actions may be brought during the life of the co-tenancy to obtain damages or injunctive relief. As to termination, any co-tenant generally has the right to seek judicial partition. Courts favor partition in kind, physically dividing the property into separate parcels corresponding to the co-tenants' interests when feasible. Where a physical division is impractical, would prejudice the parties, or would substantially reduce the overall value of the land, a court may instead order partition by sale and then apportion the sale proceeds among the co-tenants according to their fractional interests. Co-tenants may agree by contract not to partition, but such non-partition agreements are enforceable only if they are limited to a reasonable period and serve legitimate ends (such as maintaining family property or facilitating a business venture). Agreements that purport to bar partition indefinitely or for an unreasonably long time are invalid as unreasonable restraints on alienation and will not prevent a co-tenant from seeking partition.
cards.mnemonic: "WP": Waste rules and Partition rights, limits on no-partition Pacts.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 3 of 3 for real-property-017: focuses on waste actions between co-tenants and partition / non-partition agreement rules.
cards.clozeLite: Any {{c1::co-tenant}} may sue another for {{c2::waste}} and may seek {{c3::judicial partition}}; {{c4::non-partition agreements}} are valid only for a {{c5::reasonable time}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Tenant's Duty to Repair and Habitability Interaction
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 022-1. Tenant's Duty to Repair and Habitability Interaction
cards.front: Tenant's Duty to Repair and Habitability
cards.frontPrompt: What is the tenant's common law duty to repair, and how is that duty modified in residential leases by the implied warranty of habitability?
cards.backPlain: 1. Tenant's duty to repair at common law: 1.1 The tenant has a duty to maintain the premises. 1.2 The tenant must make ordinary repairs to keep the property in its pre-lease condition, excluding normal wear and tear unless the lease provides otherwise. 1.3 This duty can be largely modified or allocated by the lease terms. 2. Residential leases and the implied warranty of habitability: 2.1 In residential leases, the tenant's duty to repair is limited by the implied warranty of habitability. 2.2 The landlord, not the tenant, generally bears responsibility for maintaining basic habitability (e.g., heat, water, structural safety) regardless of lease provisions. 2.3 A tenant's failure to repair in residential leases is evaluated against this backdrop: the tenant still must avoid damage and may need to make minor, ordinary repairs, but cannot be required to waive habitability protections.
cards.cloze: 1. Tenant's duty to {{c1::repair}} at common law: 1.1 The tenant has a duty to {{c2::maintain the premises}}. 1.2 The tenant must make {{c3::ordinary repairs}} to keep the property in its pre-lease condition. 1.3 This duty can be largely {{c4::modified by the lease terms}}. 2. Residential leases and {{c5::implied warranty of habitability}}: 2.1 In residential leases, the tenant's duty to repair is {{c6::limited}} by the implied warranty of habitability. 2.2 The {{c7::landlord}} generally bears responsibility for maintaining basic habitability. 2.3 The tenant still must avoid {{c8::damage}} and may need to make {{c9::minor, ordinary repairs}}, but cannot be forced to {{c10::waive habitability protections}}.
cards.easyContent: At common law, tenants must maintain the premises and make ordinary repairs, but in residential leases that duty is limited by the landlord's implied warranty of habitability.
cards.mediumContent: Common law imposes on tenants a duty to maintain the premises and make ordinary repairs, subject to modification by lease terms. In residential leases, however, the implied warranty of habitability shifts core repair and maintenance obligations—especially those affecting basic living conditions—to the landlord, leaving the tenant primarily responsible for ordinary upkeep and avoiding damage.
cards.hardContent: At common law, tenants are obligated to maintain the premises and make ordinary repairs necessary to preserve the property in its pre-lease condition, excluding ordinary wear and tear unless the lease provides otherwise. These repair obligations can be rearranged or expanded by agreement in the lease. In residential leases, though, the tenant's repair duties operate within the framework of the implied warranty of habitability. That warranty places primary responsibility on the landlord to keep the premises safe and habitable, including essential services and structural soundness, regardless of contrary lease language. The tenant still must not damage the premises and must handle minor, ordinary upkeep, but cannot be saddled with the duty to ensure habitability or to waive habitability protections.
cards.mnemonic: Common law: tenant repairs; Habitability: landlord handles living conditions.
cards.clozeLite: At {{c1::common law}}, tenants must {{c2::maintain the premises and make ordinary repairs}}, but in {{c3::residential leases}} the {{c4::implied warranty of habitability}} shifts core repair duties to the {{c5::landlord}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Tenant's Duty Not to Commit Waste
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 022-2. Tenant's Duty Not to Commit Waste
cards.front: Tenant's Duty Not to Commit Waste
cards.frontPrompt: What is the tenant's common law duty regarding waste, and what are the three types of waste?
cards.backPlain: 1. General duty not to commit waste: 1.1 At common law, a tenant must not commit waste, meaning they must not substantially harm or improperly alter the landlord's reversionary interest in the property. 2. Types of waste: 2.1 Voluntary (affirmative) waste: - Overt, intentional or negligent acts that substantially reduce the property's value. - Examples: Removing fixtures, tearing down structures, or exploiting resources contrary to normal use. 2.2 Permissive waste: - Waste by neglect or omission. - Failure to take reasonable steps to protect the property from damage (e.g., not fixing leaks, allowing property to fall into disrepair). 2.3 Ameliorative waste: - Unauthorized alterations that change or increase the property's value without the landlord's consent. - Even beneficial improvements can be waste if they materially change the character of the property or the landlord's expectations.
cards.cloze: 1. General duty: 1.1 A tenant has a duty not to commit {{c1::waste}}, meaning they may not substantially harm or improperly alter the landlord's {{c2::reversionary interest}}. 2. Types of waste: 2.1 {{c3::Voluntary (affirmative) waste}}: Overt acts that substantially {{c4::reduce the property's value}} (e.g., removing fixtures). 2.2 {{c5::Permissive waste}}: Waste by {{c6::neglect or omission}}, such as failing to take reasonable steps to protect the property. 2.3 {{c7::Ameliorative waste}}: Unauthorized alterations that {{c8::change or increase value}} without the {{c9::landlord's consent}}, even if seemingly beneficial.
cards.easyContent: Tenants must not commit waste. Waste can be voluntary (harmful acts), permissive (neglect), or ameliorative (unauthorized improvements that change the property).
cards.mediumContent: The tenant's common law duty not to commit waste protects the landlord's reversion. Voluntary waste consists of overt acts that reduce value (like removing fixtures). Permissive waste is failure to maintain or protect the property, leading to deterioration. Ameliorative waste is making unauthorized changes that increase or alter the property's value or character without the landlord's consent.
cards.hardContent: At common law, tenants owe a duty not to commit waste, which safeguards the landlord's reversionary interest. Voluntary or affirmative waste arises from intentional or negligent acts that substantially reduce the property's value, such as destroying structures or stripping fixtures. Permissive waste results from the tenant's failure to exercise reasonable care in maintaining the property—e.g., ignoring leaks or failing to secure the building—so that it deteriorates. Ameliorative waste involves unauthorized improvements or alterations that change or even increase the property's value without the landlord's consent. Despite being beneficial from the tenant's perspective, such changes can still be actionable waste if they materially alter the property's character or undermine the landlord's intended use or expectations.
cards.mnemonic: Waste types: V-P-A – Voluntary, Permissive, Ameliorative.
cards.clozeLite: Tenant's {{c1::common law duty not to commit waste}} protects {{c2::landlord's reversion}} and includes {{c3::voluntary}}, {{c4::permissive}}, and {{c5::ameliorative}} waste.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Destruction of Premises – Common Law vs Modern
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 022-3. Destruction of Premises – Common Law vs Modern
cards.front: Destruction of Premises: Common Law vs Modern
cards.frontPrompt: What are the tenant's obligations when the leased premises are destroyed without fault of either party at common law and under modern law?
cards.backPlain: 1. Destruction of premises without fault (common law rule): 1.1 At common law, the tenant bore the risk of loss when the premises were destroyed without the fault of either landlord or tenant. 1.2 The tenant remained obligated to pay rent despite destruction of the premises. 1.3 The tenant could not terminate the lease solely because the premises were destroyed. 2. Modern law approach: 2.1 Modern law generally shifts the risk of loss in the event of destruction without fault. 2.2 In many jurisdictions, if the premises are substantially or totally destroyed without the fault of either party, the tenant may terminate the lease. 2.3 Termination typically ends the tenant's future rent obligation from the date of destruction or a statutory/contractual date.
cards.cloze: 1. Common law rule: 1.1 When the premises were destroyed without fault, the {{c1::tenant}} bore the risk of loss. 1.2 The tenant remained obligated to {{c2::pay rent}} even after destruction. 1.3 The tenant generally could {{c3::not terminate}} the lease solely due to destruction. 2. Modern law: 2.1 Modern law generally allows the {{c4::tenant}} to {{c5::terminate the lease}} when the premises are substantially or totally destroyed without fault of either party. 2.2 Upon proper termination, the tenant's obligation to {{c6::pay future rent}} usually ends from the time of destruction or as provided by law or contract.
cards.easyContent: At common law, tenants still had to pay rent even if the premises were destroyed without fault. Modern law typically lets tenants terminate the lease and stop paying future rent when the premises are destroyed without fault.
cards.mediumContent: If leased premises were destroyed without fault of landlord or tenant, common law treated the tenant as still bound to the lease and required continued rent payments. Modern law usually reverses this: substantial or total destruction without fault generally permits the tenant to terminate the lease and end future rent obligations as of the destruction or a statutory/contractual date.
cards.hardContent: Under common law, destruction of the leased premises without fault of either landlord or tenant did not relieve the tenant of the obligation to pay rent. The tenant bore the risk of loss and had no automatic right to terminate the lease solely because the premises were rendered unusable. Modern law, by contrast, generally allows termination when the leased premises are substantially or completely destroyed without the fault of either party. Upon such destruction, if the tenant properly invokes termination rights, the lease ends and the tenant's obligation to pay future rent is discharged from the time of destruction or as specified by statute or contract, shifting the risk of physical loss away from the tenant.
cards.mnemonic: Destruction: CL = tenant stuck; Modern = tenant can walk.
cards.clozeLite: At {{c1::common law}}, tenants still had to {{c2::pay rent}} after {{c3::destruction without fault}}; {{c4::modern law}} lets tenants {{c5::terminate and end future rent}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Tenant's Duties to Pay Rent and Avoid Illegal Use
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 022-4. Tenant's Duties to Pay Rent and Avoid Illegal Use
cards.front: Tenant's Duties: Pay Rent and Avoid Illegal Use
cards.frontPrompt: What are the tenant's duties to pay rent and to avoid illegal use of the premises, and what remedies does the landlord have for breaches?
cards.backPlain: 1. Duty to pay rent: 1.1 At common law and under modern law, the tenant has a basic duty to pay rent as agreed in the lease. 1.2 If the tenant fails to pay rent and wrongfully holds over after expiration or termination, a tenancy at sufferance arises. 1.3 The landlord may pursue eviction, damages for unpaid rent, or other remedies provided by statute or the lease. 2. Duty not to use property for illegal purposes: 2.1 The tenant must not use the premises for illegal purposes (e.g., ongoing criminal enterprises or activities prohibited by law). 2.2 If the tenant uses the premises for an illegal purpose, the landlord may terminate the lease or seek damages and injunctive relief. 2.3 Occasional, minor illegal activities typically do not constitute a material breach of this duty and may not justify termination. 2.4 Many leases and statutes specifically authorize termination upon proof of substantial or continuing illegal use.
cards.cloze: 1. Duty to {{c1::pay rent}}: 1.1 The tenant must pay rent as {{c2::agreed in the lease}}. 1.2 If the tenant fails to pay rent and wrongfully holds over, a {{c3::tenancy at sufferance}} arises. 2. Duty not to use for {{c4::illegal purposes}}: 2.1 The tenant must not use the premises for illegal purposes, such as ongoing criminal enterprises. 2.2 For illegal use, the landlord may {{c5::terminate the lease}} or seek {{c6::damages and injunctive relief}}. 2.3 {{c7::Occasional, minor illegal activities}} usually do not amount to a material breach justifying termination.
cards.easyContent: Tenants must pay rent and not use the premises for illegal purposes. Nonpayment can lead to a tenancy at sufferance and eviction, while substantial illegal use lets the landlord terminate or seek damages and injunctions.
cards.mediumContent: A tenant is obligated to pay rent as specified in the lease, and wrongful nonpayment plus holdover creates a tenancy at sufferance, allowing the landlord to evict and recover unpaid rent. The tenant also must not use the property for illegal purposes; substantial or ongoing illegal use lets the landlord terminate the lease or seek damages and injunctive relief, though minor, occasional illegal acts usually are not enough for termination.
cards.hardContent: The tenant's duty to pay rent is fundamental: rent must be paid in the amount and at the times set by the lease. If the tenant fails to pay and remains in possession after the lease term or after a lawful termination, a tenancy at sufferance arises, permitting the landlord to pursue eviction and monetary damages for unpaid rent or use and occupancy. Separately, tenants must refrain from using the premises for illegal purposes, which typically means more than isolated minor violations and includes ongoing criminal activity or uses contrary to law. When a tenant engages in such illegal use, the landlord may terminate the lease and seek damages and injunctive relief, especially where the lease or governing statutes expressly authorize termination for substantial or repeated illegal conduct. Occasional, minor illegal activities generally do not constitute a material breach sufficient to justify termination.
cards.mnemonic: PAY & OBEY: Pay rent, Obey law, or Exit.
cards.clozeLite: A tenant must {{c1::pay rent as specified in the lease}} and {{c2::avoid substantial or ongoing illegal use}} or the landlord may {{c3::evict and seek damages}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 022-5. Tenant's Liability to Third Parties (Tort)
cards.frontPrompt: When can a tenant be liable in tort to third parties for conditions on the leased premises?
cards.backPlain: 1. Tenant's control and tort liability: 1.1 A tenant who is in possession and control of the leased premises may be liable in tort for injuries to third persons. 1.2 Liability typically arises from dangerous conditions on those portions of the property within the tenant's control. 2. Scope of tenant's responsibility: 2.1 The tenant must exercise reasonable care to keep areas under their control in a reasonably safe condition. 2.2 If the tenant knows or should know of a dangerous condition and fails to remedy it or warn, the tenant may be liable for resulting injuries to lawful visitors or others owed a duty of care. 2.3 The landlord's concurrent duties (e.g., in common areas) do not eliminate the tenant's separate duty in areas the tenant controls.
cards.cloze: 1. Tenant's control: 1.1 A tenant may be liable in tort for injuries to third persons caused by {{c1::dangerous conditions}} on portions of the premises within the tenant's {{c2::control}}. 2. Duty of care: 2.1 The tenant must exercise {{c3::reasonable care}} to keep areas under their control reasonably safe. 2.2 If the tenant {{c4::knows or should know}} of a dangerous condition and fails to {{c5::remedy or warn}}, they may be liable for resulting injuries. 2.3 The landlord's duties in other areas do {{c6::not eliminate}} the tenant's own duty in areas the tenant controls.
cards.easyContent: Tenants can be liable in tort to third parties for injuries caused by dangerous conditions in areas they control if they fail to use reasonable care to fix or warn of those conditions.
cards.mediumContent: Because tenants usually control the leased space, they may be liable in tort when dangerous conditions there injure third parties. A tenant who knows or should know of a hazard in areas under their control must use reasonable care to repair it or warn; failure to do so can create liability, independent of the landlord's separate obligations.
cards.hardContent: Tenants who are in control of leased premises owe ordinary tort duties to third parties entering those areas. When a dangerous condition exists in a portion of the property under the tenant's control, and the tenant knows or should know of the risk, the tenant must take reasonable steps to correct the hazard or adequately warn those foreseeably at risk. Failure to exercise such reasonable care can result in tort liability for injuries to entrants such as customers, guests, or other lawful visitors. The landlord's duties—especially regarding common areas or latent defects—do not negate the tenant's concurrent responsibility in areas the tenant controls.
cards.mnemonic: Tenant in CONTROL must CONTROL hazards: fix or warn.
cards.clozeLite: A tenant is liable in tort for {{c1::dangerous conditions}} in {{c2::areas under the tenant's control}} when the tenant {{c3::knows or should know of the hazard}} and {{c4::fails to repair or warn}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 024-1. Landlord Remedies – Tenant Retains Possession
cards.backPlain: If a tenant breaches leasehold duties but remains in possession of the premises, the landlord has two primary options: 1. Eviction (summary proceeding) 1.1 The landlord may file a summary eviction proceeding to recover possession of the premises. 2. Continue the lease and sue for rent 2.1 The landlord may choose to keep the lease in effect and instead sue the tenant for rent due (and any other amounts owed under the lease).
cards.frontPrompt: When a tenant breaches but remains in possession, what remedies does the landlord have?
cards.cloze: If a tenant {{c1::breaches}} leasehold duties but {{c2::remains in possession}} of the premises, the landlord has two primary options: 1. {{c3::Eviction (summary proceeding)}} – the landlord may file a summary proceeding to {{c4::recover possession}}. 2. {{c5::Continue the lease and sue for rent}} – the landlord may keep the lease in effect and {{c6::sue for rent due and other amounts owed}}.
cards.easyContent: If the tenant breaches but stays in the unit, the landlord can either evict through a summary proceeding or keep the lease and sue for rent due.
cards.mediumContent: When a tenant breaches and remains in possession, the landlord may (1) file a summary eviction action to regain possession, or (2) elect to continue the lease and sue the tenant for accrued rent and other amounts due under the lease.
cards.hardContent: If a tenant breaches leasehold duties but does not abandon the premises, the landlord’s remedies focus on either recovering possession or collecting money. The landlord may file a summary eviction proceeding to remove the tenant and regain possession. Alternatively, the landlord may elect to continue the lease in force, leaving the tenant in possession, and sue for rent due (and any other amounts owed under the lease, such as late fees or other charges).
cards.mnemonic: Tenant stays: P-R—Possession (evict) or Rent (keep lease, sue).
cards.clozeLite: If a tenant {{c1::breaches and stays in possession}}, landlord may {{c2::evict via summary proceeding}} or {{c3::keep lease and sue for accrued rent}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 024-2. Landlord Remedies – Tenant Abandons (SIR)
cards.backPlain: If a tenant breaches leasehold duties and abandons the premises, the landlord’s options are commonly summarized as SIR: 1. Surrender 1.1 The landlord may treat the tenant’s abandonment as an offer of surrender. 1.2 If the landlord accepts the surrender, the lease terminates and the tenant is released from further liability for future rent. 2. Ignore (minority rule) 2.1 Under the minority rule, the landlord may ignore the abandonment and do nothing to re-let. 2.2 The landlord may then hold the tenant liable for unpaid rent as it comes due under the lease. 3. Re-let (majority rule) 3.1 Under the majority rule, the landlord must make reasonable efforts to re-let the premises to a new tenant. 3.2 The landlord may then hold the breaching tenant liable for losses, typically the difference between the contract rent and the new tenant’s rent, plus reasonable costs of re-letting.
cards.frontPrompt: If a tenant breaches and abandons the premises, what options does the landlord have under the SIR framework, and which option is the majority rule?
cards.cloze: If a tenant {{c1::breaches}} and {{c2::abandons}} the premises, the landlord’s options are often summarized as {{c3::SIR}}: 1. {{c4::Surrender}} – the landlord may {{c5::treat abandonment as an offer of surrender}} and, by accepting it, {{c6::terminate the lease and release the tenant from further liability}}. 2. {{c7::Ignore (minority rule)}} – under the {{c8::minority rule}}, the landlord may {{c9::ignore the abandonment and not re-let}}, holding the tenant {{c10::liable for unpaid rent}} as it accrues. 3. {{c11::Re-let (majority rule)}} – under the {{c12::majority rule}}, the landlord must {{c13::make reasonable efforts to re-let}} and may then {{c14::recover losses}} from the breaching tenant, typically the {{c15::difference between contract rent and new rent plus re-letting costs}}.
cards.easyContent: If the tenant breaches and abandons, think SIR: the landlord can accept Surrender, Ignore abandonment (minority rule) and keep charging rent, or Re-let (majority rule) and recover the loss between contract rent and the new rent plus costs.
cards.mediumContent: Where a tenant breaches and abandons, the landlord has three main options summarized as SIR. The landlord may accept Surrender, terminating the lease and future liability. Under a minority rule, the landlord may Ignore the abandonment and continue to hold the tenant liable for rent. Under the majority rule, the landlord must attempt to Re-let the premises to mitigate damages and may then recover the difference between the lease rent and the new rent plus reasonable re-letting costs from the breaching tenant.
cards.hardContent: When a tenant breaches and abandons the premises, the landlord’s remedies are often described by the SIR mnemonic. First, the landlord may treat the abandonment as an offer of Surrender; by accepting the surrender, the landlord terminates the lease and releases the tenant from further obligations for future rent, though accrued obligations may remain. Second, under a minority rule, the landlord may Ignore the abandonment, decline to re-let, and hold the tenant liable for unpaid rent as it comes due for the remainder of the lease term. Third, under the majority rule, the landlord has a duty to make reasonable efforts to Re-let the premises to new tenants and may then hold the breaching tenant liable for losses, usually calculated as the difference between the contract rent and the rent obtained on re-letting, plus reasonable costs of re-letting (such as advertising or brokerage fees).
cards.mnemonic: SIR: Surrender, Ignore (minority), Re-let (majority).
cards.clozeLite: If a tenant abandons, the landlord can {{c1::Surrender}}, {{c2::Ignore (minority rule)}}, or {{c3::Re-let (majority rule)}} the premises.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Limits on Landlord Remedies – No Self-Help, Security Deposits, Retaliatory Eviction
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 024-3. Limits on Landlord Remedies – No Self-Help, Security Deposits, Retaliatory Eviction
cards.front: Limits on Landlord Remedies – Self-Help, Security Deposits, Retaliatory Eviction
cards.backPlain: 1. No self-help 1.1 A landlord may not use self-help to recover possession after a tenant’s breach. 1.2 Prohibited self-help measures include forcibly removing the tenant or the tenant’s belongings, changing the locks, and shutting off essential utilities. 2. Security deposit 2.1 A security deposit is typically collected at the beginning of a lease to secure the landlord against damages or abandonment. 2.2 When the lease terminates, the landlord must return the security deposit to the tenant. 2.3 The landlord may deduct only for actual damages or other contractually permitted losses (such as unpaid rent or authorized fees). 3. Retaliatory eviction 3.1 A landlord is prohibited from retaliatory eviction or other retaliatory measures when a tenant lawfully exercises protected rights. 3.2 Protected tenant activities include reporting housing code or other legal violations and asserting or enforcing statutory or contractual tenant rights.
cards.frontPrompt: What limits constrain a landlord’s remedies after tenant breach with respect to self-help, handling security deposits, and retaliatory eviction?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::No self-help}} 1.1 A landlord may not use {{c2::self-help}} to recover possession after a tenant’s breach. 1.2 Prohibited measures include {{c3::forcibly removing the tenant or belongings}}, {{c4::changing locks}}, and {{c5::shutting off utilities}}. 2. {{c6::Security deposit}} 2.1 A security deposit is typically collected at lease inception to secure against {{c7::damages or abandonment}}. 2.2 When the lease {{c8::terminates}}, the landlord must {{c9::return the security deposit}} to the tenant. 2.3 The landlord may deduct only for {{c10::actual damages}} or other {{c11::contractually permitted losses}} (such as {{c12::unpaid rent or authorized fees}}). 3. {{c13::Retaliatory eviction}} 3.1 A landlord is prohibited from {{c14::retaliatory eviction}} or other {{c15::retaliatory measures}} when a tenant {{c16::lawfully exercises protected rights}}. 3.2 Protected activities include {{c17::reporting housing code or other violations}} and {{c18::asserting or enforcing statutory or contractual tenant rights}}.
cards.easyContent: Landlords cannot use self-help (like lockouts or shutting off utilities) to retake possession. They must return security deposits at lease end, keeping only amounts for actual damages or contractually allowed losses. They also may not retaliate against tenants—such as by evicting—because tenants report violations or assert their legal rights.
cards.mediumContent: Landlord remedies are limited by three major doctrines. First, no self-help: a landlord must use lawful eviction procedures and may not resort to forcible removal, lockouts, or cutting utilities to oust a tenant. Second, security deposits must be properly handled: they are collected to secure against damage or abandonment, but at lease termination the landlord must return the deposit, retaining only amounts for actual damages or other contractually authorized deductions, like unpaid rent. Third, retaliatory eviction is prohibited: a landlord cannot evict or otherwise punish a tenant because the tenant reported housing code or other violations or exercised statutory or contractual tenant rights.
cards.hardContent: Even when a tenant breaches, the landlord’s remedies are limited. The landlord may not engage in self-help to recover possession; instead, the landlord must pursue formal legal processes (such as summary eviction). Self-help measures like forcible removal of the tenant or the tenant’s property, lock changes to exclude the tenant, or shutting off essential utilities are prohibited. Security deposits, typically collected at the outset of the lease to secure against damage or abandonment, must be handled in good faith. When the lease ends, the landlord must return the deposit to the tenant, minus only legitimate deductions for actual damage to the premises, unpaid rent, or other losses expressly allowed by the lease or governing law. Additionally, landlords are barred from retaliatory eviction and other retaliatory conduct. A landlord may not evict, raise rent, or otherwise penalize a tenant in response to the tenant’s lawful exercise of protected rights, such as reporting housing code or other legal violations to authorities or asserting statutory or contractual tenant protections.
cards.mnemonic: SRS: no Self-help, proper Refund, no Sanctions (retaliation).
cards.clozeLite: Limits on landlord remedies: {{c1::no self-help to evict}}, {{c2::proper return of security deposits minus damages}}, and {{c3::no retaliatory eviction for tenant rights}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Assignments and Subleases – General Transferability of Leaseholds
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 029-1. General Transferability of Leaseholds
cards.front: Assignments and Subleases – General Rule on Transferability
cards.backPlain: General rule: Unless restricted by the terms of the lease, a tenant may transfer her leasehold interest either in whole (an assignment) or in part (a sublease). • Assignment: Transfer of the tenant’s entire remaining leasehold interest (both in duration and physical area) to another. • Sublease: Transfer of less than the tenant’s entire leasehold interest (e.g., shorter duration or smaller portion of the premises). The characterization as assignment vs. sublease affects privity and which party is directly liable to the landlord, but the baseline ability to transfer exists absent valid restrictions in the lease.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general rule on a tenant’s ability to transfer a leasehold, and how are assignments and subleases distinguished at a basic level?
cards.cloze: General rule: Unless {{c1::restricted by the terms of the lease}}, a tenant may transfer her leasehold interest either {{c2::in whole (an assignment)}} or {{c3::in part (a sublease)}}. An {{c4::assignment}} is a transfer of the tenant’s {{c5::entire remaining leasehold interest}} (both in duration and physical area) to another. A {{c6::sublease}} is a transfer of {{c7::less than the tenant’s entire leasehold interest}} (such as a shorter duration or only part of the premises).
cards.easyContent: By default, a tenant can transfer the leasehold unless the lease restricts transfers. If she transfers the entire remaining interest, it’s an assignment; if she transfers less than the whole, it’s a sublease.
cards.mediumContent: Leasehold interests are generally transferable. Unless the lease says otherwise, a tenant may transfer her interest either in whole (assignment) or in part (sublease). An assignment occurs when the tenant conveys her entire remaining interest in the premises; a sublease occurs when the tenant conveys less than her entire remaining interest, whether in duration or physical area.
cards.hardContent: By default, a tenant’s leasehold interest is freely transferable unless the lease specifically restricts transfer. A transfer in whole—where the tenant conveys the entire remaining lease term and interest in the premises—is an assignment. A transfer in part—where the tenant retains some portion of the duration or physical space—is a sublease. This classification as assignment or sublease is critical because it determines which parties are in privity of estate and contract with the landlord and who is directly liable for rent and covenants.
cards.mnemonic: ALL goes = Assignment; a SLICE stays = Sublease; default = transferable.
cards.clozeLite: Leaseholds are {{c1::generally transferable}} unless the {{c2::lease restricts transfer}}. {{c3::Assignment}} = transfer of {{c4::entire remaining interest}}; {{c5::sublease}} = {{c6::less than entire interest}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 029-2. Assignments – Privity and Rent Consequences
cards.backPlain: Assignment definition and effect: • The tenant transfers the entire leasehold interest (both in duration and physical area) to the assignee. Privity: • The assignee is in privity of estate with the landlord. – As a result, the assignee and landlord are bound by all covenants that run with the land (e.g., rent, repair, etc.). • The original tenant–assignor remains in privity of contract with the landlord unless there is a novation. Rent and liability: • The assignee owes rent directly to the landlord while in possession because of privity of estate. • The assignor remains liable for unpaid rent and other contractual obligations to the landlord until the landlord expressly releases the tenant via novation or other clear agreement. Thus, after an assignment, both assignee (via privity of estate) and assignor (via privity of contract) can be on the hook for lease obligations unless a novation cuts off the assignor’s contract liability.
cards.frontPrompt: After an assignment of a lease, who is in privity of estate and privity of contract with the landlord, and who can be held liable for rent?
cards.cloze: In an {{c1::assignment}}, the tenant transfers the {{c2::entire leasehold interest}} (both duration and physical area) to the assignee. Privity: • The {{c3::assignee is in privity of estate}} with the landlord and is bound by {{c4::covenants that run with the land}}. • The {{c5::assignor remains in privity of contract}} with the landlord absent novation. Rent and liability: • The {{c6::assignee owes rent directly to the landlord}} while in possession. • The {{c7::assignor remains liable for unpaid rent}} and other contractual obligations unless the landlord expressly releases the tenant via {{c8::novation}}.
cards.easyContent: In an assignment, the entire leasehold is transferred. The assignee comes into privity of estate with the landlord and must pay rent directly. The original tenant stays in privity of contract and remains liable for unpaid rent unless there is a novation releasing them.
cards.mediumContent: An assignment occurs when the tenant transfers her entire remaining leasehold interest. The assignee enters privity of estate with the landlord and is bound by covenants that run with the land, including rent. The original tenant (assignor) usually remains in privity of contract with the landlord and is secondarily liable for rent and other lease obligations unless the landlord expressly agrees to a novation that substitutes the assignee and releases the assignor.
cards.hardContent: In an assignment, the tenant conveys the entire remaining leasehold interest, including both the duration and physical premises, to an assignee. This places the assignee in privity of estate with the landlord, so the assignee and landlord are mutually bound by all covenants that run with the land (such as the covenant to pay rent or to repair). The original tenant–assignor, however, typically remains in privity of contract with the landlord because the lease is a contract between them; as a result, the landlord may sue the assignor for unpaid rent or other contractual breaches unless and until the landlord agrees to a novation that releases the assignor and substitutes the assignee as the contractual tenant. Thus, after an assignment, the landlord may usually look to both the assignee (via privity of estate) and the assignor (via privity of contract) for performance of lease obligations.
cards.mnemonic: Assignment: All goes over, but contract leash stays until novation.
cards.clozeLite: After an {{c1::assignment}}, the {{c2::assignee is in privity of estate}} and {{c3::the original tenant remains in privity of contract}} with the landlord, so {{c4::both can be liable for rent unless a novation releases the assignor}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 029-3. Subleases – Privity and Rent Consequences
cards.backPlain: Sublease definition and effect: • A sublease is a transfer of less than the tenant’s entire leasehold interest from the sublessor (original tenant) to the sublessee. Privity: • The sublessor (original tenant) remains in privity of estate and in privity of contract with the landlord. – The relationship between tenant and landlord is unchanged by the sublease. • There is typically no direct privity of estate or contract between the landlord and the sublessee. Rent and liability: • The sublessee pays rent to the sublessor, not to the landlord. • The sublessee is not directly liable to the landlord for rent or lease covenants unless the sublessee expressly assumes those obligations. Thus, in a sublease, the original tenant remains the landlord’s only tenant, and the sublessee is treated as the original tenant’s tenant, with no automatic direct liability to the landlord.
cards.frontPrompt: In a sublease, who remains in privity of estate and contract with the landlord, and what are the sublessee’s obligations regarding rent and covenants?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::sublease}} is a transfer of {{c2::less than the tenant’s entire leasehold interest}} from the sublessor (original tenant) to the sublessee. Privity: • The {{c3::sublessor remains in privity of estate and privity of contract}} with the landlord; the landlord–tenant relationship is unchanged. • There is typically {{c4::no direct privity}} between the landlord and sublessee. Rent and liability: • The {{c5::sublessee pays rent to the sublessor}}, not the landlord. • The sublessee is {{c6::not directly liable to the landlord for rent}} and {{c7::not bound by lease covenants unless expressly assumed}}.
cards.easyContent: In a sublease, the original tenant keeps the legal relationship with the landlord and remains in privity of estate and contract. The sublessee pays rent to the original tenant and is not directly liable to the landlord unless the sublessee expressly assumes lease obligations.
cards.mediumContent: A sublease is created when the original tenant transfers less than her entire interest to another. The original tenant (sublessor) stays in privity of estate and privity of contract with the landlord, so the landlord–tenant relationship is unchanged. The sublessee pays rent to the sublessor and is not directly liable to the landlord for rent or covenants unless the sublessee affirmatively assumes those obligations.
cards.hardContent: A sublease arises when the original tenant conveys a lesser interest than her full remaining lease term or premises to a sublessee. Because the tenant retains some interest, she remains in both privity of estate and privity of contract with the landlord; therefore, the landlord continues to treat the original tenant as the tenant for all lease purposes. The sublessee’s relationship is with the sublessor: the sublessee pays rent to the sublessor and is not ordinarily in privity of estate or contract with the landlord. Consequently, the sublessee is not directly liable to the landlord for rent or other lease covenants unless the sublessee expressly assumes those obligations in an agreement that the landlord can enforce (e.g., as a third-party beneficiary).
cards.mnemonic: Sublease = Slice; sublessee pays tenant, tenant pays landlord.
cards.clozeLite: In a {{c1::sublease}}, the {{c2::original tenant}} stays in {{c3::privity of estate and contract}} with the landlord, and the {{c4::sublessee pays rent to the sublessor}} unless {{c5::obligations are expressly assumed}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 029-4. Assignment/Sublease Restrictions – Construction and Waiver
cards.backPlain: Restrictions on assignment or sublease: • Lease provisions restricting assignment or sublease are generally enforceable. • Such provisions are construed against the landlord, meaning ambiguities are resolved in favor of the tenant’s ability to transfer. Construction: • Clauses are read narrowly; if a clause restricts “assignments,” it may not automatically restrict subleases, unless the language clearly covers both. • Courts often resist forfeitures and disfavor unduly broad readings of restraint-on-alienation clauses. Waiver of restrictions: • Once the landlord gives the tenant permission to assign or sublet contrary to a restriction, that restriction is generally treated as waived for that tenant, unless the lease clearly provides otherwise. • The landlord can preserve the restriction by expressly stating that consent to one transfer does not waive the right to enforce the clause against future transfers. Bottom line: Consent-to-assign or sublet clauses are valid but strictly construed against the landlord, and consent typically operates as a waiver of restrictions unless clearly limited.
cards.frontPrompt: How are lease clauses restricting assignments or subleases treated by courts, and when does a landlord’s consent operate as a waiver of those restrictions?
cards.cloze: Restrictions on transfer: • Lease provisions restricting assignment or sublease are generally {{c1::enforceable}}. • Such provisions are {{c2::construed against the landlord}}, so ambiguities favor the tenant’s ability to transfer. Construction: • Clauses are read {{c3::narrowly}}; a restriction on “assignments” does not automatically bar subleases unless {{c4::clearly stated}}. Waiver: • Once the landlord gives a tenant permission to assign or sublet despite a restriction, that restriction is generally treated as {{c5::waived}} going forward for that tenant, unless the lease {{c6::clearly provides otherwise}}. • The landlord may preserve the restriction by {{c7::expressly stating that consent to one transfer does not waive future enforcement}}.
cards.easyContent: Clauses that restrict assignments or subleases are valid but strictly construed against the landlord. Ambiguities are read to allow transfer. If a landlord consents to an assignment or sublease once, that usually waives the restriction unless the lease clearly says consent doesn’t waive it for future transfers.
cards.mediumContent: Lease provisions limiting assignment or sublease are enforceable, but courts construe them narrowly and against the landlord as restraints on alienation. A clause that mentions only assignments may not be read to bar subleases unless the language clearly extends to them. When a landlord consents to a transfer despite such a restriction, that consent generally waives the restriction for that tenant unless the lease specifically preserves the landlord’s right to enforce it against later transfers (for example, by stating that consent to one transfer does not waive future enforcement).
cards.hardContent: Consent-to-assign and consent-to-sublet clauses are valid restraints on the tenant’s ability to alienate, but because they operate as restraints on alienation, courts interpret them strictly against the landlord. The provisions are enforceable, yet ambiguities are resolved in favor of transferability: a clause that only mentions “assignments” may not reach subleases unless clearly drafted to do so. Furthermore, when a landlord voluntarily consents to an assignment or sublease that would otherwise violate a restriction, that consent typically functions as a waiver of the restriction for that tenant with respect to similar transfers, unless the lease contains clear language reserving the landlord’s right to enforce the restriction later (e.g., “consent to one assignment or sublease shall not be deemed a waiver of this provision as to future transfers”).
cards.mnemonic: R-CAN: Restraint, Construe Against, Non-waiver needed.
cards.clozeLite: Courts {{c1::strictly construe}} lease {{c2::assignment/sublease restrictions}} against the landlord, and {{c3::landlord consent}} usually {{c4::waives the restriction}} unless {{c5::non-waiver language}} is in the lease.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 030-1. Easements – Definition and Estates
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of an easement 1.1 An easement is a non-possessory property interest that confers a right to use another's land. 2. Servient and dominant estates 2.1 Servient estate: The burdened land subject to the easement. 2.2 Dominant estate: The benefited land (when the easement benefits a parcel rather than a person). Not all easements have a dominant estate (e.g., easements in gross).
cards.frontPrompt: What is an easement, and what are the servient and dominant estates?
cards.cloze: An {{c1::easement}} is a {{c2::non-possessory property interest}} that confers a {{c3::right to use another's land}}. The {{c4::servient estate}} is the {{c5::burdened land}}. The {{c6::dominant estate}} is the {{c7::benefited land}}, and it is not present in every easement (e.g., easements in gross).
cards.easyContent: An easement is a non-possessory right to use another’s land. The land burdened is the servient estate; the land benefited, if any, is the dominant estate.
cards.mediumContent: An easement is a non-possessory property interest giving the holder a right to use someone else’s land. The land subject to the easement is the servient estate. If the easement benefits a particular parcel, that parcel is the dominant estate; some easements (like easements in gross) have no dominant estate.
cards.hardContent: An easement is a non-possessory property interest that confers a right to use another's land, rather than to possess it. The land burdened by the easement is the servient estate. If the easement benefits a particular parcel of land, that parcel is the dominant estate. Not all easements have a dominant estate—for example, easements in gross benefit a person or entity instead of a parcel.
cards.mnemonic: Servient serves the burden; Dominant dominates the benefit.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::easement}} is a {{c2::non-possessory right to use}} another’s land; the {{c3::servient estate}} is burdened, the {{c4::dominant estate}} is benefited.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 030-2. Easements – Appurtenant vs. In Gross
cards.backPlain: 1. Easement appurtenant 1.1 Entitles the owner of a dominant estate to use a servient estate's land. 1.2 The benefit "runs with" the dominant estate and passes automatically with its transfer, even if not mentioned in the conveyance. 2. Easement in gross 2.1 Entitles an individual or entity (not as owner of a dominant parcel) to use the servient estate. 2.2 Attaches only to the servient estate; there is no dominant estate. 2.3 Examples: The right to place a billboard on another's lot, to run utility lines across land, or to fish in another's pond. 2.4 Compared to a license: Similar in that it allows use of land, but an easement in gross is a property interest that is generally irrevocable and may be transferred.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the difference between an easement appurtenant and an easement in gross, and how do they operate on the land?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Easement appurtenant}} entitles the owner of a {{c2::dominant estate}} to use a {{c3::servient estate}}'s land and {{c4::passes automatically with the dominant estate}} even if not mentioned in a conveyance. An {{c5::easement in gross}} entitles an {{c6::individual or entity, not a dominant landowner}} to use the {{c7::servient estate}}, attaches only to the {{c8::servient estate}}, and there is {{c9::no dominant estate}}. Typical examples include rights to place {{c10::billboards}}, run {{c11::utility lines}}, or {{c12::fish}} in another's pond. Unlike a {{c13::license}}, an easement in gross is generally {{c14::irrevocable}} and may be {{c15::transferred}}.
cards.easyContent: An appurtenant easement benefits a parcel (the dominant estate) and automatically runs with that land. An easement in gross benefits a person or entity, has no dominant estate, and is tied only to the servient land; it is a transferable, generally irrevocable property interest, unlike a license.
cards.mediumContent: An easement appurtenant benefits a dominant parcel and burdens a servient parcel; the benefit runs automatically with transfers of the dominant estate, even if not mentioned. An easement in gross benefits a person or entity, not a parcel; it is attached only to the servient estate and involves no dominant estate. Common examples of easements in gross include billboard, utility, and fishing rights. Unlike a license, an easement in gross is an irrevocable, transferable property interest.
cards.hardContent: An easement appurtenant entitles the owner of a dominant estate to use a servient estate's land. The benefit is tied to the dominant parcel and passes automatically with any conveyance of that parcel, even if the easement is not expressly mentioned in the deed. By contrast, an easement in gross entitles a particular individual or entity, as such, to use the servient estate. It attaches only to the servient land, and there is no dominant estate.
