Examples include the right to place a billboard on another's lot, to run utility lines across land, or to fish in another's pond. These look similar to licenses because they authorize use of land, but an easement in gross is a non-possessory property interest that is generally irrevocable and may be transferred, whereas licenses are usually revocable and non-transferable.
cards.mnemonic: Appurtenant: attached to land; in gross: attached to guy.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::easement appurtenant}} benefits a {{c2::dominant parcel}} and runs with that land; an {{c3::easement in gross}} benefits a {{c4::person or entity only}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 030-3. Easements – Affirmative vs. Negative
cards.backPlain: 1. Affirmative easement 1.1 Entitles its holder to make affirmative use of the servient estate (e.g., crossing, laying pipes, drawing water). 2. Negative easement 2.1 Entitles its holder to restrict the servient estate from otherwise permissible activities (e.g., blocking light or air, building above a certain height, interfering with support or flow of an artificial stream). 2.2 Functionally similar to a restrictive covenant but conceptually treated as an easement that limits how the servient land may be used.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the difference between an affirmative easement and a negative easement?
cards.cloze: An {{c1::affirmative easement}} entitles its holder to make {{c2::affirmative use}} of the {{c3::servient estate}} (such as crossing, laying utilities, or drawing water). A {{c4::negative easement}} entitles its holder to {{c5::restrict the servient estate}} from {{c6::otherwise permissible activities}}, such as interfering with light, air, support, or the flow of an artificial stream.
cards.easyContent: An affirmative easement lets the holder do something on the servient land. A negative easement lets the holder stop the servient owner from doing something they otherwise could do.
cards.mediumContent: An affirmative easement gives the holder a right to affirmatively use the servient estate—such as crossing it or running utility lines. A negative easement gives the holder the right to prevent the servient owner from engaging in otherwise lawful uses of the land, like blocking light or air or interfering with support; it operates as a use restriction on the servient land.
cards.hardContent: Affirmative easements authorize the holder to make positive use of the servient estate—e.g., entering and crossing over the land, laying pipes or utility lines, or drawing water. Negative easements constrain the servient owner's freedom to use her land in ways that would otherwise be lawful, such as building in a way that blocks light or air, deprives neighboring land of support, or interferes with the flow of an artificial stream. Although similar in function to restrictive covenants, negative easements are treated doctrinally as non-possessory interests that restrict how the servient estate can be used.
cards.mnemonic: Affirmative = Act on land; Negative = say No to uses.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::affirmative easement}} lets the holder {{c2::affirmatively use the servient estate}}; a {{c3::negative easement}} lets the holder {{c4::prevent otherwise lawful uses}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 030-4. Easements – Methods of Creation
cards.backPlain: 1. Overview 1.1 Easements may be created by: 1.1.1 Express grant or reservation. 1.1.2 Implication. 1.1.3 Necessity. 1.1.4 Prescription. 2. Express easements 2.1 Created by written grant or reservation that satisfies the Statute of Frauds. 2.2 Grant: Landowner conveys an easement to another. 2.3 Reservation: Landowner conveys land but reserves an easement over it. 3. Implied easements 3.1 Arise from prior use or circumstances showing the parties likely intended an easement, even though it is not in writing (e.g., implied by existing, apparent, and reasonably necessary use at the time of severance). 4. Easements by necessity 4.1 Typically arise when a parcel is landlocked as a result of a conveyance, and access is strictly necessary. 5. Prescriptive easements 5.1 Created by use of another's land that is adverse/hostile, open and notorious, continuous, and for the statutory period, analogous to adverse possession (but confers only a use right, not title).
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main ways easements can be created, and what is the basic idea behind each method?
cards.cloze: Easements may be created by {{c1::express grant or reservation}}, {{c2::implication}}, {{c3::necessity}}, or {{c4::prescription}}. An {{c5::express easement}} is created by written {{c6::grant}} or {{c7::reservation}} that satisfies the {{c8::Statute of Frauds}}. An {{c9::implied easement}} arises from {{c10::prior or existing use}} and circumstances showing the parties likely {{c11::intended an easement}} even without a writing. An easement by {{c12::necessity}} typically arises when a parcel is {{c13::landlocked}} as a result of a conveyance and access is {{c14::strictly necessary}}. A {{c15::prescriptive easement}} is created by {{c16::adverse/hostile}}, {{c17::open and notorious}}, {{c18::continuous}} use for the {{c19::statutory period}}, analogous to adverse possession but conferring only a {{c20::use right}} rather than {{c21::title}}.
cards.easyContent: Easements can be created by: (1) express grant or reservation in a writing satisfying the Statute of Frauds; (2) implication from prior or existing use that the parties likely intended to continue; (3) necessity, usually when a landlocked parcel needs access; and (4) prescription, through adverse, open, continuous use for the statutory period.
cards.mediumContent: An express easement is created by written grant or reservation that satisfies the Statute of Frauds. An implied easement arises when a prior, apparent, and reasonably necessary use suggests the parties intended an easement even though it was not written. An easement by necessity typically occurs when, as a result of a conveyance, a parcel becomes landlocked and access is strictly necessary. A prescriptive easement results from adverse, open and notorious, continuous use of another’s land for the statutory period, similar to adverse possession but giving only a use right, not title.
cards.hardContent: Easements may be created in four principal ways. (1) Expressly: by written grant or reservation that satisfies the Statute of Frauds; a grant conveys an easement to another, while a reservation arises when a grantor conveys land but reserves an easement over it. (2) By implication: when, at the time of severance, an existing, apparent, and reasonably necessary use of one parcel for the benefit of another indicates the parties likely intended the use to continue as an easement even though it was not reduced to writing. (3) By necessity: typically when a conveyance leaves a parcel landlocked, and a right of way over the grantor’s or grantee’s remaining land is strictly necessary to access a public road. (4) By prescription: where the claimant’s use of another’s land is adverse/hostile, open and notorious, and continuous for the statutory period, analogous to adverse possession but resulting only in a non-possessory right to use, not ownership.
cards.mnemonic: Think "PINE": Prescription, Implication, Necessity, Express.
cards.clozeLite: Easements arise by {{c1::express grant or reservation}}, {{c2::implication from prior use}}, {{c3::strict necessity for access}}, or {{c4::prescription like adverse possession}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Easement by Implication – Prior Use by Common Grantor
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 034-1. Easement by Implication – Prior Use by Common Grantor
cards.front: Easement by Implication – Prior Use by Common Grantor
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition: An easement by implication from prior use arises when a common grantor previously used one part of a single tract of land in an easement-like way to benefit another part, and then conveys or divides the land. 2. Elements (PCNI): 2.1 Prior easement-like use: An easement-like use exists prior to the division of a single tract of land. 2.2 Continuous and apparent: The common grantor’s use is continuous and apparent (i.e., not sporadic or hidden). 2.3 Reasonably necessary: The use is reasonably necessary for enjoyment of the dominant tenement (not merely convenient, but need not be strictly indispensable in most jurisdictions). 2.4 Intended to continue: Circumstances show that the parties intended the use to continue after the division of the land. 3. Effect: When these elements are satisfied, the law implies an easement in favor of the parcel that benefits from the use (the dominant estate) over the parcel that bears the burden (the servient estate).
cards.frontPrompt: When does an easement by implication from prior use by a common grantor arise, and what are its elements?
cards.cloze: 1. Definition: An {{c1::easement by implication from prior use}} arises when a {{c2::common grantor}} previously used one part of a single tract in an {{c3::easement-like way}} to benefit another part, and then conveys or divides the land. 2. Elements ({{c4::PCNI}}): 2.1 {{c5::Prior easement-like use}}: An easement-like use exists prior to the {{c6::division of a single tract}} of land. 2.2 {{c7::Continuous and apparent}}: The common grantor’s use is continuous and apparent (not sporadic or hidden). 2.3 {{c8::Reasonably necessary}}: The use is reasonably necessary for enjoyment of the {{c9::dominant tenement}}. 2.4 {{c10::Intended to continue}}: Circumstances show that the parties intended the use to continue after the division of the land. 3. Effect: When these elements are satisfied, the law {{c11::implies an easement}} in favor of the benefited parcel (dominant estate) over the burdened parcel (servient estate).
cards.easyContent: An implied easement from prior use arises when, before dividing a single tract, a common grantor used one part to benefit another in an easement-like way, the use was continuous and apparent, reasonably necessary, and intended to continue after division.
cards.mediumContent: An easement by implication from prior use requires: (1) an easement-like use existing before division of a single tract; (2) the common grantor’s use was continuous and apparent; (3) the use was reasonably necessary for enjoyment of the dominant parcel; and (4) the parties intended this use to continue after the land was divided. If all are met, an easement is implied in favor of the benefited parcel.
cards.hardContent: An easement by implication from prior use arises when a common grantor, before subdividing a single tract, uses one portion of the land in an easement-like way (such as a roadway, drain, or utility line) to benefit another portion. The elements are: (1) prior easement-like use existing before division; (2) the common grantor’s use is continuous and apparent, meaning it is regular and visible or discoverable upon reasonable inspection; (3) the use is reasonably necessary for the enjoyment of the dominant tenement (more than mere convenience, but usually not strict necessity); and (4) the parties intended the use to continue after the land was divided, which may be inferred from the nature of the use and the conveyance. When these conditions are met, the law implies an easement burdening the servient parcel and benefiting the dominant parcel.
cards.mnemonic: PCNI: Prior use, Continuous, Necessary, Intended.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::easement by implication from prior use}} requires {{c2::prior easement-like use before division}}, {{c3::continuous and apparent use}}, {{c4::reasonable necessity}}, and {{c5::intent to continue after division}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 034-2. Implied Easements – Subdivision Plats
cards.backPlain: 1. Rule: An easement may be implied from a subdivision plat even without prior use of the easement-like feature. 2. Subdivision plat doctrine: 2.1 When a landowner subdivides a tract into lots and sells the lots with reference to a recorded map or subdivision plat, purchasers acquire implied easements consistent with the plat. 2.2 Typical examples include implied easements over streets, alleys, and other ways shown on the plat that provide access to the lots. 3. Rationale: By selling lots with reference to the plat, the grantor is treated as having intended that the streets and ways shown on the plat be available for use by the lot owners, so the law implies easements to make the lots usable as depicted.
cards.frontPrompt: How can a subdivision plat create implied easements even without prior use, and what is typically implied?
cards.cloze: 1. Rule: An {{c1::easement may be implied from a subdivision plat}} even without prior use. 2. Subdivision plat doctrine: 2.1 When a landowner subdivides a tract and sells lots with reference to a recorded {{c2::map or subdivision plat}}, purchasers acquire {{c3::implied easements consistent with the plat}}. 2.2 Common examples are implied easements over {{c4::streets, alleys, and other ways}} shown on the plat that provide access to the lots. 3. Rationale: By selling lots with reference to the plat, the grantor is treated as having {{c5::intended}} that the streets and ways shown be available for use by the lot owners, so the law {{c6::implies easements}} to make the lots usable as depicted.
cards.easyContent: When lots are sold with reference to a subdivision plat or map, courts imply easements over streets and ways shown on the plat so that lot owners can use the lots as depicted, even if those routes were not previously used.
cards.mediumContent: Under the subdivision plat doctrine, if a developer sells lots by reference to a recorded plat, the buyers get implied easements consistent with that plat, typically for streets, alleys, and other ways shown that provide access to the lots. This implication does not depend on prior use, but on the inference that the parties intended those ways to be available.
cards.hardContent: Implied easements can arise from subdivision plats even where no prior easement-like use existed. When a tract is subdivided and lots are conveyed by reference to a recorded map or subdivision plat, each purchaser is deemed to receive implied easements over streets, alleys, and similar ways shown on the plat that provide access or other necessary benefits to their lots. The underlying rationale is that by marketing and conveying lots with reference to the plat, the developer manifests an intent that the roadways and other depicted ways are available for use by the lot owners, and the lot owners buy in reliance on that representation; therefore, the law implies easements consistent with the planned layout.
cards.mnemonic: PLAT: Plat Lots Assume Thoroughfares
cards.clozeLite: Selling lots by {{c1::reference to a recorded subdivision plat}} gives buyers {{c2::implied easements}} over {{c3::streets, alleys, and ways shown}} on the plat.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 034-3. Implied Easements – Profit à Prendre
cards.backPlain: 1. Rule: The holder of a profit à prendre generally has an implied easement to enter and pass over the servient land as reasonably necessary to exercise the profit. 2. Profit à prendre and access: 2.1 A profit à prendre is a nonpossessory right to enter another’s land and remove natural resources (e.g., minerals, timber, game). 2.2 Because the profit would be useless without a way to reach the resources, the law implies an easement of access as reasonably necessary to locate, reach, and remove them. 3. Scope: The implied easement encompasses only such routes and methods of access as are reasonably necessary to use the profit; it does not allow unreasonable or excessive burdening of the servient estate.
cards.frontPrompt: How does a profit à prendre give rise to an implied easement, and what is the scope of that implied easement?
cards.cloze: 1. Rule: The holder of a {{c1::profit à prendre}} generally has an {{c2::implied easement}} to enter and pass over the servient land as {{c3::reasonably necessary}} to exercise the profit. 2. Profit à prendre and access: 2.1 A profit à prendre is a {{c4::nonpossessory right to enter another’s land and remove natural resources}} (e.g., minerals, timber, game). 2.2 Because the profit would be {{c5::useless without access}}, the law implies an {{c6::easement of access}} as reasonably necessary to locate, reach, and remove the resources. 3. Scope: The implied easement covers only such routes and methods of access as are {{c7::reasonably necessary}} to use the profit and may not {{c8::unreasonably burden}} the servient estate.
cards.easyContent: A profit à prendre (right to take resources from land) carries an implied easement letting the holder enter and cross the land as reasonably necessary to reach and remove the resources, but not in a way that unreasonably burdens the land.
cards.mediumContent: The holder of a profit à prendre, such as a right to remove timber or minerals, has an implied easement of access over the servient land to exercise the profit. This access is limited to what is reasonably necessary to find, reach, and remove the resources and cannot be used in a way that excessively burdens the servient estate.
cards.hardContent: A profit à prendre is a nonpossessory interest that allows its holder to enter another’s land and remove natural resources like minerals, timber, or game. Because the profit would have no practical value without a way to reach the resources, courts imply an easement of access in favor of the profit holder. This implied easement permits entry onto and passage over the servient land as reasonably necessary to locate, extract, and transport the resources. However, the implied easement is limited in scope: it includes only those routes and methods that are reasonably necessary under the circumstances and may not be exercised in a manner that unreasonably or excessively burdens the servient estate.
cards.mnemonic: PROFIT PATH: Profit needs a path, but not a pounding.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::profit à prendre}} carries an {{c2::implied easement of access}} limited to what is {{c3::reasonably necessary}} and not {{c4::unreasonably burdensome}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Termination of Easements – Estoppel, Release, and Abandonment
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 037-1. Termination of Easements – Estoppel, Release, and Abandonment
cards.front: Termination of Easements – Estoppel, Release, and Abandonment
cards.frontPrompt: How can an easement be terminated by estoppel, by release, or by abandonment, and what key limits apply to each?
cards.backPlain: 1. Termination by Estoppel 1.1 An easement is terminated by estoppel where the servient owner reasonably relies on the easement holder's conduct or representations indicating an intent to abandon the easement. 1.2 Non-use alone is insufficient to create estoppel; there must be conduct or representations plus reasonable reliance. 2. Termination by Release 2.1 The easement holder can terminate the easement by executing and delivering a deed of release to the servient tenement owner. 2.2 Because an easement is an interest in land, the release generally must satisfy deed formalities. 3. Termination by Abandonment 3.1 An easement is terminated by abandonment if its holder physically demonstrates an intent to permanently abandon the easement. 3.2 Mere words expressing an intent to abandon, or mere non-use of the easement, are insufficient by themselves without physical acts that are inconsistent with continued use.
cards.cloze: 1. Termination by {{c1::Estoppel}} 1.1 An easement is terminated by estoppel where the {{c2::servient owner reasonably relies}} on the easement holder's {{c3::conduct or representations indicating an intent to abandon}} the easement. 1.2 {{c4::Non-use alone is insufficient}} to create estoppel; there must be conduct or representations plus reasonable reliance. 2. Termination by {{c5::Release}} 2.1 The easement holder can terminate the easement by executing and delivering a {{c6::deed of release}} to the servient tenement owner. 2.2 Because an easement is an interest in land, the release generally must satisfy {{c7::deed formalities}}. 3. Termination by {{c8::Abandonment}} 3.1 An easement is terminated by abandonment if its holder {{c9::physically demonstrates an intent to permanently abandon}} the easement. 3.2 {{c10::Mere words or non-use are insufficient}} without physical acts that are inconsistent with continued use.
cards.easyContent: Easements can end by: (1) estoppel, when the servient owner reasonably relies on the holder’s apparent abandonment; (2) release, by a deed of release from the holder to the servient owner; and (3) abandonment, when the holder’s physical acts show a permanent intent to give it up (mere words or non-use are not enough).
cards.mediumContent: Consent- or intent-based terminations include: (1) estoppel, which requires the servient owner’s reasonable reliance on the holder’s conduct or representations implying abandonment, with non-use alone insufficient; (2) release, where the holder executes and delivers a deed of release to the servient owner, satisfying deed formalities; and (3) abandonment, which requires physical acts by the holder that demonstrate an intent to permanently relinquish the easement—mere words or non-use alone do not terminate it.
cards.hardContent: An easement may be terminated through the parties’ conduct and intent in several ways: (1) Estoppel: the easement ends where the servient owner reasonably relies on the easement holder’s conduct or representations indicating an intent to abandon the easement; non-use alone is not enough—there must be conduct plus reasonable reliance. (2) Release: because an easement is an interest in land, the holder can terminate it by executing and delivering a deed of release to the servient tenement owner, complying with deed formalities. (3) Abandonment: the easement is terminated if its holder physically demonstrates an intent to permanently abandon it, such as by blocking the easement route or making inconsistent improvements; mere words or non-use are insufficient without such physical acts.
cards.mnemonic: Consent/intent-based terminations: E.R.A. – Estoppel, Release, Abandonment.
cards.clozeLite: Easements can end by {{c1::estoppel}} ({{c2::servient owner reasonably relies}}), {{c3::release}} ({{c4::deed of release}}), or {{c5::abandonment}} ({{c6::physical acts showing permanent intent}}).

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Termination of Easements – Necessity, Destruction, Merger, Prescription, Expiration
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 037-2. Termination of Easements – Necessity, Destruction, Merger, Prescription, Expiration
cards.front: Termination of Easements – Necessity, Destruction, Merger, Prescription, Expiration
cards.frontPrompt: How can an easement be terminated by end of necessity, destruction, merger, prescription, or expiration by its own terms?
cards.backPlain: 1. Termination When Necessity Ends 1.1 Easements by necessity automatically end when the need that created them ceases. 1.2 This mode applies specifically to easements created by necessity. 2. Termination by Destruction of the Servient Tenement 2.1 Destruction of the servient tenement terminates an easement. 2.2 Exception: If the destruction results from the willful conduct of the servient owner, the easement is not terminated on this basis. 3. Termination by Merger 3.1 An easement terminates automatically if one person acquires title to both the easement and the servient land. 3.2 Once merged, later re-dividing the merged title will not automatically revive the easement; a new easement must be created if desired. 4. Termination by Prescription 4.1 The servient owner may extinguish an easement by interfering with its use using the elements of adverse possession. 4.2 Typically, this requires open and notorious, actual, continuous, exclusive, and hostile interference for the statutory period. 5. Termination by Expiration or Condition 5.1 If the easement was established for a set term, expiration of that term terminates the easement. 5.2 If the easement is made to expire upon stated conditions, occurrence of the stated conditions will terminate the easement.
cards.cloze: 1. Termination When {{c1::Necessity Ends}} 1.1 Easements by necessity automatically end when the {{c2::need that created them ceases}}. 1.2 This mode applies specifically to easements created {{c3::by necessity}}. 2. Termination by {{c4::Destruction of the Servient Tenement}} 2.1 Destruction of the servient tenement {{c5::terminates an easement}}. 2.2 Exception: If the destruction results from the {{c6::willful conduct of the servient owner}}, the easement is not terminated on this basis. 3. Termination by {{c7::Merger}} 3.1 An easement terminates automatically if {{c8::one person acquires title to both the easement and the servient land}}. 3.2 Once merged, later {{c9::re-dividing the merged title will not revive}} the easement. 4. Termination by {{c10::Prescription}} 4.1 The servient owner may extinguish an easement by interfering with its use using the elements of {{c11::adverse possession}}. 4.2 Typically, this requires {{c12::open and notorious, actual, continuous, exclusive, and hostile interference for the statutory period}}. 5. Termination by {{c13::Expiration or Condition}} 5.1 If the easement was established for a {{c14::set term}}, expiration of that term terminates the easement. 5.2 If the easement is made to expire upon {{c15::stated conditions}}, occurrence of the stated conditions will terminate the easement.
cards.easyContent: Easements also end automatically or structurally when: (1) a necessity-based easement’s need ends; (2) the servient tenement is destroyed (unless willfully destroyed by the servient owner); (3) one owner comes to hold both the easement and servient land (merger, with no automatic revival); (4) the servient owner blocks it using adverse possession elements (prescription); or (5) a set term ends or a stated condition occurs under the easement’s terms.
cards.mediumContent: Automatic or structural terminations include: (1) end of necessity, which terminates easements by necessity once the underlying need ceases; (2) destruction of the servient tenement, which ends the easement unless the destruction was willfully caused by the servient owner; (3) merger, when a single owner acquires title to both the easement and the servient estate, and re-dividing the property later does not revive the easement; (4) prescription, where the servient owner extinguishes the easement by interfering with its use in a manner satisfying all elements of adverse possession; and (5) expiration, where the easement ends at the conclusion of a fixed term or upon occurrence of a condition specified in the easement itself.
cards.hardContent: Several modes of termination operate largely by operation of law: (1) End of necessity: easements created by necessity automatically expire when the need that justified the easement ends. (2) Destruction of the servient tenement: if the servient tenement is destroyed, the easement terminates, unless the destruction results from the willful conduct of the servient owner, in which case the owner cannot benefit from their own wrongful act. (3) Merger: when one person acquires title to both the easement and the servient land, the easement is extinguished by merger; if that owner later re-divides the property, the former easement is not automatically revived and must be recreated if desired. (4) Prescription: the servient owner can extinguish the easement by obstructing its use in a manner that is open and notorious, actual, continuous, exclusive, and hostile for the statutory period, mirroring adverse possession. (5) Expiration or condition: if the easement is created for a fixed term, it ends when that term expires; if the instrument states that the easement terminates upon a specified condition, occurrence of that condition terminates the easement.
cards.mnemonic: Structural/automatic terminations: NDMPE – Necessity ends, Destruction, Merger, Prescription, Expiration.
cards.clozeLite: Easements can terminate automatically by {{c1::end of necessity}}, {{c2::destruction of the servient tenement}}, {{c3::merger}}, {{c4::prescription}}, or {{c5::expiration by its own terms}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Adverse Possession – Statute of Limitations, Disability, and Future Interests
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 045-1. AP – SoL, Disability, and Future Interests
cards.front: Adverse Possession – Statute of Limitations, Disability, and Future Interests
cards.backPlain: 1. Statute of limitations and disability: - The statute of limitations for adverse possession does not begin to run if the true owner was under a legal disability when the adverse possession began. - Common legal disabilities include minority and mental incompetence. - Only disabilities existing at the start of adverse possession count; later-arising disabilities generally do not toll the period. 2. Future interests: - The statute of limitations does not run against future interest holders (e.g., remaindermen, executory interest holders) until their interest becomes possessory. - Adverse possession against the present estate holder does not cut off the rights of future interest holders until the limitations period runs after their interest vests in possession.
cards.frontPrompt: How do disabilities of the true owner and the existence of future interests affect when the statute of limitations runs for adverse possession?
cards.cloze: For adverse possession, the {{c1::statute of limitations}} does not begin to run if the true owner was under a {{c2::legal disability}} (such as {{c3::minority}} or {{c4::mental incompetence}}) when the adverse possession began. Only disabilities that {{c5::exist at the start of adverse possession}} toll the period. As to {{c6::future interests}}, the limitations period does not run against {{c7::future interest holders}} (e.g., {{c8::remaindermen}}) until their interest becomes {{c9::possessory}}. Adverse possession against the present estate holder does not by itself cut off the future interest until the period runs after the future interest {{c10::vests in possession}}.
cards.easyContent: For adverse possession, the statute of limitations is tolled while the true owner is under a qualifying disability when possession begins, and it does not run against future interest holders until their interest becomes possessory.
cards.mediumContent: Adverse possession’s statute of limitations will not start if, at the time adverse possession begins, the true owner is under a legal disability such as minority or incompetence. Disabilities that arise later do not toll the period. In addition, the limitations period does not run against future interest holders—like remaindermen—until their interest actually becomes possessory.
cards.hardContent: Under adverse possession, the statute of limitations is affected by disabilities and future interests. If the true owner is under a legal disability (such as being a minor or mentally incompetent) when the adverse possession starts, the limitations period does not begin to run until the disability is removed. Only disabilities existing at the inception of the adverse possession matter; later-arising disabilities typically do not toll the period. Separately, limitations do not run against future interest holders, such as remaindermen or executory interest holders, until their interest becomes possessory. Thus, adverse possession against a life tenant does not cut off the remainderman’s rights until the remainderman’s interest has vested in possession and the statutory period then runs against them.
cards.mnemonic: Start disabled, clock delayed; future interest, clock when possessed.
cards.clozeLite: Adverse possession’s clock {{c1::doesn’t start if the owner is disabled at entry}}, and {{c2::doesn’t run against future interests until they’re possessory}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 045-2. AP – Restrictive Covenants
cards.front: Adverse Possession – Effect on Restrictive Covenants
cards.backPlain: Restrictive covenants and adverse possession: 1. Violating the covenant: - If the adverse possessor’s use of the land violated a restrictive covenant, the covenant will not run with the land after title is acquired by adverse possession. - The new title reflects the actual use—contrary to the covenant—and the burden is effectively extinguished. 2. Complying with the covenant: - If the adverse possessor’s use complied with the restrictive covenant, the covenant will run with the land. - The burden and benefit (if any) continue to bind and benefit subsequent owners after adverse possession.
cards.frontPrompt: How does adverse possession affect whether a restrictive covenant runs with the land?
cards.cloze: If the adverse possessor’s use of the land {{c1::violated}} a restrictive covenant, the covenant will {{c2::not run with the land}} once title is acquired by adverse possession. By contrast, if the adverse possessor’s use {{c3::complied}} with the covenant, the covenant {{c4::will run with the land}} and continue to bind future owners.
cards.easyContent: A restrictive covenant survives adverse possession only if the adverse possessor’s use complied with it; if the possessor violated the covenant, it will not run with the land after adverse possession.
cards.mediumContent: Adverse possession can extinguish or preserve restrictive covenants. If the possessor’s use violates the covenant, the resulting title is free of that covenant, so it will not run with the land. If the possessor’s use is consistent with the covenant, the covenant remains attached to the land and continues to run.
cards.hardContent: With restrictive covenants, the key is the adverse possessor’s use. When an adverse possessor uses the land in a way that violates the restrictive covenant, and then acquires title by adverse possession, the covenant is treated as not running with the land to that parcel—the title reflects the nonconforming use and is effectively unburdened by that covenant. Conversely, if the adverse possessor’s use is in compliance with the covenant, the covenant remains in effect and continues to run with the land, binding subsequent owners even after adverse possession.
cards.mnemonic: Violate it, vacate it; comply, it will apply.
cards.clozeLite: If an adverse possessor {{c1::violates a restrictive covenant}}, the new title is {{c2::free of that covenant}}; {{c3::compliance}} means it {{c4::continues to run with the land}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 045-3. AP – Color of Title
cards.backPlain: Color of title and adverse possession: 1. Definition: - Color of title is a defective or invalid written claim of title to property (e.g., a void deed or improperly executed instrument) that appears to convey title but does not actually do so. 2. Effect on scope of possession: - When an adverse possessor occupies only part of the land described in the instrument under color of title, that possession is often sufficient to acquire title to the entire parcel described in the instrument, not just the portion actually occupied. - The defective instrument defines the boundaries of the claim, so constructive possession extends to the whole described tract, subject to competing possessors.
cards.frontPrompt: What is color of title in adverse possession, and how does it affect the scope of land acquired?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Color of title}} is a {{c2::defective or invalid written claim of title}} (such as a void deed) that appears to convey property but does not actually do so. If an adverse possessor actually occupies {{c3::part}} of the land described in the instrument under color of title, that possession can allow them to acquire title to {{c4::the entire parcel described}} in the instrument, not just the portion physically occupied.
cards.easyContent: Color of title is a defective written claim to land. If you adversely possess part of the land under color of title, you can usually gain title to the entire tract described, not just the part you occupy.
cards.mediumContent: Color of title refers to an invalid written instrument that appears to convey title. In adverse possession, a possessor who actually occupies only part of the land described under that instrument can acquire title to the entire described parcel, because the instrument defines the outer boundaries of the constructive possession.
cards.hardContent: Color of title arises when a person holds a defective written instrument—such as a void or voidable deed—that purports to convey ownership of a tract. Although the instrument does not actually transfer valid title, it establishes a claim of right. In many jurisdictions, an adverse possessor who occupies only a portion of the land described in that instrument can nevertheless obtain title, through adverse possession, to the entire parcel described. The instrument effectively sets the metes and bounds of the constructive possession, so long as there are no competing adverse possessors within that tract.
cards.mnemonic: Colored paper, bigger parcel: bad deed, whole described tract.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Color of title}} is an {{c2::invalid written instrument}} that appears to convey land; it lets an adverse possessor of {{c3::only part}} claim {{c4::the entire described parcel}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 045-4. AP – Government Land
cards.backPlain: Government land and adverse possession: 1. General rule: - Government-owned land generally cannot be acquired by adverse possession. - This immunity typically applies to both federal and state (and often local) government property. 2. Rationale and variations: - The doctrine protects public property and resources from being lost through inattention or lack of enforcement. - Some jurisdictions may allow adverse possession against the government only in narrow circumstances or by specific statute, but the default exam rule is that government land is not subject to adverse possession.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general rule about acquiring government-owned land by adverse possession?
cards.cloze: As a general rule, {{c1::government-owned land}} {{c2::cannot be acquired}} by adverse possession. Public property held by the {{c3::federal}}, {{c4::state}}, or often {{c5::local}} government is generally {{c6::immune}} from adverse possession unless a statute clearly provides otherwise.
cards.easyContent: Government-owned land is generally immune from adverse possession and cannot be acquired that way, absent a specific statutory authorization.
cards.mediumContent: The default rule is that property owned by the government—federal, state, or local—is not subject to acquisition by adverse possession. This rule protects public property from being lost by neglect, and any exceptions are typically created by statute.
cards.hardContent: Adverse possession generally does not run against the government. Land owned by public entities, including the federal government and most state and local governments, is treated as immune from acquisition by adverse possession. The rationale is that public property should not be forfeited due to the government’s failure to police its boundaries. While some jurisdictions have statutes that carve out limited exceptions or allow adverse possession of certain categories of government property, the bar-exam baseline is that government land cannot be acquired through adverse possession.
cards.mnemonic: GOVT: Government Ownership Void to Taking by AP.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Government-owned land}} is generally {{c2::immune from adverse possession}} {{c3::unless a statute expressly allows it}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Adverse Possession – Leasing by Adverse Possessor and Marketable Title
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 045-5. AP – Leasing and Marketable Title
cards.front: Adverse Possession – Leasing and Marketable Title
cards.backPlain: Leasing by the adverse possessor and marketable title: 1. Leasing while adversely possessing: - An adverse possessor may lease all or part of the property to a third party. - The lease is treated as an exercise of the possessor’s claim of ownership and does not destroy the continuity or exclusivity of adverse possession. - The adverse possessor remains in constructive possession through the tenant. 2. Marketability of title acquired by adverse possession: - Title obtained via adverse possession is not considered marketable title in a typical real estate transaction until it has been confirmed by a court. - A quiet title action is generally required to establish record title and render the adverse possessor’s title marketable.
cards.frontPrompt: Can an adverse possessor lease the land and still adversely possess it, and is title acquired by adverse possession considered marketable?
cards.cloze: An {{c1::adverse possessor}} may {{c2::lease}} all or part of the land to a third party and still be treated as {{c3::in possession}}, because the tenant’s occupancy counts as the possessor’s own. However, title obtained by adverse possession is {{c4::not marketable}} until it is confirmed in an {{c5::action to quiet title}} or similar proceeding.
cards.easyContent: An adverse possessor can lease the land and still be considered in possession through the tenant, but title acquired by adverse possession is not marketable until quieted in court.
cards.mediumContent: Leasing is consistent with adverse possession: the adverse possessor can lease all or part of the property and still maintain continuous, exclusive possession through the tenant. However, even after the statutory period runs, the adverse possessor’s title is not marketable until a quiet title action or similar court judgment establishes record title.
cards.hardContent: An adverse possessor’s ability to exploit the land includes leasing it. Renting all or part of the land to a tenant is treated as an assertion of ownership and does not interrupt or negate the adverse nature of possession; the tenant’s occupancy is attributed to the adverse possessor, preserving continuity and exclusivity. Nonetheless, as a matter of conveyancing, title acquired solely by operation of adverse possession is generally not considered marketable because it is not yet of record and may be subject to challenge. To render the title marketable in a standard real estate transaction, the adverse possessor typically must obtain a judicial decree—such as in an action to quiet title—confirming their ownership.
cards.mnemonic: Lease to keep, quiet to market.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Leasing}} is consistent with {{c2::adverse possession}}; but title acquired by adverse possession is not {{c3::marketable}} until a {{c4::quiet title action}} or similar judgment.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Equitable Conversion – Definition and Creditor Consequences
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 048-1. Equitable Conversion – Definition and Creditor Consequences
cards.front: Equitable Conversion – Definition and Creditor Protection
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition and timing: 1.1 Equitable conversion applies during escrow—after a valid land sale contract is executed but before delivery of the deed. 1.2 During this period, the buyer is treated in equity as owning the real property. 1.3 The seller is treated as owning personal property: the right to the sale proceeds. 1.4 The seller holds legal title in trust for the buyer. 2. Effect on seller’s pre-contract creditors: 2.1 For claims or judgments against the seller arising before the land sale contract, any judgment against the seller is converted into an interest in the seller’s sale proceeds. 2.2 Such a judgment is not enforceable against the real property itself. 2.3 This protects the buyer’s equitable ownership by limiting the creditor to the seller’s personal property interest in the proceeds.
cards.frontPrompt: In a land sale contract, what is equitable conversion, when does it apply, and how does it protect the buyer against the seller’s pre-contract creditors?
cards.cloze: During {{c1::escrow}} (after a valid {{c2::land sale contract}} but before {{c3::delivery of the deed}}), {{c4::equitable conversion}} treats the {{c5::buyer}} as owning the {{c6::real property}} in equity. The {{c7::seller}} is treated as owning {{c8::personal property}}—the {{c9::right to the sale proceeds}}—and holds {{c10::legal title in trust}} for the buyer. For {{c11::claims or judgments against the seller arising before the contract}}, any judgment is converted into an {{c12::interest in the sale proceeds}} and is {{c13::not enforceable against the real property}}, protecting the buyer.
cards.easyContent: Equitable conversion applies between contract and deed delivery. The buyer is treated as owning the land, the seller as owning only a personal property right to the proceeds and holding legal title in trust. Pre-contract judgments against the seller attach only to the seller’s proceeds, not the land, protecting the buyer.
cards.mediumContent: Once a land sale contract is signed and before the deed is delivered, equitable conversion treats the buyer as the equitable owner of the real property, while the seller has a personal property interest in the sale proceeds and holds legal title in trust for the buyer. As a result, a pre-contract judgment against the seller is converted into an interest in the seller’s proceeds and cannot be enforced against the land, so the buyer’s equitable interest in the property is protected from those creditors.
cards.hardContent: Equitable conversion arises upon execution of a valid land sale contract and continues until delivery of the deed. During this period, equity regards the buyer as the owner of the real property, and the seller as owning personal property—the right to receive the contract sale proceeds—while holding legal title in trust for the buyer. This recharacterization protects the buyer from the seller’s pre-contract creditors: any judgment against the seller based on obligations arising before the contract is satisfied out of the seller’s personal property interest (the sale proceeds) and is not enforceable against the land itself. The creditor’s claim is effectively converted into an interest in the seller’s proceeds rather than a lien on the land.
cards.mnemonic: BEC: Buyer owns Estate; seller owns Cash (proceeds).
cards.clozeLite: Upon signing a {{c1::land sale contract}}, {{c2::equitable conversion}} makes the {{c3::buyer the equitable owner}} and the {{c4::seller owner of proceeds only}}, so {{c5::pre-contract seller judgments attach to proceeds, not land}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Equitable Conversion – Risk of Loss Before Closing
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 048-2. Equitable Conversion – Risk of Loss Before Closing
cards.front: Risk of Loss Under Equitable Conversion
cards.backPlain: 1. Default rule (most jurisdictions): 1.1 If the property is destroyed or damaged before closing through no fault of either party, the buyer bears the risk of loss in most jurisdictions. 1.2 This is true even if the buyer has not yet taken possession of the property. 2. Contractual allocation of risk: 2.1 The parties are free to contract differently and allocate the risk of loss as they wish. 2.2 A contract provision can place risk on the seller until closing or on the party in possession. 3. Insurance proceeds: 3.1 If the seller carries insurance and the property is damaged or destroyed before closing, the seller must credit any insurance proceeds received from the loss against the purchase price. 3.2 This prevents the seller from both retaining the full purchase price and keeping the insurance recovery (avoiding a windfall).
cards.frontPrompt: Under equitable conversion, who bears the risk of loss if the property is destroyed before closing, can the parties change this by contract, and what must happen with any insurance proceeds?
cards.cloze: Under {{c1::equitable conversion}}, if the property is {{c2::destroyed or damaged before closing}} through no fault of either party, the {{c3::buyer}} bears the {{c4::risk of loss}} in {{c5::most jurisdictions}}, {{c6::even if the buyer has not taken possession}}. The parties may {{c7::reallocate}} this risk by {{c8::contract}} (e.g., keeping risk on the seller until closing). If the {{c9::seller}} receives {{c10::insurance proceeds}} for the loss, the seller must {{c11::credit those proceeds against the purchase price}}, preventing a {{c12::windfall}}.
cards.easyContent: Between contract and closing, most jurisdictions put the risk of accidental destruction of the property on the buyer, even before possession. The parties can change this by contract, and if the seller is insured and collects, the insurance proceeds must be credited against the purchase price.
cards.mediumContent: Because equitable conversion treats the buyer as the equitable owner of the land once the contract is signed, in most jurisdictions the buyer bears the risk of loss if the property is destroyed through no fault of the parties before closing, even if the buyer has not yet taken possession. The parties can contractually allocate risk differently, such as keeping it on the seller until closing or tying it to possession. If the seller’s insurance pays for the loss, the seller must credit the insurance proceeds against the purchase price so the seller does not both collect full price and keep the insurance funds.
cards.hardContent: Equitable conversion shifts beneficial ownership to the buyer upon execution of the land sale contract. As a result, in most jurisdictions, if the property is accidentally destroyed or materially damaged before closing through no fault of either party, the buyer bears the risk of loss—even if the buyer has not yet taken possession. However, this default can be overridden by express contract terms reallocating the risk (for example, keeping risk on the seller until legal title passes or on the party in possession). Where the seller carries property insurance and collects on a casualty loss before closing, equity requires that the seller apply, or credit, those insurance proceeds toward the buyer’s purchase price, preventing the seller from being overcompensated by both the buyer and the insurer.
cards.mnemonic: Equitable Conversion: Buyer Becomes Beneficial owner, so Buyer Bears Burn.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::equitable conversion}}, the {{c2::buyer usually bears the risk of loss}} before closing, but {{c3::the parties can reallocate risk by contract}}, and {{c4::seller’s insurance proceeds must be credited to the purchase price}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Equitable Conversion – Death of Buyer or Seller Before Closing
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 048-3. Equitable Conversion – Death of Buyer or Seller Before Closing
cards.front: Equitable Conversion – Effect of Death Before Closing
cards.backPlain: 1. Passing of interests on death: 1.1 If the buyer or seller dies after execution of the land sale contract but before closing, rights to the contract pass according to the nature of each party’s interest under equitable conversion. 2. Seller’s interest: 2.1 Under equitable conversion, the seller’s interest is a personal property interest in the right to receive the sale proceeds. 2.2 Therefore, on the seller’s death before closing, the seller’s interest passes as personal property through the seller’s estate. 2.3 The seller’s estate can sue for the sale proceeds from the buyer (or buyer’s estate). 3. Buyer’s interest: 3.1 Under equitable conversion, the buyer’s interest is an equitable real property interest in the land. 3.2 Therefore, on the buyer’s death before closing, the buyer’s interest passes as real property through the buyer’s estate. 3.3 The buyer’s estate can sue for delivery of the property (specific performance) from the seller (or seller’s estate).
cards.frontPrompt: If the buyer or seller under a land sale contract dies before closing, how does equitable conversion determine how each party’s interest passes and what each estate can demand?
cards.cloze: If the {{c1::buyer or seller}} dies after execution of a {{c2::land sale contract}} but before {{c3::closing}}, {{c4::equitable conversion}} controls how their interests pass. The {{c5::seller}} holds a {{c6::personal property}} interest in the {{c7::sale proceeds}}, so on the seller’s death this passes as {{c8::personalty}} and the seller’s estate can sue for the {{c9::sale proceeds}}. The {{c10::buyer}} holds an {{c11::equitable real property}} interest in the {{c12::land}}, so on the buyer’s death this passes as {{c13::realty}} and the buyer’s estate can sue for {{c14::delivery of the property}} (specific performance).
cards.easyContent: Because of equitable conversion, if the seller dies before closing, the right to the sale proceeds passes as personal property through the seller’s estate. If the buyer dies, the equitable interest in the land passes as real property through the buyer’s estate, which can demand delivery of the property.
cards.mediumContent: Under equitable conversion, after the land sale contract is signed, the seller’s interest is a personal property right to the purchase money, while the buyer’s interest is an equitable real property interest in the land. If the seller dies before closing, the seller’s interest passes as personalty, and the seller’s estate can enforce the contract to obtain the sale proceeds. If the buyer dies before closing, the buyer’s interest passes as realty, and the buyer’s estate can seek specific performance to obtain conveyance of the property.
cards.hardContent: Equitable conversion recharacterizes interests under a land sale contract so that, between contract and closing, the seller owns a personal property right to the proceeds and the buyer holds an equitable interest in the land. If the seller dies during this interval, the seller’s interest is treated as personalty: it passes through the seller’s estate as personal property, and the personal representative may sue the buyer (or buyer’s estate) for the purchase money. Conversely, if the buyer dies before closing, the buyer’s equitable interest is treated as realty: it passes through the buyer’s estate as real property, and the buyer’s estate can seek specific performance or delivery of the deed from the seller (or seller’s estate). This reflects the maxim that equity regards as done that which ought to be done.
cards.mnemonic: Seller gets $ (personalty); buyer gets building (realty).
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::equitable conversion}}, the {{c2::seller’s interest becomes personalty}} and the {{c3::buyer’s interest becomes realty}}; each passes through {{c4::their estate}} accordingly.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Implied Promise of Marketable Title – Definition and Defects
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 049-1. Implied Promise of Marketable Title – Definition and Defects
cards.front: Implied Promise of Marketable Title – Definition and Defects
cards.backPlain: 1. Implied promise of marketable title in land sale contracts 1.1 Every land sale contract contains an implied promise that the seller will provide marketable title at closing. 1.2 Marketable title means title that is free from a reasonable risk of litigation at the time of closing. 2. Defects that render title unmarketable 2.1 Title acquired by adverse possession that has not been quieted (i.e., no quiet title action or judicial decree confirming title). 2.2 Title encumbered by interests such as servitudes, mortgages, or future interests, subject to the seller’s right to satisfy outstanding mortgages or liens with the sale proceeds at closing. 2.3 Existing zoning ordinance violations at the time of sale. 3. Waiver of the implied promise 3.1 The buyer may waive the implied promise of marketable title. 3.2 The seller may not waive this protection on the buyer’s behalf.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the implied promise of marketable title in a land sale contract, what common defects make title unmarketable, and who can waive this protection?
cards.cloze: 1. Every land sale contract contains an implied promise that the seller will provide {{c1::marketable title}} at closing. 2. {{c2::Marketable title}} means title that is {{c3::free from a reasonable risk of litigation}} at the time of {{c4::closing}}. 3. Defects that render title {{c5::unmarketable}} include: 3.1 Title acquired by {{c6::adverse possession}} that has not been {{c7::quieted}}. 3.2 Title {{c8::encumbered by interests}} such as {{c9::servitudes, mortgages, or future interests}}, subject to the seller’s right to satisfy mortgages or liens with the {{c10::sale proceeds at closing}}. 3.3 Existing {{c11::zoning ordinance violations}} at the time of sale. 4. Waiver: The implied promise of marketable title can be {{c12::waived by the buyer}}, but {{c13::not by the seller}}.
cards.easyContent: Every land sale contract includes an implied promise that the seller will deliver marketable title at closing—title free from a reasonable risk of litigation. Unquieted adverse possession, significant encumbrances, and existing zoning violations make title unmarketable, and only the buyer can waive this protection.
cards.mediumContent: The implied promise of marketable title requires the seller to deliver title at closing that is free from a reasonable risk of litigation. Title is unmarketable where it rests on unquieted adverse possession, is encumbered by servitudes, mortgages, or future interests (unless liens will be satisfied from sale proceeds at closing), or where there are existing zoning violations. This promise may be waived by the buyer, but not by the seller.
cards.hardContent: Every land sale contract contains an implied promise that the seller will convey marketable title at closing—title that is free from a reasonable risk of litigation. Several defects commonly render title unmarketable: (1) title that depends on adverse possession but has not been quieted by judicial action; (2) title burdened by nontrivial encumbrances, such as servitudes, mortgages, or future interests, subject to the seller’s ability to satisfy outstanding liens from the sale proceeds at closing; and (3) existing zoning ordinance violations at the time of sale. The buyer may expressly or impliedly waive the implied promise of marketable title, but the seller cannot unilaterally waive this protection.
cards.mnemonic: Marketable title defects: AVE—Adverse possession, Violations, Encumbrances.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::implied promise of marketable title}} requires title {{c2::free from a reasonable risk of litigation}}; defects include {{c3::unquieted adverse possession}}, {{c4::nontrivial encumbrances}}, and {{c5::existing zoning violations}}. Only the {{c6::buyer}} can waive it.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Implied Duty to Disclose and Not Misrepresent; Implied Warranty of Quality
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 049-2. Implied Duty to Disclose and Not Misrepresent; Implied Warranty of Quality
cards.front: Implied Duty to Disclose and Not Misrepresent; Implied Warranty of Quality
cards.backPlain: 1. Implied promise to disclose and make no material false statements 1.1 The seller must not materially misrepresent facts or make false statements concerning the property. 1.2 The seller has a duty to disclose known, latent material defects—defects that are not readily observable or discoverable upon reasonable inspection. 1.3 The seller’s disclosure duty may be disclaimed only if the disclaimer is clear and specific. 2. Implied warranty of quality (new construction) 2.1 For new property, the seller–builder is subject to an implied warranty of quality in construction. 2.2 This warranty generally covers latent construction defects that render the property unfit for its intended use or materially impair its value.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the seller’s implied duty to disclose and not misrepresent in a land sale contract, when can this duty be disclaimed, and what implied warranty applies to new construction?
cards.cloze: 1. Sellers in land sale contracts are subject to an implied promise to {{c1::disclose}} and make no {{c2::material false statements}}. 2. The seller must not {{c3::materially misrepresent facts}} or make false statements concerning the property. 3. The seller has a duty to disclose {{c4::known, latent material defects}}—defects that are {{c5::not readily observable or discoverable on reasonable inspection}}. 4. This disclosure duty may be disclaimed only if the disclaimer is {{c6::clear and specific}}. 5. For {{c7::new property}}, the seller–builder is subject to an {{c8::implied warranty of quality in construction}}, covering {{c9::latent construction defects}} that render the property {{c10::unfit for its intended use}} or materially impair its value.
cards.easyContent: Sellers in land sale contracts may not lie about the property and must disclose known latent material defects, unless they clearly and specifically disclaim that duty. For new construction, the seller–builder also gives an implied warranty of quality covering latent construction defects.
cards.mediumContent: In every land sale contract, the seller implicitly agrees not to materially misrepresent facts and to disclose known latent material defects—problems that are not reasonably discoverable by the buyer. This disclosure duty can be disclaimed only with a clear and specific disclaimer. Additionally, for new construction, the seller–builder provides an implied warranty of quality in construction, generally covering latent defects that make the property unfit for its intended use or significantly reduce its value.
cards.hardContent: Beyond marketable title, land sale contracts contain an implied promise governing the property’s condition and the seller’s conduct. The seller must not materially misrepresent facts or make false statements about the property and has an affirmative duty to disclose known latent material defects—defects that are not apparent on reasonable inspection but that would matter to a reasonable buyer. Any attempt to disclaim this disclosure duty must be clear and specific; vague “as is” language is usually insufficient standing alone. For newly constructed property, the seller–builder is further bound by an implied warranty of quality in construction, which protects the buyer against latent construction defects that render the structure unfit for its intended use or materially impair its value.
cards.mnemonic: Disclosure & Quality: "Don’t Lie, Don’t Hide, Build Right."
cards.clozeLite: In every {{c1::land sale contract}}, the seller must {{c2::not materially misrepresent facts}} and {{c3::disclose known latent material defects}}. For {{c4::new construction}}, the seller–builder gives an {{c5::implied warranty of quality}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Remedies for Breach of Implied Promises and Merger Doctrine
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 049-3. Remedies for Breach of Implied Promises and Merger Doctrine
cards.front: Remedies for Breach of Implied Promises and Merger Doctrine
cards.backPlain: 1. Buyer’s obligation to notify and allow cure 1.1 If the seller breaches the implied promises (e.g., marketable title, disclosure), the buyer must notify the seller before closing. 1.2 The buyer must give the seller a reasonable time to cure any defects. 2. Buyer’s remedies if the seller fails to cure 2.1 If the seller does not cure within a reasonable time, the buyer may: 2.1.1 Rescind the contract. 2.1.2 Sue for damages. 2.1.3 Demand specific performance. 2.1.4 File suit to quiet title (where the dispute concerns title). 3. Merger doctrine 3.1 If the buyer fails to notify the seller of the defect before closing, the land sale contract merges into the deed at closing. 3.2 After merger, the seller is generally not liable for contractual promises in the land sale contract. 3.3 The buyer’s post-closing remedies are limited to covenants contained in the deed.
cards.frontPrompt: What must a buyer do when an implied promise in a land sale contract is breached, what remedies are available if the defect is not cured, and how does the merger doctrine affect these rights at closing?
cards.cloze: 1. When an implied promise in a land sale contract is breached, the buyer must {{c1::notify the seller before closing}} and give a {{c2::reasonable time}} to {{c3::cure}} the defect. 2. If the seller fails to cure, the buyer may: 2.1 {{c4::Rescind}} the contract. 2.2 Sue for {{c5::damages}}. 2.3 Demand {{c6::specific performance}}. 2.4 File a suit to {{c7::quiet title}} where title is in dispute. 3. Under the {{c8::merger doctrine}}, if the buyer does not raise the defect before closing, the land sale contract {{c9::merges into the deed}}. 4. After merger, the seller is generally not liable for {{c10::contractual promises}} in the land sale contract, and the buyer’s remedies are limited to {{c11::covenants in the deed}}.
cards.easyContent: If an implied promise in a land sale contract is breached, the buyer must object before closing and give the seller time to cure. If not cured, the buyer can rescind, seek damages, specific performance, or quiet title. If the buyer closes without objecting, the contract merges into the deed and later claims are limited to deed covenants.
cards.mediumContent: On breach of an implied promise in a land sale contract (such as marketable title or disclosure), the buyer must notify the seller before closing and allow a reasonable opportunity to cure. If the seller fails to cure, the buyer may rescind, sue for damages, seek specific performance, or bring a quiet title action. If the buyer proceeds to closing without raising the issue, the merger doctrine provides that the land sale contract merges into the deed, so the seller is no longer liable on contractual promises and the buyer’s post-closing rights are limited to deed covenants.
cards.hardContent: When a seller breaches an implied promise under a land sale contract—such as the promise of marketable title or the duty to disclose—the buyer must object prior to closing and give the seller a reasonable chance to cure the defect. If the seller does not cure within a reasonable time, the buyer has several options, including rescission of the contract, an action for damages, a suit for specific performance, and, where the problem is with title, a quiet title action. However, if the buyer goes through with closing without timely objection, the merger doctrine applies: the land sale contract merges into the deed, extinguishing contractual claims under the contract and leaving the buyer to rely solely on covenants expressed in the deed for any post-closing relief.
cards.mnemonic: Before closing: many remedies. After: Merger Means Deed Only.
cards.clozeLite: If a seller breaches an {{c1::implied promise}} in a land sale contract, the buyer must {{c2::object before closing and allow time to cure}} or else {{c3::merger limits post-closing claims to deed covenants}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Deeds – Validity: Execution, Delivery, and Acceptance
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 050-1. Deeds – Validity: Execution, Delivery, and Acceptance
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for a deed to be legally effective, including lawful execution, delivery (including conditional/third-party delivery), and acceptance?
cards.backPlain: 1. Function of a deed 1.1 A deed passes legal title from the seller (grantor) to the buyer (grantee). 2. Validity requirements for a deed 2.1 Lawful execution 2.1.1 The deed must be signed by the grantor. 2.1.2 It must reasonably identify the parties. 2.1.3 It must contain a legal description of the real estate. 2.2 Delivery 2.2.1 Delivery requires the grantor’s intent to be presently bound by the conveyance. 2.2.2 Title passes upon effective delivery and generally cannot be rescinded. 2.2.3 Present intent controls; physical transfer of the paper is not required. 2.3 Conditional or third‑party delivery 2.3.1 If a deed is delivered with conditions or via a third party (e.g., an escrow agent), courts look to the grantor’s intent. 2.3.2 A key question is whether the grantor retained control or power to rescind the transfer; retention of control may mean no present intent to convey. 2.4 Acceptance 2.4.1 The grantee must accept the deed; acceptance is usually presumed. 2.4.2 A non‑existent or void entity cannot accept a deed. 2.4.3 An express rejection by the grantee is an ineffective delivery and prevents title from passing.
cards.cloze: 1. Function of a deed 1.1 A {{c1::deed}} passes {{c2::legal title}} from the {{c3::grantor}} to the {{c4::grantee}}. 2. Validity requirements for a deed 2.1 {{c5::Lawful execution}} 2.1.1 The deed must be {{c6::signed by the grantor}}. 2.1.2 It must reasonably {{c7::identify the parties}}. 2.1.3 It must contain a {{c8::legal description}} of the real estate. 2.2 {{c9::Delivery}} 2.2.1 Delivery requires the grantor’s {{c10::intent to be presently bound}} by the conveyance. 2.2.2 {{c11::Title passes upon effective delivery}} and generally {{c12::cannot be rescinded}}. 2.2.3 {{c13::Present intent}} controls; {{c14::physical transfer is not required}}. 2.3 {{c15::Conditional or third‑party delivery}} 2.3.1 Courts look to the {{c16::grantor’s intent}} when a deed is delivered with conditions or via a third party (e.g., escrow). 2.3.2 A key question is whether the grantor {{c17::retained control or power to rescind}} the transfer. 2.4 {{c18::Acceptance}} 2.4.1 The grantee must accept the deed; acceptance is usually {{c19::presumed}}. 2.4.2 A {{c20::non‑existent or void entity}} cannot accept a deed. 2.4.3 An {{c21::express rejection}} by the grantee makes delivery {{c22::ineffective}}.
cards.easyContent: A deed passes legal title and is effective only if: (1) lawfully executed (signed by the grantor, identifies the parties, and describes the land), (2) delivered with the grantor’s present intent to be bound (physical transfer not required), and (3) accepted by the grantee (presumed unless the grantee rejects or is a void entity).
cards.mediumContent: A deed conveys legal title from grantor to grantee and must be validly executed and delivered, and accepted. Lawful execution requires the grantor’s signature, identification of the parties, and a legal description of the property. Delivery turns on the grantor’s present intent to be bound; title passes upon effective delivery and generally cannot be rescinded, and no physical handover is required. For conditional or third‑party (escrow) delivery, courts look to the grantor’s intent and whether the grantor retained power to rescind. Acceptance by the grantee is required but presumed, unless the grantee is a non‑existent/void entity or expressly rejects, in which case there is no effective delivery.
cards.hardContent: A deed is the instrument that passes legal title in land, but only if it satisfies the deed validity requirements. Lawful execution requires that the deed be signed by the grantor, reasonably identify the parties, and contain a legal description of the real estate. Delivery is a question of the grantor’s present intent to be bound by the conveyance; upon effective delivery, title passes and generally cannot be rescinded, and physical transfer of the document is unnecessary. When the deed is delivered conditionally or via a third party (such as an escrow agent), courts focus on whether the grantor intended a present transfer and whether the grantor retained control or the power to rescind; retention of control can defeat delivery. Acceptance by the grantee is required but usually presumed; however, a non‑existent or void entity cannot accept, and an express rejection by the grantee renders delivery ineffective so that title does not pass.
cards.mnemonic: "LED" for deed validity: Lawful execution, Effective delivery, and Delivery must be Accepted.
cards.atomizationNotes: Validity requirements focus on execution, delivery (including conditional/third‑party), and acceptance.
cards.clozeLite: A deed is effective only if {{c1::lawfully executed}}, {{c2::delivered with present intent to be bound}}, and {{c3::accepted by the grantee}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Deeds – General Warranty, Special Warranty, and Quitclaim
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 050-2. Deeds – General Warranty, Special Warranty, and Quitclaim
cards.front: Types of Deeds – General Warranty, Special Warranty, Quitclaim
cards.frontPrompt: How do general warranty, special warranty, and quitclaim deeds differ in terms of covenants for title and the protection they provide?
cards.backPlain: 1. Overview of deed types 1.1 Deeds differ in the scope of covenants for title they provide to the grantee. 2. General warranty deed 2.1 A general warranty deed includes six covenants for title (present and future covenants). 2.2 It provides the broadest protection to the grantee because the covenants usually cover all defects in title, whether arising before or during the grantor’s ownership. 3. Special warranty deed 3.1 Under a special warranty deed, the grantor assures that: 3.1.1 He has not conveyed the land to another; and 3.1.2 The land is free from encumbrances that attached while the grantor owned the land. 3.2 The grantor does not warrant against title defects arising before his period of ownership. 4. Quitclaim deed 4.1 A quitclaim deed transfers whatever interest the grantor purports to have in the property, if any. 4.2 It includes no covenants for title, not even a promise that the grantor has title to convey. 4.3 It offers the least protection to the grantee, who takes the risk that the grantor may have no interest.
cards.cloze: 1. Overview of deed types 1.1 Deeds differ in the scope of {{c1::covenants for title}} they provide to the grantee. 2. {{c2::General warranty deed}} 2.1 A general warranty deed includes {{c3::six covenants for title}}. 2.2 It provides the {{c4::broadest protection}} to the grantee, usually covering defects arising {{c5::both before and during}} the grantor’s ownership. 3. {{c6::Special warranty deed}} 3.1 Under a special warranty deed, the grantor assures that: 3.1.1 He has not {{c7::conveyed the land to another}}; and 3.1.2 The land is {{c8::free from encumbrances}} that attached {{c9::while the grantor owned the land}}. 3.2 The grantor does {{c10::not warrant against title defects}} arising {{c11::before}} his period of ownership. 4. {{c12::Quitclaim deed}} 4.1 A quitclaim deed transfers {{c13::whatever interest the grantor purports to have}} in the property. 4.2 It includes {{c14::no covenants for title}}, not even a promise that the grantor {{c15::has title to convey}}. 4.3 It offers the {{c16::least protection}} to the grantee, who takes the risk that the grantor may have {{c17::no interest}}.
cards.easyContent: General warranty deeds give the strongest protection with six covenants for title; special warranty deeds only cover defects caused or allowed by the grantor during his ownership; and quitclaim deeds simply transfer whatever interest the grantor has, with no title covenants at all.
cards.mediumContent: Deeds differ in the covenants for title they provide. A general warranty deed includes six covenants for title and usually protects the grantee against all title defects, whenever they arose. A special warranty deed is narrower: the grantor only promises that he has not conveyed the land to someone else and that no encumbrances attached while he owned the land, leaving earlier defects uncovered. A quitclaim deed offers no covenants; it merely transfers whatever interest the grantor has, if any, and does not even promise that the grantor has title to convey.
cards.hardContent: The main deed types vary by the extent of title protections they provide. A general warranty deed includes six covenants for title—typically three present and three future covenants—and provides the broadest protection because the grantor effectively warrants against title defects regardless of when they arose. A special warranty deed is more limited: the grantor covenants only that he has not previously conveyed the same property to another and that the property is free from encumbrances that attached while he owned it, but he does not warrant against pre‑existing defects. A quitclaim deed is the most bare‑bones instrument; it merely conveys whatever interest the grantor purports to have, if any, with no covenants for title and no representation that the grantor has any interest to convey at all, leaving the grantee to bear the risk of defects and even of total lack of title.
cards.mnemonic: "GW–SW–Q" from strongest to weakest: General Warranty (broad), Special Warranty (limited to seller’s acts), Quitclaim (questionable—no covenants).
cards.atomizationNotes: Focuses on comparing general warranty, special warranty, and quitclaim deeds by their covenants for title.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::general warranty deed}} gives {{c2::six covenants for title}}; a {{c3::special warranty deed}} covers {{c4::defects caused by the grantor}}; a {{c5::quitclaim deed}} gives {{c6::no covenants for title}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Foreclosure – Sale, Deficiency Judgment, and Surplus Distribution
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 058-1. Foreclosure – Sale, Deficiency Judgment, and Surplus Distribution
cards.front: Foreclosure – Sale, Deficiency Judgment, and Surplus
cards.backPlain: 1. Foreclosure Basics 1.1 Upon default, the mortgagee can satisfy the debt through foreclosure, typically by judicial action. 1.2 The property is sold at a foreclosure sale to satisfy the debt in whole or in part. 2. Deficiency Judgment 2.1 If the debt exceeds the sale proceeds, the mortgagee may file suit against the mortgagor for the remaining balance. 2.2 This remaining balance is called a deficiency, and the court may enter a deficiency judgment in favor of the mortgagee. 3. Surplus Proceeds and Junior Liens 3.1 If the foreclosure sale proceeds exceed the debt balance, the surplus does not go to the mortgagee. 3.2 Junior lienholders are paid from any surplus in order of their priority. 3.3 Any remaining surplus after satisfying junior liens goes to the mortgagor.
cards.frontPrompt: After a mortgagor defaults, how does foreclosure work, and what happens if the foreclosure sale produces either insufficient or surplus proceeds (deficiency judgment and junior liens)?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Foreclosure Basics}} 1.1 Upon default, the {{c2::mortgagee}} can satisfy the debt through {{c3::foreclosure}}, typically by {{c4::judicial action}}. 1.2 The property is {{c5::sold at a foreclosure sale}} to satisfy the debt in whole or in part. 2. {{c6::Deficiency Judgment}} 2.1 If the {{c7::debt exceeds}} the {{c8::sale proceeds}}, the mortgagee may sue the mortgagor for the {{c9::remaining balance}}. 2.2 This remaining balance is called a {{c10::deficiency}}, and the court may enter a {{c11::deficiency judgment}} in favor of the mortgagee. 3. {{c12::Surplus Proceeds and Junior Liens}} 3.1 If sale proceeds {{c13::exceed the debt balance}}, the surplus does not go to the mortgagee. 3.2 {{c14::Junior lienholders}} are paid from any surplus in order of their {{c15::priority}}. 3.3 Any remaining surplus after junior liens are paid goes to the {{c16::mortgagor}}.
cards.easyContent: On default, the mortgagee may foreclose and sell the property. If the sale proceeds are less than the debt, the mortgagee may obtain a deficiency judgment for the balance. If there is a surplus, junior lienholders are paid in order of priority, and any remaining amount goes to the mortgagor.
