cards.mediumContent: Foreclosure is typically accomplished by judicial action, resulting in a sale of the mortgaged property to satisfy the debt. When the foreclosure sale proceeds are insufficient, the mortgagee may sue the mortgagor for the deficiency and obtain a deficiency judgment. If the sale proceeds exceed the debt, the surplus is distributed to junior lienholders according to their priority, and then any remaining surplus is returned to the mortgagor.
cards.hardContent: Upon the mortgagor’s default, the mortgagee may institute foreclosure proceedings, usually by judicial action, to have the property sold to satisfy the debt in whole or in part. The foreclosure sale proceeds are first applied to the foreclosing mortgagee’s debt. If the debt exceeds the sale proceeds, the mortgagee may sue the mortgagor for the remaining balance and obtain a deficiency judgment. If the sale proceeds exceed the foreclosing mortgagee’s debt, the surplus is not retained by that mortgagee. Instead, junior lienholders are paid from the surplus in order of their lien priority, and any remaining surplus after all junior liens are satisfied belongs to the mortgagor.
cards.mnemonic: FMJ-M: Foreclosing mortgagee, Junior liens, then Mortgagor.
cards.clozeLite: Foreclosure sale proceeds first pay {{c1::the foreclosing mortgagee}}; any {{c2::deficiency}} leads to a judgment, and any {{c3::surplus}} goes to {{c4::junior lienholders then mortgagor}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Redemption in Equity, Equitable Mortgages, and Statutory Redemption
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 058-2. Redemption in Equity, Equitable Mortgages, and Statutory Redemption
cards.front: Redemption in Equity and Statutory Redemption
cards.backPlain: 1. Equitable Right of Redemption 1.1 At any time prior to a judicial foreclosure sale, the mortgagor has an equitable right to redeem the property. 1.2 To redeem, the mortgagor must pay the amount due (typically the full amount of the debt plus interest and costs). 2. Equitable Mortgages and Redemption 2.1 An equitable mortgage arises where a transaction is structured so that the creditor appears to hold legal title via a deed, but the substance is a secured loan. 2.2 In such equitable mortgage situations, the mortgagor still retains the equitable right of redemption before a foreclosure sale. 3. Statutory Right of Redemption 3.1 In some jurisdictions, the mortgagor is given an additional statutory right of redemption after the foreclosure sale. 3.2 The statutory right of redemption allows the mortgagor, for a specified period after the sale, to buy back the property, typically by paying the foreclosure sale price (or other statutorily defined amount). 3.3 This statutory right exists only where provided by statute and can extend the mortgagor’s ability to recover the property beyond the sale date.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the mortgagor’s equitable right of redemption (including in equitable mortgage situations), and how does a statutory right of redemption differ?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Equitable Right of Redemption}} 1.1 At any time {{c2::prior to a judicial foreclosure sale}}, the {{c3::mortgagor}} has an equitable right to {{c4::redeem}} the property. 1.2 To redeem, the mortgagor must {{c5::pay the amount due}} (typically full debt plus interest and costs). 2. {{c6::Equitable Mortgages and Redemption}} 2.1 An {{c7::equitable mortgage}} arises when the creditor appears to hold {{c8::legal title via a deed}}, but the transaction is in substance a {{c9::secured loan}}. 2.2 In such situations, the mortgagor still retains the {{c10::equitable right of redemption}} before foreclosure. 3. {{c11::Statutory Right of Redemption}} 3.1 In some jurisdictions, the mortgagor is given an additional {{c12::statutory right of redemption}} {{c13::after the foreclosure sale}}. 3.2 This statutory right allows the mortgagor, for a specified {{c14::post-sale period}}, to {{c15::buy back the property}}, typically by paying the {{c16::foreclosure sale price}} or other statutory amount. 3.3 The statutory right exists only where {{c17::provided by statute}} and can extend the mortgagor’s ability to recover the property beyond the sale date.
cards.easyContent: Before a judicial foreclosure sale, the mortgagor has an equitable right to redeem by paying the amount due, even in equitable mortgage situations where the creditor holds title by deed. In some jurisdictions, the mortgagor also has a statutory right of redemption after the sale, allowing repurchase of the property within a set time by paying a statutory amount.
cards.mediumContent: The equitable right of redemption gives the mortgagor the ability to redeem the property at any time before a judicial foreclosure sale by paying the amount due, including interest and costs. This right applies even when the mortgage is structured as an equitable mortgage, where the creditor holds legal title via a deed but the substance is a secured loan. In addition, some jurisdictions provide a statutory right of redemption that permits the mortgagor, for a specified period after the foreclosure sale, to buy back the property, usually by paying the sale price or a similar statutory amount. This statutory right exists only by statute and extends redemption rights beyond the sale date.
cards.hardContent: The equitable right of redemption allows a mortgagor, at any time before a judicial foreclosure sale, to reclaim the mortgaged property by paying the amount due—typically the full outstanding debt, plus interest, costs, and sometimes fees. This right is grounded in equity and applies even in equitable mortgage scenarios: where a transaction is structured so that the creditor appears to hold legal title through a deed, but the arrangement is substantively a secured loan, courts treat it as an equitable mortgage. In such cases, the mortgagor retains the equitable right of redemption prior to foreclosure. By contrast, a statutory right of redemption is a creature of statute. In jurisdictions that recognize it, the mortgagor may redeem the property for a specified period after the foreclosure sale by paying the amount required under the statute, commonly the foreclosure sale price plus certain additional sums. This statutory right extends the mortgagor’s opportunity to recover the property beyond the date of the foreclosure sale and exists only where expressly provided by legislation.
cards.mnemonic: E before S: Equitable before Sale; Statutory after Sale.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::equitable right of redemption}} lets a mortgagor redeem {{c2::any time before a judicial foreclosure sale}} by {{c3::paying the full amount due}}. A {{c4::statutory right of redemption}} lets the mortgagor {{c5::redeem for a set period after the sale, if a statute provides it}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 058-3. Deed in Lieu of Foreclosure
cards.backPlain: 1. Deed in Lieu of Foreclosure – Concept 1.1 To avoid the time, expense, and uncertainty of foreclosure, the mortgagor can agree to convey a deed to the property directly to the mortgagee. 1.2 The deed in lieu of foreclosure is given in full or agreed satisfaction of the mortgage debt. 2. Validity Requirements 2.1 Such transactions are generally valid so long as they are fair and reasonable under the circumstances. 2.2 Courts scrutinize deeds in lieu of foreclosure for overreaching or unconscionability, especially if the mortgagor is in a weak bargaining position. 3. Practical Effect 3.1 If valid, the deed in lieu of foreclosure extinguishes the mortgage debt to the extent agreed. 3.2 It typically ends the mortgagor’s ownership interest and the need for foreclosure proceedings.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a deed in lieu of foreclosure, and under what conditions is it valid as an alternative to foreclosure?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Deed in Lieu of Foreclosure – Concept}} 1.1 To avoid foreclosure, the {{c2::mortgagor}} can agree to convey a {{c3::deed to the property}} directly to the {{c4::mortgagee}}. 1.2 This deed is given in {{c5::satisfaction of the mortgage debt}} (in full or as agreed). 2. {{c6::Validity Requirements}} 2.1 Such a transaction is valid only if it is {{c7::fair and reasonable under the circumstances}}. 2.2 Courts may scrutinize it for {{c8::overreaching}} or {{c9::unconscionability}}, particularly when the mortgagor has {{c10::limited bargaining power}}. 3. {{c11::Practical Effect}} 3.1 If valid, the deed in lieu of foreclosure {{c12::extinguishes the mortgage debt}} to the extent agreed. 3.2 It ends the {{c13::mortgagor’s ownership interest}} and usually eliminates the need for {{c14::foreclosure proceedings}}.
cards.easyContent: A deed in lieu of foreclosure is when the mortgagor voluntarily deeds the property to the mortgagee instead of going through foreclosure, in satisfaction of the debt. It is valid only if fair and reasonable and typically ends both the mortgagor’s ownership and the need for foreclosure.
cards.mediumContent: Rather than proceeding with foreclosure, the mortgagor may convey a deed in lieu of foreclosure to the mortgagee in full or agreed satisfaction of the mortgage debt. Courts allow this as long as the arrangement is fair and reasonable and not the product of overreaching or unconscionability. When valid, the deed in lieu of foreclosure extinguishes the debt to the agreed extent and ends the mortgagor’s ownership, avoiding formal foreclosure proceedings.
cards.hardContent: A deed in lieu of foreclosure is an alternative remedy where, instead of undergoing a foreclosure sale, the mortgagor voluntarily conveys title to the mortgaged property directly to the mortgagee. The deed is given in full or otherwise agreed satisfaction of the mortgage obligation and is intended to avoid the delay, expense, and uncertainty of foreclosure. Such arrangements are generally enforceable if they are fair and reasonable under the circumstances. Courts will scrutinize deeds in lieu closely for signs of overreaching, oppression, or unconscionability, particularly where the mortgagor is distressed or has little bargaining power. If the transaction is valid, the deed in lieu of foreclosure extinguishes the mortgage debt to the extent agreed, terminates the mortgagor’s ownership interest, and usually obviates the need for formal foreclosure proceedings.
cards.mnemonic: DEED: Debtor Ends Execution, avoids Default sale.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::deed in lieu of foreclosure}} is a {{c2::voluntary conveyance of title}} by the mortgagor to the mortgagee {{c3::in agreed satisfaction of the debt}} if {{c4::fair and reasonable, not unconscionable}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 058-4. Mortgagee Possession and Lien/Title/Intermediate Theories
cards.front: Mortgagee Possession – Lien, Title, and Intermediate Theories
cards.backPlain: 1. Mortgagee’s Right to Possession Before Foreclosure 1.1 The mortgagee’s right to possess the mortgaged property before foreclosure depends on the jurisdiction. 2. Lien Theory 2.1 Under lien theory, the mortgage is treated as a lien on title. 2.2 The mortgagor retains legal and equitable title and the right to possession until foreclosure. 2.3 Therefore, under lien theory, the mortgagee has no right to possess prior to foreclosure. 3. Title Theory 3.1 Under title theory, the mortgage is viewed as transferring legal title to the mortgagee, subject to the mortgagor’s equitable rights. 3.2 The mortgagee has the right to possess the property at any time upon demand, even before default, unless the mortgage or other agreement provides otherwise. 4. Intermediate Theory 4.1 Under intermediate theory, the mortgage gives the mortgagee a lien that converts into a right to possession upon the mortgagor’s default. 4.2 Thus, the mortgagee’s right to possess arises upon default. 5. Other Routes to Possession and Duties of Mortgagee in Possession 5.1 Regardless of theory, the mortgagee can always take possession with the mortgagor’s consent or after the mortgagor’s abandonment of the property. 5.2 A mortgagee in possession assumes the risk and duty of accounting for rents and profits. 5.3 A mortgagee in possession also must manage the property with reasonable care. 5.4 The mortgagee in possession may incur tort liability to third parties arising out of the condition or management of the property.
cards.frontPrompt: Under lien, title, and intermediate theories, when may a mortgagee take possession before foreclosure, and what duties arise once the mortgagee is in possession?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Mortgagee’s Right to Possession Before Foreclosure}} 1.1 The mortgagee’s right to possess before foreclosure depends on the {{c2::jurisdiction}}. 2. {{c3::Lien Theory}} 2.1 The mortgage is treated as a {{c4::lien on title}}. 2.2 The {{c5::mortgagor}} keeps legal and equitable title and the right to {{c6::possession}} until foreclosure. 2.3 Therefore, under lien theory, the mortgagee has {{c7::no right to possess prior to foreclosure}}. 3. {{c8::Title Theory}} 3.1 The mortgage is viewed as transferring {{c9::legal title}} to the {{c10::mortgagee}}, subject to the mortgagor’s equitable rights. 3.2 The mortgagee has the right to {{c11::possess the property at any time upon demand}}, even before default, unless otherwise agreed. 4. {{c12::Intermediate Theory}} 4.1 The mortgage is initially treated as a {{c13::lien}}, but upon {{c14::default}} the mortgagee acquires a right to {{c15::possession}}. 4.2 Thus, under intermediate theory, the mortgagee’s right to possess arises {{c16::upon default}}. 5. {{c17::Other Routes to Possession and Duties}} 5.1 In any jurisdiction, the mortgagee can take possession with the mortgagor’s {{c18::consent}} or after {{c19::abandonment}} of the property. 5.2 A mortgagee in possession must {{c20::account for rents and profits}}. 5.3 A mortgagee in possession must {{c21::manage the property with reasonable care}}. 5.4 The mortgagee in possession may incur {{c22::tort liability to third parties}} arising from the condition or management of the property.
cards.easyContent: A mortgagee’s right to possession before foreclosure depends on the theory used: no right under lien theory, a right at any time under title theory, and a right upon default under intermediate theory. The mortgagee can also possess with consent or after abandonment, but once in possession must account for rents, manage the property reasonably, and may face tort liability.
cards.mediumContent: In lien theory jurisdictions, the mortgage is only a lien; the mortgagor retains title and possession until foreclosure, so the mortgagee has no pre-foreclosure right to possession. In title theory jurisdictions, legal title is in the mortgagee, who may demand possession at any time, even before default, absent a contrary agreement. Under intermediate theory, the mortgage operates as a lien, but upon default the mortgagee gains a right to possess. In all jurisdictions, the mortgagee may also take possession with the mortgagor’s consent or after abandonment, but a mortgagee in possession must account for rents and profits, manage the property with reasonable care, and may incur tort liability to third parties.
cards.hardContent: A mortgagee’s right to take possession of the mortgaged premises prior to foreclosure depends on the jurisdiction’s theory of mortgages. Under lien theory, the mortgage creates only a security interest; the mortgagor retains both legal and equitable title and the right to possession, and the mortgagee has no right to possession before foreclosure. Under title theory, the mortgage is regarded as conveying legal title to the mortgagee, subject to the mortgagor’s equitable rights; accordingly, the mortgagee may demand and take possession of the property at any time, including before default, unless the parties agree otherwise. Under intermediate theory, the mortgage initially operates as a lien, but upon the mortgagor’s default the mortgagee’s interest ripens into a right to possess, so the right to possession arises upon default. Regardless of theory, the mortgagee can also obtain possession by the mortgagor’s consent or upon abandonment of the property. Once a mortgagee is in possession, the mortgagee must account for all rents and profits, manage the property with reasonable care, and may be subject to tort liability to third parties arising out of the condition or management of the premises.
cards.mnemonic: L-T-I: Lien = Later, Title = Anytime, Intermediate = In default.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::lien theory}}, the mortgagee has {{c2::no pre-foreclosure right to possession}}; under {{c3::title theory}}, may demand possession {{c4::anytime}}, and under {{c5::intermediate theory}}, only {{c6::upon default}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Foreclosure Priority – Recording and Purchase Money Mortgages
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 059-1. Foreclosure Priority – Recording and Purchase Money Mortgages
cards.front: Foreclosure Priority – Recording and Purchase Money Mortgages
cards.backPlain: 1. Priority of creditors 1.1 Creditors must record their interests. 1.2 Recorded interests generally take priority in the order in which they are recorded. 1.3 Purchase money mortgages (PMMs) are superior to all other interests in the property. 1.4 A PMM is a mortgage given in exchange for funds used to buy the property. 1.5 A PMM may be given either to the seller as part of the purchase price or to a third-party lender; if both exist, the seller's PMM is senior to the third-party lender's PMM. 1.6 Creditors can contractually agree to subordinate their priority to a junior creditor.
cards.frontPrompt: How is priority among mortgage creditors determined, and what special priority rules apply to purchase money mortgages and subordination agreements?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Priority of creditors}} 1.1 Creditors must {{c2::record}} their interests. 1.2 Recorded interests generally take priority in the order in which they are {{c3::recorded}}. 1.3 {{c4::Purchase money mortgages (PMMs)}} are {{c5::superior to all other interests}} in the property. 1.4 A PMM is a mortgage given in exchange for funds used to {{c6::buy the property}}. 1.5 A PMM may be given either to the {{c7::seller}} as part of the purchase price or to a {{c8::third-party lender}}; if both exist, the {{c9::seller's PMM}} is senior to the {{c10::third-party lender's PMM}}. 1.6 Creditors can contractually agree to {{c11::subordinate}} their priority to a junior creditor.
cards.easyContent: Creditors must record their mortgages, and earlier-recorded interests usually have priority. Purchase money mortgages, given to buy the property, are superior to other interests, and parties can change priority by subordination agreements.
cards.mediumContent: Priority among mortgages is mainly "first in time, first in right" based on recording: creditors must record, and recorded interests usually take priority in the order of recording. Purchase money mortgages (PMMs), given to finance the purchase, are superior to other interests, and if both a seller PMM and a third-party lender PMM exist, the seller's PMM is senior. Creditors may alter this normal order through contractual subordination agreements.
cards.hardContent: Mortgage priority is governed largely by recording statutes: creditors must record their interests, and as a default rule, recorded interests take priority according to the order of recording. A key exception is the purchase money mortgage (PMM)—a mortgage given in exchange for funds used to buy the property. PMMs are superior to all other interests in the property, regardless of the timing of those other interests, subject to specific jurisdictional nuances. A PMM may be given either to the seller as part of the purchase price or to a third-party lender, and when both exist, the seller's PMM is senior to the third-party lender's PMM. Parties may re-order these priorities through express subordination agreements, by which a creditor agrees to have its interest treated as junior to another.
cards.mnemonic: P-R-P: Purchase money, then Recording, unless Parties change it.
cards.clozeLite: Mortgage priority is usually {{c1::first in time, first in right}} based on {{c2::recording}}. {{c3::Purchase money mortgages}} are {{c4::superior to other interests}}, but {{c5::subordination agreements}} can reorder priority.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Foreclosure – Junior Interests and Necessary Parties
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 059-2. Foreclosure – Junior Interests and Necessary Parties
cards.front: Foreclosure – Junior Interests and Necessary Parties
cards.backPlain: 2. Junior interests 2.1 Junior interests are terminated by foreclosure of a superior claim, assuming the junior interest holders are properly joined. 2.2 Upon foreclosure of a senior interest, junior interest holders cannot look to the land to satisfy their debts. 2.3 Junior interest holders can seek a deficiency judgment against the debtor, but they have no further interest in the subject property. 2.4 Necessary parties: junior interest holders are necessary parties and must be included in a senior foreclosure action; otherwise, the junior interest will remain on the land.
cards.frontPrompt: What happens to junior interests when a senior mortgage is foreclosed, and why are junior lienholders necessary parties to a senior foreclosure action?
cards.cloze: 2. {{c1::Junior interests}} 2.1 Junior interests are {{c2::terminated by foreclosure of a superior claim}}, assuming the junior interest holders are {{c3::properly joined}}. 2.2 Upon foreclosure of a {{c4::senior interest}}, junior interest holders {{c5::cannot look to the land}} to satisfy their debts. 2.3 Junior interest holders can seek a {{c6::deficiency judgment}} against the debtor, but they have {{c7::no further interest}} in the subject property. 2.4 Necessary parties: junior interest holders are {{c8::necessary parties}} and must be included in a senior foreclosure action; otherwise, the junior interest will {{c9::remain on the land}}.
cards.easyContent: A proper foreclosure of a senior mortgage wipes out joined junior interests. Junior lienholders then lose their rights in the land but can still sue the debtor for any remaining debt. Junior lienholders are necessary parties; if they are not joined, their junior lien survives on the property.
cards.mediumContent: When a senior mortgage is foreclosed, any junior interests that are properly joined in the action are terminated: junior lienholders cannot look to the land anymore and instead may pursue deficiency judgments against the debtor personally. Junior lienholders are necessary parties to a senior foreclosure; failure to join them means their junior interest remains attached to the property despite the foreclosure sale.
cards.hardContent: In a senior foreclosure, the key issue for junior interests is joinder. Junior liens that are properly joined as parties to the senior foreclosure are extinguished by the foreclosure sale: those junior lienholders lose recourse against the land and instead must seek recovery via a deficiency judgment against the debtor. Because foreclosure aims to deliver clear title up to the level of the foreclosing lien, junior lienholders are necessary parties to a senior foreclosure action. If a junior lienholder is not joined, its interest is not terminated and remains an encumbrance on the land after the sale, reducing the value of the buyer’s title and leaving that junior lienholder free to foreclose later.
cards.mnemonic: JND: Joined Juniors Nullified; unJoined Not Destroyed.
cards.clozeLite: In a {{c1::senior mortgage foreclosure}}, {{c2::properly joined junior interests are terminated}} and {{c3::junior lienholders are necessary parties}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Foreclosure – Effect of Junior Foreclosure on Senior Interests and Buyer
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 059-3. Foreclosure – Effect of Junior Foreclosure on Senior Interests and Buyer
cards.front: Foreclosure – Effect of Junior Foreclosure on Senior Interests and Buyer
cards.backPlain: 3. Senior interests 3.1 Senior interests are unaffected by junior interest foreclosures. 3.2 A buyer of foreclosed property takes the property subject to any senior interests. 3.3 The buyer is not personally liable for the senior debt, but the senior mortgage remains on the land and can be foreclosed if not paid.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the effect of foreclosing a junior mortgage on senior interests and on the obligations of the buyer at the foreclosure sale?
cards.cloze: 3. {{c1::Senior interests}} 3.1 Senior interests are {{c2::unaffected}} by junior interest foreclosures. 3.2 A buyer of foreclosed property takes the property {{c3::subject to}} any senior interests. 3.3 The buyer is {{c4::not personally liable}} for the senior debt, but the senior mortgage {{c5::remains on the land}} and can be foreclosed if not paid.
cards.easyContent: Foreclosing a junior mortgage does not affect senior mortgages. The buyer at a junior foreclosure sale takes the property subject to all senior interests, which remain on the land, though the buyer is not personally liable on those senior debts.
cards.mediumContent: Senior interests are not impacted by foreclosure of a junior lien: they remain attached to the property. A purchaser at a junior foreclosure sale takes title subject to all senior mortgages. Although the buyer is not personally liable for the senior debt, the senior mortgage continues to encumber the land and may be foreclosed if not paid, which practically pressures the buyer to satisfy the senior lien.
cards.hardContent: Foreclosure of a junior mortgage leaves all senior interests intact. Senior mortgages are unaffected in both their lien status and priority; they continue to encumber the property. A buyer at a junior foreclosure sale therefore takes title subject to all senior mortgages. The buyer does not assume personal liability for the senior debt absent an express assumption agreement, but the senior lien remains on the land and can be foreclosed if payments are not made. As a result, the economic risk of the senior lien effectively shifts to the buyer, who must either pay off or refinance the senior mortgage or risk losing the property to a future senior foreclosure.
cards.mnemonic: Junior sale: B-S-S — Buyer takes Subject to Seniors that Survive.
cards.clozeLite: Foreclosure of a {{c1::junior mortgage}} leaves {{c2::all senior interests intact}}; the buyer takes {{c3::subject to senior mortgages}} but is {{c4::not personally liable on them}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Lateral support – definition and natural-state strict liability
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 060-1. Lateral support – definition and natural-state strict liability
cards.front: Lateral support – definition and strict liability for natural-state land
cards.backPlain: 1. Lateral support – definition 1.1 Ownership of land includes the right to have the land supported in its natural state by adjoining land. 1.2 A neighboring landowner who excavates or otherwise removes lateral support can be liable if this causes subsidence or damage to the adjacent land. 2. Strict liability for land in its natural state 2.1 If the excavating landowner’s conduct causes damage to adjacent land in its natural condition (i.e., without buildings or artificial additions), the excavator is strictly liable. 2.2 Strict liability applies even if the defendant used utmost care in making the excavation or removing support. 2.3 This natural-state rule focuses on whether the land itself would have subsided due to the removal of support, independent of any added structures.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a landowner’s right to lateral support, and when is an excavating neighbor strictly liable for damage to land in its natural state?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Lateral support}} – definition 1.1 Ownership of land includes the right to have the land supported in its {{c2::natural state}} by {{c3::adjoining land}}. 1.2 A neighboring landowner who {{c4::excavates}} or otherwise removes lateral support can be liable if this causes {{c5::subsidence}} or damage to the adjacent land. 2. {{c6::Strict liability}} for land in its natural state 2.1 If the excavating landowner’s conduct causes damage to adjacent land in its {{c7::natural condition}} (without buildings or artificial additions), the excavator is {{c8::strictly liable}}. 2.2 Strict liability applies even if the defendant used {{c9::utmost care}} in making the excavation. 2.3 This rule focuses on whether the {{c10::land itself}} would have subsided due to the removal of support, independent of any {{c11::added structures}}.
cards.easyContent: Lateral support is the right to have your land, in its natural state, physically supported by neighboring land. If a neighbor’s excavation causes your natural land to subside, the neighbor is strictly liable even if they used utmost care.
cards.mediumContent: Every landowner has a right to lateral support from adjoining land. If a neighbor’s excavation or similar activity removes that support and the adjacent land, in its natural condition (without buildings or artificial additions), subsides or is damaged, the excavator is strictly liable, regardless of the care exercised.
cards.hardContent: Lateral support is the right of a landowner to have the soil of her land, in its natural state, physically supported by contiguous parcels. An adjoining owner who excavates or otherwise removes lateral support breaches this right if the neighbor’s land in its natural condition subsides or is damaged. In such a case, the excavator is strictly liable: the plaintiff need not prove negligence, and the defendant’s use of utmost care is no defense. The inquiry is whether the land, without buildings or other artificial weight, would have collapsed due to the removal of support.
cards.mnemonic: Lateral + Natural = automatic strict liability.
cards.clozeLite: If {{c1::lateral support}} is removed and {{c2::natural land (no buildings)}} subsides, the excavator is {{c3::strictly liable}} {{c4::regardless of care}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Lateral support and buildings – strict liability vs negligence
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 060-2. Lateral support and buildings – strict liability vs negligence
cards.front: Lateral support and buildings – strict liability vs negligence
cards.backPlain: 1. Lateral support when buildings are present 1.1 When buildings or other structures sit on the supported land, the standard for liability depends on whether the land would have collapsed in its natural state. 2. Strict liability for damage to buildings 2.1 For the defendant excavator to be strictly liable for damage to buildings on adjacent land, the plaintiff must show that the land would have collapsed in its natural state, even without the buildings, due to the defendant’s excavation. 2.2 If the extra weight of the buildings is not necessary to cause subsidence—that is, the land by itself would have failed—strict liability covers both the land and the building damage. 3. Negligence standard for buildings 3.1 If the land would not have collapsed in its natural state and subsidence or damage occurs only because of the added weight of buildings or other artificial conditions, strict liability does not apply to the building damage. 3.2 In that situation, the plaintiff must prove that the defendant was negligent in excavating or removing support. 3.3 If negligence is proven, the defendant is liable for loss or damage to both the adjacent land and its buildings.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the presence of buildings affect liability for removal of lateral support, and when is strict liability versus negligence the governing standard?
cards.cloze: 1. Lateral support when {{c1::buildings}} are present 1.1 When structures sit on the supported land, liability depends on whether the {{c2::land would have collapsed in its natural state}}. 2. {{c3::Strict liability}} for damage to buildings 2.1 The defendant is strictly liable for damage to buildings on adjacent land only if the plaintiff shows that the land would have {{c4::collapsed in its natural state}}, without the buildings, due to the defendant’s excavation. 2.2 If the extra weight of the buildings is {{c5::not necessary}} to cause subsidence, strict liability covers both land and building damage. 3. {{c6::Negligence}} standard for buildings 3.1 If the land would {{c7::not have collapsed}} in its natural state and subsidence occurs only because of the {{c8::added weight of buildings}}, strict liability does not apply to the building damage. 3.2 In that situation, the plaintiff must prove that the defendant was {{c9::negligent}} in excavating or removing support. 3.3 If negligence is proven, the defendant is liable for loss or damage to both the {{c10::adjacent land}} and its {{c11::buildings}}.
cards.easyContent: If a neighbor’s excavation damages your buildings, strict liability applies only if your land would have collapsed even without the buildings. If the extra weight of the buildings causes the problem, you generally must prove the neighbor was negligent to recover for building damage.
cards.mediumContent: When buildings are on the supported land, strict liability for removal of lateral support extends to building damage only if the land, in its natural state, would have collapsed due to the excavation. If the land itself would not have subsided and the damage occurs because of the added weight of buildings, strict liability does not apply to that building damage; instead, the plaintiff must prove the excavator was negligent. If negligence is shown, the excavator is liable for damage to both the land and the buildings.
cards.hardContent: The presence of buildings modifies lateral support liability. Strict liability for removal of lateral support is primarily concerned with protecting land in its natural condition. Accordingly, an excavating defendant is strictly liable for damage to structures on the adjacent parcel only if the plaintiff can establish that the land, without the buildings, would have collapsed because of the excavation. If, by contrast, the land would have remained stable but for the added weight of buildings or artificial improvements, strict liability does not reach the building damage. In that event, the plaintiff must proceed under a negligence theory—showing that the defendant failed to use reasonable care in excavating or shoring up the neighbor’s land. Upon proving negligence, the plaintiff may recover for harm to both the land and the superimposed structures.
cards.mnemonic: Natural fall = no fault; building fall = find fault.
cards.clozeLite: With buildings, {{c1::strict liability}} for lateral support covers them only if {{c2::natural-state land}} would have {{c3::collapsed anyway}}; otherwise you need {{c4::negligence}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 060-3. Subjacent support – definition and liability
cards.front: Subjacent support – definition and liability rules
cards.backPlain: 1. Subjacent support – definition 1.1 Subjacent support concerns underground (subjacent) structures that must support the surface estate. 1.2 Typical subjacent structures include parking garages, tunnels, mines, and similar underground works. 1.3 The duty is to support the surface land and the structures that existed when the subjacent estate was created or severed from the surface. 2. Liability for failure of subjacent support 2.1 Strict liability: Subjacent owners are strictly liable if their failure to provide adequate support causes subsidence or damage to the surface land or to surface structures that pre-existed the creation of the subjacent estate. 2.2 Negligence: For damage to buildings or structures constructed on the surface after the subjacent estate was created, the subjacent owner is liable only if negligent in maintaining or providing support. 2.3 The key distinction is between pre-existing surface structures, which are protected by strict liability, and subsequently constructed buildings, which generally require proof of negligence for recovery.
cards.frontPrompt: What is subjacent support, and what are the strict liability and negligence rules governing damage to surface land and structures?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Subjacent support}} – definition 1.1 Subjacent support concerns {{c2::underground (subjacent) structures}} that must support the {{c3::surface estate}}. 1.2 Typical subjacent structures include {{c4::parking garages}}, {{c5::tunnels}}, {{c6::mines}}, and similar underground works. 1.3 The duty is to support the {{c7::surface land}} and the structures that existed when the {{c8::subjacent estate}} was created or severed. 2. Liability for failure of subjacent support 2.1 {{c9::Strict liability}}: Subjacent owners are strictly liable if their failure to provide adequate support causes subsidence or damage to the surface land or to {{c10::pre-existing surface structures}}. 2.2 {{c11::Negligence}}: For damage to buildings or structures constructed on the surface {{c12::after}} the subjacent estate was created, the subjacent owner is liable only if {{c13::negligent}}. 2.3 The key distinction is between {{c14::pre-existing}} surface structures, which are protected by strict liability, and {{c15::subsequently constructed}} buildings, which generally require proof of negligence.
cards.easyContent: Subjacent support is the duty of underground estates—like mines or tunnels—to support the surface land and the structures that existed when the underground estate was created. The subjacent owner is strictly liable for failing to support the land and those pre-existing structures, but only negligent for damage to later-built structures.
cards.mediumContent: Subjacent support arises when the surface estate is separated from an underlying estate used for things like tunnels, mines, or parking garages. The subjacent owner must support the surface land and any structures that existed when the subjacent estate was created. If failure of support causes subsidence or damage to the land or those pre-existing structures, strict liability applies. For damage to structures built on the surface after the subjacent estate was created, the subjacent owner is only liable on a negligence theory.
cards.hardContent: When the surface estate is severed from the underlying estate, the holder of the subjacent estate (e.g., a mining company, tunnel operator, or garage owner) assumes a duty of subjacent support. This duty requires maintaining sufficient structural integrity so that the surface land and the buildings existing at the time of severance are adequately supported. If withdrawal of subjacent support causes subsidence or damage to the land itself or to these pre-existing structures, the subjacent owner is strictly liable; the plaintiff need not prove fault. However, structures added after the creation of the subjacent estate are treated differently: damage to these later-constructed buildings is compensable only if the subjacent owner failed to exercise reasonable care—i.e., was negligent—in maintaining support.
cards.mnemonic: SUB-J: Support Under Buildings—Jointly strict for originals, negligent for newcomers.
cards.clozeLite: Subjacent support is {{c1::the duty of an underlying estate}} to support {{c2::the surface land}} and {{c3::structures existing when the subjacent estate was created}}; {{c4::strict liability}} applies to land and pre-existing structures, but {{c5::only negligence}} for later-built structures.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 063-1. Zoning Power – Source and Limits
cards.frontPrompt: What is the source of government zoning power, and what limits apply to zoning ordinances?
cards.backPlain: Zoning Power – Source and Limits: 1. Source of zoning power 1.1. Government may enact zoning laws to reasonably control land use. 1.2. Cities and counties must be authorized by an enabling act to exercise zoning power. 2. Limits on zoning ordinances 2.1. Zoning ordinances must be reasonably related to the public welfare. 2.2. Zoning ordinances must not be overly or unduly restrictive. 2.3. Zoning ordinances must not be racially discriminatory.
cards.cloze: Zoning Power – Source and Limits: 1. Source of zoning power 1.1. Government may enact zoning laws to reasonably control {{c1::land use}}. 1.2. Local governments (cities and counties) must be authorized by an {{c2::enabling act}} to exercise zoning power. 2. Limits on zoning ordinances 2.1. Zoning ordinances must be reasonably related to the {{c3::public welfare}}. 2.2. They must not be {{c4::overly or unduly restrictive}}. 2.3. They must not be {{c5::racially discriminatory}}.
cards.easyContent: Governments can zone only if an enabling act authorizes it, and any zoning ordinance must reasonably serve public welfare, not be overly restrictive, and not be racially discriminatory.
cards.mediumContent: Zoning power allows government to enact laws controlling land use, but cities and counties need authority from an enabling act. Even when authorized, zoning ordinances are limited: they must be reasonably related to public welfare, cannot be unduly restrictive, and cannot be racially discriminatory.
cards.hardContent: Government zoning power is a delegated police power, exercised by localities only when an enabling act authorizes them to regulate land use. Any zoning ordinance enacted under this authority must satisfy constitutional limits: it must be reasonably related to the public welfare (e.g., health, safety, morals, general welfare), cannot be overly or unduly restrictive in relation to its objectives, and cannot be racially discriminatory.
cards.mnemonic: Zoning needs E-P-R: Enabling, Public welfare, no Racial bias.
cards.clozeLite: Local {{c1::zoning power}} exists only if an {{c2::enabling act}} authorizes it, and ordinances must {{c3::serve public welfare}}, {{c4::not be unduly restrictive}}, and {{c5::not be racially discriminatory}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 063-2. Zoning Variances – Definition and Requirements
cards.frontPrompt: What is a zoning variance and what must a landowner show to obtain one?
cards.backPlain: Zoning Variances – Definition and Requirements: 1. Definition of variance 1.1. A variance is government permission for a landowner to be exempt from or vary the literal restrictions of a zoning ordinance. 2. Requirements for obtaining a variance 2.1. The landowner must show undue hardship. 2.2. The landowner must also show that granting the variance will not be contrary to the public welfare.
cards.cloze: Zoning Variances – Definition and Requirements: 1. Definition of variance 1.1. A variance is government permission for a landowner to be {{c1::exempt from or vary the literal restrictions of a zoning ordinance}}. 2. Requirements for obtaining a variance 2.1. The landowner must show {{c2::undue hardship}}. 2.2. The landowner must also show that granting the variance will {{c3::not be contrary to the public welfare}}.
cards.easyContent: A variance is permission to break a zoning rule. To get it, the owner must show undue hardship and that the variance will not harm the public welfare.
cards.mediumContent: A zoning variance allows a landowner to depart from the literal terms of a zoning ordinance. To obtain a variance, the owner must demonstrate undue hardship under the existing restrictions and that granting the variance will not be contrary to the public welfare.
cards.hardContent: A zoning variance is an individualized administrative exception that permits a landowner to be exempt from or to vary the literal restrictions of a zoning ordinance. The applicant bears the burden to prove (1) undue hardship from strict application of the ordinance to the property, and (2) that granting the variance will not be contrary to the public welfare—i.e., it will not unduly harm neighboring properties or frustrate the purposes of the zoning scheme.
cards.mnemonic: Variance = V‑UP: Vary ordinance, Undue hardship, not against Public welfare.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::zoning variance}} lets an owner {{c2::depart from the literal terms}} of a zoning ordinance by showing {{c3::undue hardship}} and {{c4::no harm to public welfare}}.

cards.subject: Real Property
cards.topic: Nonconforming Uses – Definition, Compensation, and Amortization
cards.rawHeader: Real Property 063-3. Nonconforming Uses – Definition, Compensation, and Amortization
cards.front: Nonconforming Uses – Definition, Compensation, and Amortization
cards.frontPrompt: What is a nonconforming use in zoning, and how may the government deal with it?
cards.backPlain: Nonconforming Uses – Definition, Compensation, and Amortization: 1. Definition of nonconforming use 1.1. A nonconforming use is a once lawful existing use of property that is now deemed nonconforming under a new zoning law. 2. Protection of lawful nonconforming uses 2.1. The government generally cannot eliminate a lawful nonconforming use all at once unless just compensation is paid. 3. Amortization 3.1. The government may use amortization to address nonconforming uses. 3.2. Under amortization, the government allows the use to continue for a set period of time or makes payments over a set period of time until the landowner recoups the value of the nonconforming use.
cards.cloze: Nonconforming Uses – Definition, Compensation, and Amortization: 1. Definition 1.1. A nonconforming use is a once lawful existing use of property that becomes nonconforming under a {{c1::new zoning law}}. 2. Protection and compensation 2.1. The government generally cannot eliminate a lawful nonconforming use {{c2::all at once}} unless {{c3::just compensation}} is paid. 3. Amortization 3.1. The government may use {{c4::amortization}} to deal with nonconforming uses. 3.2. Amortization means the government allows the use to continue for a {{c5::set period of time}} or makes payments over a {{c6::set period of time}} until the landowner {{c7::recoups the value of the nonconforming use}}.
cards.easyContent: A nonconforming use is a once lawful use made illegal by new zoning. It usually cannot be shut down immediately without compensation, but the government can phase it out over time through amortization so the owner recoups its value.
cards.mediumContent: A nonconforming use arises when a previously lawful use becomes inconsistent with a new zoning ordinance. The government generally may not terminate such a use immediately without paying just compensation. Instead, it may adopt an amortization scheme, allowing the use to continue or compensating over a set period so the owner can recoup the value of the nonconforming use.
cards.hardContent: A nonconforming use is a use of property that was lawful when established but becomes nonconforming upon enactment of new zoning. Because of due process and takings concerns, the government generally may not eliminate a lawful nonconforming use all at once without providing just compensation. As an alternative, many jurisdictions use amortization provisions, under which the nonconforming use is allowed to continue or is compensated for a fixed period of time so that the landowner can recapture the economic value of the use before it must cease.
cards.mnemonic: N-C-A: New law, Can’t cut, use Amortization.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::nonconforming use}} is a {{c2::previously lawful use}} made illegal by {{c3::new zoning}}, which generally {{c4::cannot be terminated immediately without just compensation}} but may be {{c5::phased out through amortization}}.
